column2: It started a year ago with Yves Saint Laurent's romantic peasants. Now everyone is on a romantic kick.
ATLANTA, May 29 "Well," says the black guitarist, "here we are, in living color."

Anne Cox Chambers, the newly appointed Ambassador to Belgium, took time out last week from a hectic round of Government briefings to spend a day in New York. The Atlanta publisher met here with top executives of four American corporations with interests in Belgium.

CAIRO Egypt's armed forces, the most important Arab factor in the Middle Eastern military equation, are desperately seeking to plug the holes in their armament left by the virtual cutoff of Soviet supplies.

VILLA RIDGE, Mo., May 29 Bob Gassoff, defenseman on the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League, was killed tonight in a motorcycle accident in Franklin County, about 30 miles West of St. Louis, the Missouri Highway Patrol said. He was 24 years old.

Larry McBride has been staying away from school for nearly four weeks now. So have Domingo Reyes, Joanne Ocean and more than a thousand other students of the Alexander Hamilton Vocational and Technical School. They have been drawn into a rancorous squabble of succession over who will be the principal of the school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Sarah Jean Kain, a freelance cartographer, was married in Rocky River. Ohio, yesterday to Philip Fitzgerald de Give of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alan Davis of St. Philip's Christian Church at the home of the bride's mother, Helen A. Kain.

STAY HOME, KING KONG Circusminded New Yorkers who have wondered how it would be to perform and haven't we all? have their chance tomorrow morning at 147 Spring Street, starting at 8:30. Acts of all kinds and ages are invited to audition for the city's first resident sawdust company, the Big Apple Circus, which makes its debut the weekend of the Fourth of July in Battery Park.

PARIS, May 29 Leonid I. Brezhnev said on French television tonight that relations between the Soviet Union and France were "good, but we are ambitious for more, and we think unused possibilities for that exist."

The marriage of Sandra Joan Clyman to Jonathan Merrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yale Merrill of Baltimore, took place in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Clyman, parents of the bride. Rabbi Herschel Cohen performed the ceremony.
WASHINGTON A quartet of essays on a thumbless handful of subjects.

The marriage of Esther R. Weil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Well of New York, to Harold Sturm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sandor Sturm of Toronto, took place at the New York Hilton yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi M. Weiss, assisted by Rabbi Bernard Rosensweig.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 The lineup listed 33 in the field, but it soon worked out to a two-man auto race today and in the end A.J. Foyt beat Gordon Johncock and won the Indianapolis 500.

BERKELEY, Calif, May 29 The grades students receive, like the dollars they spend, have gone down in value in recent years, prompting college and university administrators to search for ways to halt what has come to be known as "grade inflation."

GUILFORD, Conn, Last year, in time for the Bicentennial, the men of Rescue Fire Company 5 of Stony Creek, Conn., published a small "miscellany," in part to celebrate their volunteer fire company's 75th anniversary and partly to raise funds for a new fire house. The booklet contained this historical anecdote which haunts me:

Anthony T. DePace, an architect who worked closely with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn, died Saturday at the Astor Gardens Nursing Home in the Bronx. He was 84 years old and had lived at the home for more than a year.

JERUSALEM, May 29 Menahem Begin thwarted a potential revolt in the Likud bloc today over his choice of Moshe Dayan as Foreign Minister. At the same time, Mr. Begin temporarily deferred action on the nomination of Mr. Dayan, whom he still supports, in an effort to placate a new political party that Likud hopes will help it form a broad-based majority coalition government.

WASHINGTON, May 29 The Carter Administration has gone out of its way on several occasions to demonstrate its coolness toward Chile's military Government while continuing to maintain correct relations. Meanwhile, Chile's demo-

In advance of announcing her candidacy for Mayor of New York City, Bella S. Abzug sought yesterday to remove the issue that some politicians believe cost her the nomination for United States Senator last year.

Because it was Sunday and because they got some essential help from Manager Earl Weaver of Baltimore and his left fielder, Pat Kelly, the Minnesota Twins were able to beat the Orioles, 3-2, yesterday. Minnesota increased its lead in the American League West to three games over the Chicago White Sox, who lost to the Yankees, 5-2.

Two women were arrested yesterday and charged in the abduction, beating and imprisonment of a woman whom the police found in their apartment. The police said the woman told them she had been seized outside her Brooklyn home early yesterday by Vernon LeGrand, the son of self-styled "Bishop" DeVernon LeGrand.

Paul McClellan Jones, the president of the Carpet Wool Council since 1968, died yesterday of cancer at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 68 years old and lived at 27 Hotel Drive in White Plains.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, was married today to Lilla Burt Cummings, a Washington lawyer, in a private ceremony on the campus of Southern Methodist University in Dallas, his office announced.
WASHINGTON, May 29 The delivery of the nation's packages has changed dramatically in recent years and appears headed for even bigger changes.

By the end of this holiday weekend, ambulances will have been called upon to rescue some 20,000 person seriously injured in motor vehicle accidents and another 40,000 who suffered other urgent, possibly life-threatening injuries or illnesses.
Mamie Eisenhower, speaking at commencement exercises at Eisenhower College in Seneca Falls, N.Y., said she may not be able to attend another graduation.
Machine tool orders in April ran well ahead of a year ago but were below the March total, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend.
As cool weather took over yesterday from steamy heat, New Yorkers and their neighbors flocked to countryside and shore and to Memorial Day weekend events.

GLIMMEN, the Netherlands, May 29 South Moluccan terrorists holding 56 hostages at gunpoint on a train here refused this afternoon for the second time to release one of them, who is seven months pregnant.

ZURICH The Swiss banking industry, that legendary world of numbered accounts and anonymous millions, has reached a turning point. Here in the industry's capital, bankers are increasingly convinced that the future will bring them tighter controls, less secrecy, a more hostile political environment and slower growth than they have enjoyed in the past.

There is, in Andrew Field's "Nabokov: His Life in Part," a fair amount of really rather tedious talk about the difficulty of truly knowing a person or a past or, particularly, the character of a writer whose "truth"' lives in the work of his imagination. To illustrate this somewhat obvious point, Mr. Field avers that "I possess only one fragment of pure Nabokov, half a sentence to be precise."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 29 In distance yacht races on Long Island Sound, like the Storm Trysail Club's annual competition out to Block Island and back, which ended here today, most of the sailors know one another by reputation if not personally or by boat recognition.
WASHINGTON, May 29 President Grant bought it. President Theodore Roosevelt got rid of it. Congress acquired it. Jacqueline Kennedy borrowed it. And now the United States Senate wants it back.

By the time the 10th game of the quarterfinal candidate's match between Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Bent Larsen of Denmark came up, Larsen had every reason to be disheartened. Victory in the series would go to the player who took the majority of points out of 12 games and the score stood at 3 -5 against him.
The Yankees treated a young pitcher rudely yesterday in their 5-2 defeat of the Chicago White Sox, but after the game Reggie Jackson engaged in an exercise in diplomacy.

Andres Batista, who gave a guitar recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night, is steeped in both the classical and flamenco guitar traditions. As a composer for the guitar, he draws freely from those sources as well as from the gypsy music that helped shape the flamenco style.

RAMADAN CITY, Egypt, May 29 (AP) President Anwar el-Sadat, reacting to President Carter's call for compensation for Palestinians, said today that he would demand $2.1 billion for Egyptian oil exploited by Israel.
Most of those who died in the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire were victims of smoke inhalation rather than fatal burns, Kentucky officials said.

BERGENFIELD, May 29 Business and municipal leaders in North Jersey will meet in Bergenfield High School on June 11 to weigh proposals for changes in Federal and state flood-control regulations that ban construction is areas described as flood-prone.

ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., May 30 President Carter suggested today that there might soon be stronger ties between the United States and Cuba, but he cited that nation's military presence in Africa and its political prisoners as continuing impediments.
Alvin Roth of New York City and Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J., are a formidable partnership in any company, and perhaps the best mixed pair in the world.

The Liberal Party has awarded its ballot line for Manhattan Borough President to Robert F. Wagner Jr. The endorsement was announced by Henry J. Stern, the party's county chairman and Mr. Wagner's fellow Councilman-at-large for Manhattan.

Karen Jean Palmore, daughter of Dr. Erdman Palmore of Durham, N.C., and Mrs. Stanley Silverstone of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Brim Beckerman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Beckerman of New York. Rabbi Charles Scheer performed the ceremony at the McIntosh Center at Barnard College, from which the bride graduated May 18.

IZMIR, Turkey, May 28 Fifteen years ago, Feramuz Eryilmaz came to this shipping and industrial center on Turkey's west coast from the eastern city of Sivas. In the past he has always favored conservative parties, but in the national elections on June 5 he will vote for the Republican People's Party, a social democratic party headed by Bulent Ecevit.

If the air of late May seems to have a strange, golden glint, particularly in the woodland, it is not only because the sunlight has its own aura. The air itself is dusted with the substance of life, the incredibly extravagant pollen crop from the trees.
Racing at Belmont Park returned to near-normal stride yesterday after parimutuel clerks ended their 10-day strike against the New York Racing Association.
SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 30 Firefighters, with the aid of a massive bulldozer and crane, churned through the wreckage of the Beverly Hills Supper Club today, searching for more bodies of fire victims.

A Princeton-educated Arab prince wants to buy an 18-room luxury apartment at 640 Park Avenue, but other well-to-do apartment owners there haven't decided whether to let him, residents of the building have reported.

JERSEY CITY, May 30 Governor Byrne relaxed between campaign stops here the other day by kicking off his shoes, putting his feet on a desk in the Journal Square law office of Kenneth McPherson and sipping some iced tea.

MIAMI Two area ministers, long-time acquaintances who are on opposite sides of the June 7 Dade County referendum on civil rights of homosexuals, met by chance in an elevator here last week. One cleric, indirectly referring to the bitter dispute that has shattered friendships, asked the other, "Do you still like me?"

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 30 Elmsford, Canadian-owned and making her first start of the season, led virtually all the way tonight to win the $30,100 Goldsmith Maid Trot for 3-year-old fillies at the Meadowlands.

ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., May 30 President Carter suggested today that there might soon be stronger ties between the United States and Cuba, but he cited that nation's military presence in Africa and its political prisoners as continuing impediments.

Fifteen daguerreotypes, believed to be the earliest known photographs of American slaves, have been discovered in an unused storage cabinet in the attic of Harvard University's Peabody Museum of Archeology and Ethnology.

LONDON, May 30 It was an evening of music fit for a queen. Drawing on the resources that have given it new international reknown during the 25year reign of Queen Elizabeth II, the Royal Opera staged a shimmering silver jubilee gala tonight. The Queen and members of her family watched from a specially constructed box as stars from a dozen countries sang operatic excerpts and performed five ballets.

In a footnote right at the beginning of this long and careful book, Daniel Yergin reminds us that "Westerners have no access whatsoever to relevant Soviet archives.... No Westerner can know how the Soviet leaders among themselves interpreted and misinterpreted American intentions and capabilities. So the historian today, like the policymaker in the postwar years, must seek to develop a consistent and reasonable interpretation based upon what is available."
BOSTON, May 30 Clell Lavern Hobson Jr., known widely as Butch, never had such a good block thrown on him when he played strong safety for Bear Bryant's University of Alabama football team in 1970.
Arthur Sainer's "Carol in Winter Sunlight," being performed at the Theater for the New City, 113 Jane Street, through June 5, is less a play than a catalogue of urban pains and pleasures.

WASHINGTON, May 30 Federal investigators have found evidence that the Diplomat National Bank, originally formed to serve the Asian-American community here, was the target of a takeover attempt by alleged agents of the South Korean Government.

NORWALK, Calif., May 30 (AP) Houston McTear, kept out of the Olympics by an injury, stunned one of the finest 100-meter-dash fields ever assembled with a victory in the Muhammad Ali invitation track meet today.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, Tuesday, May 31 The South Moluccan terrorists still holding 56 hostages in the north of the Netherlands seem to have softened after a week of determined confrontation with the Dutch Government.

Travis K. Hedrick, a retired labor union public relations official and a former reporter for The Chattanooga Times and The Associated Press, died in Arlington County Hospital, Arlington, Va., yesterday morning of cancer. He was 73 years old.

If American employees complain of lack of opportunity and object to better fringe benefits and more pay for Japanese sent here why not dispatch the Americans to Tokyo for training and pay them better benefits than the Japanese?

Wells Twombly, sports columnist for The San Francisco Examiner, who won several national awards for his writing, died yesterday at Kaiser Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. Mr. Twombly, who was 41 years old, entered the hospital May 20 for treatment of "an acute internal disorder."
Dr. Henry A. Kissinger is expected to withdraw from consideration for appointment to a professorship and an endowed chair at Columbia University, according to people close to the situation.

TRENTON, May 30 Governor Byrne and other backers of casino gambling for Atlantic City are trying to overcome criticisms of the enabling legislation on the Governor's desk with an avalanche of economic statistics.
NEW DELHI, May 30 (AP) An express train fell into a flood-swollen river in northeastern India today, killing at least 44 persons and injuring many others, railroad officials reported.
William L.F. Gardiner, a New York lawyer in real-estate and surrogate law, died Sunday at Stamford Hospital in Stamford, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.
ROME, May 30 (AP) A former military intelligence chief and 76 other persons went on trial here today on charges of participating in right-wing plots to overthrow the Government.

CRUCIBLE An exhibition of more than 150 pieces of 18th-century Latin American decorative art is on display through Aug. 7 at the Inter-American Relations Gallery, 680 Park Avenue. The objects have not been exhibited outside their own countries.

While the management resolutely kept trying to trade their best player, the New York Mets resolutely won the battle for last place yesterday when they lost both games of a doubleheader to the Montreal Expos and worsened the sense of disaster hanging over Shea Stadium.

The old soldiers on the march outnumbered the 300 to 400 spectators but barely at Manhattan's Memorial Day parade yesterday up Riverside Drive from 72d Street. And when they reached the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, at 89th Street, they found a flagpole but no flag.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 Woodward Kingman, a 51-year-old banker, is to assume what may be the greatest challenge of his career management of the formerly corruption-ridden principal pension fund of the teamsters' union.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) Gold prices dipped slightly lower and the dollar eased against most major currencies on London bullion and money markets today. This is a holiday in most of Europe.

For a long time I resisted the feminist argument that I was an oppressor. It was not because I found the suggestion altogether distasteful. Most people harbor secret urges to do a little oppressing now and then, and I was no exception.
Racing at Belmont Park returned to near-normal stride yesterday after parimutuel clerks ended their 10-day strike against the New York Racing Association.
Paul Desmond, whose alto saxophone was as essential to the Dave Brubeck Quartet as Mr. Brubeck's piano, died early yesterday at his home at 77 West 55th Street. He was 52 years old.

It sounds like a textbook dispute between the local nationals and their foreign-owned employers. Some parties blame a culture barrier. Others point to a differing work ethic, the language problem, and the sheer difficulty of doing business in a foreign land.

Carol Anthony is like a novelist who has worked for years on characterization and has finally learned the skills of projecting depth and dimension. Her papier-mache-people, artfully sculptured and ingeniously costumed, have always been arresting. In the past, she has concentrated her talents on capturing the spirit of childhood. Now she has taken on adults.

John B. Crimmins, a longtime aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and former aide to Govs. Charles F. Hurley and Paul Dever of Massachusetts, died Sunday at Boston's West Roxbury Veterans Administration Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.
The way people bank, pay bills and even handle money is being changed, by an electronic revolution among the nation's financial institutions.
There were no easy winners, and a few likely losers, on the bold guitar program that Dennis Koster assembled for his concert Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Do you have faith in the future of New York City? That is the question that the Assembly's Committee on Cities was asking yesterday in Coney Island, in the fourth of a series of citywide street forums.
J. Herbert Todd, a retired executive of Todd Shipyards Corporation, died in Pinehurst, N.C., yesterday after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

Having spent the last 15 years risking his Christian faith and confusing his Japanese tongue, Jacob Yuroh Teshima finally won his earthly reward this month; he was awarded a doctor's degree from the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

Men's Liberation has its virtues, too particularly in a ballet company such as New York City Ballet, whose director, George BalanChine, once made the somewhat controversial statement: "Ballet is woman." Well, it isn't, Indeed, anthropologists are in agreement that in primitive tribes dancing is more often a masculine than a feminine function. In the well-organized ranks of classic ballet, female and male should be equal constituents.

Lovers of the Delaware River, a magnificent stream that, although within easy reach of millions, has somehow retained much of its pristine beauty and vitality, are rejoicing that an enlightened program of water releases from its three New York City-owned reservoirs is under way.
The advertising business could be committing suicide killing itself with a short-range, penny-pinching attitude toward personnel training.

Thomas P. Beaumont, a former vice president of United Brands in Boston and an executive for 15 years with the Young Rubicam advertising agency, died on Saturday while visiting relatives in Greenwich, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

Louis Westfall Munro, who retired in 1968 as president of Doremus Company, the advertising an dpublic rela tions firm at 120 Broadway, died Saturday in his home on Ridge Road, Syosset, L.I. He was 81 years old.

For two weeks, the credit markets have been caught by surprise, first with prices declining when many people though they would rise and then rising when many believed prices would drop. By the end of last week, however, the fog over the ...

RICHMOND, May 31 (UPI) Lieut. Alice Cook, U.S.N.R., may resume her career as Lieut. Comdr. Alice Cook, U.S.N., thanks to a court decision that motherhood should not necessarily rule out active duty in the military service.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) An animalprotection group has accused Amnesty International of "horrendous and disgust ing" experiments on hogs involving electric shocks and red-hot metal rods.

One prominent Wall Street investment banker recently remarked somewhat facetiously but nonetheless approvingly that William E. Simon, who was Secretary of the Treasury in the preceding Republican administration

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 30 (AP) A New York man arrested here in connection with a heroin ring will be returned to the United States to face charges, an official of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency said today.
VIENNA, May 30 (Reuters) Defense Minister Karl Luetgendorf resigned today to avoid almost certain dismissal in a brusing political quarrel over Austrian arms shipments to Syria.

PARIS, May 30 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Carter Administration would ask Congress for an emergency increase of $375 million in American foreign aid this year "to help meet the most acute needs of the world's poorest nations."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 Saudi Arabia has reportedly decided to take control of all foreign banks operating in that country.
TRENTON, May 30 Questions being put by organizations to the candidates for Governor indicate that the state income tax may not be the all-encompassing issue after all.

The huge silver punch bowl went to Ch. McKendree's Bold Venture, the striking Irish setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York at the conclusion of the Queensboro Kennel Club's 54th all-breed show in Jacob Riis Park. On his way to the top prize, the setter outclassed 1,219 competitors and won his 11th best in show last night.

I am male, white, 46. I have undergraduate and graduate degrees from two reasonably well-known Eastern institutions. My first job lasted for four years, my second for ten, my third for seven. I have a wife, three daughters, a mortgaged home and a 1972 "Beetle" for which I paid cash.

The old soldiers on the march outnumbered the 300 to 400 spectators but barely at Manhattan's Memorial Day parade yesterday up Riverside Drive from 72d Street. And when they reached the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, at 89th Street, they found a flagpole but no flag.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 30 (AP) A Federal judge today ordered the Food and Drug Administration to return 6,700 cases of apricot pits to an East Tennessee businessman who testified they had helped his wife overcome cancer.

Irvie Eugene Lattimer, spiceal-features engineer for the long-lines department of the American Telephone Telegraph Company until his retirement 24 years ago, died Sunday night at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 88 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 30 To give a new push to his drive to deter the spread of nuclear weapons, President Carter has selected Gerard C. Smith, arms-control chief in the Nixon Administration, to become Ambassador at Large for high-level negotiations with other nations on the nuclear issue.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) Kojak, Columbo and most other television detectives frequently trample on the Constitution and may be subtly persuading the public that such conduct is acceptable from real-life police officers, two law professors warn.

OTTAWA, May 30 Development experts from many countries and international agencies met here today to discuss long-range plans to convert a vast, chronically parched African area along the fringes of the Sahara into a permanent source of food for other needy African nations.
The way people bank, pay bills and even handle money is being changed by an electronic revolution among the nation's financial institutions.

Although conservationists applauded the hunting ban announced May 19 by the Kenyan Government, many people familiar with the wildlife situation in that East African country say the move's major impact will not be to halt the ...

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles, which owns Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and is reported to be completing negotiations to lease two Boardwalk properties in Atlantic City for a gambling casino hotel, has been in trouble in Nevada over suspicions of involvement with Meyer Lansky, the reputed organized-crime figure.
The appointment of two new editors was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The New York Times.
MANIZALES, Colombia With the international boom in coffee prices, it would seem that growers in this No. 2 coffee-exporting nation would be awash in prosperity.

Dr. Cecil R. Bowman, an assistant physician at New York Hospital and a fellow at the Cornell University Medical College, drowned in a boating accident in the Adirondacks near Tupper Lake, N.Y., on Saturday. He was 31 years old.

YEREVAN, U.S.S.R. In some respects the Soviet Union seems like a collection of separate countries united by little more than ubiquitous statues of Lenin. Of course the pervasive Communist Party organization enforces political conformity and the Government exerts centralized economic control.

They circle the neck in the vicinity of the collar bones or climb up to the chin in the manner of an 18th-century dandy. Sometimes they edge a jacket or form a flounce on a skirt. They transform a shirt into a blouse and they add a flirtatious feeling to almost anything.

WASHINGTON, May 30 The Carter Administration is moving on two fronts to put into force one of the most costly and controversial environmental protection proposals of the President's monthold national energy plan, a requirement that new coal-burning boilers be fitted with pollution-filtering, flue gas scrubbers.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles, which owns Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and is reported to be completing negotiations to lease two Boardwalk properties in Atlantic City for a gambling casino hotel, has been in trouble in Nevada over suspicions of involvement with Meyer Lansky, the reputed organized-crime figure.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, Tuesday, May 31 The South Moluccan terrorists still holding 58 hostages in the north of the Netherlands seem to have softened after a week of determined confrontation with the Dutch Government.
Frank Coughlan, a 53-year-old insurance man from San Francisco, spent Memorial Day exactly as planned with two long swims separated by a continent.

VIENNA, May 29 George Balanchine brought one of his bestknown ballets in three-quarter time, "Liebeslieder Walzer," to the city of the waltz last night, and a glittering audience at the State Opera House responded with enthusiasm.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30-Investigations of illegal aliens in California have been "paralyzed" by paper work issuing from mass requests for a stay of deportation under a Federal District Court order in Chicago, according to officials for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service here.
RANGOON, Burma, May 30 (UPI) Ba Maw, 85, the head of Burma's Government during the Japanese occupation in World War II, died Saturday, it was reported today.
SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 30 (AP) Following is a list of the dead, identified as of late today, in the fire Saturday night at the Beverly Hills Supper Club here:

WASHINGTON, May 30 A Federal panel investigating the Food and Drug Administration has found major shortcomings in its regulation of the pharmaceutical industry and will propose 91 detailed changes tomorrow.

It is widely agreed in Wall Street that International Business Machines has been the outstanding growth stock of the post-World War II period, and the stock remains the top holding among institutions. But for the first time, it seems, some analysts are beginning to question whether I.B.M. can continue to hold its commanding lead in computers and thus rate its heavy institutional following.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30-Sources traveling with Rosalynn Carter on her seven-nation tour of the Caribbean and Latin America said today that the United States hd proposed a formal eachange of doplomats with Cuba, but without a full resumption of diplomatic relations.

Ideal spring weather encouraged an unusually large crowd to attend the Naumburg concert on Central Park's Mall late Sunday afternoon. Nearly every bench was full for the occasion, which opened the 52d continuous season of free outdoor concerts established in 1905 by Elkan Naumburg.

GANTON, England, May 30 (AP) Fred Ridley, a 24-year-old law student from Winter Haven, Fla., defeated Pat Mulcare of Ireland today, 7 and 6, in the first round of the British Amateur golf championship.

GUATEMALA, May 30 A meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank began here today with the reading of an anticapitalist message from the gunmen who kidnapped El Salvador's Ambassador to Guatemala yesterday.

Charles F. Preusse, a gruff-voiced New York City official who was known as the "chief trouble-shooter" for four years during the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital on Long Island after a brief illness. Mr. Preusse was 75 years old and had homes in East Hampton and at 522 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 30 (AP) Rhodesian forces were said to have struck deeper into Mozambique today in search of Rhodesian black nationalists' guerrilla bases. Mozambique charged that the invaders were attacking its army bases as well.

Do you have faith in the future of New York City? That is the question that the Assembly's Committee on Cities was asking yesterday in Coney Island, in the fourth of a series of citywide street forums.

Fifteen daguerreotypes, believed to be the earliest known photographs of American slaves, have been discovered in an unused storage cabinet in the attic of Harvard University's Peabody Museum of Archeology and Ethnology.

WASHINGTON, May 30 To give a new push to his drive to deter the spread of nuclear weapons, President Carter has selected Gerard C. Smith, arms-control chief in the Nixon Administration, to become Ambassador at Large for high-level negotiations with other nations on the nuclear issue.

WASHINGTON, May 30 A Federal panel investigating the Food and Drug Administration has found major shortcomings in its regulation of the pharmaceutical industry and will propose 91 detailed changes tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether 59 airports in 33 states and Puerto Rico have cooperated in monopolistic practices by car rental firms using their premises.
MANCHESTER, England, May 30 (AP) An 11-year-old British schoolboy has made chess history by becoming the youngest person ever to qualify for a national championship final.

Edward Hopper is 10 years dead and gone from his skylighted studio at 3 Washington Square North, and professors talk about sociology there now in the great wash of light that flows down through the slope of roof glass. Hopper spent 50 years in that light, silently making paintings about the heart of this city, showing people and places defined in solitude and in great angled planes of color and shade.

The nation's 14,000 insured commercial banks earned a record $7.6 billion in 1976 on stockholders equity of $72.3 billion, an increase in earnings of 6 percent from 1975, a bank publication reported yesterday.
Gilbert W. Taishoff, a builder, realestate broker and consulting engineer, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

At least once every eight years the American people entrust the Presidency to a man with no experience on the job, but the owners of baseball teams dislike such risks. When in the market for a manager, most of them look for someone who has held the position elsewhere, not necessarily with distinction.

An Albany scientist is in serious condition suffering from rabies, the deadly viral disease he was trying to prevent through research aimed at developing an oral vaccine to stop the spread of the infection in wild animals.
Dr. Henry A. Kissinger is expected to withdraw from consideration for appointment to a professorship and an endowed chair at Columbia University, according to people close to the situation.

MAYS LANDING, N.J., May 30 With Seattle Slew, the 3-year-olds' band leader resting in his Belmont Park barn, five colts he had beaten in Triple Crown races and two others competed today for the top prize in the $124,200 Jersey Derby and for the role of second fiddle in the division.
They just look like more cash machines built into bank walls, but to Citibank they are a $50 million gamble that the consumer can be wooed and won with electronic services.

What can the consumer gain or lose in an electronic funds transfer world? The convenience would be 24-hour access to funds from any number of locations around the country or the world. The time and possibly the cost for paying bills could drop.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30 Rosalynn Carter and Prime Minister Michael Manley of Jamaica discussed finances, Cuba, Panama, human rights and rain today as the First Lady made the first stop on her seven-nation diplomatic mission to Latin America.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday an agreement with Rumania to supply up to 27.3 million tons of high grade metallurgical coal, valued at nearly $2 billion, to Rumania's expanding steel industry.

PARIS, May 30 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Carter Administration would ask Congress for an emergency increase of $375 million in American foreign aid this year "to help meet the most acute needs of the world's poorest nations."

DEVON, Pa., May 30 Buddy Brown, a 19-year-old rider from North Salem, N.Y., piloted Viscount to victory in the open jumper class tonight at the Devon Horse Show and finished tied for first place in the battle for the championship.

The decision by Ray Kroc, the owner of the San Diego Padres, to hire Alvin Dark as the new manager of his ball club is beyond criticism so far. Dark, who was named to replace John McNamara on Sunday, joined his new team in San Francisco yesterday and led the Padres to victory in both games of a doubleheader, 12-8 and 9-8.

Depreciation and retained earnings have traditionally been one of the major sources for corporate expansion and a study by the Conference Board suggests that reliance on internally generated capital is likely to become even heavier over the next four years.

In the last decade or so, the art of budgeting has taken on an aspect of the fashion world: A new style or simply a fad, some critics say becomes popular for a few years, only to be replaced in turn by a newer trend.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 30 The ornate state Senate chamber had already been the scene of one world-class filibuster earlier in the month. So when Gene Jones of Houston rose on Friday afternoon, cleared his throat and began reading slowly from a dusty law book, there was a certain amount of groaning and head-holding.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 30 (AP) Responding to a Miami controversy over a ban on discrimination against homosexuals, the Florida House approved today bills outlawing marriages by persons of the same sex and bar- ing homosexuals from adopting children. Opponents charged that neither bill was necessary.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) Dennis Eckersley of the Cleveland Indians, who pitched 7 2-3 hitless innings to wrap up his last outing, hurled a no-hitter at Municipal Stadium tonight in beating Frank Tanana and the California Angels, 1-0.
LAUREL, Md., May 30 (AP) Officials at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center here are calling this year's crop of eggs from the rare whooping crane "a real bonanza."

Renaldo Nehemiah surpassed the national schoolboy record for the 120-yard high hurdles three times yesterday at the Eastern States outdoor track and field championships, but only one clocking was official and that one was the best.

PARIS, May 30 (AP) Brian Gottfried overcame France's Patrice Dominguez and a noisy partisan crowd today and reached the quarterfinals of the $300,000 French open tennis championships. Harold Solomon, another American favorite, was beaten.

A child advocacy group has issued a report charging that, as a result of the financial crisis in the city's public schools, many handicapped children are now being taught by teachers who have seniority, but no experience in special education.

"Money ... Money ... Money!" the three men in the subway car gloat, pulling handfuls of fake greenbacks from their attache cases as a hand-held color camera records the action for this "underground" film.
KEY WEST, Fla. May 30 (AP) Thieves stole more than 400 of James J. Audubon's watercolors of North American birds, valued at $400,000, from his restored home here, the police said.

ATLANTA, May 30 The New York Apples came from behind tonight to beat the Soviets, 27-23, and extended their winning streak to four straight marches. They return home tomorrow night for the first of five matches.
FOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 30 More than 20,000 persons in Orange County, south of Los Angeles, are getting an education these days at a college without a single building or full-time teacher.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 (AP) Dr. Dale R. Corson, the president of Cornell University, was named today to the new post of chancellor by the school's trustees.

LIME ROCK, Conn., May 30 Al Holbert of Warrington, Pa., drove his highly modified Chevrolet Monza to victory today in the $50,000 Camel GT Challenge race at Lime Rock Park. Holbert beat the runner-up, Hurley Haywood, by 1-1/3 laps, in the International Motor Sports Association 100-mile race. Haywood of Jacksonville, Fla., pilots a turbocharged Porsche Carrera.

There is some debate as to whether Isadora Duncan was born in 1877 or 1878. Just to be on the safe side, two generations of her disciples have just celebrated the 100th anniversary of her birth with a program of dances composed by the legendary Isadora herself and by her first students.

FOR four years, I felt I had blown it, the 60's had blown it, and we would never again see the heights. And then one day I heard myself reciting that line and became aware that I don't feel that way anymore."

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court invalidated today the latest in a series of six legislative reapportionment plans for Mississippi, saying the proposed districts were not close enough to each other in population to meet the Court's one-man, one-vote formula for fair distribution of political power.
It's midnight and the night people are out, ready for action. The discotheque scene in Manhattan has not only revived but exploded.

Frank Panicoli demonstrated how to fry an egg with sunlight. Jonathan Bisignano showed how he would use a solar heater for his room at home so that he could stop arguing with his mother about how high to set the thermostat. And, Hyung Lee explained how everything around the home, even garage, could be used to produce energy.

The credit markets were affected by developments on several fronts yesterday. The Federal funds rate climbed as high as 5 percent and prices declined but only modestly. The Treasury announced that it would pay off $710 million of the $5.71

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday accused Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court and the special state anticorruption prosecutor, John F. Keenan, of having used "coercive" methods to get a Queens County grand jury to indict Judge Robert T. Groh of Civil Court last November on charges of bribery and grand larceny.
The Jets, officially New Yorkers once again, have not forced their season-ticket holders to take the one regular-season game to be played in New Jersey.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday accused Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court and the special state anticorruption prosecutor, John F. Keenan, of having used "coercive" methods to get a Queens County grand jury to indict Judge Robert T. Groh of Civil Court last November on charges of bribery and grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Con tending that the Carter Administration had overestimated costs for welfare, Supplemental Security Income and Medicaid, a Senate panel today cut $1.8 billion from an appropriations billl for the Depart ments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare.

Five of the 10 Democrats and two of the four Republicans seeking their parties' governorship nominations next Tuesday are given virtually no chance of winning, though in most cases they are campaigning vigorously and optimistically.
PARIS, May 31 The United States has offered to join with the Communist countries in aiding the developing world, "when and where they are willing to do it."

BONN, May 31 (Reuters) United States Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that the Federal Government planned to study a newly developed diesel car from Volkswagen as part of its efforts to promote energy savings and higher safety standards.

GENESIS In the spring of 1927 "The Second Man," the first work of the late S.N. Behrman to be produced, started the illustrious career of the playwright career of the playwright and scenarist who was best known for his urbane and witty stage comedies.
OTTAWA, May 31 Canada has sold another 3 million metric tons of wheat to Communist China for a total so far this year of 4.5 million metric tons, the Canadian Wheat Board announced today.

NEW HAVEN, May 31 A team of Yale University medical researchers said today that cases of Lyme arthritis, which is thought to be transmitted by ticks, had been found throughout a wide area of coastal New England and on Long Island.

The deadline by which a purchaser of a 1977 Pontiac, Buick or Oldsmobile car equipped with a Chevrolet engine must choose either to exchange the car or receive a free, three-year insurance policy on it was extended yesterday from June 1 to June 11 by State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Korn.

Barry Farber talked with the final guest on his radio interview show at 3 A.M. yesterday, and seven hours and 40 minutes later, he was in Times Square to announce that he was running for Mayor of New York.

UNIONDALE, L.I., May 31 Winning all five events for the first time this season, the New York Apples defeated the San Francisco Golden Gaters, 31-20, in World Team Tennis tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

TRENTON, May 31 The principal author of the casino-gambling bill Governor Byrne will sign in Atlantic City Thursday said today that "it is not true" that the bill might allow organized crime to move in on the operations.

WHAT'S PABA? It's not a new cereal of a Latin dance craze. It stands for paraaminobenzoic acid, whose drivatives may help keep a lot of sun worshippers from turning into wrinkled prunes or courting skin cancer as they lie on beaches this summer.

At the urging of the New York State Assembly, the United States Food and Drug Administration has validated a list of manufacturers who have Government approval to produce generic equivalents of 1,600 brand-name prescription drugs. Generic drugs generally are considerably less expensive than brand-name equivalents.
A 29-year-old convict seized his lawyer at the Camden County jail yesterday afternoon and held her hostage for eight hours until the authorities agreed to dismiss a number of charges against him.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to stay the jail sentences of John N. Mitchell and H.R. Haldeman pending their final effort to win review of their Watergate coverup convictions.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that seniority systems that perpetuate the effects of past racial discrimination, placing blacks at a disadvantage to whites in the competition for better jobs and other benefits, are not necessarily illegal.

GUATEMALA, May 31 Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that United States economic aid to Argentina would depend on whether the Argentine military regime improves its respect for human rights.

A QUIET but substantial package of prime-time television gets under way tonight at 8 on Channel 13 with an hour-long profile of Linus C. Pauling. "Crusading Scientist," written and produced by Robert Richter, is part of public television's "Nova," a long-running series put together by Boston station WGBH. The portrait of Dr. Pauling is openly admiring, if not celebratory, and more than enough supporting evidence is included for solid justification.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 31 Rhodesian troops hunting guerrilla bases inside neighboring Mozambique have seized a town 50 miles from the Rhodesian border and intend to remain until all guerrilla forces in the area are wiped out, the commander of the raid said today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The kidnapping and murder trial of the 12 Hanafi Moslems accused of taking 149 persons hostage last March and holding them at gunpoint for nearly thre days in three downtown buildings opend today in District of Columbia Superior Court.

TEL AVIV, May 31 Israel cautioned the United States today that President Carter's statements about a "homeland" and compensation for the Palestinians were raising Arab expectations unrealistically and might harden the Arabs' attitude in Middle East peace talks.

SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 31 A team of state and Federal investigators completed today their first full day of searching through the ruins of the Beverly Hills Supper Club here, seeking clues to what caused the complex to erupt into an inferno that claimed the lives of 158 persons and injured more than 100 others late last Saturday.

Garry Maddox, the Philadelphia outfielder, opened the game at Veterans Stadium last night with his fourth homer of the season, then drove in two more runs with a triple in the seventh inning to spearhead the Phillies to a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The victory was Philadelphia's fifth straight.

The New York Mets, feuding with their star players and limping along with the worst record in baseball, dismissed Joe Frazier as manager yesterday and replaced him with one of their senior players, Joe Torre.

Three priests who speak Spanish and have long been involved in Hispanic affairs were named yesterday by Pope Paul VI as auxiliary bishops of the New York Archdiocese a move that recognizes the desire of archdiocesan leaders for stronger ties to the New York Hispanic community.

A new report analyzing the degree to which member countries of the International Labor Organization have lived up to their treaty commitments on worker freedom has again focused attention on what the future role of the United...
LOS ANGELES, May 31 The administration of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., has announced a sweeping proposal to institure powerful state controls over California's urban growth.
Credit cards, those wallet-stuffing pieces of plastic that play a major role in the move toward a cashless or checkless society, are undergoing change.

Erich Hirschfeld has been reappointed president of Willoughby-Peerless, a leading chain of photographic specialty stores, Harvey Berkey, president of Berkey Photo Inc., the parent company, announced yesterday.

The Matsushita Electric Corporation of America said yesterday that it had been advised by Kuwait that products it made under license from the RCA Corporation would be boycotted by that Arab nation. A spokesman said that Qatar and Syria had also apparently taken similar action.
PERTH, Australia Australians, it is sometimes said, work hard at their leisure. Weekends and sports give meaning to their lives.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (UPI) Carolyn McKendrick, 24-year-old girlfriend of Tyrone Everett the Philadelphia boxer, was charged today with his slaying. Mrs. McKendrick surrendered to the police this morning.
ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 31 The South Moluccans holding 56 hostages on a train near here have asked for mediators to help end their standoff with the Dutch Government.

PARIS, May 31 (AP) Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine left-hander, ruthlessly knocked Stan Smith out of the $300,000 French open tennis championships, 6-1, 6-2, 6-1, today and moved into the quarterfinals.

WHITE PLAINS, May 31 The police of the Westchester County town of Greenburgh said today that ballistic tests indicated that the same weapon, a .32caliber handgun, was used in three shootings into private homes or apartments Monday night.

PARIS Three critically important Mediterranean elections are taking place this spring and it is hard to say which is historically the most significant. The first was Israel's May vote which eased from power a Labor Party that had ruled the state since its creation in 1948.
TOKYO, May 31 (AP) The dollar remained unchanged at 277.275 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today.
The National Council on Alcoholism is planning a nationwide campaign to warn women of the danger of drinking during pregnancy.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 31 Kenya's Minister for Tourism and Wildlife said today that the Government would follow up its ban on big-game hunting with a program to crack down on poachers, whose activities are a major cause of the dwindling of the country's wildlife.

It would seem that the forces interested in the success of the Universal Product Code could mount a national educational advertising campaign that points up the consumer benefits of the revolutionary laser-equipped, computerized supermarket checkout system. Perhaps it would prevent the localized outcries from consumer activists.

The marriage of Gretchen MalletPrevost Leefmans and Allan M. Siegal took place yesterday in the courthouse of the Appellate Division, First Department, New York State Supreme Court. Justice Samuel J. Silverman performed the ceremony.

ALBANY, May 31 Governor Carey said today that he opposed efforts to require refundable deposits on bottles and cans, and indicated that he preferred instead a national "resource recovery" program that would collect discarded containers and find new industrial uses for the material.

SOARING prices for fresh fruits and vegetables helped thrust the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City to a record level last week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

GANTON, England, May 31 (AP) Two of the most heralded American amateur golfers, Dick Siderowf, the defending titleholder, and Bill Sander, the current United States champion, were ousted today from the British Amateur tournament. The total American contingent that started 54-strong yesterday was reduced to a mere handful.

MONTREAL, May 31 The Aluminum Company of Canada has decided to proceed with plans to increase production capacity in Quebec with an initial $200 million investment and the news has given the province's buffeted Government a tremendous lift. The company is a subsidary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reuters) The United States today expressed its concern over the latest Rhodesian raid into Mozambique and "the negative effect" it could have on peace efforts in southern Africa.
G. Bradford Cook, a former general counsel and chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was barred yesterday by the United States Supreme Court from practicing before it.

Shortly after taking command of the New York Mets last night, Joe Torre was sitting at his desk in the manager's office and making out his first lineup card. He did it quickly, easily, as if he had been doing it almost all his life.

TRENTON, Ohio, May 31 Slowly, nervously, Ronald Butts, a custodian at Wayne Elementary School here, hitched the United States flag to the chain of a pole and dutifully raised the banner the length of the cylinder, then brought it back down, stopping at half-staff.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) A Government panel recommended today removal of the secrecy surrounding Food and Drug Administration regulation of drugs and urged more formal relationships between the agency and the pharmaceutical industry. Details of the report was disclosed yesterday.
Jeanette Sivak, who is 13 years old, is kept awake nights by "prostitutes running to get into cars, cursing and screaming when the cars won't stop, getting punched."

WHEN I was growing up, one of the sights in town was a motherdaughter team in matching outfits, both their heads clipped in girlish bobs. They walked miles each day through the department stores and busiest streets on an endless shopping trip, totally absorbed in each other talking, talking, talking down the years.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 31 Rosalynn Carter delighted some 1,500 Costa Ricans who met her at the airport here today by greeting them in Spanish.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 31 (Reuters) Former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam narrowly retained leadership of the Australian Labor party today, then announced that he would step down 18 to 24 months after the next general election in 1978.

JERICHO, L.I. There is a spot near Exit 40 of the Long Island Expressway in Nassau County where the Meadow Brook Club is visible on the northern horizon. In the foreground, until a couple of years ago, the late George Wicks had a sod farm.

TRENTON, May 31 The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered today that all political, promotional and institutional advertising by gas, electric and telephone utilities be charged to the companies' stockholders, and not to business expenses to be paid for by customers in the form of higher rates.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31 Andrew Young seemed to have mollified Sweden's chief delegate today with the assurance that he had not singled out Sweden as having "racist" attitudes.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 Joseph G. Smith, a steel executive, educator, historian and prominent Roman Catholic layman, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital, where he had been hospitalized for three weeks with a heart ailment. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The United States shortly will quietly pass a new and complicating milestone in the arms race by deploying a more accurate and powerful warhead capable of destroying Soviet missiles in their silos.

BOSTON, May 31 Compared with previous encounters, the game between the Yankees and the Red Sox tonight represented a pause in their intense, exciting competition, an exhibition contest almost. Not even two Gil Patterson pitches that sailed high and inside and hit George Scott and Carlton Fisk could enliven the proceedings.

GUATEMALA, May 31 (AP) El Salvador's ambassador to Guatemala, Eduardo Casanova Sandoval, was freed by kidnappers tonight unhurt except for a gunshot wound in the foot he received during his abduction, a family spocesman said.

Kingfish is a band with strong associations with the San Francisco rock scene the Grateful Dead and the New Riders of the Purple Sage in particular so its appearance Monday and yesterday at the Bottom Line, just before tonight's world premiere of the Grateful Dead's movie, is all the more appropriate.

While many people still equate the term accountant with being a certified public accountant, a growing corporate trend in the last five years has been the encouragement of a different type of accountant who does not have a C.P.A. after his name.

"Auto racing, I'm sad to say, is still a white man's sport," said Wendell Scott, the first black stock-car driver, whose career spans more than two decades. His earnings in that time, he said, are just over $180,000 (less than $9,000 a year).
DEL RIO, Tex., May 31 Miguel decided to come to the United States barefooted. Wearing shoes was not part of his American Dream.

WASHINGTON, May 31 Congressional reaction was skeptical today to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's proposal that United States foreign aid to the world's poorest nations be increased by $375 million a year.

What began as fundamental experiments by two physicists at the General Electric Company's 76-year-old research and development center in Schenectady, N.Y., has turned into a new technique for manufacturing semiconductor circuits up to a thousand times faster than by previous methods.

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S minor Fokine festival, which continues at the Metropolitan Opera House until tonight's performance, has had to ring the changes on only four ballets. On Monday night it reintroduced "Le Spectre de la Rose" into the repertory, to share the bill with "The Firebird" and "Petrushka."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 31 Rhodesian troops hunting guerrilla bases inside neighboring Mozambique have seized a town 50 miles from the Rhodesian border and intend to remain until all guerrilla forces in the area are wiped out, the commander of the raid said today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 A Congressional study released today has set the stage for a sharp legislative battle, with a finding that the Government has failed to adequately monitor an experiment in which mutual savings and loan associations converted to ownership by stockholders.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 31 By a near-record margin of 32 points, the Portland Trail Blazers blew the Philadelphia 76ers off the court again tonight, 130-98, and tied the National Basketball Association's final playoff series at two games apiece.

WESTPORT, Conn. The filling stations have not gone out of business and all the cars have not been put up on blocks yet, but a federally sponsored experiment in mass transit here is beginning to make significant inroads into this suburb's heavy reliance on the private automobile.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 31 A year ago, Noes Sollisa's 23-year-old brother, Bob, was sentenced to six years in a Dutch prison for his role in seizing the Indonesian Consulate in Amsterdam in December 1975 and demanding freedom for the South Moluccan Islands, which are part of Indonesia.

ACCIDENTS AND EMERGENCIES are by definition unexpected events. But a little planning for the fact that such things happen to everyone sooner or later can do a lot to minimize their adverse effects, make life more pleasant for the victim, and perhaps even save a life.

LONDON, May 31 We will go to London for the Queen's Jubilee, we said, and since there has been so much discord over Concorde, we will fly that supersonic bird and find out whether it was worth all the fuss. Conclusion: Very expensive, very convenient, very steady, very noisy, but worth it, yes.
CONCORD, N.H., May 31 A Federal grand jury here began an investigation today into possible misuse of Federal funds by Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. A very predictable thing happens in this country whenever the economy takes a sharp turn for the worst: The illegal alien is rediscovered. Politicians, journalists, organized labor, and other interest groups rush to blame him for every imaginable problem afflicting American society, from high unemployment to rising crime rates, escalating socialservice costs, overpopulation, and balance-of-payments deficits.

June Foster Auslander Wells of New York and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Ridgely W. Harrison in New York. The ceremony was performed by Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. of the Civil Court of New York at the home of the bride.
New plant and equipment appropriations by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers continued at an exceptionally high level in the first quarter of 1977, rising 30 percent above the year-ago rate.

ALBANY, May 31 A bill that would permit New York City to require that all future Civil Service employees be residents of the city was passed by the Assembly today. In previous years, such measures have failed in the Senate, but the present bill is felt to have a better chance there this year.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court today defended the rights of the multi-generation "extended family," striking down a zoning ordinance in Ohio that tightly limited the number of persons and their relationships to one another who may live in a single-family dwelling.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 Viscount, an aged bay gelding who got a late start in his international career, moved far out front in the race for the open jumper championship by winning his second class in three starts tonight at the Devon Horse Show.
To the outsider, the Hasidim of Brooklyn may seem basically alike bearded men in black suits rushing to work or synagogues, women wearing scarves and wigs, many of them pushing baby carriages.
The big guns are gathering for a shootout Friday at the Grand Central Racquet Club.

PARIS, May 31 Representatives of the world's poor and starving today criticized as inadequate a package of economic concessions offered them here yesterday at the north-south talks by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and other officials of industrial countries.

WASHINGTON, May 31 Senator Richard Stone, a leading supporter of Israel, is due to confer in Israel later this week with Menahem Begin on the policies of the next Israeli government and remind him of the importance to Israel of American Congressional and public opinion.
JERUSALEM, May 31 Two weeks after Israel's surprising election result, a large number of Israelis are wondering about the country's future both internally and internationally.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 31 King Hussein of Jordan gave full support today to the United States to start the process for peace in the Mideast but said that he feared the chances of a new war had increased with the recent election victory of the right-wing Likud bloc in Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The United States shortly will quietly pass a new and complicating milestone in the arms race by deploying a more accurate and powerful warhead capable of destroying Soviet missiles in their silos.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 (UPI) Reporters on The Boston Globe, The San Francisco Examiner and The Anchorage Daily News were among the winners today in the 1977 Gerald Loeb Awards for distinguished business and financial journalism.
PARIS, May 31 France has decided to hold up its controversial sale of a nuclear plant to Pakistan, officials disclosed here today.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 31 Many of the nation's largest industrial companies are offering more jobs to this year's college graduates than they had expected to earlier, indicating they believe the economy is improving more rapidly than they thought it would last fall.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) The dollar dropped in value against almost all West European currencies today, and the British pound shot up by more than a quarter-cent to close at $1.72. The price of gold dropped on European bullion markets.
Grandmaster Anatoly Lein, a Russian emigre living in New York, won the Moses Mitchell Tournament or Champions at the Manhattan Chess Club with a 5 1-2-1 1-2 score.

ALBANY, May 31 Legislation intended to slow the placing of severely mentally and physically disabled New York children in institutions outside New York and to insure decent care for the 800 children already out-of-state was introduced today in the Assembly.

Ben Grauer, whose name and voice were familiar to millions of radio listeners for more than four decades, died early yesterday morning in New York University Medical Center Hospital. He was admitted to the hospital with a heart ailment last Friday and is believed by doctors to have died in his sleep. He would have been 69 years old tomorrow.

Dennis Eckersley had the phone off the hook all yesterday morning at home in the Cleveland suburb of North Royalton. "I don't blame him," said Frank Robinson, manager of the Indians. "He's going to be under a tremendous amount of pressure from the public."

Nancy Fox Weber and Charles Michael Platt, who are authors, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in the Municipal Building. The bride, who will continue to use her maiden name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Weber of West Hartford, Conn. Mr. Platt's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Platt, reside in Letchworth, England.

Mayor Beame,the Board of Estimate and the City Council leadership moved yesterday and early today toward settling their disagreements over next year's budget after resolving a momentary scare that threatened to create a $44 million deficit.

THE "GOOD MORNING, AMERICA" show on ABC-TV has signed up Margaret Trudeau to cover portions of Queen Eliza beth II's Silver Jubilee celebrations in England. A network spokesman said the estranged wife of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada would prepare "a sort of photo-journal" to be seen sometime next week. Mrs. Trudeau will appear on the program.
John J. Oberdorf, executive vice president of the Transway International Corporation, died Saturday of cancer in Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck, N.J. He was 63 years old.

It's hard to tell whether all the felicitations are justified; much of its work overseeing the nation's intelligence services goes on in secret. But from what is known, the committee is entitled at least to some credit.

Thomas Michalak, a 36-year-old Polish-born conductor and a resident of the United States since 1963, has been named music director of the New Jersey Symphony, effective today.

A Congressional subcommittee was told yesterday that child pornography was one of the fastest growing and most lucrative components of the commercial sex industry and involved more than 300,000 children below 16 years of age. PLAINS, Ga., May 31 President Carter came home again today home to this dusty little village that has been burdened by his success.

The stock market continued to display broad-based weakness yesterday as numerous former favorites hit their lowest prices of 1977.
