WASHINGTON, May 31(AP) The prices that farmers get for raw products as they move into the consumer pipeline rose 2 per cent between April 15 and May 15, the sixth consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

Three priests who speak Spanish and have long been involved in Hispanic affairs were named yesterday by Pope Paul VI as auxiliary bishops of the New York Archdiocese a move that recognizes the desire of archdiocesan leaders for stronger ties to the New York Hispanic community.
PARIS, May 31 France has decided to hold up its controversial sale of a nuclear plant to Pakistan, officials disclosed here today.

Perry Lentz is an associate professor of English at Kenyon College in Ohio who graduated from the same institution in 1964. Not long ago he was looking over some classroom notes that he had inherited from Denham Sutcliffe, one of his own professors, and he made a startling discovery.
EPSOM, England, May 31 "Which do you fancy for the Derby," asks a sign in the window of a London bookmaker, "a frog or a bulldog?"

Labor talk gave way to basic horse talk about speed, stamina and class yesterday as Belmont Park became a smooth-running race track again. For the first time in eight days of racing at the strike-slowed meeting, horseplayers had to pay to get into the track as well as out of it.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that states may refuse to pay unemployment benefits to any worker who is laid off because of a strike against his employer, whether or not the worker is participating in the strike himself.
DESPITE CANARDS to the contrary, more than a few New Yorkers take pride in knowing their city and pleasure in helping the confused and lost.
Describing himself as "unflinchingly conservative," Barry Farber, the radio interviewer, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor of New York.
The top executives at N.W. Ayer ABH International are twice blessed today. They've gotten a nice piece of business and a swell excuse to go south come winter.

WEST PATERSON, May 31 "Call it an answer to faith," the Rev. Alphonse J. Stephenson said as he looked at a $250,000 icon returned early this morning to St. Ann Melkite Catholic Church. The icon, depicting the Blessed Virgin holding the infant Jesus and surrounded by gold, silver and precious stones, was stolen from its shrine a week ago yesterday.

SECUNDA, South Africa While the United States searches anxiously for ways to reduce its dependence on imported oil, South Africa, with no natural oil of its own, has embarked on an ambitious project to produce substantial amounts of gasoline and other liquid motor fuel from coal.

A strong performance by a visiting British expert brought him a title in the concluding event of the Eastern regional championships at the New York Hilton Hotel Monday night, and frustrated a bid by a famous New York partnership for two straight victories.
Describing himself as "unflinchingly conservative," Barry Farber, the radio interviewer, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor of New York.
The top executives at N.W. Ayer ABH International are twice blessed today. They've gotten a nice piece of business and a swell excuse to go south come winter.

GANTON, England, June 1 (AP) Madden Hatcher 3d, a high school student from Columbus, Ga., salvaged some pride for the Americans today from the wreckage of their British Amateur challenge by winning two matches to remain among the last 32 competitors.

Asarco Inc., sent out a trial balloon yesterday, cutting the price of copper by 3 cents, to 68 cents a pound. None of the other major producers followed its lead and none would comment on Asarco's action.

With show-business celebrities at the press tables and a Dixieland combo next to the dais playing "I like New York in June," Bella S. Abzug yesterday threw her hat a big-brimmed black straw into the race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) The General Accounting Office said today that more employees of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation should be required to file financial disclosure statements.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 31 (AP) Robert Laird Duncan Sr. of Westfield, N.J., a former all-America quarterback and longtime high school athletic director, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 74 years old.

A little-noted recommendation in President Carter's national energy plan is a call for 6,000 vans, to move Government workers to and from their jobs. The idea deserves the President's boost; Congress should now add its support. Van pooling is one of those ideas whose excellence is matched by its simplicity.

With speeches and champagne, with show-business and political personalities, with the strains of music and straining moving men, the controversial Manhattan Plaza apartment complex near Times Square finally welcomed its first residents yesterday.
Elizabeth Bancroft Schlesinger, a leading feminist, died yesterday in the home of a son, Thomas B. Schlesinger, in Williamsburg, Va. She was 90 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Landmark job discrimination cases such as those in steel and communications might have to be reconsidered under yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding seniority systems, legal sources said today.
After Harvey, a gray rabbit, had bitten six people, his owners decided to turn him over to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to prevent cruelty to humans.
In a strong turnaround from a year ago, sales in May of six of New York City's largest department stores achieved their biggest year-to-year gain in 33 months.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 1 The Philadelphia 76ers and Portland Trail Blazers. Like a couple of dozen extratall Jekyll-Hydes, flew across the country today to resume their struggle for the National Basketball Association championship in Philadelphia Friday night, with the basketball world wondering which would display which manifestation in tame No.5.

TWO OF THE FEW indisputable giants of 20th-century dance two people who left their im print on its history are Martha Graham and the late Michel Fokine. New York has been celebrating both American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House last night completed a weeklong Fokine festival, while at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company is continuing its season of Graham works, which runs through June 11.
Beginning next Thursday, The Home Section of The New York Times will carry a regular column on backgammon, A.M. Rosenthal, the executive editor of the newspaper, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission tentatively voted 4 to 3 today to let the American Telephone Telegraph Company decide whether to cancel or continue its Telpak bulk private telephone line service.

GLORIA SWANSON has a white stained floor in her living room. The library floor of Henry Fonda's East Side town house is bleached, as are the floors in the Central Park West apartment of Robert Metzger, the interior designer.

ASSEN, The Netherlands, June 1 Dutch Government authorities and South Moluccan terrorists could not agree on mediators today and for the 10th night, the armed kidnappers held 60 hostages aboard a train and in a village school in northeast Holland.

NEWARK, June 1 The postmaster in Atlantic City has been arrested for allegedly helping mastermind a $1 million robbery at the main post office there, Federal officials said today. They said that he gave the building's master key and other security information to four men accused of looting three postal vaults on Feb. 27.

Jack McGowan, writer of the screenplays for some of Hollywood's betterknown musicals, died Saturday at the Sanger Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street, where he had lived since 1972. He was 81 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The recall of 280,000 jars of Beechnut baby food containing mold has been announced by the Food and Drug Administation.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) Concern about diminishing stocks sparked a demand that lifted old crop soybean futures 13 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today.
PARIS An unusual collection of gouaches has been on display at the new auction hall in the former Gare d'Orsay commercial art for fabrics by the painter Raoul Dufy.

Nineteen major firms in the brokerge and investment banking industry issued a strong position statement yesterday backing the auction market for securities and attacking last month's Securities and Exchange Commission proposal to allow New York Stock Exchange members to trade listed stocks off-board.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) James R. Schlesinger sharply cut back today two goals of President Carter's energy program the number of homes that can be insulated and the number that will get some solar heating and cooling.

NEWARK, June 1 The postmaster in Atlantic City has been arrested for allegedly helping mastermind a $1 million robbery at the main post office there, Federal officials said today. They said that he gave the building's master key and other security information to four men accused of looting three postal vaults on Feb. 27.
Alexander Marcus, professor emeritus of physicis at City College of New York, died May 16 at his home in Evanston, Ill. His age was 88.

With all outstanding issues resolved, the City Council last night adopted Mayor Beame's $13.9 billion expense budget for next year with only minor modifications and headed for approval of the $1.4 billion capital budget. The Board of Estimate was expected to follow suit on both budgets.

PARIS, Thursday, June 2 After nearly 18 months of difficult and slow-moving talks, the representatives of the world's rich and poor nations appeared to be approaching agreement early today on a limited international program intended to help the developing world, but a deadlock over plans to make increases in the price of oil more difficult threatened to sour relations between the rich and poor naions.

Saying it is prepared to produce about $3.2 million per club as a dowry, the World Hockey Association is waiting this week for the blessing of the National Hockey League board of governors and the N.H.L. Players Association in the W.H.A.'s proposed union with the older league. But an official invitation to end the expensive fiveyear rivalry between the leagues may not be as imminent as the W.H.A. owners would like to believe.

COMPLAINTS ABOUT the Guggenheim Museum's supposed inhospitability to the art it was built to contain have been in the air years since before the museum opened in 1959, in fact. When the opening did arrive, The New York Times called the building "a war between architecture and painting in which both come out badly maimed," and the contestants in the battle, maimed or not, have continued to joust at least gently since that time.

PANAMA CITY, June 1 (AP) United States and Panamanian negotiators have drafted substantial portions of a general Panama Canal treaty and have prepared a second treaty designed to guarantee the canal's neutrality, informed sources close to both sides reported.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The United States said today that Rhodesia's seizure of a Mozambican town in pursuit of guerrillas could have "extremely serious consequences" for the region. Officials said they were considering a range of possible responses, including support for new Security Council moves against Rhodesia.

PARIS, Thursday, June 2 After nearly 18 months of difficult and slow-moving talks, the representatives of the world's rich and poor nations appeared to be approaching agreement early today on a limited international program intended to help the developing world, but a deadlock over plans to make increases in the price of oil more difficult threatened to sour relations between the two blocs.

TRENTON, June 1 Plans for a $50 million "justice complex" in downtown Trenton to house the state judiciary system, the Department of Law and Public Safety and the Department of the Public Advocate were announced today by Governor Byrne.
ATLANTA, June 1 Josephine Mathewson Wilkins, a civic leader, philanthropist and early supporter of the civil rights movement in the South, died Monday in Port Charlotte, Fla. She was 83 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim and United Nations diplomats have condemned Rhodesia's foray into Mozambique but there has been no move so far to take the incident to the Security Council.

ALBANY, June 1 State correctional officials conceded today under questioning at a Legislative hearing that they had no real evidence that the controversial temporary-release program for prisoners was reducing crime.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 (UPI) Palestinian guerrillas charged today that Israeli troops had crossed three miles into southern Lebanon and seized a border village after a "fierce" predawn battle that left 30 cilivians dead or wounded.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 1 Half boat, half aeroplane and all nostalgia the 34-year-old, four-engine Southern Cross lifted from the waters of Manhasset Bay this afternoon on a flight to Ireland and into the past.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that a new labor agreement in the steel industry should raise the cost of producing a ton of steel by 4 percent this year and about 3 percent in each of the succeeding years.

Barri B. McDonough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. McDonough of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the home of her parents, to G. Christopher Blauvelt, son of Mrs. George W. Blauvelt of Naples, Fla., and Cotuit, Mass., and the late Mr. Blauvelt. The Rev. Jack G. Shutte of the First Presbyterian Chuch in Greenwich performed the ceremony.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 Candidates pledged to fight mandatory busing of children to achieve racial integration of schools here were elected to two of three seats on the Los Angeles Board of Education yesterday.

Guy Lafleur, the right wing whose two goals and seven assists helped the Montreal Canadiens sweep the Boston. Bruins in the Stanley Cup championship series, was in town yesterday to collect a plaque and a 1977 car for being Sport magazine's most valuable player in the National Hockey League playoffs. Lafleur warned that the Canadiens planned to keep the heat on the rest of league, whether their "excellence" was bad for hockey or not.

ALBANY, June 1 After a long and bitter debate that resurrected nearly every argument of the last decade for and against abortion, the State Senate went on record tonight in favor of an anti-abortion amendment to the United States Constitution.

William Castle, who made millions producing and directing films that horrified audiences and often left critics muttering about poor taste, suffered a heart attack at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., Tuesday night and died at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Eight leading Republicans endorsed today President Carter's call for energy conservation, but they challenged the need for stiff new taxes on gasoline or big cars and said that the supply of oil was not so grim as Mr. Carter suggested.
TEL AVIV, June 1 (Reuters) The Israeli Army tonight denied reports from Beirut that its troops made a large-scale incursion into southern Lebanon last night.

BALTIMORE, June 1 The retrial of Gov. Marvin Mandel and five friends on Federal corruption charges finally began in United States District Court here today after a series of delays occasioned by the Governor's two-month illness and a minor but dramatic accident this morning that left him shaken but unharmed:

What ails the stock market? Wall Street itself is baffled. The economy is moving up at a strong clip, and the expansion probably will carry well into 1978. The Carter Administration continues to reassure business of its love

LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 1 A special grand jury's report into the investigation and prosecution in the Peter Reilly murder case made public here today concluded that the youth accused of murdering his mother was a victim of a widespread pattern of harassment and improper activity, on the part of a local prosecutor and the state police.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Carter Administration's plan to revise the nation's welfare system is designed to save billions of dollars by tightening the eligibility requirements for public relief, according to Administration officials familiar with the proposal.

CHAMPAIGN, III., June 1 (UPI) Tito Steiner, an Argentine Olympic athlete, took over first place after today's first event and never trailed in winning the National Collegiate decathlon with 7,659 points, the fourth Brigham Young University winner of the event in the Last five years.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Calling himself a "low-interest-rate man," Budget Director Bert Lance said today that banks were unable to justify their higher prime lending rates on the basis of higher loan demand and warned that the new round of increases threatened to make inflation worse and weaken the business recovery.
TOKYO, June 1 In a highly unusual display of official candor. Chinese authorities have described last summer's giant Tangshan earthquake as the most deadly in China in more than four centuries.
A chase came to an end yesterday with an unusual display of police marksmanship: two bank robbery suspects hit by a single bullet.

WHEN THE NUMBER of commercial buildings going into default in Manhattan began to increase a year or so ago, New York City began encouraging landlords to cent vacant commercial space for residential use.

OTTAWA, June 1 Overriding the objections of environmentalists, the Canadian Government authorized today offshore exploratory drilling for oil and natural gas in the Beaufort Sea for the next three years.

The Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University said yesterday that its latest poll showed that only 45 percent of New Jersey's adults could name at least one of the 10 Democrats running for Governor in Tuesday's primary election, and only 17 percent could name one or more of the four Republicans.

Bad news comes from both the top and bottom of Co-op City, the world's largest housing project in the Bronx. On the bottom, the dredged sand has been settling into marsh, damaging the roads, sidewalks and playgrounds, and the pipe conduits that run below. At the top, there has been no settlement of the year-long dispute over how the project can avert bankruptcy. The truce that postponed foreclosure expires within a week.
TOKYO, June 1 In a highly unusual display of official candor, Chinese authorities have described last summer's giant Tangshan earthquake as the most deadly in China in more than four centuries.

PARIS, June 1 (AP) Brian Gottfried battled from two sets down and beat top-seeded Ilie Nastaste, 4-6, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3, in the quarterfinals of the $300,000 French open tennis championships tonight.

The Actors Fund of America, like the theatrical charity organization, has opened a new shop at 210 West 44th Street featuring theater memorabilia, objets d'art, silver, jewelry, furniture records, autographed programs, photographs, books, costumes and clothing. Profits from the venture will be used to assist needy performers.

THREE YEARS AGO Judith Somogi became the first woman to conduct the New York City Opera and two years ago she led her first symphonic program, directing the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Hollywood Bowl. On Tuesday night Miss Somogi's career blossomed a bit more when she made her debut with the New York Philharmonic in a Promenades concert that left no doubts about her basic musicianship and competence as a baton wielder.

TRENTON, June 1 Governor Byrne announced today the creation of two lawenforcement groups to prevent efforts by three organized-crime "families" to take over restaurant and liquor businesses in Atlantic City.
Only a little more than half of the American public is aware that the United States must import oil to meet its energy needs, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

CHARLESTON, S.C. Anyone who has served in the military knows there are frustrations and inequities that need to be dealt with from time to time. There are grievance procedures within all the services that should and must work. But there is nothing a military commander can do about complaints over low pay, long working hours, and the potential for bodily injury while performing normal military duties.

EAST BRUNSWICK, June 1 By the year 2000, the family could become a relic, men and women will enter the work force later and leave earlier and the gap between generations will become a chasm, Kai T. Erikson, a sociologist from Yale University, predicted today.
Spacecraft soaring into the outer parts of the solar system and toward its heart have confirmed that Jupiter is bathing a vast region with radiation.

NOTHING LIKE A DAME Agatha Christie is represented Off Off Broadway in a new production believed to be the American debut of "The Unexpected Guest." The late Dame Agatha's whodunit opened in London back in 1958, alongside her marathon "The Mousetrap" (still running), and was lost in the shuffle, although notices were good.

DETROIT, June 1 The prosecution ended its case today in the trial of two Filipino nurses charged with murdering two patients and poisoning seven others at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Carter Administration and Congress were de nounced today at a meeting of organizations and individuals opposed to a Congressional ban on the use of Medicaid finds for abortions.
MOSCOW, June 1 A leading Jewish dissident and human-rights activist has been formally charged with treason in a move by Soviet authorities that has few precedents since the days of Stalin.

The United States Constitution forbids a prison warden to inflict cruel punishment, such as flogging, on a convicted criminal who breaks prison rules. But the Constitution allows a teacher to flog a child, without giving him or her the chance to explain, for responding slowly to instructions.
LOS ANGELES, June 1 Policemen and firemen here got some good news the other day: Under a wage formula that has been in use for 52 years, their annual base pay will rise shortly to $20,358.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 1 The tax fraud trial of a Bay Area attorney, Harry Margolis, moving into its 11th week in United States District Court here, today heard testimony from the actress-singer Barbara McNair.
Twenty-three institutions in New York State have been awarded a total of $8.5 million in grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

KENT, N.Y., June 1 A sacred ceremony from the mountains of Tibet was enacted today in the rustling forest of this small American town.

Peter M. Fraser, who retired in 1957 as chairman of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, Hartford, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital after a brief illness. He lived in West Hartford, and was 86 years old.
Movie-related stocks starred yesterday as the general market staged a sharp rally after a two-week slump that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest level in nearly 17 months.

A player who returned to the tournament scene after an absence of a decade or more world notice one development that has nothing to do with the game itself. He would observe large numbers of young players carrying something that looks like an attache case.
Governor Byrne said yesterday that if he were defeated in New Jersey's Democratic primary for Governor on Tuesday, it would be because of voter rejection of the state income tax.

GLIMMEN, the Netherlands, June 1 Political terrorists like the South Moluccans holding 56 train passengers here always call on the international press to play a major role in their hijacking dramas. Correspondents and television and radio crews have answered the call in overwhelming numbers this time.

Edwin L. Gasperini, a trial lawyer who served a number of state investigative agencies, died yesterday in the offices of his law firm, Gasperini Savage, at 10 East 53d Street. He was 53 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.. June 1 He was playing on an artificial surface for the first time and in a rather unfamiliar position, but Franz Beckenbauer's metropolitan area debut tonight was still impressive.
MEMPHIS, June 1 (AP) Cook Industries, the Memphis-based agricultural commodity trading firm, said today that its fourth-quarter losses would probably amount to $60 million.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The House of Representatives voted today to impose a ceiling of 69,000 on the number of porpoises that may be killed in the nets of tuna fishermen this year, but it declined to mandate a future reduction of the quota.

ROME, May 31 After weeks of delay and over the protests of the Soviet Embassy, the organizers of a major arts festival decided today to go ahead with plans to devote a major part of their new program to dissent in Eastern Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., June 1 To improve chances for Congressional passage of changes in labor laws this year, organized labor will probably sidetrack the most controversial element in its legislative package, its demand for repeal of the so-called state "right to work" laws.

David Davis is a violinist who can play difficult music calmly and with considerable technical success when he focuses his skill and musicianship on something like Bartok's Sonata for Solo Violin or the Paganini-Kreisler "I Palpiti," which he did at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night.
RECIFE, Brazil June 1 (AP) A seven-story building of shops and apartments collapsed today, killing eight persons, the police reported.

"There's no business like show business . . . " That refrain from the old Irving Berlin song took on new meaning in the 1976-77 theater season that ended Tuesday night. The season brought substantial rises in audiences and in ticket revenues, set new records for the Broadway theaters and made show business one of the few growth industries in the otherwise shrinking New York City economy.

HERE WAS A huge grouping of rhododendrons around "the mansion" down the street from where I lived when I was young perfect for hiding In. I was much more taken by their branched shelter than by the masses of flowers that almost lit up the early summer evenings; beneath those bushes I found caves worthy of Robinson Crusoe.

VIENNA, June 1 Soviet-bloc ambassadors and counselors sidle up to their Western colleagues at cocktail parties here and in other capitals these days and, after the usual bland preliminaries, ask them what they think about last week's changes in the Kremlin leadership.
PARIS, June 1 The French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, told the foreign press here today, that "there is no more effective party in France" than his.

CINCINNATI, June 1 (AP) Dave Bristol, manager of the Atlanta Braves, disclosed tonight he had received a fiveday suspension and a $500 fine from League, as a result of an alleged bumpLeague as a result of an alleged bumping incident involving an umpire. Bristol said he was appealing the ruling, thus allowing him to continue managing until the appeal is settled.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 "One small drip of water wastes 25 gallons a day, or 9,000 gallons a year," cautioned an airport sign.
Chester J. Woolworth, founder and chairman of the Woodstream Corporation, manufacturer of sports equipment and hardware, in Lititz, Pa., died in his home in Lancaster, Pa., Friday. His age was 84.

Amrita Ghosh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shankar Ghosh of Calcutta, India, was married yesterday to Richard M. Douglas, son of Mr. and Mrs. G.A. Douglas of Stockholm and New York. The civil ceremony was performed in the office of the Consulate General of India at the New India House by Queens Deputy City Clerk Robert E. Whalen.

With all outstanding issues resolved, the City Council last night adopted Mayor Beame's $13.9 billion expense budget for next year with only minor modifications and headed for approval of the $1.4 billion capital budget.

Inflation is here to stay, Nothing Jimmy Carter or Arthur Burns or anyone else does is likely to lower the inflation rate below 6 percent in the next few years. Because of the way the American economy is structured, even the harshest anti-inflationary measures would have small effect on the cost of living in the foreseeable future. The practical response is to learn to live with it.

WASHINGTON, June 1 One of the country's smallest minority groups got a hearing at the Vice-Presidential mansion today, as Joan Mondale presided over the first is a series of working luncheons that she is having to consider the problems of artists.
DEVON, Pa., June 1 When Amy Brumder checked the amateur-owner jumper standing before the final class at the Devon horse show today, she could have wept.

TOKYO, June 1 From the monochrome mass of Japanese politicians, Yohei Kono, 39 years old, has emerged as a new star in less than a year. In the campaign for the election to the upper house of Parliament, which will probably be held July 3, he and his party, the New Liberal Club, are the most closely watched opposition group.

Mary Lea Johnson D'Arc, heiress to the Johnson Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, was the target of a murder plot allegedly planned by her husband, Dr. Victor D'Arc, a psychiatrist, a Bronx jury was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The White House spokesman, Jody Powell, said today that if the Soviet Union was willing to undertake "serious negotiations" on limitation of strategic nuclear weapons, the United States "can make changes" in plans to deploy a more accurate intercontinental missile warhead capable of destroying more Soviet missiles in their launching silos.

SCARSDALE N.Y., June 1 When Jack Nicklaus was playing in the United States Open at Winged Foot in 1974, he was asked by a proud member of that outstanding golf club, "Isn't Winged Foot West as good a course as you've played, Jack?"

Prince Saud al-Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister and a likely heir to the Saudi throne, has been identified as the Arab prince who has been trying to buy a luxury Park Avenue apartment. Real-estate informants said yesterday that he suffered a setback Tuesday.

Here are some basic steps to be taken when converting a commercial building in Manhattan into a residential co-op: Inspect the building and its records thoroughly. Look for violations or major faults, proper zoning, proper assessment and a free and clear title.
Governor Byrne said yesterday that if he were defeated in New Jersey's Democratic primary for Governor as Tuesday, it would be because of voter rejection of the state income tax.

James L. Ketelsen has been elected president of Tenneco Inc., a multi-industry company based in Houston. He succeeds Wilton E. Scott, who has been chairman, president and chief executive officer since October 1975. Mr. Scott, who is 64, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

THIS IS A championship season for table tennis tables and it's about time. Al- though 600,000 tables were sold in this country last year, there hasn't been much progress in table tennis table design since 1902 when "Ping-Pong," the first instruction book on the game, was published. But three tables now on the market indicate pat the Ping-Pong ball is bouncing in new directions.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Landmark job discrimination cases such as those in steel and communications might have to be reconsidered under yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding seniority systems, legal sources said today.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) The Lonrho Trading Company, once exclusive supplier of oil to Rhodesia, said last night that it had filed suit in London against American, British and other oil companies for allegedly suppling fuel to the white Rhodesian Government in defiance of United Nations sanctions.

The Xerox Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company each introduced computer readout systems using lasers in New York City yesterday, marking a further penetration by lasers into the word-processing business.
DAMASCUS, Syria The Soviet Union has resumed the delivery of arms to Syria, but these have not included any of the new aircraft, missiles or tanks now being deployed by the Soviet forces.
EPSOM, England, June 1 The Minstrel won the English Derby today by a neck over Hot Grove in a stretch drive hat was a double triumph for Lester Piggott, his jockey.
MONTREAL, June 1 Joe Torre, in the midst of his instant transformation from player to manager, issued simple instructions to the Mets tonight in his first meeting with the players.

A five months' supply of copper and copper scrap overhanging the market has led domestic producers to cut prices of the metal and has helped bring about the lowest prices of the year for copper shares.

Steven Goldberg is an assistant professor in the department of sociology at City College and a man who is interested in logic. And he objects to the Trans World Airlines slogan, "Being the best isn't everything. It's the only thing," not because it's not grammatical but because it's not logical.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 A shortage of operating funds forced the postponement today of scores of trials in Alabama courts, which had been cited in recent years as national examples of reform and efficiency. The salaries of many court officials also were cut off.

It took nearly seven months and more journeys through the Manhattan telephone book than the detectives would care to remember. Not to mention the grand jury lists or the treks to Brooklyn and the Bronx and Queens. Or the many times they returned to the scene of the crime and stared at the empty apartment and wondered what they were not seeing.
DETROIT, June 1 The domestic auto industry winding up the 1977 model year, is scheduling production of a record 949,000 cars in June, up 8.6 percent from May's total.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 29 Dressed in festive regalia, Abe Conklin and Charles Tillman, Osage Otoe Indians from Oklahoma City, were up and prancing on nearly every dance.

A Queens County grand jury briefly held up action against Judge Robert T. Groh of Civil Court last November on charges of bribery and grand-larceny as some of the jurors were apparently more interested in the possible involvement of the judge's former superior, Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, in the alleged bribery incident.

Although Alfred Hart's violin recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night listed familiar names, the first part of the program was not hackneyed. Bach's Sonata for violin and keyboard No. 5 in F minor, Schubert's Sonatina No. 1 in D (Op. 137) and Schumann's Sonata No. 2 in D minor (Op. 121) are not encountered as often as many other works in the repertory.
WASHINGTON, June 1(AP) Ethiopia, cutting one more tie to the United States, is calling home its last 81 mili- tary men training here.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 1 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown told 851 graduating Air Force Academy cadets today that the Carter Administration hoped to "avoid altogether" increases in military spending beyond those forced by inflation.

PARIS, June 1 The French Foreign Office spokesman today denied that France was withholding delivery of critical components of a nuclear reprocessing plant to Pakistan, as was reported in this morning's New York Times.

The Commonwealth, Oil Refining Company filed suit yesterday in the Superior Court of Puerto Rico at San Juan seeking $400 million in damages from PPG Industries and another company for allegedly blocking a trade agreement.

TOLLER CRANSTON has been called "a Nureyev on ice," a Renaissance man, the pioneer of artistic skating, a maverick and a raging egomaniac. But now, sitting in his luxurious apartment across from Carnegie Hall, he could only he called depressed.

FORT THOMAS, Ky., June 1 Andrew L. Scholl's father recently characterized his son jokingly as a typical teen-ager who was too lazy to pick up his shoes or clean up his room. Much has happened in recent days to change that description of the 17-year-old high school student and many other young people in this area.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 1 (AP) Pat Bradley is serving notice to everyone else entered in the S1OO,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament that starts tomorrow at the Wykagyl Country Club that she intends to retain her title. The event has been increased to 72 holes and has a first prize of $15,000.

Major central banks around the world bought and sold approximately $20 billion to stablize the value of their currencies in the latest quarter, about unchanged from the previous quarter, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

I WAS looking for something anything that would product a soft light," Ingo Maurer recalled during a visit to New York last week. That search took the West German lighting designer to Paris, where he found what he was looking for bamboo and lacquered rice-paper fans. Then the quest took him to Tokyo, where he sought and found craftsmen capable of executing the designs he had in mind.
American science continues to be "strong, competitive and dynamic," but is showing some disturbing signs of decay, according to a study for the National Foundation.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 1 After leading from the second inning against the Minnesota Twins tonight, the Yankees found themselves in an unenviable spot in the ninth inning the tying run at third base, the winning run at second base and Rod Carew at bat.
LONDON, June 1(AP) The dollar had a mixed day in erratic light trading in European money markets today. The price of gold moved up a dollar an ounce in Zurich and more in London.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Atlantic Richfield Company has told the Interstate Commerce Commission that the carrying of oil through the Alaska pipeline will cost $6.04 a barrel much higher than the $5.50 Federal officials had expected.

WASHINGTON One year after Senator Frank Church's committee documented widespread abuses and lawbreaking by the nation's intelligence agencies, its successor, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, has announced that the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence agencies are "under the control of the President" and "fully . . . accountable" to Congress. If so, reform has been remarkably swift.

BEIRUT, June 1 The Palestine Libenation Organization has created a new army with the double mission of fighting Israel and confronting Lebanese right-wing Christians who oppose the Palestinian presence here.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The White House spokesman, Jody Powell, said today that if the Soviet Union was willing to undertake "serious negotiations" on limitation of strategic nuclear weapons, the United States "can make changes" in plans to deploy a more accurate intercontinental missile warhead capable of destroying more Soviet missiles in their launching silos.
"There's no business like show business...."

WASHINGTON, June 1 "They think they're supposed to run the Government," Representative David R. Obey said the other day about the Carter Administration. "They would be perfectly happy if we never changed a dime."
HEN FLORENCE HECHT takes her show on the road, the fans follow. Along the highway, the signs beckon them on like marquee lights to the suburban lawns where Florence plants her billboard.

WASHINGTON To Howard D. Samuel, Deputy Under Secretary of Labor for International Affairs, those who talk about free trade these days are kidding themselves. And that includes, he said, certain other agencies of the Carter Administration.

Until yesterday, most horseplayers had never heard of Spirit Level. Now they Know him as a promising newcomer, a fresh 3-year-old colt that can beat horses like Sanhedrin, Giboulee and Coined Silver while going a mile and an eighth with only 114 pounds on his back.

CABLE TELEVISION'S long standing promise of relief from the mass processing of traditional broadcasting formats creeps forward almost imperceptibly but not insignificantly. True, after nearly a decade of publicity-hustling, Manhattan remains the only one of the city's boroughs covered by an official franchise, shared by Manhattan Cable and Teleprompter. But cable sales are booming in the more affluent suburbs, and the always desperate search for programming is becoming more intense.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Carter Administration's plan to revise the nation's welfare system is designed to save billions of dollars by tightening the eligibility requirements for public relief, according to Administration officials familiar with the proposal.
It's the year of the firsts for Pentel of America, a subsidiary of the Japanese, family-operated writing-instrument manufacturer.

KATE SAYS TO Harvey: "You are incredibly full of anger, Harvey; when are you going to come to terms with that?" Harvey replies to Kate: "I'm not full of anger. I'm full of granola. I'm trying to come to terms with granola."

More than a third of the 29,000 New York City children in foster care have been kept there years longer than necessary, the City Comptroller's office said yesterday, often harming the children and adding an unnecessary $233 million to the city budget.

The start of Concorde test flights to Kennedy International Airport has been delayed at least two weeks more. This resulted when a panel of Federal appeals judges yesterday sharply questioned the clarity of the Federal stand on the legality of New York City's ban on the supersonic plane.

Wicker is here in superabundance, rivaling the best in other furniture materials. Add light floors, growing plants, summer slipcovers, an uncluttered room, and you'll have the recipe for the most popular look around. On the other hand, wicker is equally compatible with patchwork and chintz, rush rockers and old floors, and crowded hominess.

THE MAIL that has come to me within the short span of this column's appearance in the Home Section has been most gratifying, and I regret all the more that time and the scarcity of secretarial help do not permit me to correspond privately with my readers. But questions raised by some may interest others, and I will occasionally devote a column to matters brought up in the mail.
The decisions about how New York City will spend its money next year were made at a meeting at Gracie Mansion that began the night before last and did not break up until dawn yesterday.
THE fashion news about underwear has long been negative, focusing on the bras women didn't wear anymore and the T-shirts or old sweaters they slept in instead of nightgowns.

Every month, it seems, someone must announce for Mayor, and Bella S. Abzug, who came in with June yesterday, occupied the self-confident thoughts of Edward I. Koch, March's entry, as he finished his morning grapefruit and coffee and glanced out at a mild cloudburst keeping the city gray and wet.

With speeches and champagne, with show-business and political personalities, with the strains of music and straining moving men, the controversial Manhattan Plaza apartment complex near Times Square finally welcomed its first residents yesterday.
"You don't win pennants in April and May," was the comment of Cincinnati's Joe Morgan during a three-game series with the Dodgers in Los Angeles last week.
In changing managers, the New York Mets produced one giant leap for Joe Torre, but only one small step for the organization.

Three veterans of "Godspell" and a recent "New Face" are making a collection of songs called "Words," now at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street sound considerably better than the songs really are.

TOSSING back a toast five years ago, to his friend the late Igor Stravinsky, George Balanchine noted that "in Russia we drink to the health of the guy that died." On that particular occasion they also danced a weeklong memorial in the form of the Stravinsky Festival.

With show-business celebrities at the press tables and a Dixieland combo next to the dais playing "I like New York in June," Bella S. Abzug yesterday threw her hat a big-brimmed black straw into the race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City.

THE American way of designing using fashion designers to style home furnishings products is now catching on with the French. Taco division of Texunion, the largest printers of dress and home furnishings fabrics in France (it prints 300,000 yards a day) is about to introduce its first collection by Karl Lagerfeld, the man who designs the highpriced Chloe fashions.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) New factory orders and shipments of manufactured products declined slightly in April, the Commerce Department said today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency, which tried to keep secret for years the site of its headquarters, in suburban Langley, Va., is planning to open its doors to tourists.
NAKFA, Ethiopia After 15 years of armed struggle, rebels seeking independence for the northernmost Ethiopian province of Eritrea say that their goal is in sight.

By sending his troops 50 miles into neighboring Mozambique, Prime Minister Smith of Rhodesia has added a new tactic to a now familiar strategy. The tactic seeks to inflame an already tense situation and to bid for military advantage. The strategy is to concede nothing to the blacks who seek political power in Rhodesia in the hope that the Western nations will in the end help to preserve the regime of the minority whites.
IT WAS BAD enough when the design for the new kitchen that had looked so good on paper proved to be so out of plumb with reality that the cabinets and sink had to be moved at an extra cost of $180.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 1 Fresh from visits to two democracies, Rosalynn Carter was given a military welcome today when she arrived in Ecuador, the first country on her diplomatic tour to be ruled by the armed forces.

EXTRAORDINARY is the paprika of adjectives. Galvanic in the right hands, it can take away all appetite in the wrong ones. So the Museum of Modern Art took a small gamble when it chose the title "Extraordinary Men" for the exhibition of recently acquired portrait drawings that will be on view there through July 17. (Its successor and sequel, "Extraordinary Women," will open in late July.)
FITZROY CROSSING, Australia The federal Government has spent more on aid to the Australian aborigines in the last five years than in the previous 50 years.
PARIS, June 2 The United States and Vietnam today opened the second round of talks here on normalizing relations. The atmosphere was gloomier than in the first round here May 3 and 4.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June. 2 (AP) The Rhodesian military command announced today that Rhodesian troops who invaded Mozambique last weekend were on their way home after having killed at least 32 black guerrillas and destroyed four rebel camps.
The Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it was maintaining its AA rating on Quebec bonds following an extensive review of both the economy and the move for independence in the province.

OTTAWA, June 2 Representatives of 20 countries and more than a score of international development organizations announced a five-year, $3 billion program today to build up the economies of seven sub-Saharan countries that have periodically been ravaged by severe drought.

The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's money supply showed no change in the week ended May 25 as it continued to decelerate from the unusually rapid growth rate it showed in April. At the same time, the Fed reported

PARIS, Friday, June 3 The 27-nation north-south talks ended early today with major oil-producing countries and other developing lands refusing to agree to the demands of the United States and the rest of the industrial world for continuing consultations on energy questions.

A singular ensemble consisting of Robert Johnson will perform at 8 P.M. tonight and tomorrow in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art as the institution, carrying on a recent summer tradition, opens the garden to the public, free of charge, on weekend evenings.

Stephen Boyd, an Irish-born actor who was in dozens of Hollywood films but never quite reached star status, died in Los Angeles yesterday, apparently of a heart attack suffered while playing golf. He was 48 years old.
Quicker than that old punchline, "Ready when you are C.B.," Seattle Slew disappeared again into the early morning fog at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The House, considering a bill to establish a Department of Energy, defeated a major proposal of the Carter Administration by refusing today to give the head of the new department the authority to set natural gas prices.
I CAN NEVER, if I am driving anywhere near northwest Connecticut in spring, summer of fall, resist swinging by the Housatonic River to wet a line.

IF WE TAKE special delight in finding truly wonderful restaurants thriving in the city, it is because we firmly believe that serious eaters will go almost anywhere for a great meal, and that no so-called bad neighborhood can kill a really good restaurant. There could be no more perfect case in point than Gargiulo's in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, a popular meeting place for local politicians.
MEMPHIS, June 2 (UPI) A board member of the financially troubled Cook Industries says two top executives who resigned under fire last week had exceeded the company's grain trading limits.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., June 2 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall committed the Carter Administration today to a campaign for a global minimum wage.

To avoid accumulation in the air of sufficient carbon dioxide to cause major climate changes, it may ultimately be necessary to restrict the burning of coal and other fossil fuels, according to Dr. William D. Nordhaus of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

Governor Carey said yesterday that rents in rent-controlled or stabilized apartments should be related to the tenants' ability to pay "so that those who need rent control will have it, and those who don't need it and can afford higher rents will pay them."

Although New York City's new Charter envisioned a reduced role for the Mayor in the budget-making process and new power for the City Council and the Board of Estimate, it was clear when the budgets were finally adopted early yesterday ...
MINEOLA, L.I., June 2 State Senator John R. Dunne said today that he had been forced to contribute 1 percent of his salary to the Nassau County Republican Party to advance his political career.

DETROIT, June 2 The American Motors Corporation said today that it would lay off 3,000 workers at its Wisconsin plants for a week beginning Monday. A.M.C. has been cutting production in recent months because of a long sales slump. A spokesman said the company would suspend production of Matador and Pacer models for the coming week, affecting 1,900 at the Kenosha assembly plant and 1,100 at the Milwaukee body plant.

The second New York Loft Jazz Celebration 30 jazz concerts in a three-day, round-the-clock marathon that begins tonight at 8 P.M. shouldn't be called a Loft Jazz Celebration at all, according to John Fischer, the pianistcomposer who runs Environ, one of the four downtown performing spaces participating in the event. It should be called a Jazz Loft Festival.

Between dealings with the usual avalanche of city business, Mayor Beame took a few moments recently to tend to an item on his calendar marked "Jewish Museum." He issued a proclamation naming Sunday as Jewish Museum Day.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 Garfield Todd, the white Rhodesian politician who is a leading advocate of black majority rule, sat in the office of Andrew Young, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, the other day relating recents incidents of torture and murder he said had been committed by the "terrorist" regime of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

Mary Carlyle Lind, an interior designer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Kenneth Lind of Llewellyn Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Jarvis James Slade, managing partner of the Hampton Capital Company, a private merchant banking firm.

Jimmy Carter is turning out to be the most conservative Democratic President since Grover Cleveland. Behind all the headlines about a foreign policy based on human rights, Andrew Young's gadfly attacks on entrenched racism and James Schlesinger's comprehensive energy program, the stark fact is that the Carter economic policies have turned out to be not much different from Gerald Ford's.

The Philadelphia 76ers went through another of their secret two-hour practices yesterday, while the Portland Trail Blazers held an open two-hour work-out, in preparation for tonight's fifth game of the N.B.A. championship series. Tonight's game is at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday that more companies raised their dividends last month than in any previous May since it began keeping records of monthly dividends in 1955. The 262 companies that increased dividends compared with 212 a year earlier and the previous May high of 242 in 1974.
ROME, June 2 Pope Paul VI today elevated his principal aide to cardinal, thus placing him among the candidates for the papacy.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Sucrest Corporation, its former chairman and two officers and a New York sugar broker yesterday with violating antifraud and reporting provisions of Federal securities laws.

ALBANY, June 2 Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, said today that Governor Carey's proposed $750 million economic-development bond issue needed substantial revision before the Senate would consider passing it.

DETROIT, June 2 The General Motors Corporation said today only 6,095 owners of 1977 model Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars accepted its offer to exchange their present cars because they have engines built by the Chevrolet division.

ROME, June 2 (AP) Vincenzo Cazzaniga, The former president of the Exxon Corporation's Italian subsidiary, arrested 12 days ago on fraud charges, was released on $113,000 bail today, court officials said.

ATOUCH of emotional darkness creeps into almost everything that Manuel Alum chore ographs, whether it is an obsessional study or a comic piece such as his recent "El Tango." "El Tango" evoked a sinister quality, although it presented a humorous ballroom trio dancing the tango.
ZURICH, June 2 The scandal-rocked Swiss-banking industry today announced an agreement designed to prevent the use of the famed bank secrecy regulations as a cover for funds of dubious origin.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 2 Future Fame and Mistletoe Shalee won the $30,250 divisions of the Tarport Hap Pace for 3-year-old fillies at the Meadowlands tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Menahem Begin has sent a representative to the United States in an effort to ease apprehension among Americans about the likely emergence of his right-wing Likud bloc as the head of the next Israeli government.

There aren't many ways to mix culture and the summer sun. But visitors to the Silvermine Guild of Artists in Connecticut will be able to wander this weekend through six acres of green hills and lawns set in the midst of a tiny pre-Revolutionary town near New Canaan. They'll picnic under the trees by a small stream, observe the ducks gliding across the nearby pond and peer at an extraordinarily eclectic sampling of contemporary art.

A 70-minute history of broadcasting, produced by TVTV is being shown several times each day through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Two investigations are under way to see if those with advance knowledge of the takeover of the New York Magazine Company by the Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch traded illegally in the company's stock. New evidence that water in the lower reaches of the Mississippi River may contain cancer-causing compounds that could threaten public health has been discovered by a team of scientists from the Louisiana State University Medical Ceter in New Orleans.

ZURICH, June 2 Spokesmen for Switzerland's three biggest banks maintain that the agreement announced today by the banking industry and the central bank only codifies what these banks do already.

SAN FRANCISCO MARK TWAIN, who used to work the San Francisco beat for the Overland Monthly, called the city by the Golden Gate "heaven on the half shell." And so it was envisioned by the bookselling and publishing twain who flocked to San Francisco in record numbers this week from all over the country and from foreign lands for the American Booksellers Association annual house party.
ROME, June 2 Pope Paul VI today elevated his principal aide to cardinal, thus placing him among the candidates for the papacy.

SOLEDAD, Calif., June 2 (AP) Sirhan Sirhan told two Los Angeles County supervisors today that he still had a mental blackout about his killing of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and repeated, "I can't remember, I can't remember." He also suggested, his lawyer said, that he be taken back to the scene of the killing, perhaps with a psychiatrist, to help him recall the slaying.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Carter Administration intends to appoint Dr. Julius B. Richmond of Harvard Medical School as both Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, according to sources here.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Carter Administration said today that it was "deeply concerned" over reports from Moscow that Soviet authorities planned to put a Jewish dissident and humanrights activist on trial for treason a charge punishable by a prison term of at least 10 years or execution.

DEVON, Pa., June 2 Quiet Touch, who is so high-tensioned, nervous and easily rattled that she is ridden in competition but never in training, won the green working hunter championship tonight at the Devon Horse Show.

NATHAN'S FAMOUS will be there, as you might expect, with hot dogs and Pepsi-Cola, but so will Stuart Levin, bringing with him from the Top of the Park a pheasant, veal and pistachio pate. Hamburgers? Sure, from Dalys Dandelion, but Warner LeRoy is sending over roasted chicken tarragon from Maxwell's Plum. Chili dogs? Tacos? Of course, and from Anita's Chili Parlor, but Vincent Sardi will be along with his cannelloni au gratin too.

There is a side to Clammy Dale that might not be suspected by those who know her from her performances with the New York City Opera and in "Porgy and Bess." On Wednesday evening at the Manhattan Theater, 321 East 73d Street, she showed that she can also sing popular songs with results that are so stunning that those who do this on a full-time basis might pick up a few pointers from her.
ANCHORAGE, June 2 (AP) The State of Alaska has hired lawyers in Washington to challenge tariff rates filed by owners of the trans-Alaska pipeline with the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 2 Laetrile the controversial cancer drug, became legal in Indiana yesterday. But if the United States Food and Drug Administration has its way, the drug will never be truly "legal" in Indiana or anywhere else.

After reaching new highs for four straight weeks, crude oil stocks dropped to 308.5 million barrels in the latest reporting week, as compared with 313.8 million barrels in the previous week, and 282.9 million barrels in the year-earlier level, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 2 Perhaps as many as a thousand or more migrating sharks converged off this Gulf Coast resort today for the second day, driving bathers from the 85-degree waters and creating a scene that many said reminded them of the motion picture "Jaws."
Betty Ford, suffering from arthritis, is too weak to travel and has been told by her physician to cancel her schedule for the next few months, an aide said yesterddy in Palm Springs, Calif.

The main rivals for the Republican nomination for Governor in New Jersey State Senator Raymond H. Bateman and Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean said yesterday that new leadership ws needed to revitalize New Jersey, and each said he was the man to provide that leadership.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland agreed today to steps that could increase the ability of farmer cooperatives to enter the lucrative trade in export grain now dominated by private corporations.

Don King, the boxing promoter, announced here yesterday that he had signed Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight champion, to defend his title in early July against Alfio Righetti of Italy. No other details were available.
Kurt Lowenstein, a retired metals industry executive, died at his Santa Barbara, Calif., home Wednesday. He was 78 years old.

DUBLIN, June 2 (AP) Charles Blair set an amphibian plane carrying his actress wife Maureen O'Hara and other passengers down on Lake Derg on the River Shannon 95 miles southwest of here tonight after a flight from New York.

NEW BRUNSWICK, June 2 Dawn's thick haze over the campus of Rutgers University burned away by midmorning. And at 10:30 sharp, the university's 152year-old bell began tolling in Queen's Tower, summoning graduates for the processional for the state university's 211th commencement.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 Calling it a "historic moment," Governor Byrne sat at a Boardwalk table draped in blue bunting today and, to the applause of a crowd estimated by the police at 5,000, signed legislation to permit casino gambling in Atlantic City.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2 The varsity crews from Cornell and Penn qualified today for Saturday's finals of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta on Lake Onondaga that is the sport's national championship. These two crews won their qualifying heats in competition that began at 6:30 A.M. in an effort to beat the weather.

CHICAGO, June 2 In the hope that additional training in reading will persuade more students to stay in high school once they get there, more than half the eighth graders in Chicago Public School District Nine will not be passed on to the ninth grade this fall.

MEXICO CITY The Mediterranean fruit fly, which causes millions of dollars worth of damage to crops in Central and South America, has now spread into southern Mexico, raising fears that the pest may eventually reach the United States.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., June 2 Mark Belger and Steve Scott took the first steps toward their long-sought revenge today. The outstanding middle-distance runners comfortably won their trial heats in the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships, and in doing so, put themselves in positions to reverse recent misfortunes.

The 12-Meter yacht Intrepid, two-time defender of the America's Cup, will not participate in the trials for the 23d defense tihs summer in Newport and is up for sale. The decision was announced yesterday by Rear Adm. Sheldon H. Kinney, president of the New York Maritime College at Fort Schuyler. The college's fund-raising arm, Fort Schuyler Foundation Inc., owns Intrepid and the new 12-Meter Enterprise, both designed by Olin Stephens.

Miki Gorman, who is 42 years old, stands 4 feet 11 inches tall and weighs in at 89 pounds, will very likely not be put off her pace in the women's minimarathon tomorrow when she races in Central Park, where the event will be competing with a lavish food spectacle.
CLEVELAND, June 2 (AP) Dr. Renee Richards, the transsexual ten nis player from New York, today signed a two-year contract to play World Team Tennis with the Cleveland-Pittsburgh Nets.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 2 (AP) George Archer, on the verge of quitting the tour until he won the Sahara Invitational last fall, birdied his last three holes for a six-under-par 66 that staked him to a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the $250,000 Kemper open golf tournament.

MONTREAL, June 2 With Joe Torre manipulating the strings more adroitly than Bil Baird with his puppets, the Mets continued making impressive and aggressive changes in their play tonight as they defeated the Montreal Expos, 7-4.

THE RAVISHING exhibition of robes and masks from the No theater of Japan that opened at Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, this week, was seven years in the planning and it shows. DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, June 1 The protesters marched through the black stone walls built by Roman armies 1,600 years ago and down the main street of this provincial capital in eastern Turkey. The engagement of Wendy Ann White to Alexander Patrick Haig has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. White of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Gen. Alexander Meigs Haig Jr., U.S.A., Commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, and Mrs. Haig of Mons, Belgium.

EAST HAMPTON RACHEL is the rabbi's wife. She and Rabbi Sunshine live on the Island's North Shore, where Rachel attends to the duties that are those of most rebbetzin. She mothers her children, marches for peace, writes and keeps track of baseball scores. Rachel Sunshine also knows the emotions that go with having a husband who has been discharged by one of his congregations.

LE BOURGET, France, June 4--Charles A. Lindbergh was honored today on the spot where the late flier concluded his historic flight 50 years ago. But a plane crash yesterday and the continuing controversy over the supersonic Concorde sought equal time on a day dedicated to the world's most famous pilot.

NEW JERSEY has officially recognized alcoholism as a disease for more than a year now, Governor Byrne having signed the Alcoholism Rehabilitation and Treatment Act early in 1976. Now, the state's law-enforcement system is being asked to match its actions to the new policy.

"Annie," Broadway's darling and everybody's favorite waif, was named best musical of 1977 and swept six other Tony awards last night as the New York theater establishment gathered at the Shubert Theater to honor what everyone says has bees the best season in years.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 5 (AP) Tom Weiskopf, making his move on the par-five holes, broke out of a threeway tie today with a two-under-par 70 and captured the Kemper open golf tourney by two strokes. It was his first PGA Tour victory in two years.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5 The other night there were rumors of fighting in the streets of the Christian eastern part of Beirut and of a bomb explosion in the Moslem western sector. They were only rumors, but many people believed that something happened that night because press censorship bars reports on such incidents as matters of security.

Once upon a time, monarchs were totemic figures, embodying symbolic and religious authority. Later, they became chief warriors and political rulers. They represent not transient majority opinion on political and economic issues as do elected political leaders but rather the continuity of the nation and of the whole people.

CHICAGO, June 6 "We take fun seriously" is a slogan being used by Atari Inc., a leading manufacturer of television games, at the 12th annual summer Consumer Electronics Show here.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) In a fourminute ceremony, with Watergate never mentioned, H.R. Haldeman and John N. Mitchell were ordered today to begin serving their prison terms by noon on June 22 for their role in conspiring to cover up the historic burglary.

A dramatic testimonial to the impact of advertising and special product displays on supermarket sales is contained is a study released yesterday by the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute and E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company.

Gillette's Safety Razor division has shifted its Trac II shaving system from Benton Bowles, which introduced it in 1971, to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn. The product was backed by $6 million in advertising last year.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that commission rates on stocks, unfixed since May 1975, continued to decline during the fourth quarter of last year and now stand at an average 15.7 percent below the level that prevailed before the agency ordered free competition among brokers.

TRENTON, June 6 A special emergency program for monitoring the state's 127 miles of Atlantic Ocean beaches, with an early warning system for potential threats of fish kills or deposits of trash and sewage, goes into effect this week in a joint effort by the state and Federal Governments to safeguard swimmers and tourists from polluted water.

ALBANY, June 6 The Legislature tonight voted to ban topless entertainment i nbars, an action the State Liquor Authority refused to take on its own last year. The measure approved tonight would authorize the Liquor Authority to suspend or revoke the license of any establishment that allowed its female employees to appear topless or that features topless entertainment.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) Members of Congress, except those representing Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia, would be exempted from taxes by Washington-area governments under a bill approved today in the House.

WHITE PLAINS, June 6 Divers were searching channels into Lord Tivoli Bay on the grounds of the Barrytown Seminary of the Unification Church today for the body of a 17-year-old boy who apparently drowned in a boating accident over the weekend.

The Cunard Line passenger ship Queen Elizabeth 2, the world's largest active passenger liner, will spend 17 days at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation drydock at Bayonne's Military Ocean Terminal late this year.

Joan Coffin Leib was married yesterterday to H. Clifton Whiteman, president of the Bowery Savings Bank. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell. There was a reception at the River Club.

WASHINGTON, June 6 Saudi Arabia appears virtually certain to raise its oil prices between now and the end of the year in an effort to erase a pricing division within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

The search for a public accounting firm to conduct the enormous, pathbreaking initial audit of New York City's financial books and records has narrowed to two firms, and the selection may be made by the end of the week, according to John C. (Sandy) Burton, Deputy Mayor for Finance.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The Carter Administration will propose tomorrow a major change in Federal criminal justice policy, supporting abolition of parole for convicts, an aide to Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) Consumers continued installment borrowing at near record levels in April, raising their outstanding credit by $2.66 billion, the Federal Reserve said today.
The special police unit investigating the killer who calls himself Son of Sam was striving yesterday to find the source of four bizarre nicknames the killer used in a second letter.

Golfers are either the most charitable sportsmen or else they just don't know enough to come in out of the rain. There were 244 good and bad swingers who played in a pouring rain yesterday at Old Orchard Country Club ...

Coffee futures prices, which fell to a three-month low last week, rebounded yesterday with limit gains of 6 cents a pound on all except the spot July delivery. The spot contract rose 15 cents a pound.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 6 (UPI) Arnold Palmer seems to have passed the qualifying procedure for the United States Open golf tournament but he won't know for sure until tomorrow. The 47year-old Palmer, winner of 61 tour events, played two qualifying rounds today and had a 36-hole total of 142.
LONDON, June 6 (AP) The dollar ended nearly unchanged on Europe's currency markets today, and gold finished the day at $143.125 an ounce at Zurich, up from Friday's $141.875.
Michael Cristofer looked remarkably wide awake yesterday for a man who had been up all night celebrating, after his play, "The Shadow Box," won the Tony award Sunday night as best play of the year.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Andrew Young said today that, in describing Gerald R. Ford and Richard M. Nixon as racists, "I certainly didn't mean anything derogatory about the personal lives of either."

WASHINGTON, June 6 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States, at an East-West review conference later this year, would urge the Soviet Union and its allies to carry out all provisions of the Helsinki accords, including the controversial human rights clauses.

The Carter Administration urged a Federal appeals court yesterday to rule out the ban by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on test flights of the supersonic Concorde airliner, declaring that the agency's actions had been "unfair, dilatory, arbitrary and unreasonable."

Candidates for the Democratic and Republican gubernatorial nominations in New Jersey spent their final primary campaign moments yesterday looking for the few votes they believed could mean the difference today in what is likely to be the two close contests.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) The chairman of a House committee on United States servicemen missing in Southeast Asia said today that the remains of 22 Americans to be returned by Vietnam would not reach this country until August at the earliest.

Anita Bryant and her Save Our Children Inc. are doing the 20 million lesbians and gay men in America an enormous favor: They are focusing for the public the nature of the prejudice and discrimination we face.

On the theory that everybody is somebody, publishers of the world are churning out "Who's Whos" at an allinclusive rate.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) A Federal Grand Jury indicted three steel companies today on charges of fixing prices for reinforcing steel bars sold in western Missouri and Kansas from 1963 to 1972.

Judy Jarvis has a theatrical imagination, but very little choreographic facility. The program of her works at the Theater of Riverside Church on Sunday was static to the point of tedium. Tableaux succeeded tableaux, and while they had some initial interest pictorially, all tended to be boringly repetitive.

WASHINGTON, June 6 The Justice Department has expanded its investigation into the allegedly illegal Korean lobbying effort to determine whether it was deliberately covered up by senior United States Government officials, according to sources knowledgeable about the inquiry.
WASHINGTON, June 6 Andrew Young said today that, in describing Gerald R. Ford and Richard M. Nixon as racists, "I certainly didn't mean anything derogatory about the personal lives of either."

CHICAGO, June 6 Charles O. Finley revealed today that he was preparing a new lawsuit against the basebal lcommissioner, Bowie Kuhn. The owner of the Oakland A's refused to divulge the nature of the suit. He said also that he was appealing the verdict of an earlier suit in which Kuhn was upheld in blocking the sale of three Oakland players.

When the Baltimore Orioles arrived at Milwaukee's County Stadium last night for the opener of their two-game series with the Brewers they produced an invasion of their own to coincide with the 33d anniversary of D-Day, the World War II allied invasion of France.
MONTREAL, June 6 A debate opens tomorrow in the Quebec Assembly on how far to go to make French virtually the only language of this Canadian province.
ALBANY, June 6 Governor Carey today released a list of 776 projects he would like to see benefit from his proposed $750 million economic-development bond issue.

ALBANY, June 6 The Legislature gave final approval today to liberalized rules for the conduct of "Las Vegas Nights" at which religious and charitable organizations can raise money through games of chance.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service denied today that it had started an investigation into under-the-table income allegedly received by some of the nation's top amateur athletes.
After George Willig's walk up the side of the 1,350-foot South Tower of the World Trade Center last May 26, a television news reporter looked him in the eye and asked, "What's your angle, anyhow?"

NAIROBI, Kenya June 6 (Reuters) The Uganda radio, quoting "a reliable source," said tonight that President Idi Amin would leave by special plane tomorrow to attend the Commonwealth conference in London.
LONDON, June 7 (AP) The dollar gained ground across Europe today. Currency dealers attributed the gain to weakness in the Swiss franc.
RYE, N.Y., June 7 If any of their employees dared treat the captains of industry the way the Apawamis Club's golf course did today, they would all be out of work.

The remaining 59 panels, which were considered irreplaceable, were moved to a building on West 52d Street, where they were placed under lock and key and where yesterday it was discovered that they, too, had been stolen.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla. No American union is richer in tradition than the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, born of immigrants in the sweatshops of the Lower East Side at the turn of the century.

ARLINGTON, Tex., June 7 A flyball lost in a high Texas evening sky led to a 7-3 defeat for the Yankees tonight as they bowed to the Rangers at Arlington Stadium.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 7 A spokesman for the South Korean Government issued a severely worded statement today condemning Mr. Kim for blaming President Park for the scandal.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) In a change of plans, the United States and Panama have decided to resume Canal Zone treaty negotiations later this week in Washington, the State Department said today.
NEWARK, June 7 (UPI) Joel R. Jacobson, the president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, has forbidden his staff to make overnight trips to conventions.

To the delight of 1,000 lunch-hour onlookers, 12 spirited Tennessee walking horses were put through precision drills yesterday on the west mall of City Hall Park by members of the Police Department's mounted unit.

NAKFA, Ethiopia (AP) In the 11 weeks since insurgents captured this northern Eritrean town, they have turned it and the nearby area into a center for the instruction of thousands in new skills.
