Brendan T. Byrne will be the underdog in his re-election campaign for Governor against a strong Republican opponent.

OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany (AP) Test performances of a modernized version of this Alpine town's 300year-old Passion Play will take place on Aug. 13, 14, 15, 19, 20 and 21. The dress rehearsals are to help decide which script to use for the 1980 production of the play, which is staged every 10 years. Some rehearsals are to be open to the public, a town council spokesman said.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 7 It was virtually a state occasion here last night when the remarkable theater fes tival founded 25 years ago by the late Sir Tyrone Guthrie had its formal opening. There was a tent on the lawn for drinks, long black cars to deliver the guests of honor, and a company of bagpipers to blow them in.

ALBANY, June 7 A bill that would allow more elderly people to receive care at home, instead of in nursing homes, under Medicare and Medicaid was reported favorably from the Senate Health Committee today.
A wealthy Queens grandmother whose hired hit man, according to the police, got cold feet and turned informer was arrested yesterday on charges of plotting to kill her son-in-law.

ABADAN, Iran-When a newly built unit goes into operation later this month at this Persian Gulf oil center here, what is already the world's largest refinery in area will become the world's largest in output.

IT HAS BEEN 17 years since Nora Kaye, one of American Ballet Theater's first stars and once the country's great dramatic ballerina, threw 36 pairs of toe shoes out of a car while driving through the Black Forest in Germany.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 Five Internal Revenue Service employees who have been accused of accepting improper gratuities from the Gulf Oil Corporation while they audited Gulf's returns have been given dismissal notices.
PLAINS, Ga., June 7 (AP) The Rev. Bruce Edwards, former pastor of President Carter's hometown Baptist church, said today that he had accepted a post with a church in Hawaii.

Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps told a Congressional committee yesterday that President Carter is preparing to set up an interdepartmental task force to examine what the Federal Government can do to encourage women in business.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 A rights group, in a report to the United Nations, accused Guinea today of having tortured and murdered political prisoners and appealed to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim to intervene "to halt the reign of terror instigated by President S kou Tour ."

Rain clouds forced thousands of graduates and their relatives and guests indoors at yesterday's 53d commencement exercises at Queens College. Since there was no hall big enough to seat them all, thousands had to make do with closedcircuit television to follow the proceedings.

He calls her "my fianc e" and she calls him "my lover," but they do not plan to marry. Today, as they see it, there are only two real reasons to marry: religion and children. Having neither, they chose to live in unconnubial bliss.

The phenomenon is relegated to the good old days, to some "golden age" when, supposedly, classy programming was given the added dimension of spontaneity. The element of distorting sentimentality in this nostalgia is thick enough to be cut with an antenna.

Outside Pastrano's dressing room, his wife pounded the door. "Willie! Let me in! Willie! It's me. Please let me in!" But the people around Willie Pastrano would not. And as I walked away, she was crying and clawing at the door.

Governor Byrne won nomination for a second term yesterday in the New Jersey primary election. His victory, by considerably less than a majority, was made possible by the record field of nine challengers, who splintered the Democratic vote.

Where was Andrew Young when Jimmy Carter failed to avoid Playboy interviewers? Defending Jimmy Carter for his campaign crack about "ethnic purity" in neighborhoods. We continue to believe in Mr. Young's underlying message, but his sloppy habits of speech should draw a penalty: just one coherent speech on race in international affairs, delivered standing in one place.

In an initiative that has upset two of the nation's most prominent public accounting firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed the confidential workpapers of Touche Ross Company, one of the two firms, and asked a Federal court to compel Touche Ross to produce the documents.

Ellen Karoline Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rose of Old Westbury, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club to Dr. Paul Lloyd Scharf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Scharf of Roslyn, L.I., and Hallandale, Fla. Cantor David Benedict of Lawrence, L.I., performed the ceremony.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 Straight from being cooled off in the torrid heat of Texas, the Yankees turned hot again tonight in the evening coolness of Wisconsin. Coming from 100-degree to 50degree weather here, the Yankees looked 50 degrees better, too, in beating the Milwaukee Brewers, 9-2, and regaining first place in the American League East.

TRENTON, June 8 Fresh from his victory over nine opponents in yesterday's Democratic primary, Governor Byrne today challenged his Republican rival, Senator Raymond H. Bateman to a debate on the issues as early as this Sunday.

The Federal program of legal help for the poor has come of age. After a long and turbulent fight in Congress the program was removed from Executive control in 1974 and established as a sheltered, independent corporation. Now, three years later, there is general agreement that the experiment has worked.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 8 Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, said today after meeting with Roy Boe, the owner of the New York Nets, that the basketball team would remain in the county.
WASHINGTON, June 8 Three times in the last seven years; Representative Thomas S. Foley voted to create a consumer protection agency. This year, he intends to vote no.
Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home. Cooper Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street

HACKENSACK, June 8 Little by little, Bergen County is moving toward transforming into reality a decades-old dream of changing a 7.5-mile stretch of the Hackensack River into a freshwater lake offering recreational, cultural and historical attractions for tens of thousands.

CAIRO, June 8 (UPI) An Arab League official warned today that President Carter's attempts to keep United States companies from complying with the Arab boycott of Israel would result in the blacklisting of those concerns, from business in the Arab world.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June Pele, Giorgio Chinaglia and Franz Beckenbauer scored the goals tonight to lead the Cosmos to a 3-0 triumph over the Strikers. The victory moved the Cosmos into first place in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League for the first time this season.

Korvettes Inc., which had a loss of $1.6 million in its most recent fiscal year, plans to spend $50 million to $55 million over the next five years to remodel and "upgrade" half of its 58 stores, many of them in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The White House acknowledged today that President Carter's 1975 income taxes were being audited and then admitted that it had made a misleading statement in asserting that the President had sought the audit in a voluntary effort to set a precedent in Government ethics.
The stock market continued to move ahead yesterday, broadening Tuesday's rally in stepped-up trading.

Federated Department Stores, a Cincinnati-based department store chain, announced yesterday the sale of its three Gold Key furniture warehouse stores to a group of purchasers that includes the present divisional management.

PEOPLE GIVE THEIR houses names and their cars names, but now there is an apartment whose environmental furniture has a name it's called "The Structure." "We don't know what else to call it," said Charles Boxenbaum, the architect who designed if for Bob Sauer, an advertising copy writer. "It's like a sculpture piece the parts are all clamped together."

WASHINGTON, June 8 The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that two of its employees had been placed on "administrative leave" pending the outcome of a Justice Department investigation involving I.C.C. trucking decisions.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The Justice Department asked a five-judge Federal appeals court today to overturn an "erroneous and ambiguous" lower court ruling that would force the Government to impose penalty duties on a wide range of consumer electronic products from Japan.

The election for Governor of New Jersey this fall will apparently be a public referendum on the relative merits of an income tax vs. a sales tax as the most palatable method of providing increased state aid and providing court-ordered refinancing of public education.
DARIEN, Conn., June 8 Dave Muraskin, a 30-year-old New York attorney, carted off a silver trophy today for winning hip second consecutive Westchester Golf Association amateur championship.
Prices of old-crop soybeans and products dropped their daily permissible limits yesterday, while the new-crop deliveries closed with steep losses.

JEANNETTE, Pa, June 8 (UPI) State Representative John Laudadio died of a heart attack yesterday in Westmoreland Hospital, Greensburg. His staff said he had suffered two previous attacks. He was 60 years old and a Democrat.
ALBANY, June 8 Governor Carey signed into law today a ban on pilot lights in gas appliances sold after June 1, 1980, an action intended to avoid wasteful use of energy.

WASHINGTON, June 8 An attempt by members of the New York delegation to have Congress ban the supersonic Concorde jet from Kennedy International Airport was defeated, 274 to 128, in the House late today.
Imported French beer? You've got to be kidding. The French are big in wine, what do they know from beer?
SIDNEY SHELDON'S "The Other Side of Midnight" is one of those best-selling novels that all too soon has become not a major motion picture, but a lengthy, expensive one.

VICTORIA, Seychelles, June 8 (Reuters) President France Albert Ren who was brought to power in a coup on these Indian Ocean islands Sunday, said today his Government would not be Marxist but would develop a form of socialism appropriate for the country.
WASHINGTON The income tax system can be simplified for everyone except the people who prefer their taxes complicated, according to Senator Russell B. Long.
WASHINGTON, June 8 Militant leaders of the gay rights "movement" cannot minimize the defeat they suffered at the polls in Miami this week.

"The Leaves Are Fading," which American Ballet Theater presented for the first time this season Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is one of Antony Tudor's few plotless ballets.
Four Japanese motorcycle makers denied charges that they were dumping their products in the United States market.

CHICAGO, June 8 Michael Anthony Bilandic was destined to become Mayor of the nation's second largest city. Like his predecessor, Richard J. Daley, Mr. Bilandic was born and reared in the Bridgeport section of the city, and still lives there.

Atomic scientists have devised a new method of carrying out carbon-14 dating of archeological and paleontological specimens that promises to more than double the time span from which ancient organic objects can be dated.

NORTHRIDGE, Calif., June 8 The car drives slowly past new subdivision homes in Northridge, Encino, Chatsworth, Grenada Hills, and other cities in the sprawling San Fernando Valley, and black faces look out from the car windows.

EVEN THOUGH millions of young people have managed to acquire it, Led Zeppelin remains an acquired taste. The British rock quartet, which opened a run of six long-since-sold-out shows at Madison Square Garden Tuesday, makes a monstrously loud, deliberately abrasive kind of music far removed not only from the sweet rustlings of classical music, jazz and Tin Pan Alley, but even from the tuneful, rhythmically enlivening rock songs of the 1960's.

THE DEAL is almost set for Terence Conran, the industrial designer who owns London's Habitat chain, to design a collection of furniture for Kroehler, the mass-market furniture company that raised its design level this year with a line by Angelo Donghia.

In what may be the largest corruption scandal ever to rattle the city's prison system, 21 current and former Department of Correction employees and seven alleged confederates were indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of taking bribes to smuggle narcotics, guns and ammunition, liquor and restaurant food into the Brooklyn House of Detention for use by inmates.
The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8 Syria's Foreign Minister said here today after seven hours of talks with Lebanese leaders that the eight-year-old agreement regulating the presence of Palestinian guer illas in Lebanon would be put into full effect soon.

The name of one of the companies providing mortgage financing for the projected Palace Hotel was given incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The correct name is the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

Frances Holm Saponaro, five feet tall and weighing 95 pounds, runs outside and pulls arriving patients from the back seats of automobiles or through the rear doors of ambulances and helps carry or push them into the emergency room of the Bellevue Hospital Center.

SAN DIEGO, June 8 The American Institute of Architects rejected by a narrow margin today proposals that would have restructured the architectural profession by permitting architects to engage in building contracting and advertising.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 8 It is still too early to foresee an end to the ordeal of 55 Dutch hostages taken by young South Moluccan radicals 17 days ago. But already, the Dutch and young people in South Moluccan communities in their midst are saying they see no way to avoid more violent actions in the future.

Suffolk County Executive John V.N. Klein accused the Long Island Lighting Company of wrongfully collecting deposits from new customers in 35 out of 50 cases reviewed by the county's Department of Consumer Affairs.
CHICAGO, June 8 A 1977 winter wheat crop almost as large as last year's bumper yield was forecast today by the Agriculture Department.
WASHINGTON, June 8 The State Department said today that the Administration had not yet made a decision on the sale of 250 F-18L fighter planes to Iran.

Medtronic, Inc., maker of implantable heart pacemakers and other electronic medical devices, reported yesterday a 63.3 percent rise in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and 11.5 percent for the fiscal year ended April 30.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The General Accounting Office sharply criticized the Carter Administration today for proposing an energy program that the Administration itself concedes is in conflict with its own national goals for energy use.

DUNE buggies, snowmobiles, trail bikes, campers, mobile homes and motor homes artifacts of the good life, all have proliferated with such bewildering speed over the nation's recreational landscape that there are times when even the insurance companies are confused.
LONDON, June 8 The conference of Commonwealth heads of government opened in London today, preoccupied with the big man who wasn't there President Idi Amin of Uganda.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 8 (AP) A former State Civil Service Commissioner was ordered yesterday to pay the Borough of Roselle $10,000, which he accepted as a bribe when he was a Roselle councilman.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 8 Governor Carey today stepped into the controversy over the Nestle Company's proposal to switch corporate sites in Westchester County. He asked the Harrison Town Board to refer the issue to its Planning and Zoning Board a procedure that would give the state time to help resolve the dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 8 A key Senate subcommittee, seeking to head off a water projects veto by President Carter, tentatively agreed today to kill eight of the 18 dams and irrigation schemes he wants eliminated, Senate sources said.

PARIS, June 8 The French Government announced today its intention of acquiring a controlling interest in Dassault, the big airplane manufacturing company, as part of its efforts to streamline the nation's aerospace industry.
PATNA, India, June 5 "A leader, a leader, we want a leader to address the election meetings!" the candidate on the phone shouted.

RYE, N.Y., June 8 The day he became 55 years old, Dale Morey was invited to join the 915-member United States Seniors' Golf Association. It also meant he could enter the group's championship tournament.
LONDON, June 8 (AP) The dollar slipped back a bit on Europe's currency markets today except in Amsterdam, where it rose to 2.4700 guilders from 2.4675 yesterday.

Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of New York State Supreme Court has appointed a partner in his son-in-law's law firm as receiver in two foreclosure actions involving the Chrysler Building, a position for which the lawyer has so far received $504,000 in legal fees.

MONTREAL, June 8 Having hoped to solve the question of accommodation with the World Hockey Association at these meetings, the National Hockey League's Board of Governors despaired today of untwining the web of complications and directed its fact-finding committee to continue its work.

BOSTON, June 8 (UPI) Massachusetts today became the ninth rate in the nation to ask Congress to convene a convention for the purpose of adding an amendment barring abortion to the United States Constitution.

BY COMMON CONSENT, the New York City Ballet is among the most musical dance companies the world has ever known. Now for a conundrum: 52 works, of one size or another, were originally announced for the company's current season at the New York State Theater. Of these, only four had their choreography set to specially commissioned scores all the others used existing music.

DETROIT, June 8 A Federal judge, citing insufficient evidence, today dismissed murder charges against one of two nurses charged with poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, but let stand a murder charge against the second nurse as well as some of the poisoning and conspiracy charges against both of them.

Principals of the Riese Brothers Organization, the largest privately held restaurant owners in New York, are expected this morning to be named to the board of the Horn Hardart Company and to receive an option to buy 200,000 shares of the concern's common stock for $5.50 a share. If exercised, the option to buy would make Irving and Murray Riese the largest shareholders in Horn Hardart.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 8 (AP) Gov. James B. Edwards signed today a bill to reinstate the death penalty in this state.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 (Reuters) Oil would be used as an instrument in economic bargaining between the third world and the developed nations, Venezuelan Minister of State Manuel Perez Guerrero said here today.
WASHINGTON, June 8, (Reuters) A Federal grand jury today charged the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company and eight other defendants with conspiring to fix beer prices in Hawaii.
WASHINGTON, June 8 President Carter sharply assailed today proposed legislation, backed by the automobile industry, that would significantly loosen air pollution controls.

The name of one of the companies providing mortgage financing for the projected Palace Hotel was given incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The correct name is the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

The Tandy Corporation, which has quietly compiled one of the strongest growth records in recent years among companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange, passed out disappointing news to shareholders this week.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The House ethics committee voted today to require every member of the House to disclose details of his association with South Korea in an effort to ascertain the scope of the allegedly illegal Korean attempt to influence Congress.

KATHARINE KUH swore she'd never do it. After all, she reminded herself then, "I've been anti-establishment all my life I couldn't, wouldn't work for a big bank." But now, nine years, 4,000 works of art, close to $1 million and countless hundreds of thousands of miles later, she says she has enjoyed her job with the First National Bank of Chicago more than anything she has ever done.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 8 President Suharto today banned all commodity futures trading, which is unregulated in Indonesia. He said the move would help farmers with small holdings.

Q. We have oil-fired, hot water heat and get our domestic hot water from a coil located inside the same boiler that provides our heat. When the house does not need heat we leave the oil burner switch off, turning it on only when we anticipate the need for hot water. Thus, our oil burner does not fire at all during the night, or during the day when no one is at home.
REUNIONS, The very word sends anxiety through the populace. To go or not to go? Will I know anybody? Will anybody know me?

HARTFORD, June 8 The Connecticut General Assembly adjourned tonight, four hours before its midnight deadline, with leaders on both sides of the aisle calling the session the most productive one in many years.

A tug of war for control of Avis Inc., the nation's second largest car rental company, appeared to be in the making yesterday. Two bidders Norton Simon Inc. and Fuqua Industries have already come forward and reports are circulating.

A former partner in S.J. Salmon and Company, a defunct stock brokerage firm, pleaded guilty in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday to charges in separate indictments that he conspired to manipulate over-the-counter stocks and tried to defraud the Securities Investors Protection Corporation.
Overcrowding in New York City prisons is being seriously aggravated by the inability of the state to accept hundreds of felons sentenced here, according to city corrections authorities.
ALBANY, June 8 Bernard M. Kilbourn, a 53-year-old practicing dentist from Utica, was chosen today as the next Republican state chairman.

IN SCORES of Hollywood movies of the 1930's, Sylvia Sidney always was a nice girl. Sometimes in trouble with the law, sometimes intent on revenge, underloved and underfed, overworked and oppressed, put-upon, pursued, and passed-over but always somehow nice. She was a nice girl off-screen, too, who arrived in Hollywood with a duenna and made five films in her first year there by sometimes camping out at the studio.

A former executive of the Hartz Mountain Corporation was found guilty by a Federal jury of commercial bribery and fraud yesterday in what was described as the first conviction in a drive against white collar crime.

This is the time of year when insulation contractors are usually able to take a little time off. The winter and the flurry of last-minute insulation jobs that goes with it is past, and their pace generally does not pick up again until the first nip in the autumn air sends worried homeowners to the yellow pages.

The number of hysterectomies performed in Saskatchewan hospitals dropped dramatically after a medical committee, which started monitoring the reasons the operation was done, found a large percentage to be "unjustified."

Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, seemed to provide a preview in New York this week of the Federal Government's strategy for increasing the enrollment of minorities in the nation's institutions of higher education.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Democratic Congressional leaders met with President Carter this morning and said afterward that they would be surprised if the President vetoed the Labor-Health, Education and Welfare appropriations bill, scheduled to come up on the floor of the House next Wednesday.

When Bess Myserson left her job as New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, several companies saw an opportunity for a public relations coup if they could hire her as consumer adviser, spokesman or consultant. One auto manufacturer offered her $350,000, she says, to spend six days shooting advertisements. She turned it down.

As the years slipped by and the pictures drawn in a child's mind faded away, Clifford C. Doze sometimes tried to remember what his mother had been like how she had looked, the color of her clothes and what she had said to him the day she went out to buy him an ice-cream cone and never came back.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 9 (UPI) Brian Gottfried won two matches within three hours today and led a group of six United States players into the quarterfinal round of the $100,000 John Player grass court tennis tournament.

The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been the Kellogg Company's agency internationally for more than 40 years, has just picked up a domestic assignment. Its Chicago office will handle Salada Foods Inc.-United States division, which has billings estimated at $1.5 million to $2 million.

ALBANY, June 9 The Assembly today approved a bill that delays any substantive revision of the state's public employee pension law by extending for two years the system of three coexisting retirement benefit plans.

There will be Bach around the clock on WBAI this Sunday as the listenersponsored FM radio station celebrates its second annual Bach Day with 20 hours and 30 minutes of programming devoted to the music of Johann Sebastian Bach:

WASHINGTON, June 9 The two top Republican Congressional leaders urged President Carter today to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate alleged South Korean bribery, gift-giving and other favors intended to influence United States policy toward Korea.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Henry A. Kissinger warned tonight that the growing political strength of Communist parties in Western Europe posed a grave threat to he nature of the Western world and he urged concerted efforts to prevent Communist election victories in Italy, France and Spain.

The nation's 7,500 largest companies spend more than $1.6 billion annually for what is called in-house education of their employees, according to a survey just released by the Conference Board. The independent research organization said the figures did not include some $220 million for tuition-refund programs and $180 million for other outside courses taken by employees.

ALBANY, June 9 A special panel set up by Governor Carey today recommended a number of procedural restrictions on abortions on teen-agers that it said would reconcile the right of a young woman to get a legal abortion with the "right of a parent to care for his child."

In a dance-filled season, the most talked-about event has been the revival of Martha Graham's 1931 "Primitive Mysteries," which will be on view tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M., and at 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Lunt-Fontanne theater.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he was not certain that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had stopped the allegedly illegal investigative tactics carried out in the 1960's and early 1970's.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) Commodity futures in the soybean complex again same under active selling pressure today in the Chicago Board of Trade.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, blocked recently in an attempt to spend money for new rail transportation, voted yesterday to shift a $240 million mass-transit commitment to bus projects.
Hearings on the future of the Federal Housing Administration are on the agenda in Washington this summer at a time when the F.H.A. is bearing a heavy load of operational problems.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Senate reached a compromise on the highly controversial automobile pollution issue tonight, voting to delay imposition of stricter controls on car fumes but not to weaken the standards permanently in a significant way.

In a heavy downpour, Mayor Beame held an outdoor news conference yesterday on the outskirts of Kennedy International Airport to prove his contention that the Federal Aviation Administration had been "lax for years" in failing to reduce noise levels of aircraft.
FARMINGVILLE, L.I. The roadside hot dog, that sustainer of travelers and truck drivers, is becoming harder to find in Suffolk County.

Cynthia Suzanne Jarvis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Jarvis of Babylon, L.I., was married yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral to John Strathern MacGregor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. MacGregor Jr. of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Michael Crimmins performed the ceremony.

The last person invited to a boy-girl party, as they are known in junior high school circles, is a parent. It's nothing personal, parents are told, but would they please plan to be out of the house on the night of the party? And would they please stock the refrigerator before leaving?

Sitting behind a desk cluttered with papers and hurriedly scribbled notes, Willis Reed thumbed through a book of blue, yellow and pink loose-leaf pages yesterday. "When you think of opera, you think of pageantry, and we want it to be a night which conjures up images of castles and balls and the opera."

The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to dissolve the interim operating committee, which managed its operations, and to name Joseph T. Lynaugh, its executive vice president, as the corporation's acting president.

Dr. Frederick S. Baldi, a physician who headed the Philadelphia County prison system from 1938 to 1953, died on Tuesday at a Philadelphia nursing home. He was 90 years old and had been in retirement since 1956 when he ended his career as warden of the Rockview State Penitentiary.
Unsettled weather in recent days has sometimes limited the success of East Coast salt-water fishermen.

ATLANTA, June 9 On the stage, The Second Chapter of Acts looks like any other rock group, blue-jeaned, shirts open, guitars slung down low in front of the microphones.

Ireland's political problems, never too far removed from New York City's, came up again Wednesday when City Council President Paul O'Dwyer walked out of an Israel Bonds dinner rather than appear with Governor Carey.

The Chancellor of New York City schools ordered a Queens school district yesterday to comply with a ruling that would send 100 white students to predominantly black high schools and 1,400 black or Hispanic students to either pre dominantly white high schools or to their neighborhood school, virtually all-black Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights.

ROME, June 9 United States officials are watching the rise of Communist influence in Western Europe with the utmost care, but under Jimmy Carter they are not following the Kissinger line of issuing public warnings about it.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The House Ways and Means Committee rejected today an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, evidently killing any such plan for the rest of this year, but approved in modified form a "gas-guzzler" tax on big cars, a key element of President Carter's national energy program.

The nation's money supply continues to grow more slowly, the Federal Reserve disclosed yesterday, and the slowdown caused the credit markets to advance strongly late yesterday afternoon after the data were published.

Many intellectuals and policymakers have advocated United States military retrenchment on the ground that some third-world regional powers can sustain local stability and safeguard American interests abroad without United States military involvement; they also, however, denounce arms transfers to non-Western countries as immoral and detrimental to their economic development.

Former President Gerald R. Ford, in a speech in New York City last night, called for an end to terrorism and attendant "lavish media attention," and also to bargaining with terrorists or giving them sanctuary.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled today that even if prosecutors have amassed enough evidence to prove a criminal case against someone, they are permitted to wait many months to charge him formally while they seek possible accomplices.

WASHINGTON In about three months, the Carter Administration has promised, it will put a major tax-reform package before the American public. The task it, faces in the meantime is mammoth, as are the problems that will confront the Congress, the business world, investors and other interested parties once the President finally makes his, proposals.

While day-long rain pelted the statue of Secretariat yesterday at Belmont Park, nine owners fearlessly named their horses to challenge undefeated Seattle Slew in tomorrow's 109th running of the Belmont Stakes.

TOKYO, June 9 (AP) The dollar fell by almost one Japanese yen today, bring ing its slide this week on the Tokyo currency exchange to a total of 2.6 yen.

The Seagram Company, the world's largest distillers, yesterday reported a 10.9 percent decline in net income for the third fiscal quarter ended April 30, but a 20.6 percent rise for the nine-month perod. Sales in both periods set records.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) When the President's Physical Fitness Awards were handed out tonight at the Francis Junior High School, Amy Carter was the first to get one.

SEATTLE, June 9 (AP) Alice Franklin Bryant, an outspoken antiwar activist, teacher, political candidate and author died at her home here Tuesday. She was in her late 70's and had been ill for more than a year.

Six patients at the Bronx Psychiatric Center died three of suicide and a seventh was beaten in circumstances of "institutional indifference and ineptitude," the State Commission of Investigation charge yesterday.

Newhouse theaters since 1973, would vacate the theater complex at the conclusion of a return engagement of Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard," which will begin June 28.

In its center reaches it is a roisterer, a street of cafes, drinking places and restaurants, and it comes alive with darkness.

HOBOKEN When Joan Mann of Manhattan wants to take a weekend spin in the country, she boards a train in the 14th Street Port Authority TransHudson tube station, rides to Hoboken, walks two blocks to the municipal parking garage and picks up her 1972 Hornet station wagon.

WASHINGTON, June 9 A House subcommittee examining the future impact of doubling the country's use of coal as a substitute for oil and gas heard gloomy reports today that cast doubts on President Carter's energy plan.

Ralph Lauren, who has brought a special panache to his women's sports clothes, became the newest member of fashion's Hall of Fame yesterday. He was selected for the top award of the Coty American Fashion Critics by a jury meeting at the St. Regis Hotel.

Six days from the trading deadline in baseball, the Mets left New York last night for seven games in Houston and Atlanta, still "hot," still in last place, still denying that any high-level deal for Tom Seaver was "imminent."

TRENTON, June 9 Assured that there would be no elephants the symbolic mascot of the Republican party in the State Opera's performance Saturday night of "Adida," Governor Byrne proclaimed today the start of "Festival '77" in the summer cultural season sponsored by the New Jersey Council of the Arts.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, suggested today that the White House is now prepared to accept a net revenue loss in the tax reform program it will propose to Congress this year.

MOSCOW, June 10 Any city planner in New York would be envious: no crazy-quilt pattern of privately owned land, no protesting citizens, no need for elaborate zoning incentives to induce profit-hungry developers to do what's right for efficiency and esthetics.

One for the Money A new study reveals that using one officer in patrol cars is just as effective and a great deal cheaper than using two. Sponsored by the Police Foundation, whose director is former New York City Police Commissioner Patrick Murphy, it shows that each one-man car saves San Diego more than $112,000 a year.
MEMPHIS, June 9 (AP) Tom Storey, a former song-and-dance man in a Las Vegas hotel, scored a surprising sevenunder-par 65 today and established a two-stroke lead in the $200,000 Memphis Golf Classic.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The Carter Administration has quietly begun a drive to improve the machinery for the collective defense of human rights in the Western Hemisphere.
WASHINGTON June 9 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today that indirect purchasers do not have the right to collect damages from businesses that illegally increase prices.

DETROIT, June 9 Filipina Narciso took the witness stand today in Federal District Court to declare her innocence of charges that she murdered and poisoned patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, where she worked as a nurse.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The State Department announced today that the Bulgarian Government had allowed the young daughters of a Bulgarian couple who came to this country 10 years ago to join their parents here yesterday.
MIAMI, June 9 (AP) An oilfield has been discovered in the middle of the Big Cypress Swamp, but the size of the find may not be determined before next year, Exxon USA has annnounced.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 9 (AP) William H. Bailey, who was denied his seat in the Rhode Island legislature and was sent to Michigan to serve a prison sentence for shoplifting, underwent more than five hours of surgery today for cancer of the rectum.

BEIRUT, LEBANON, June 9, (AP) A man identifying himself as spokesman for a group called "Justice Commandos for Armenian Genocide" claimed responsibility for the killing of the Turkish Ambassador to the Vatican. In a telephone call to The Associated Press office here, he said his group had carried out the attack "as revenge." He then hung up.

Horace Silver, who led the jazz world into hard bop more than 20 years ago, has sustained his distinctive qualities as a composer and pianist as well as the crackling drive of his quintet with remarkable consistency for the last two decades.

There's a show being given tomorrow evening that includes acrobatics, dance, grotesque makeup and elaborate costumes, and it will all be presented under the rubric of "opera." But this will be Chinese Opera, which is not at all like Western opera.

Thirty-one persons and three companies were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of stealing millions of undersized "seed" clams from the Great South Bay in Suffolk County, posing a threat to Long Island's $100 million-a-year hard clam industry.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that it is unconstitutional for states to insist that nonprescription contraceptives be sold only in drug stores or by doctors.

WHEN WE ARRIVED at Island Pond in Harriman State Park, our only companions were an elderly man fishing from the rocks near the boat landing and a pair of mating Canada geese in the marsh on the west shore.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the only foreign flagship carrier with public-share ownership, reported profitable operations in its fiscal year ended March 31 for the first time in five years.

The mechanical doll is second only to the mythic bird as a pretext for creating a ballet, so it was inevitable that George Balanchine would succumb to the lure eventually. At this time of year two summers ago, he created "The Steadfast Tin Soldier," which has taken its modest place in the repertory of the New York City Ballet.

TOKYO, June 9 "When I left my country, I had a different idea of what I would do in the outside world," said Nguyen Cong Hoan dejectedly. "I have had much sadness. I must not let myself be discouraged, although I feel that my hands and feet are tied and I can't do or say much."

The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in Avis stock early yesterday as Fuqua Industries made a new bid for the nation's No. 2 car rental company and reports continued to build that several new bidders would soon enter the picture A. leading Middle Western industrial company, a container maker and pet food company flush with cash or the ability to raise it were widely mentioned as possible new bidders.

If you want to get in touch with Howard Swanson, write him a letter. The Manhattan-based composer does not have a telephone. "If you work where you live, as I do," he said the other day, "a telephone is just distracting. I tried having one once, and had to give it up. I just couldn't get anything done."
Among the great traditional American ambitions becoming a movie star or a President has been the ownership of a seat on a stock exchange. Soon they'll be for rent.

Those who live by the sword usually die by the sword, at any rate in knockout team contests. Surprisingly, often a team that struggles through to win a match by one or two international match points, the smallest possible margins, goes down to defeat in the next round after an equally close battle. The fates have balanced the account.

Tagamet, a promising new drug for the treatment of ulcers, cleared a hurdle in Washington this week, with final approval soon by the Food and Drug Administration for sale in the United States considered assured.

Two tractor-trailers bound for New Jersey on the lower level of the George Washington Bridge narrowly missed falling into the Hudson River yeserday afternoon when they jackknifed in tandem, hurtled off the roadway and ripped through a steel-mesh safety net parallel to the roadway.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that President Carter had downgraded and diverted attention from "the central political struggle of our time that between liberal democracy and totalitarian communism."
A lawyer who says he spent $1,000 to fight a $15 parking ticket won his fight yesterday and thousands of drivers who never got around to fighting City Hall may benefit.

Several years ago, Anne DeSalvo left her West Philadelphia home, in what she calls one of that city's "two big Italian ghettoes," to come to New York and start a new life as an actress. Last month, Miss DeSalvo made her Broadway debut in Albert Innaurato's wellreceived comedy "Gemini," after acting in the play Off and Off Off Broadway, and has since won an Obie to boot.
LONDON, June 9 The Thames, London's broad avenue to the sea, was transformed into a vast stage today as this maritime nation paid spectacular tribute to Queen Elizabeth II.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 9 (Reuters) Costa Rican President Daniel Oduber said tonight he had asked Robert L. vesco, the fugitive American financier, to leave the country.

Dr. Edith B. Jackson, who was a pioneer in the observation and treatment of infants and very young children and developed rooming-in care of newborn babies by their mothers, died Suday at her home in Denver. She was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Senate reached a compromise on the highly controversial automobile pollution issue tonight, voting to delay imposition of stricter controls on car fumes but not to weaken the standards permanently in a significant way.

GENEVA, June 9 (Reuters) United States and Arab delegates today patched up a dispute over an issue involving Israel that had contributed to an American threat to withdraw from the International Labor Organization next November.

JOHANNESBURG Elsewhere, a foreigner who advocated a total reformation of the political and social order to a business gathering might expect a chilly reception. But when Andrew Young did just that here recently at a dinner for some of South Africa's most powerful executives, he was warmly, in some cases enthusiastically, applauded.

GARLANDED with quotations from Homer, Herodotus and Xenophon and glittering with the irresistible glamour of ex quisitely wrought silver and gold, the exhibition of "Thracian Treasures from Bulgaria," opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an event to delight the eye and beguile the mind.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, suggested today that the White House is now prepared to accept a net revenue loss in the tax reform program it will propose to Congress this year.

HACKENSACK, June 9 A class-action lawsuit was filed here today against a charitable foundation in Orange, demanding a full accounting of all donations it has received and dispersed since its founding in August 1974.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 9 John Stark is a strong young golfer from the University of Houston who yesterday admitted that he'd "rather play the Northern courses with the high grass than the hard pan around the greens down home in Texas."
The movie stocks were Wall Street's star performers yesterday as the general market retreated slightly after two days of higher prices.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 The expected fight between William R. Lummis and Chester C. Davis over control of the Howard Hughes estate has broken out in chancery court in Wilmington, Del.
Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California and Republican Presidential contender, criticized the Carter Administration yesterday for what he described as a "double standard" on human rights.
DETROIT, June 9 The Ford Motor Company announced today it would close two of its small-car plants with 3,525 workers for a week beginning Monday to keep inventories under control.
ROME, June 9 (AP) An unidentified gunman shot and fatally wounded Turkey's ambassador to the Vatican today. It was the third assassination of a Turkish ambassador in Europe in two years.
The long-awaited Fulton Mall project will get under way officially tomorrow, and downtown Brooklyn is kicking up its heels.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate here, said tonight that the Rhodesian Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith could not last 18 months more.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Howard H. Baker, the Senate Republican leader, today sharply criticized the Carter Administration's moves toward normalization of relations with Cuba.

The end of the school year is reward time for many of the outstanding athletes and teams in the metropolitan area. For the New Dorp baseball team the biggest prize would be a trip from the Staten Island school to Yankee Stadium on Tuesday for the Public Schools Athletic baseball final. New Dorp plays at Cardozo of Queens today in a semifinal.

HOBOKEN, N.J. When Joan Mann of Manhattan wants to take a weekend spin in the country, she boards a train in the 14th Street Port Authority TransHudson tube station, rides to Hoboken, walks two blocks to the municipal parking garage and picks up her 1972 Hornet station wagon.

WASHINGTON, June 9 A Florida newspaper publisher who has designed and test-flown a warplane that he believes could be used by the armed forces won a measure of Congressional approval for his project today over objections of the Defense Department.

The Sauter-Finegan Orchestra, the most innovative big jazz band of the 1950's, made adventurous use of piccolos, oboes, English horns, tuba, xylophone, harp and a huge battery of percussion instruments as well as elephant bells, kazoo, toy trumpet and keyboard glockenspiel, all in addition to the customary jazz band trumpets, trombones and saxophones. It disbanded 19 years ago, in 1958, after a controversial sixyear career.

Although oil will soon start flowing through the Alaskan pipeline, the plans for its distribution are still curiously unsettled. The Pacific Coast states need relatively little of the crude from Prudhoe Bay while the Midwest is thirsty for it. Nevertheless, in the ten years it has taken to plan and lay the pipeline, no definite route has been chosen to move the oil eastward.

TRENTON, June 9 New Jersey, which had considered its controls on various welfare programs, including nursinghome care for Medicaid patients, to be the most efficient in the nation, was "fined" $4.6 million yesterday for failing to inspect a nursing home on time. Nineteen other states were similarly penalized.
TAMPA, Fla., June 9 (AP) Twentytwo persons, including a fire department captain, were arrested today on arson conspiracy charges involving 22 business and residential fires in the last four years.
Young Rubicam and Time Inc. its client for 39 years, ran hand-in-hand to glory at last night's One Show, the advertising awards event.

IT IS 1,000 years from Hrotsvitha of Gandersheim, the first woman playwright, to Eve Merriam, the author of "The Club," but it is clear from Honor Moore's introduction to her anthology of plays, "The New Women's Theater," that women playwrights are sisters in feminism; they have always been concerned with consciousness-raising.

Thirty-one persons and three companies were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of stealing millions of undersized "seed" clams from the Great South Bay in Suffolk County, posing a threat to Long Island's $100 million-a-year hard clam industry.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9 An official of the Port of New York said today that chances for regaining lost Arab business were slim even though a Federal antiboycott law would equalize competition for Arab trade among Northeast ports.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 9 (AP) A highly placed Government spokesman refused today to confirm a published report indicating that Venezuela would forgo a 5 percent oil price increase scheduled for July 1.
A quizzical Mario M. Cuomo watched yesterday as commercials depicting an angry Mario M. Cuomo were shown on a television screen.

TRENTON, June 9 Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican candidate for Governor, said today that David F. Norcross, his campaign manager, would be the next Republican state chairman, and predicted that the Republican platform would contain a "no income tax" plank.
The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday it had recommended Presidential approval of a Laker Airways plan for no-reservations, no-frills New York-London service at a one-way rate of $135.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The House Ways and Means Committee rejected today an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, evidently killing any such plan for the rest of this year, but approved in modified form a "gas-guzzler" tax on big cars, a key element of President Carter's national energy program.

GRONINGEN, the Netherlands, June 9 Relatives of the 51 passengers held on a train five miles south of here for the last 18 days have passed through the emotional states of anxiety, fear and despair. Now all they feel is helplessness, they say.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Patricia J. Thoben, a lifelong paraplegic who was instrumental in ending discriminatory treatment of handicapped persons by airlines, died of cancer in Georgetown University Hospital on Tuesday. She was 44 years old.

Wesley Walker, who Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets says is "the fastest wide receiver we've had since Don Maynard," signed a series of one-year contracts with the National Football League club yesterday.

TOKYO, June 9 (Reuters) A Germanborn Jesuit scholar and playwright, Herman Heuvers, honorary pastor of St. Ignatius Church and former president of the Catholic Sophia University of Tokyo, died of a heart attack here today. He was 86 years old.
Louis Merlin Miniclier, an early pioneer in the concept of community development, has died in Seville, Spain. He was 66 years old. Memorial services were held there April 30.

POZNAN, Poland, June 3 One year after workers' riots over food prices shook Poland, the authorities are confronted with a growing human rights movement and popular discontent over widespread supply shortages.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, June 9 (AP) Fire raced through a nightclub in this West African capital early today, killing 41 people trapped when flames destroyed an electrical system operating an automatic exit, the French Consulate reported.

Almost half the unemployed workers who participated in a $10 million Federal job-training program in New York City were unemployed again 30 days after the program ended, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

KILPISJARVI, Finland Jouni Labba presides over a land majestic in its simplicity. Hills, lakes and birch-studded tundra sweep north to the Arctic waters beyond the horizon. The sun dazzles the melting patches of snow and the silence is punctuated by the bells clunking from the leather collars of his foraging reindeer.

The General Motors Corporation today won a delay until June 30 to answer a complaint by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz that thousands of buyers of 1977 Cadillacs, Buicks, Pontiacs and Oldsmobiles got cars equipped with engines made by other divisions.

ATLANTA, June 9 (UPI) A decline in cigarette smoking among doctors and dentists may presage a similar reduction in tobacco use among the general population in the next 10 to 15 years, a physician said today.

Airbus Industries, the French, German and Spanish consortium that manufactures the Airbus A-300 jumbo jet, announced in Paris that it had signed a joint venture agreement with the Pratt Whitney aircraft unit of the United Technologies Corporation to produce a version of the A-300 powered by Pratt Whitney's JT 9D-59A turbofan jet engine.
Mary Hartzell McSweeney, a medical research and medical care volunteer worker, died Tuesday in Essen, West Germany, while on vacation. She was 71 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

THE FINAL WORK of Oscar Lewis, the anthropologist, will be published this summer. His studies in the culture of poverty "The Children of Sanchez" and "La Vida" were widely acclaimed. Now his last research project has been completed by his widow, Ruth M. Lewis, and Susan M. Rigdon, their research associate.
The story of theater's 12-year struggle to survive at Lincoln Center is a story of soaring visions and dashed hopes.

IT SEEMS TO BE Richard Diebenkorn's season here, No sooner had a show of the California painter's recent works closed (at Knoedler's last week) than a Diebenkorn retrospective opened (at the Whitney Museum yesterday, through July 17); more than 130 works that display the full range of his talents, both figurative and abstract.

An all-day free program of paleontological and natural science, with activities and tours run by schoolchildren, will be offered tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. on the grounds of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street.
MILWAUKEE, June 9 A tornado ripped through the Milwaukee area Sunday. The Yankees roared through the Brewers today and last night. You could hardly tell the difference.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) The price of gold fell back today in London and Zurich, Europe's principal bullion markets. The dollar closed mixed on European money markets.

MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI) Soviet scientists contend that the planet Jupiter is a sun still in the process of being born rather than a dying sun as some astronomers have long believed.

ALBANY, June 9 The New York State Assembly today adopted a number of bills dealing with consumer and environmental issues, including one that would bar any increase in the 10-cent charge for local telephone calls from coin boxes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Gould Inc. and two executives of the electronics company with failure to disclose a $940,000 real estate deal involving some company officers. Named in the suit were William T. Ylvisaker, chairman, and Edwin C. Parker, financial vice president.

How good are the Chicago Cubs? Good enough to win the National League's Eastern Division, according to Bruce Sutter, their star relief pitcher.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, blocked recently in an attempt to spend money for new rail transportation, voted yesterday to shift a $240 million mass-transit commitment to bus projects.

Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. MONTREAL, June 9 The Cleveland Barons, a major financial headache to the National Hockey League since the original franchise entered the league in 1967, found their sixth group of owners today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Under Secretary of State Philip C. Habib and Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the South Korean and Japanese Governments supported the Administration's plan to withdraw American troops from South Korea so long as "adequate measures" were taken to insure the security of Northeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell considers it both "inappropriate and unnecessary" to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate alleged South Korean payoffs to Congressmen, according to a letter released today.

BARCELONA, Spain Socialist Party sound trucks went through the tree-lined Ramblas blaring the stirring rhythms of the Internationale. Wall posters and giant billboards whether put up by the right or the left are dominated by the flaming red and orange of the Catalan flag.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The United States and the Soviet Union will begin discussions in Washington on Monday on a possibly agreement to ban all explosions of nuclear devices, the State Department announced today. President Carter has made such an accord one of the priority arms control goals of his Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Ignoring the plea of the Canadian Government, a House subcommittee voted today to hold public hearings on confidential Gulf Oil Corporation documents alleged to prove the existence of a worldwide cartel that has successfully conspired to force up the price of uranium.

ALBANY, June 10 Moving right along, Perry B. Duryea has invested three more years of his life waiting for one last chance to try for the governorship next year. Politics is like that; the years of an ambitious life can become slender poker chips for keeping a stake open in a roundabout game and waiting for a big hand to be dealt.

NEW BLOOM Helen Gallagher is a name that immediately prompts enthusiasm and respect among show people and a large segment of theatergoers, who know the dancing, singing actress as a real professional. The mainstay of many a Broadway production, good and bad, Miss Gallagher won official recognition for her versatility with a Tony award apiece for "Pal Joey" and "No, No Nanette."

As state legislators start talking about adjournment by the Fourth of July, urgent matters affecting New York City remain unattended. Traditionally, the closing days of the Albany legislative session are as hectic as the Fulton fish market at 5 A.M. Strong leadership should be exerted to keep city matters from getting trampled in the closing rush.
Stock prices edged higher yesterday against a news background that tended to calm Wall Street fears of higher short-term interest rates. Some oil issues showed good gains.
CAPE TOWN, June 10 (AP) South Africa said today it would appoint an administrator-general for South-West Africa instead of proceeding with earlier plans for a transitional government to independence.

LONDON, June 10 (UPI) British Commonwealth leaders agreed today to support United States and British efforts to achieve peaceful transition to black rule in Rhodesia but said it could not be accomplished without destruction of the Rhodesian army.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The House today passed and sent to President Carter a compromise bill that would ban United States businessmen from aiding the Arab trade boycott of Israel and which would also give Congress a veto power over export of Alaskan oil.
An offer, by Norton Simon Inc., a conglomerate, to pay $160 million in cash for Avis Inc., the car rental company, was rejected yesterday in a development that Surprised many Wall Street analysts.

BEDMINSTER TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 10 Ronald Reagan, the former Republican Governor of California, and Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Democratic Senator from Minnesota, told a gathering of corporate executives today that they did not believe President Carter would be able to make good on his pledge to balance the Federal budget by 1981.
PARIS, June 10 (Reuters) France has begun development of its own cruise missile capable of carrying nuclear or conventional warheads over-long distances at low altitude, informed sources said today.

SOUTHWICK, Mass., June 10 In the long northward march of progress through Connecticut, the power companies and the state's regulatory authorities appear to have overlooked a small, half-forgotten community on the boundary that buys its electricity from a family in Massachusetts.

NEW DELHI, June 10 Millions voted today in state elections that will provide the first test of the ruling Janata Party's strength since it came to power, unseating Indira Gandhi in March. The voting, for state assemblies in 10 of India's 22 states, will be spread over five days, ending Tuesday.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, Saturday, June 11 Dutch marine commandos stormed a hijacked train and a village school in simultaneous dawn raids today to free 55 hostages held for 20 days by South Moluccan gunmen. The Dutch Justice Ministry said six terrorists and two hostages had been killed.

TANGSHAN, China, June 10 The rusting remains of a factory, a mangled burned-out train, a vast plain of rubble this is all that is left of Tangshan. Last July the world's worst earthquake in centuries killed about 750,000 in and around this north Chinese city.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Senate voted today to extend for up to 10 years the deadlines for cleaning up polluted air in cities, but it also adopted rules requiring steady progress toward the goal of clean air.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 10(AP) Al Geiberger, a soft-spoken, 39-year-old golfer, slow-moving and seemingly. casual under a broiling sun, shot a 13under-par 59 today that broke the PGA Tour record for 18 holes. Geiberger posted his score in the second round of the $200,000 Danny Thomas-Memsphis Golf Classic.
MOSCOW, June 10 Nikolai V. Podgorny, who was dropped last month from the ruling Politburo of the Communist Party, appears to have already effectively lost his job as President of the Soviet Union.

Joseph A. Fasullo, the former chief cashier at the brokerage house of Happin, Watson at One State Street Plaza, pleaded guilty yesterday before acting State Supreme Court Justice George F. Roberts in Manhattan to grand larceny on charges of embezzling $250,000 worth of stock held by his concern.

WASHINGTON, June 10 A career diplomat whose outspoken public defense of human rights once brought him a rebuke from Henry A. Kissinger will probably head the first United States diplomatic mission to Cuba since the 1961 break in relations, Administration officials said today.

The majority of black elected Democrats from Brooklyn endorsed the Manhattan Borough-President, Percy E. Sutton, for Mayor on the steps of City Hall yesterday, but noticeably absent was that borough's most powerful black politician, Representative Shirley Chisholm .

Not everything in the National Basketball Association's player draft is serious business. Yesterday, for example, the proceedings were delayed because the telephone operator at the Forum would not put the 22-team conference call through to the Los Angeles Lakers' general manager, Bill Sharman.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was moving 900 employees from its New York offices on Fifth Avenue to Detroit over the next 15 months.

John J. Cassese, who was president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in New York City during most of the turbulent 1960's, died Thursday after a long illness at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 64 years old.

About 100 teams of amateur enthusiasts are being recruited by Earthwatch, an organization that matches volunteers with research projects, to assist scientific expeditions in 13 states and 17 foreign countries this summer and fall. ANY DAY NOW Northeast Utilities may sign an agreement with the Metropolitan District Commission of Massachusetts to siphon water from the Connecticut River. SATHGACHIA, India, June 7--In translation into English, the name of Sathgachia, a fertile delta district town 30 miles south of Calcutta, means "Garden of Seven Trees." Despite its fertility, the entire district is a center of poverty and unemployment--and Marxism.

ROBERVAL, Quebec, June 8--The sound and the fury of Quebec's current debate over language rights are barely heard in this quiet rural community where everyone speaks French and almost never worries about doing so.

IT was just 30 years ago when Edward J. Mortola, then registrar at Fordham University, heard that Pace College, "just up the street," was looking for an assistant dean. "I went to Father Gannon and asked his advice," Dr. Mortola recalled last week, referring to the Rev. Robert L. Gannon, then president of the Jesuit school. "He said, 'Unless you turn your collar around, you'll never become president of Fordham, but you might at Pace.'"

FOR THE MODEST sum of $2 a week, any Westport youngster from 3 to 5 years of age may be registered to attend a nursery school operated by students in the Child Development II course at Staples High School. Dutch commandos, backed by jet planes dropping smoke bombs, stormed a train and school near the town of Assen, ending the siege in which South Moluccan terrorists had held 53 hostages for 20 days. Two hostages and six terrorists were killed. The seven surviving terrorists were arrested.

The New York State Legislature has voted to outlaw topless entertainment in bars, but legislators appear to have been more interested in accumulating political points than in affecting public morality.
