PETROS, Tenn., June 12--"When I went to bed last night," W.E. Hall Jr. said, "I put my 45 on the table next to my head and propped chairs against all the doors. There were dogs howling yonder until the sun came up."

The impresario Paul Szilard, who arranges all of the overseas touring of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Company, has said that during the company's season at the Avignon Festival in France, July 24 through Aug. 6, it will be joined by two Soviet guest stars from Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet.

NOTTINGHAM, England June 12 (UPI)--Tim Gullikson of Onalaska, Wis., upset Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., today, 6-4. 3-6, 13-11, to reach the final of the $100,000 John Player grass-court tournament and earn a berth at the Wimbledon tennis championships.

THOMASTON, Ga., June 12--The key to President Carter's dogged insistence on killing 18 major water projects lies a few miles west of town in the white waters of the Flint River, which the Army Corps of Engineers wanted to dam.

BRUSSELS, June 12 (UPI)--Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., turned back hard-serving Karl Meiler of West Germany today. 7-5, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, and won the Belgian Grand Prix tournament. The victory was worth $11,750.
A short while ago an acquaintance told us an amusing story about the origins of spaghetti carbonara, which means spaghetti charcoal-burner-style.
If there was any record of the youngest pair ever to finish first or second in a major championship, it would certainly have been broken during the recent Eastern Regional Championships.

SHERMAN, Tex., June 12 (AP)--The Donrey Media Group has entered into an agreement to purchase a major interest in the Red River Valley Publishing Company, which publishes The Sherman Democrat, company officials announced today. The Democrat, a North Texas daily newspaper, has a paid circulation of 19,000.

HOLLYWOOD, June 12--Susan Ford, daughter of former President Ford, has been hired as a special photographer on the movie "Jaws 2," it was announced yesterday by Richard D. Zanuck and David Brown, the picture's producers. She will report to the Martha's Vineyard location Sunday.

BEIRUT, June 12--The hard-line Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine announced today that Faiz Mansour, a 27-year-old military commander in the Chatila refugee camp here, had been shot to death by gunmen in the street near the camp.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 12 (AP)--Al Geiberger, the leader since his record round of 59, lost a three-stroke advantage and had to rally to win the Danny Thomas-Memphis golf tourney today. He beat Gary Player and Jerry McGee, the runners-up by three strokes.

Black viewers for public television are on the increase, and so are programs of particular interest to blacks, Chloe Aaron, senior vice president of programming for the Public Broadcasting Service, has told a luncheon audience of the New York chapter of the Television Academy.
A one-block street in the Bronx was renamed yesterday for Lieut. Col. Yehonatan Netanyahu, the New Yorkborn Israeli paratroop commander killed in the Entebbe raid last July 3.

So chanted the Gowanas Girls Marching Unit yesterday, their red-and-white satin glistening in the sun, their feet keeping perfect time on hot asphalt. So too, said almost half a million Puerto Ricans from the New York area, just by being at the 19th annual Puerto Rican Day parade.

Joe Burke, the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, did not make any trades yesterday, but it was difficult to convince the confused fans at Milwaukee County Stadium, where the Royals were beaten by the Brewers, 4-0, in an American League game.

The marriage of Glynn Rudich, daughter of Mrs. Nathan M. Rudich of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Rudich, to Howard J. Cohen, son of Dr. Robin Cohen of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Cohen, took place yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

The credit markets, flushed with their success in marketing a near-record volume of tax-exempt bonds last week, abound with optimism and talk of higher prices and lower interest rates in the weeks ahead. There's going to be a summer rally in the bond market and the money market, too, many fixed-income traders and analysts now predict.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 12-- Roger Jones of Ramsey upset his New Jersey rival, Kevin Byrne of Paramus Catholic, in the one-mile run and Tony Tufariello of Hewlett, L.I., won the 440-yard dash easily at the Golden West invitation schoolboy meet last night.
Frank R. Lyon Jr., retired senior vice president and general counsel of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday in Dorset, Vt., following a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11--A lack of suitable facilities has made the large-scale outdoor summer concert a rarity in the New York area, although there is hope that the Meadowlands stadium in New Jersey may fill the void next year. In the meantime the closest events of that sort take place here in Philadelphia, at John F. Kennedy Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 12--More by groping sweeps than by calculation, President Carter has fallen upon a new trade policy for the United States that tilts toward liberalism while satisfying the most urgent needs of import-injured workers.
DARJEELING, India--St Paul's, a boarding school with a distinguished past that reaches back to the grandest days of the British Empire, is concerned about its future.

A TOUCH OF CLASS Warm weather naturally prompts thoughts of outside diversions, but the Big Apple still leads the word in availability of good movie revivals the year round. A seasonal reminder is the usual stunning array of vintage screenings open to the public (on a single admission basis) in several summer courses at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. The events also include a commentary or analysis by the teacher.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP)--The Kennedy family, friends and political associates gathered today in a light mist on a muddy field at the end of a peninsula on Boston Harbor to break ground for the John Fitzgerald Kennedy memorial library.

WALDWICK, N.J., June 12--Bill Scarlett won the New Jersey State men's 35er indoor tennis championship for the second straight year today. He scored a 6-1, 6-4 victory over Peter De Lames in the final at the Waldwick Covered Courts.
While Rod Carew was hitting .595 against the Yankees in 1975, Paul Thormodsgard was playing third base for the Banning (Calif.) Nite Hawks softball team.
MANILA, June 12 (Reuters)--Three Filipinos working for Japanese and American news organizations were detained for a short time today while they ...

PETROS, Tenn., June 12--Two National Guard units and a contingent of National Guard helicopters were ordered mobilized tonight in the search for James Earl Ray and three other convicts thought to be still hiding in the mountains of Tennessee.
TRIPOLI, Libya, June 12 (AP)--Col Muammar el-Qaddafi has challenged President Carter to improve LibyanAmerican relations by consenting to the appointment of ambassadors.

The board of American Ballet Theater has named the head of one of the country's major business corporations as its new chairman in an overall reorganization designed to strengthen the company's national fund-raising effort.

ATLANTA, June 13 For the Mets, tonight's game was of minor importance compared with the big question facing the team: whether or not Tom Seaver would be traded before the deadline at midnight Wednesday night.

The unhappy aspect of New York City Ballet's weekend happened offstage, when one of its leading soloists, Bart Cook, was mugged away from the theater after Saturday night's performance, resulting in a rearrangement of casting at the New York State Theater on Sunday. On the specific instructions of George Balanchine, the explicit reason for Mr. Cook's absence he has suffered a broken nose and various other injuries was given to the matinee audience.
Before a nonblinking tote board and cheering fans who didn't have a dime on his nose, Forego breezed yesterday to one of the easiest half-length victories Belmont fans will see this year.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Trans World Airlines' advertisements that say it has a better on-time record than its major competitors are unfair and deceptive, the Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today.

As the President, the F.B.I., the Governor of Tennessee and all other authority well understood, the nation's sanity required that James Earl Ray be taken back alive. Had the murderer of Martin Luther King Jr., vanished or been slain in pursuit, the already difficult aspects of his trial and constant retrial in public debate would have spawned another decade's worth of irrefutable speculation and paranoia.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) President Carter lost another, albeit minor, part of his energy-tax package today when the House Ways and Means Committee refused his plea to increase the tax on fuel used by private aircraft.

Following is a panel discussion on unnecessary surgery adapted from the March, 1977 issue of Medical Opinion magazine. The participants were Dr. James V. Warren, chairman of the department of medicine at Ohio State University and editor-in-chief of Medical Opinion; Dr. Larry C. Carey, chairman of the Department of Surgery at Ohio State; Dr. Edwin DeCosta, a Chicago obstetriciangynecologist;

WIMBLEDON, England, June 10 The Victorian gentry who watched the first Lawn Tennis Championship tournament here 100 years ago would be dumfounded if they could see the AllEngland Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club today.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 13 (Reuters) Black guerrillas have killed four whites, one of them a child, in two ambushes in Rhodesia, a military statement said today.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 11 In the next few weeks, the bankers and the lawyer will finally start parceling out some of Joseph M. Dorgan's money. Certainly enough people have asked about it.

Dr. William J. Ronan, who is reportedly ready to resign as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is set to leave today with his wife on a 30-day first-class round-the-world air tour at the expense of the Port Authority that is officially described as a business trip.
The Dana Corporation, a leading producer of auto and truck components, reported yesterday a 13.3 percent gain in earnings for the quarter ended May 31 on a 24.3 percent sales gain.

Jay Worenklein felt a compulsion to rival the fabled late-night Chinese-food cravings of his native West Side. And 60 he had to go down from his law ledgers at Milbank Tweed, down from his hearth at Broadway and 83d Street, down to the sea.

Dr. George C. Cotzias, an internationally prominent neurologist who developed L-Dopa therapy for Parkinson's disease, died of lung cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center here, where he had taught, cared for patients and did research. He would have been 59 years old on Thursday.

JOHANNESBURG, June 13?Three black men armed with submachine guns and grenades burst into a downtown garage near police headquarters here today and opened fire, killing two white men and seriously injuring a third. The Government, asserting that the weapons were of Communist origin, described it as an outburst of urban terrorism.

ALBANY, June 13 Despite an almost certain veto, a bill to widen the scope of the state's death penalty and reshape it to comply with rulings of the United States Supreme Court was introduced in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter said today that the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation would probably be one of five men that a special selection commission has recommended for the job.
William J.A. Glancy, a lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived at 160 Cabrini Boulevard.
JERSEY CITY, June 13 (AP) Rose Cupo, whose schooling stopped in the third grade in 1907, received an elementary school diploma today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The investigation by the Senate Government Operations Subcommittee into the accounting profession began in acrimony five months ago with a sizzling 1,760page report that scored the accountants and their nominal regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 13 Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, said today that three House Republicans had made inquiries, directly or indirectly, concerning their seniority status if they would switch parties and become Democrats.

A 21-year-old man fell to his death from a 10th floor terrace of the Criminal Court Building in downtown Brooklyn in an apparent attempt to escape minutes after a jury had found him guilty of robbery.

WASHINGTON, June 13 Defense Secretary Harold Brown warned Congress today that going ahead with the development of the experimental breeder reactor would increase the risk of the spread of nuclear weapons to nations that do not now have them.
Something close to a showdown battle is taking place between suburban tax- payers and the people they hire to educate their children.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Senate changed its rules today to allow a senator's aides to solicit campaign funds for his nomination or election expenses. The change was quietly approved by voice vote without debate or opposition.

DETROIT, June 13 The Chrysler Corporation disclosed today that it made about $2.5 million in "unusual payments" to foreign government officials and union representatives during the six years that ended in December 1976.

Saturday morning was waking up to distressing news. President Carter, said the papers, wanted to rally public opinion. Rallying public opinion on a weekend in June is almost unheard of. It made you wonder if the President had a firm grip on the calendar.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 13 The rich oil-exporting countries have agreed to put up only about $10 billion to help the rest of the world pay its soaring oil bills this year, a senior international economic official disclosed here today. That is down sharply from the $15 billion to $20 billion that international groups had hoped to raise.

HARTFORD, June 13 The Fletcher family of Southwick, Mass., agreed today to let the Public Utilities Control Authority of Connecticut set the rates for the electricity it sells to a little community of customers across the border in Connecticut that they have served for 46 years and that the rest of the world seemed to have lost sight of.
STELLENBOSCH, South Africa, June 13 (AP) Stellenbosch University, South Africa's leading Afrikaans-language institution, has announced it will admit nonwhite students for the first time.

MEXICO CITY, June 13 (Reuters) Ten American prisoners recently released from Cuban jails where they had been held on drug-related charges left today for home after a stopover here from Havana, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

DETROIT, June 13 Leonora M. Perez, a Filipino nurse, testified today that she was not at work in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor on the nights she is accused of causing two patients to suffer breathing failure.

After spending more than four years in Washington in powerful, highly visible, energy-taxing, top-level Government jobs, William E. Simon slipped quietly back into diverse roles in the private sector at his New York base

WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter defended Andrew Young today as "a superb representative of our country," but said he agreed with Mr. Young that the American chief delegate to the United Nations should now "shift his emphasis more toward other developing nations outside Africa."

MARATHON, Fla. Ominous, towering black clouds, high winds and bursts of torrential rain kept us ashore most of the second of two days of fly fishing for tarpon off the Florida Keys, and the excitement of our first day's encounter with those huge, silvery, acrobatic fish was not repeated.

WASHINGTON There is a danger that the recent press reports of the growth of grain stocks because of two years of favorable harvests and the prospect of another excellent crop in 1977 may tempt persons concerned about the world food problem to conclude that it is on the way to being solved.

Merle Marsicano is a choreographer of atmosphere who is strikingly effec tive when she shapes her misty moods on a firm structural underpinning, as in "Images in the Open." Dealing, as she does, with the less-than-tangible changes in dynamics, her work is always on the point of becoming vaporous, unless provided with tensile strength to hold its shape. Her company presented a selection of four works at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter softened his criticism of Congress today but warned that if "special interests" thwarted his energy goals the country would face a catastrophe.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company was accused today of overcharging the Government millions of dollars for excess steel in building seven ships for the Navy.

JERUSALEM, June 13 They were small things on an important day in the life of Menahem Begin, but they served to illustrate something about who he is and what might be expected from him if he takes over as Israel's leader.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, in a move that surprised some money market observers, cut its prime lending rate on short-term loans to 6 percent yesterday from the prevailing industrywide 6 percent level. The change is effective today.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday the formation of a private commission to study the future course of public broadcasting in the United States in light of emerging new communications technologies and the fiscal and structural problems of the present public-television system.

President Carter's energy program is getting a rough ride in the committees of the House. The tentative decision of the Ways and Means Committee to delay the tax on inefficient automobiles the "gas guzzler" levy until 1979 seems tolerable; the decision to eliminate the proposed rebate for the most efficient small cars is understandable, since no one knew how to avoid giving a great sales boost to foreign imports.

The American Stock Exchange, which has been enjoying a success in the trading of options, yesterday asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to hold a factfinding hearing on a proposal by the New York Stock Exchange to get into the options business.

DETROIT, June 13 A jury of nine men and five women was selected here today to hear the first-degree murder trial of Al Junior Lewis, accused last November of shooting to death his estranged wife, Bettye McCaster, in her first-grade classroom in front of many of her pupils.

The Kansas City Royals, whose last view of Yankee Stadium was soured by the sight of Chris Chambliss's fly ball descending into the right-field stands for a pennant-winning home run, returned in a different position last night and engineered a different outcome.
"I never really had visions of myself as a director of any company," Marcia Hayd e said. "All I wanted to do was dance."

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Agency for International Development suppressed Census Bureau population estimates for several underdeveloped countries when the figures reflected unfavorably on A.I.D. birth control programs, according to a Congressional subcommittee.

LONDON, June 13 (AP) Gold closed at $138 an ounce in London today, its lowest price since the end of February, while the dollar had a narrowly mixed day in Europe. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 2 yen in heavy selling.

Gene Bartow, John Wooden's successor as basketball coach of the University of California, Los Angeles, will leave U.C.L.A. for a school without a team in any sport and with a gymnasium that seats only 400.

OMAHA, June 13 (AP) Mookie Wilson collected three hits and battered in a pair of runs and Tim Lewis struck out 14 tonight in leading South Carolina to a 6-2 victory over California State-Los Angeles in the 31st annual college world series.

HACKENSACK, June 13 Frank Miceli, an alleged lieutenant in the crime "family" of the late Carlo Gambino, pleaded guilty today to nine bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from an 11-month investigation of loan-sharking and other illicit activities in 1974 and 1975.

Bernard Cornfeld, founder of the defunct mutual fund empire, Investors Overseas Services, has become a member of the international jet set again, although the scene was sober rather than sybaritic. The 49-year-old former social worker, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif., appeared in a Swiss courtroom yesterday on fraud charges stemming from the collapse of the gigantic mutual fund complex.

MADRID, June 13 Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez tonight wound up Spain's first open electoral campaign in four decades, urging citizens to vote for his new center-right coalition as an alternative to the far right and the Marxist left.
WASHINGTON, June 13 In what better city could an ad agency president suggest that Government communications need regulations more than advertising does?
WASHINGTON, June 13 The President, as expected, today approved a oneyear experiment in low air fares between New York and London.

If a partnership has a five-three fit in both major suits it is generally hard to see any reason for choosing one rather than other. Ideally, one would wish to select the suit that is better provided with intermediate cards, the J-10-9, but this is rarely possible to judge in the bidding.

It was one of those perfect, blue-sky days at Arlington Cemetery. A lone bird, making a slow-motion reconnaissance flight over the classic military funeral, was reflected in the suit-polished black shoes of some naval officers attending.

Psychiatric patients in state hospitals are not eligible to receive Medicaid benefits, according to a decision by the United States Court of Appeals. It affects 40,000 patients in New York State mental hospitals who were committed involuntarily in noncriminal actions.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter said today that he was "completely convinced" that a Soviet Jew accused of treason had "to our knowledge" never worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.
Constants Hope Berliner, public relations counsel for many opera stars, died yesterday at her home at 171 West 57th Street. She was 69 years old.
There are baskets to put your vegetables in, baskets to hang on your bicycle, baskets to hold umbrellas or laundry. And then there's the art basket.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., June 13 (AP) Uranium exploration worldwide increased 37 percent during 1976, according to a Government survey, and companies in the field expect to increase drilling by about the same amount again this year.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, June 11 In these last days before the election Wednesday, the volatile Basque country has been relatively calm. There have been bombs, one death, a radio station and a TV transmitter blown up, an occasional confrontation between young demonstrators and the police.

LOCUST GROVE, Okla., June 13 (UPI) Three girls, 8, 9 and 10 years old, were beaten to death early today in an apparent sex attack at a Girl Scout camp in northeastern Oklahoma's brushy lake country, the authorities said.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, June 13 Canada's Shaw Festival, occupying a handsome new brick theater in a riverside park and a smaller theater in the courthouse, is smaller and more intimate than its Shakespearean neighbor at Stratford, 100 miles to the west. Its concentration upon Shaw tends to set its aim on wit and style and frequently achieves it rather than power and innovation.
CHICAGO, June 13 (UPI) The appointment of Gregory F. Favre as managing editor of The Chicago Daily News was announced Monday by James Hoge, editor-in-chief of The Daily News and Chicago Sun-Times.

PETROS, Tenn., June 13 James Earl Ray, recaptured early today after 54 hours of freedom, was placed in a "maximum custody" section of Brushy Mountain Penitentiary late today as the authorities began an investigation of his escape into the mountains.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter softened his criticism of Congress today but warned that if "special interests" thwarted his energy goals the country would face a catastrophe.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday the formation of a private commission to study the future course of public broadcasting in the United States in light of emerging new communications technologies and the fiscal and structural problems of the present public-television system.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 13 Officials of the Dutch Ministry of Justice today began questioning hostages of the hijacked train and the village school gathering evidence for prosecution of the seven surviving South Moluccans who held them captive for 20 days.
Tom C. Clark, a retired justice of the Supreme Court who also had served as Attorney General in the Truman Administration, died in his sleep early yesterday at the home here of his son, Ramsey.

"Arbitrary quotas," Joseph A. Califano said the other day in his commencement address at the City College of New York, would not be part of the Federal Government's "affirmative action" program to achieve greater minority-group participation in professional and higher education. But, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare added, the Government would rely "because we must rely, on numerical goals as benchmarks of progress."

YONKERS, June 13 Mr. and Mrs. James Hoar, 76 and 78 years old, were at the Yonkers pier by 9 o'clock this morning, their tickets in their hands. Half an hour later they had settled into folding chairs on the sunny deck of the Hudson River Day Line sightseeing boat, which was rocking gently in the water at the end of the pier.

The credit markets, surprised late yesterday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's decision to lower its prime rate, continued their current move toward higher prices and lower interest rates. The late-afternoon advance reinforced the corporate bond market's expectations that today's issue of Bell System bonds would yield 8 percent or less.

Norman Morrice, a British choreographer and former director of the Ballet Rambert, will replace Kenneth MacMillan as director of the Royal Ballet next September, it was announced yesterday in London by John Tooley, general administrator of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Mr. MacMillan is stepping down at his own request, citing the conflict between his administrative duties and his work as a choreographer.
Agnes Rindge Claflin. professor emeritus of art at Vassar College, died Sunday at Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N.Y. She was 77 years old and a resident of New Paltz, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The Supreme Court ruled today that children who have been living with foster parents may generally be taken from the foster families and transferred elsewhere without a hearing on the merits of the transfer.

KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia, June 13 (Reuters) More than 30 Vietnamese refugees were believed to have drowned when their boat capsized off the coast of Sabah, a Malaysian state in northern Borneo, police said today.

NEW DELHI, June 13 Two young lawyers, wearing the black robes and starchy white dickies customary in Indian courtrooms, sat in a Bombay law library the other day, sipping tea during a trial break and discussing this country's new Government.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 13 President Carter was put on notice today that, even though relations between the cities and Washington had improved under his Administration, the cities still felt they were being neglected.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts unveiled today a program for fathers on welfare. Mr. Dukakis said at a Statehouse news conference that the Massachusetts program, which requires Federal approval, sought jobs in public service, or for a nonprofit agency, for 2,000 men on welfare.

PETROS, Tenn., June 13 "They run him hard for three hours," said Tennessee's Safety Commissioner, Joel Plummer. Standing before a battery of microphones at the gates of Brushy Mountain Penitentiary, he was clearly exultant.
For want of a stitch, a horse was given medication, disqualified from victory in a nonbetting race and Stanley Dancer is so furious he wants to go to the United States Supreme Court.
Stock prices rose slightly yesterday in response to indications of a letup in the recent rise in interest rates.
TRENTON, June 13 The State Public Health Council, an advisory and rule making agency for the Department of Health, recommended today a ban on laetrile in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The proposal to provide $14 billion to bail out the Social Security System is an attempt to prevent additional taxes for average Americans and, next to energy, is President Carter's most important bill, Secretary Califano said today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 A New York State law that had denied college scholarships, tuition grants and loans to some but not all aliens was struck down today by the Supreme Court as unconstitutionally discriminatory. The vote was 5 to 4.

Dardanelle, a planist and singer, and Peter Dean, a husky-voiced singer and ukulele strummer, each of whom usually works as an individual act, have joined forces at Cleo's, Broadway at 63d Street, to make a whole that is a bit more than the sum of the parts.

Dr. William J. Ronan, who is reportedly ready to resign as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, is set to leave today with his wife on a 30-day first-class round-the-world air tour at the expense of the Port Authority that is officially described as a business trip.
VIENNA, June 13 A former Czechoslovak Communist official, Zdenek Mlynar, and his wife arrived in Austria today as political exiles.
Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens called on Mayor Beame yesterday to hold a citywide referendum to define pornography.
The police said yesterday they were searching for three suspects in the fatal stabbing of a 17-year-old student Sunday night in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

Steel production for the week ended June 11 showed an unexpected drop after the Memorial Day weekend, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. With the present bullish outlook for the steel industry, it had been expected that steel output would again resume its upward trend after the pause for the June 4 weekend, which encompassed the traditional Memorial Day lull.
Clive Toye has resigned as president, the Cosmos announced yesterday, and has signed a long-term contract as special consultant to the team.
Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

Dr. Arnold Nacht, an internist and medical director of the Washington heights Medical Group, 4337 Broadway, Manhattan died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 633 West 112th Street, Manhattan.

TEL AVIV, June 13 The Begin era opened in Jerusalem this afternoon with trumpets and fanfare as the members of Parliament who were elected May 17 were inducted.

LONDON, June 13 (UPI) Commonwealth leaders laid the groundwork for a compromise settlement of their dispute over sports links with South Africa during a weekend session at a tightly guarded retreat in Scotland.
NEW DELHI, June 13 India's food output slumped by nearly 10 million metric tons during the last year, the Indian Government disclosed today.
Prices of almost all commodity futures declined yesterday in what a score of leading brokers said was the broadest erosion of raw materials values in recent memory.

JOHANNESBURG, June 13 Three black men armed with submachine guns and grenades burst into a downtown garage near police headquarters here today and opened fire, killing two white men and seriously injuring a third. The Government, asserting that the weapons were of Communist origin, described it as an outburst of urban terrorism.

Laetrile, the controversial cancer treatment, was blamed yesterday for causing the death of a 10-month-old girl on Saturday at a Buffalo hospital. She had reportedly swallowed an unknown amount of the substance.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13 Before Rosalynn Carter began her 13-day tour to seven Latin American and Caribbean nations, there was widespread skepticism that it could produce any positive results.

The bidding contest for Avis Inc., the nation's No. 2 car rental company, was joined yesterday by Sears Holdings Ltd., a leading British retailer, which said it was interested in buying 20 to 25 percent of Avis stock for $21 a share or $41.4 million in cash.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The Supreme Court held unconstitutional today a New York law that automatically stripped political party officers of their party jobs if they refused to waive immunity and testify when called before a grand jury.

WASHINGTON, June 13 Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, went to the Capitol today to try to break the impasse between the White House and Congress concerning the Labor-H.E.W. appropriations bill, but left with little to show for his efforts.
ATLANTA, June 13 The Mets, who have been complaining about a lack of hitting, and the Braves, who have been concerned about their pitching, opened a three-game series tonight at Atlanta Stadium.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 13 The Nassau County District Attorney's office will investigate charges made today by State Senator John R. Dunne of Garden City that Hempstead Town officials and members of the staff of Francis T. Purcell made political contributions of 1 percent of their salaries.

MOUNTAINAIR, N.M., June 9 Marie Autrey was fixing beans for lunch when she looked up and saw the Government truck bouncing along the dusty road toward the ranch house. Even before it pulled to a stop in the front yard she knew what was in store.
SKIDMORE, Md., June 13 (AP) "Everything is quiet," Billy Marks of Newark said today on a grassy lot where he is camped with his two horses. "But I'm getting some hunger pains."

A public offering of $250 million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds for New York City was oversubscribed yesterday even before it was formally made at an interest rate of 7.5 percent, the lowest ever for long-term M.A.C. securities.

NEWARK, June 13 New Jersey's largest public utility announced today that it had canceled a contract with Algeria to import trillions of cubic feet of liquefied natural gas for storage and processing on Staten Island.

BOSTON, June 13 Jerry Ray, 41 years old, younger brother of James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was recaptured yesterday after escaping from Brushy Mountain State Prison in Tennessee, said today that he was glad prison guards caught his brother "before the F.B.I. agents got to him."
Tom C. Clark, a retired justice of the Supreme Court who also had served as Attorney General in the Truman Administration, died in his sleep early yesterday at the home here of his son, Ramsey.
Joseph Williams, a theatrical booking agent who reportedly opened the first belly-dancing studio in the United States, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old.
Agreement on a new contract between The New York Post and the Newspaper Guild of New York was announced last night by Theodore W. Kheel, who served as mediator in the dispute.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13 (Reuters) Two Syrians were publicly hanged in the main square of Damascus today after having been convicted of belonging to an assassination squad alleged to have been financed by Iraq.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The senate approved today a $2.5 billion research and development program to search for alternative sources of energy and find ways to increase production of domestic oil and gas.
WASHINGTON, June 13 President Carter said today that he was "completely convinced" that a Soviet Jew accused of treason had "to our knowledge" never worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

PETROS, Tenn., June 13 James Earl Ray, recaptured early today after 54 hours of freedom, was placed in a "maximum custody" section of Brushy Mountain Penitentiary late today as the authorities began an investigation of his escape into the mountains.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Supreme Court today, let stand a lower court's order that basically enforced subpoenas against seven big oil companies in an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of shortages of natural gas.

ALBANY, June 13 The State Senate approved today a one-year extension of emergency financial assistance to the state's five largest cities outside of New York. Camille Perkins Lavington of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Perkins Jr. of Denver, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Louis Edgell of New York, president of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications and senior vice president of that corporation. CAMDEN, June 13 Representatives of utilities and business generally opposed today the creation of a new Department of Energy in the state government.

CORONADO, Calif., June 15 In a display of solidarity not always characteristic of its business decisions, the National Basketball Association noted "overwhelmingly" today to take three steps intended to assure survival of the four franchises that entered it from the American Basketball Association a year ago: the New York Nets, Denver, Indiana and San Antonio.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15 Regardless of how long it took, a winner had to emerge from the slow Annapolis-toNewport ocean race and one finally did this afternoon. It was Jacknife, a new light blue 42-foot sloop owned and skippered by Jack Greenberg, a doctor from Miami.

WASHINGTON Antitrust lawyers in the Justice Department, in private practice and in Congress have been shaken by a Supreme Court decision last week that the lawyers see as weakening the antitrust laws as a deterrent to pricefixing.
Muhammad Ali traveled around town with Percy E. Sutton yesterday to help attract attention to the voter-registration drive that is the key to Mr. Sutton's mayoral campaign.
TRENTON, June 15 The continued drought in California, where many of the country's vegetables are grown, has caused some food processors to take a new look at New Jersey.

DETROIT, June 15 In what has been criticized as a flagrant case of credit card "redlining," a Detroit couple with an annual income of $50,000 has been denied a Mobil Oil Company credit card because the couple lives in Detroit and because the husband's occupation was not considered a good credit risk.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 15 Richard Remsen Jr., the former squash racquets star who has been playing on Long Island's golf courses since he was 8 years old, reached another milestone in his sports career today. Now 57, he won his first senior golf tournament.
YONKERS, June 15 This is a story of three men on a horse. The horse is Big Towner, a 3-year-old pacer who cost $5,700 and will be racing Saturday night in the $286,500 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

The number of serious fires in New York City has jumped 40 percent since 1974 and civilian deaths in fires in the city are running at a 35 percent greater rate this year than last, Fire Department records show.

TRENTON, June 15 The former superintendent of Trenton State Prison, Alan R. Hoffman, is under investigation by a state grand jury on suspicion of trying to plot the murder of an inmate, it was reported today.
For Stanley and Carl Sherman, Brooklyn College's 52d commencement yesterday forged a further link between two generations Mr. Sherman and his son, Carl received bachelor's degrees in accounting.
WASHINGTON, June 15 The Supreme Court reversed by a vote of 5-to-4 today an Illinois Supreme Court order barring a Nazi-styled political party from parading and pamphleteering in a Chicago suburb.

The credit markets, which had advanced since last Thursday in a move strong enough to push long-term interest rates to their lowest levels in more than three years, paused yesterday, and most Government securities fell in price.

COLMENAR VIEJO, Spain, June 15 The people pushed excitedly into the polling station in a modern school here, but few took any of the dozen different ballots laid out on a table or used the one curtained booth.
The National Football League, at the end of its two-day annual meeting, discovered yesterday it could not legislate morality among its owners.

Thelma Foster, Reger Gould, Seth Scholar, Robin Moulds, Christopher Clay and Christy Roberts belong to what has been called "the last oppressed minority." They are children.
SOMERVILLE, June 16--Representatives of public-employee unions said today that they opposed legislation that would require binding arbitration to settle impasses in negotiations.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The Supreme Court ruled today that the jury in a criminal case may be told that an eyewitness had identified the defendant as the perpetrator, even when the police got this initial identification from the eyewitness in a somewhat questionable fashion.

JOHANNESBURG, June 16--At least 11 blacks were wounded today, some seriously, when the police opened fire during clashes that grew out of a commemoration of the anti-Government upheaval that started in a Johannesburg black township and was to sweep others in South Africa last year.
NEW DELHI, June 16--Elections in the politically volatile state of West Bengal have swept the Communist-led Left Front into power.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The Senate today removed an expression of support for President Carter's policy of withdrawing American ground forces from South Korea from a Foreign Relations Committee bill. It also scrapped a proposal for a limited step in the direction of resuming trade with Cuba.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The major figures in the Watergate and related scandals that rocked Washington have scattered in the five years since the break-in at headquarters of the Democratic National Committee. Following is a listing of some of them, their roles in the events and where they are now.

A psychiatrist with offices in Manhattan and New Jersey has been indicted on charges of stealing $50,000 in Medicaid payments between June 1973 and March 1977, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 16--Representatives of 35 nations began discussing rules of procedure today for a review in the fall of East-West cooperation accords adopted two years ago, and the Soviet Union called for a constructive approach without polemics.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 16--Idi Amin, the 258-pound President of Uganda, was reportedly borne for 25 miles on a litter today by British residents of his country, a former British territory.

More needed rain in the growing areas dampened traders' spirits yesterday, and soybean prices closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. The new-crop September beans closed at $7.23 , down from $7.41 a bushel.

A year ago the National Endowment for the Arts released a list of grants to composers. Among names such as Elliott Carter, Gian Carlo Menotti and Virgil Thomson was that of Ken Noda of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He had been awarded $1,000 to compose an opera in three acts entitled "The Rivalry," based on the personal and political life of Andrew Jackson.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday defended the controversial expense-paid world air tour planned by its chairman, Dr. William J. Ronan, and his wife, by citing previous overseas trips by other Port Authority officials and their wives.

BELGRADE, June 16--The Belgrade "conference on security and cooperation in Europe" has begun here in a vast and elegant new building and at a time when cooperation and security between the major powers are not very promising. So the prospects for this conference are not bright, but its purposes are admirable and in some ways unique.

The three Croatians who broke into the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations on Tuesday and shot a chauffeur were charged yesterday with conspiring to seize the Yugoslav delegate to the United Nations as a political hostage.
Paul Sanasardo, whose dance company will perform through Sunday at the Roundabout Theater at 333 West 23d Street, has no trouble explaining what his work is about.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer need not arrange Saturdays off for employees who celebrate their Sabbath on Saturday if to do so the employer would have to incur such costs as overtime pay for others called in as replacements.

The New York Islanders have scheduled a news conference at 12:30 P.M. today, at which they are expected to announce the signing of Goeran Hoegosta, the Swedish national team goalie who performed so brilliantly in the recent world ice hockey championship. Stefan Persson, a defenseman for the Brynas team in Swedish Division I, was also expected to join the Islanders.
The New York City Board of Education voted Wednesday night to schedule a midwinter recess in the school calendar next year in what the board called "an experiment for the purposes of energy saving."

Cornell of Pelham, N.Y. The bride is the daughter also of the late Phyllis Seelye Brawley of White Plains.

Karen Kutsher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Kutsher of New York and Monticello, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Wilson of New Rochelle, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Plaza by Rabbi Samuel Fraint.

NO ONE who keeps up with the concert world can fail to know that Korea has produced a number of instrumentalists and singers of excellent quality. So far, however, we have little knowledge of what composers in Korea are doing.

Marjorie Hope Gross, a designer of junior sportswear for Tomboy International, a division of Domino Inc. in Los Angeles, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas E. Yates, program director of KLOS, ABC-owned FM radio station in Los Angeles.

ALBANY, June 16 (AP)--A bean isn't baked if it's cooked in the can. That is the rule set down in a bill signed into law today by Governor Carey, who said New York State's only bean baker--Grandma Brown's conformed to the new regulations.
LONDON, June 16 (AP)--Gold prices rose again in Europe today after reaching their lowest point since February at the start of the week. The dollar was narrowly mixed.

WASHINGTON, June 16--Manuel F. Cohen, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose reform policies won him the enmity and respect of Wall Street, died at George Washington University Hospital today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and a resident of Bethesda, Md.

WASHINGTON, June 16--Stung by criticism of Middle Eastern policy by American Jews, President Carter has sought in recent days to improve his standing in Israel and to ease apprehension among Israel's supporters here, many of them prominent in the Democratic Party.

Owen McGivern, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, changed his mind yesterday about accepting appointment as "trustee in possession" of Bernard Bergman's Park Crescent Nursing Home.

Frank Crisona, a former Assistant District Attorney and brother of former Judge James J. Crisona of State Supreme Court, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of offering a bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent.
The Camp Fire Girls, founded in New York City in 1910, have closed their national offices at 1740 Broadway and will open new quarters in Kansas City.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)--The number of starts on new housing increased by 1.6 percent in May from April, the Commerce Department said today.

The Carter Administration, which has been pressing for decreased airline industry regulation recently, is now turning its attention to reform of trucking regulation, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said yesterday in Washington.

"We left off the bottoms," a Halston associate explained a few weeks ago when the designer showed his fall collection on Seventh Avenue. That's the collection that goes to stores all over the country. The mannequins almost always wore heavy knitted tights with short tunic tops.

MOSCOW, June 16--Leonid I. Brezhnev, the head of the Soviet Communist Party, was also named chief of state today, becoming the first person in his country to hold both posts simultaneously.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)--The State Department today denied a report that it might cancel or postpone a visit to Japan by a team of nuclear experts scheduled to inspect the Tokai Mura nuclear reprocessing plant.

ABOARD THE BROADWAY LIMITED, June 16--This famous American train is late, two and a half hours late and holding, dawdling across the cornfields of Indiana, or maybe still in Ohio --it is hard to tell.

SINGAPORE, June 16 (UPI)--Sources in the United Nations High Commission for Refugees said today that West Germany had agreed to take 19 of the Indochinese Refugees who have been living on the deck of the tanker Leap Dal. Australia will take "up to 50," the sources said. Switzerland, France, Britain and Austria said that they had also agreed to accept refugees from the ship.

Scoring a big bridge tournament requires a massive arithmetical effort by the officials. To compute the results of a single section of play, the scorer must write on a large sheet more than 350 results and calculate a matchpoint score for each player before adding at least 28 columns of figures. During a national championship, this procedure may have to be carried out 1,000 times.

DETROIT, June 16--The nation's automobile plants are scheduled to build 212,189 cars this week, down 0.8 percent from 213,917 last week because of two small-car factory shutdowns of the Ford Motor Company, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, the industry's statistical service.

Dr. Theodore T. Fox, a cardiologist, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 38 East 85th Street.

The New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday released its monthly margin debt figures, showing that investors, who in the aggregate owe a huge amount to their brokers, increased such borrowings once again. The latest figures are either frightening or no cause for concern, depending on the point of view.

TRENTON, June 16--The state Democratic and Republican Parties began their annual conventions today, with Governor Byrne making an emotional defense of the state income tax, and Senator Raymond H. Bateman telling Republican delegates, "There is a basic lack of faith in New Jersey state government and especially in our Governor."

MOSCOW, June 16--Robert C. Toth, the correspondent of The Los Angeles Times who has undergone 13 hours of interrogation on his sources for scientific news reporting, was told today that he was free to leave the Soviet Union.

A survey of 750 taxicab drivers by the New York Truth Squad, a community service group established in 1960 to study municipal problems, indicated that a large majority of the drivers would favor the elimination of cruising in favor of specified hack stands.
Ten hours a day, six days a week, Joanne Deutsch serves pastrami, corned beef and a hundred other delicacies, with a song in her heart and a tune on her lips.

As everyone knows, the World Trade Center, at the southern tip of Manhattan, has been the site of a number of unplanned, far-out happenings, one only a couple of weeks ago when George Willig scaled the sheer wall of one of the 110-story buildings.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The du Pont family won a victory today when the Supreme Court reversed a lower court's ruling that had prevented the Christians Securities Company from merging into E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company.

OTTAWA, June 16--Restrictions on Canadian imports of clothing, the imposition of which has stirred sharp criticism in the United States, have been extended until June 30, 1978, the Minister of Industry, Jean Chr tien, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The House Ways and Means Committee began modifying today the Administration's proposals to induce industry to burn coal instead of oil and natural gas.

A victory by Tartan's $106.20-for-$2 Posture set the stage for a ninthrace triple payoff of $33,223 yesterday at Belmont Park. The 3-to-1 High Dance and the 92-to-1 Copy Gray, finishing second and third respectively rounded out the winning numbers' combination of 9-4-10.
From opposite sides of the country this week have come two of the most respected quarterly forecasts on the American economy for this year and next, and the similarities are striking.
Saying "I never intended to kill anyone," a 41-year-old unemployed salesman pleaded guilty to one count of murder by arson in last October's fire in a Bronx social club fire that claimed 25 lives.
Both sides in the nursing-home labor dispute accepted a mediator's settlement formula last night, averting a threatened walkout tomorrow by 12,000 employees at 54 nursing homes.

FOR A FEW YEARS now, the more or less annual "Recent Acquisitions" shows at the Museum of Modern Art have held wonderful surprises that we have become a little spoiled in our standards. The Matisse acquisitions have been particularly notable--two powerful and important paintings, "Male Nude" and "Notre Dame," and the 57-foot-long decoupage, "The Swimming Pool"--but there have also been paintings by Braque, Bonnard, Klee, Munch, Picasso and Dubuffet.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The House of Representatives approved today legislation designed to block the Carter Administration's new policy on busing for school desegregation.

THE BIGGEST, certainly the longest, street fair in the world, Americana '77, a kaleidoscope of antiques and crafts, of the ater, dance and food stretching 12 blocks along 52d Street from Ninth Avenue to the East River will burst forth for the third year in a row this Sunday.

A recent dispatch from Moscow suggests that it is no easier to plan a city in the Soviet world of "democratic centralism" than in the American environment of democratic factionalism. This may surprise those who think commercial competition and private speculation are the root causes of inhuman land planning.

The Gannett Company Inc., newspaper group of Rochester, announced yesterday that it had completed its largest single cash acquisition with the purchase of three newspapers in Louisiana for $54.4 million.
In this early stage of its life, the Carter Administration seems to be something of a hybrid on civil liberties --neither entirely careless of them nor particularly devoted to their protection.
How would you compare the destructive force of 11 Pittsburgh Steelers or an entire third grade class with that of a gorilla, locomotive or truck?

CHICAGO, June 16--The United States Steel Corporation agreed today to halt by 1980 the dumping of toxic pollutants from its huge Gary, Ind., works into Lake Michigan and the Grand Calumet River. The steel company, after five years of litigation, also agreed to pay $3.5 million in fines for failing to meet air and water pollution standards of the Environmental Protection Agency and the State of Indiana.

The baseball trade that sent Tom Seaver, the pitching ace of the Mets, to the Cincinnati Reds converted New York into an angry forum of debate in which old friends screamed at one another and lifelong lovers of baseball portrayed the sport as the epitome of greed.

Moses Weintraub, Assistant New York Attorney General, said yesterday afternoon that he was "working right now on extradition papers" for Anthony L. Conrad, the former chairman and president of the RCA Corporation who resigned last Sept. 16 after acknowledging failure to file Federal, state or local income tax returns for five years through 1975.

WHILE the United States, the Soviet Union and most European states meet in Belgrade this week to ex amine the effect of the Helsinki Accords, including the human rights section calling for freer exchange of people and ideas, several books are published here that cast light in the dark corners of literary freedom.

The directors of the financially troubled textile and retailing giant, United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., announced yesterday that they have dismissed George L. Staff as president and chief operating officer. They also approved phasing out the Robert Hall retail clothing division.

New York City said late yesterday that the immediate impact of a federally ordered parking ban would be a loss of all 12,700 on-street parking spaces in the midtown core area of Manhattan--not the 940 spaces it had announced a day earlier. The core area lies between Third and Eighth Avenues, from 34th to 59th Street.

HOUSTON, June 16 (UPI)--About 3,000 members of the homosexual community and their supporters held a candlelight march to a downtown hotel tonight in a peaceful protest against the appearance of the singer Anita Bryant at a lawyers' convention.

ALBANY--New York State, with the help of the United States Department of Agriculture, opened entomological warfare this week against the cereal-leaf beetle. Their big weapon was a flying armada of predatory wasps.
David L. Swasey, a portrait painter, died Wednesday at his Essex, Conn., home. He was 68 years old.

YONKERS, June 16--Yonkers officials today obtained an injunction ordering nearly 450 patrolmen and officers to end their two-day "sick-out" and sought the help of the state-created Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board in the matter.
ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, June 16 (UPI) --The sign over the one-story air terminal reads "Welcome to Grenada--the Isle of Spice."

WASHINGTON, June 16--The oil companies that own the trans-Alaska pipeline reacted angrily today to a Justice Department contention that the fees proposed by the companies were inflated by as much as $900 million a year.
The Yankees vaulted back into first place in the American League East last night as Ron Guidry overcame his ninth-inning jinx and shut out Kansas City, 7-0, at the Stadium.

LAST WEEK, we took it upon ourselves to discuss the top 10 singles, with the list derived from a collation of the sales charts of Record World, Billboard and Cash Box magazines. This week we'll apply the same approach to the top 10 albums. The idea, once again, is to select a random week, look at the best-selling disks in the country, and draw what conclusions we can about the state of music just now.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 16--There once was an Elmer E. Smathers Cup that was awarded to the Long Island Golf Association's amateur champion each year. Confirmation of this comes from George Sands, who said, "I saw it once back in the late twenties or early thirties. But I can't remember seeing it after the Second World War."
With a little help from parents and friends, the pupils at Public School 9 on the West Side presented Mozart's opera. "The Magic Flute" yesterday.
T. Denton Carman could scarcely conceal his impatience. He had asked Lester Lanin to play "The Sheik of Araby" and the orchestra had obliged, and here some reporter was asking him questions.
LACONIA, N.H., June 16 (UPI)--Nathan Brody, a leader in the treatment of alcoholism, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.
SALIX, Iowa, June 12--Every now and then, there is a town that deserves contemplating just because of the troubles it has seen and the way it has dealt with them.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday defended the controversial expense-paid world air tour planned by its chairman, Dr. William J. Ronan, and his wife, by citing previous overseas trips by other Port Authority officials and their wives.
TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif., June 16 (AP)--The Old Woman is made of iron, and at 5,000 pounds is the second largest meteorite ever found in the United States.
OSCAR WILDE'S "The Importance of Being Ernest" contains so many witty and familiar lines that in performance it can tend to sound like a group reading Roget's Thesaurus out loud.
TRENTON, June 16--Angelo Bruno, the reputed Philadelphia-South Jersey organized crime leader, appeared for more than four hours today before the State Commission of Investigation.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16--An ocean race that had few memorable qualities was put to rest here today with the awarding of prizes at the Ida Lewis Yacht Club to those who persevered most successfully on the 475-mile trip from Annapolis to Newport.

ALBANY--New York State, with the help of the United States Department of Agriculture, opened entomological warfare this week against the cereal-leaf beetle. Their big weapon was a flying armada of predatory wasps.
It was the first morning of No Parking on the block of Broadway between 57th and 58th Streets and Anthony Villani was pretty hot about it.

Miriam Beckman Spotnitz, an instructor at the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies and former director of the Manhattan office of the Jewish Board of Guardians, died Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She lived at 41 Central Park West and was 66 years old.

Isaiah E. Robinson, longtime member of the New York City Board of Education, has responded to criticism of the city school system with a strongly worded letter that he said yesterday was designed to save the schools from an "orgy of disparagement."
Natural gas stocks ranked as prominent gainers yesterday as the general market overcame its early weakness to finish with a moderate recovery.
OTTAWA, June 16 (AP)--Finance Minister Donald Macdonald today criticized the United States Congressional investigation of uranium marketing and called on President Carter to halt it.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)--President Carter announced today that he had chosen Donald L. Tucker of Tallahassee, Speaker of the Florida House, to be a member and vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

PETROS, Tenn., June 16 (UPI)--A guard who allegedly was either reading or "looked the other way" when James Earl Ray and five companions went over the wall at Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary was dismissed today for negligence.
LONDON, June 16--Who is Hank Pfister, and what is he doing beating Marty Riessen, Stan Smith, Ilie Nastase and Roscoe Tanner all in one week?

THE METROPOLITAN Opera's annual series of concert per formances in local parks is given this year to two operas by Giacomo Puccini. Tuesday's opener of "Tosca" in Central Park was afflicted with problematic weather. On Wednesday, for "La Boheme in Staten Island's Clove Lakes park, the weather was very nice indeed. And the Met responded with a nice, tidy performance.

TULSA, June 16--Little Doris Denise Milner came home for the last time today inside a short white coffin that was carried into the church two blocks from the home she left last Sunday on her way to summer camp.
VILLAS, June 16--Michael P. Flanigan, 20-year-old carpenter's helper in this Cape May County community, leaves tomorrow for Rome to participate in the canonization on Sunday of Bishop John Neumann.

On the night Pat Zachry took Tom Seaver's old Met locker and Tom Seaver's place in the Met rotation, the pitcher obtained in the trade for Tom Seaver had to wake up from a pregame nap at Shea Stadium and explain that, no, he did not have a sore arm.
Ever since a four-acre playground opened 20 years ago in the Ridgewood section of Queens, it has had the care of a major league ball field. Maybe better.

BONN, June 17 In a major concession to President Carter, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt announced today that West Germany would no longer export sensitive nuclear technology that can be used to produce atomic bombs.

GENEVA, June 17 Brig. Gen. JeanLouis Jeanmaire, 67 years old, retired commander of Switzerland's civil defense troops, was sentenced today to 18 years' imprisonment and stripped of all military titles for having passed Swiss defense secrets to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON A scientist at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., has developed a method that he asserts will triple the life of the magnetic heads that record television pictures on, or play them back from, magnetic tapes in commercial broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The Supreme Court issued a 5-to-3 ruling today in a New York homicide case that may make it easier for states to shift part of the burden of proof on some issues from the prosecution to the defense.

Although John Cranko has been dead four years now, his spirit still reigns supreme, if only as an inspiration, over the company he founded and fostered, the Stuttgart Ballet. On Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House we had two ballets that were homages to Cranko, Glen Tetley's "Voluntaries" and, having its New York premiere, Kenneth MacMillan's "Requiem."
"If you treat a child as he is, he'll stay like he is. If you treat him as what he can become, then he will show growth."

LONDON, June 17 The Labor Government of Prime Minister James Callaghan has lost the power to impose its vision of the future on the United Kingdom. It is administering, with the help of the civil service, the laws already on the...
OLD WILL Ofcourse, in the English language, Shakespeare triumphed with the word "So all my best is dressing old words new, Spending again what is already spent." (Sonnets, LXXVI.)

WASHINGTON, June 17 In an atmosphere of some confusion, the House Ways and Means Committee approved in principle today a scaled-down version of the Administration's plan to induce utilities and factories to switch from oil and natural gas to other fuels, chiefly coal.

Officials of the National FoundationMarch of Dimes are growing increasingly concerned over "an alarming" increase in the number of cases of German measles being reported. They say that during the first 22 weeks of the year there was a 73 percent increase in the number of cases reported to the Center for Disease Control compared with last year.

CHICAGO, JUNE 17 The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, holding its annual meeting in Chicago for the first time yesterday, gave stockholders a free pound of coffee and announced its first cash dividend since November 1974.

In a long-expected shift of power, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved the resignation of Dr. William J. Ronan as chairman and named Commissioner Alan Sagner of New Jersey to succeed him.

New York City's Environmental Protection Administrator said yesterday that the city had no alternative clean-air plan despite Mayor Beame's earlier insistence that there was such a plan and that it would make the Manhattan parking ban unnecessary.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 17 Gene Francis, just about the best amateur golfer in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, did very little wrong today, and when he made a mistake the ball bounced his way. The combination made him unbeatable during the first two rounds of the Long Island Golf Association's 54th amateur championship at the Huntington Crescent Club.
MADRID It is proper that Spain's first free elections in 41 years were dominated by three young men because this is now Europe's most youthful country. About two-thirds of its population is under 40.

At first glance, the action of the Gulf Oil Corporation in joining a world uranium cartel seems to be an extension of the company's inability to tell right from wrong. Gulf has already been cited for distributing $5 million in illegal contributions; now it is under grand jury investigation for possible violation of antitrust laws.

The 37,143 fans who showed up in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium last night must have thought it was a replay of the Bicentennial fireworks from the way the home team made the cannons go off in an 11-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 17 A parliamentary maneuver by pro-abortion forces led today to a vote by the House of Representatives to prohibit the one remaining legal use of Medicaid funds to finance abortions to save the life of the mother.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) The dollar rose in value today against six European currencies while the price of gold in Europe dropped.
WHTE PLAINS, June 17 Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, one of the strongest women competitors in the area, won her third Women's Metropolitan Golf Association match-play championship today.
Francis X. Giaccone, a former State Supreme Court justice, died yesterday at his Mineola, L.I., home. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) An unpublished statistical study by Canadian scientists shows a link for the first time between the use of artificial sweeteners and an increased risk of bladder cancers in men, a spokesman for the United States Food and Drug Administration said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 17-A tradition died a gentle death on the lawns of the British Embassy last night, its passing eased with strawberries and cream, blooming hats, and a slightly pregnant and very affable princess speaking the "polite, meaningless words" that are traditional, too.
Wernher von Braun, the master rocket builder and pioneer of space travel, died of cancer Thursday morning. He was 65 years old.
At one time, they were delicately sprinkled with cologne and used to fan, flutter and flirt. Lace-trimmed handkerchiefs were as basic as white gloves in the wardrobe of any well brought-up woman.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The Environmental Protection Agency approved today a thermal discharge system for the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant, ending a two-year dispute and clearing the way for further construction of the plant.

Dr. Benjamin W. Lee, head of the theoretical group at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab) in Batavia, Ill., and an internationally known physicist, was killed Thursday in a highway accident. He was 42 years old.

A little over two decades ago the late Sewell Avery, the crusty old chairman of Montgomery Ward Company had piled up so much cash against the onslaught of a depression he was sure would materialize that the nation's second biggest retailer was derisively known on Wall Street as "the bank with the department store front."

Soybean futures for the near July delivery plunged the daily limit of 30 cents a bushel under heavy selling yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The contract closed at $7.58 , off 30 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, June 17 An interview given late last year by Roderick M. Hills, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to a publication that is being sued by the commission is causing both amusement and embarrassment within the S.E.C.

The Emergency Financial Control Board, unable to resolve a continuing disagreement over whether New York City's budget for next year was balanced, yesterday put off consideration of the budget and the city's financial plan for 30 days while it gets another accounting opinion on the dispute.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 A Federal investigation underway here links the fathers of two applicants for an Atlantic City liquor license to organized crime, gambling and loan-shark operations.

NEW HAVEN, June 17 The New Haven Board of Police Commissioners agreed today to open public hearings next Wednesday in its investigation of wiretaps allegedly made illegally by the police between 1965 and 1971.
DETROIT, June 17 The husband of the Detroit schoolteacher who was shot to death in front of her class of first and second graders last fall was convicted here today of second-degree murder.
The New York City administration was accused yesterday by two mayoral candidates of failing to collect millions of dollars in taxes and Federal funds it could get if it operated efficiently.
ALBANY, June 17 Governor Carey today offered a rare public apology to a fellow politician who was the subject of one of the Governor's famous one-liners at his news conference this week.

Amanda Jane Urban, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Urban of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Ken Auletta, a writer for The New Yorker magazine and a weekly political columnist for The Daily News. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pat V. Auletta of Brooklyn.
Avis Inc. gave up yesterday its last ditch legal effort to block a $22 a share tender offer by Norton Simon Inc. for all of the auto rental company's outstanding stock.
EASTBOURNE, England, June 17 Led by Billie Jean King and Chris Evert, the United States easily defeated South Africa, 3-0, today in the Federation Cup and advanced to the final against Australia.

After 15 years at 98 cents, the Clipit, a pocket gadget for clipping coupons and articles from newspapers, finally went the way of all products in an inflation-ridden economy. This spring, the Clipit's retail price rose to $1.19.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) Charles O. Finley sued the National Basketball Association and four former members of the American Basketball Association today, accusing them of a million-dollar default in buying his now-defunct Memphis Tams.
Motion picture issues again were in the spotlight yesterday as the stock market's best-performing group, while prices generally showed only narrow changes.

YONKERS, June 17 With the quest for thoroughbred racing's 1977 Triple Crown now history and Seattle Slew the reigning monarch, the campaign for harness horse racing's version starts tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 13 A national library of human genetic errors is being compiled here at the University of Oregon Health Sciences Center.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) A former official of the Gulf Oil Corporation conceded today that he not only participated in a secret international uranium cartel but actually helped fix prices for the organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 Chaim Herzog, Israel's chief delegate, protested to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today against the exclusion of his delegation from an African-sponsored meeting and called the action sordid and shameful.
DETROIT, June 17-For 30 years or more, the music education programs of the public schools here have been the foundation on which the careers of many of today's top entertainers were built.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Vice President Mondale said today that the United States believed Israel should not be asked to withdraw from occcupied Arab territories unless it could obtain "real peace" from the Arab states.

MOSCOW, June 17 (AP) Robert C. Toth, the correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who was questioned for more than 12 hours by Soviet security police in the past week, left the Soviet Union today with his family.
Mayor Beame's first steps toward implementing a wide parking ban in midtown Manhattan have resulted primarily in incoherence and confusion, most of which seems to have been created by City Hall.

Deborah Jean Kadison, daughter of Mary M. Kadison of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and Herbert Kadison of New York, was married yesterday to Allan McKevlin Bryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Bryan of Columbia, S.C. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's parents by Douglas F. Dent of Greenville, S.C., a notary public.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 A Federal investigation underway here links the fathers of two applicants for an Atlantic City liquor license to organized crime, gambling and loan-shark operations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 17 Yugoslav human rights proponents, who had been led to hope that many political prisoners here would be freed to coincide with the opening of the Belgrade conference on East-West cooperation, say they are bitterly disappointed.

The Public Broadcasting Service will air a repeat tomorrow night of last weekend's NBC afternoon program on which the issue of human rights was debated by three prominent Americans and three English-speaking citizens of the Soviet Union.
Robert Middleton, a longtime actor in motion pictures and on television and the Broadway stage, died Tuesday in Encino, Calif. He was 66 years old.
Amanda Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Henderson of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Frederick Cannell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Best Cannell of New York.

The Aluminum company of America, the nation's largest producer, announced yesterday that it would increase its price for unalloyed primary aluminum ingots by 2 cents a pound to 53 cents a pound, effective with shipments ib ir after July 5. Alcoa said the increase was needed to offset rising costs of energy, materials, labor and services.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 The two new 12-Meter yachts, Enterprise and Independence, will start the America's Cup summer tomorrow when they race against each other on Rhode Island Sound. The third yacht, Courageous, will be given the day off by the America's Cup Committee, but she will be out on Sunday to race Enterprise. The Monday pairing is Courageous and Independence.

WASHINGTON, June 17(AP) Senate and House conferees agreed today on a $36.1 billion measure authorizing military weapons procurement and research.
