WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) President Carter endorsed today the efforts of a private committee to build a Jewish cadet chapel at the United States Military Academy.

Dorothy Brandon, who began a career in the newspaper business running copy on a Philadelphia newspaper at the age of 15 and was an award-winning foreign correspondent for the old New York Herald Tribune for many years, died Wednesday after a long illness at Beekman-Downtown Hospital after a long illness. She was 78 years old.

BONN, June 17 In a major concession to President Carter, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt announced today that West Germany would no longer export sensitive nuclear technology that can be used to produce atomic bombs.

JOHANNESBURG, June 17 Violence in townships outside the city of Uitenhage was reported to have claimed the lives of at least nine blacks including six who were said to have been shot by the police while looting liquor stores and two others who were reported to have burned to death in a fire at another liquor outlet. No cause was given for the death of a ninth man, who was added to the list tonight.
The Consolidated Edison Company and Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union reached agreement last night on a new three-year contract, averting a strike that had been threatened for today.
PRAGUE, June 17 The international Olympic summit meeting approved in principle today a plan to disperse the Games after 1984 among several cities, if that was necessary to avoid financial strain.

The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that toxic and possibly cancer-causing chemicals polybrominated biphenyls, or PBB have been found near manufacturing plants in Staten Island and northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 17(AP) The 14th annual Japan-United States Businessmen's Conference ended today in sharp disagreement on the question of whether the Japanese yen was still undervalued despite an increase of almost 10 percent in the past six months.

TEL AVIV, June 17-Israel's new governing coalition approved a foreign policy program today that Prime Minister-designate Menahem Begin will present to Parliament when he introduces his Cabinet, probably on Monday.

Mary Lucy Colson Deans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Deans Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to David Robinson Lamb, son of Carol Lamb of Oyster Bay, L.L., and Stephen B. Lamb of Port Villa, New Hebrides.

The New York Philharmonic's "Rug Concerts," begun in 1973 as a bargain-priced, youth-oriented summertime series, returned Thursday night after a one-season hiatus made necessary by the rebuilding of Avery Fisher Hall. The posture of the audience was familiar there still were no chairs on the main floor, and people stretched out on foam pillows but just about everything else appeared different.

UNIONDALE, L.I., June 17 Substantial changes in the makeup of the New York Islanders were only beginning today when 23-year-old Goran Hogosta, goaltender for the Swedish national squad and his teammate, Stefan Persson, a defenseman, each signed two year contracts with the Islanders.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The Environmental Protection Agency approved today a thermal discharge system for the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant, ending a two-year dispute and clearing the way for further construction of the plant.
Three men who pleaded guilty to participating in a multimillion-dollar stock manipulation swindle received suspended sentences today from United States District Court Judge Morris E. Lasker.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Vice President Mondale said today that the United States believed Israel should not be asked to withdraw from occcupied Arab territories unless it could obtain "real peace" from the Arab states.

BOSTON, June 17 In their continuing battle for first place, the Red Sox started a home-run barrage against the Yankees early tonight and by the time the smoke had cleared they won the game, 9-4, and were back on top of the American League East by a halfgame.
Marion Cleveland Amen, daughter of former President Grover Cleveland died Wednesday at her home at 404 East 66th Street. She was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, said today that he had given help "in 1972 or 1973" to Thomas Gambino, the son of Carlo Gambino, the late Mafia chieftain. He described the younger Gambino as a prep school classmate who was "a fine kid," who had no crime record and who was "a victim of prejudice" because of his name.

WASHINGTON, June 17 A tradition died a gentle death on the lawns of the British Embassy last night, its passing eased with strawberries and cream, blooming hats, and a slightly pregnant and very affable princess speaking the "polite, meaningless words" that are traditional, too.

TULSA, Okla., June 17 In 94-degree weather under a scorching sun, Hubert Green, who grew up in Alabama's heat, took the 36-hole lead in the United States Open today with a three-underpar 67 for 136. He was one shot ahead of Terry Diehl, a 27-year-old touring pro from Rochester who was the 1969 New York State amateur champion.
The 63-year-old steamer South American, the last remaining Great Lakes passenger ship, faces a bleak future.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Agency for International Development has temporarily blocked Israel from using $90 million in economic aid to buy two Boeing 747 jumbo jets for El Al Israel Airlines.

Robert Ulich, a philosopher who fled Nazi Germany in 1934 and embarked on a teaching career at Harvard University that spanned more than a quarter of a century, died Thursday in Germany after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 87 years old.

PARIS, June 17 (AP) The InternationalHerald Tribune, responding to rumors that the newspaper planned to move its headquarters from Paris, said in its Saturday issue that it was "hopeful" it could solve production problems here. Noting that the paper and its predecessors had been situated in Paris for 90 years, the statement said: "We want to stay."

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 John Cottone, the United States Attorney for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, said today that his office was investigating the funding practices of the 1976 Presidential campaign of Gov. Milton J. Shapp.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 (Claiming widespread abuses, Edward Sadlowski, who was defeated this spring for the, United Steelworkers' presidency, asked today for a United States Labor Department investigation of the steelworkers' election in the hope of having it overturned.

CHICAGO, June 17 Seven commodities brokers were charged here today in the first phase of a Federal crackdown an illegal prearranged trading that may have cost the Government millions of dollars in tax revenue.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Top-ranking Pentagon officials issued a reprimand this evening to Lieut. Gen. Donn Starry, commander of the V Corps in West Germany, far failing to clear a controversial high school commencement address in that country with superiors before he gave it last week.

WASHINGTON, June 17 In an atmosphere of some confusion, the House Ways and Means Committee approved in principle today a scaled-down version of the Administration's plan to induce utilities and factories to switch from oil and natural gas to other fuels, chiefly coal.

The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that toxic and possibly cancer-causing chemicals polybrominated biphenyls, or PBB have been found near manufacturing plants in Staten Island and northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 17 A parliamentary maneuver by pro-abortion forces led today to a vote by the House of Representatives to prohibit the one remaining legal use of Medicaid funds to finance abortions to save the life of the mother.

ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, June 17 President Carter's policy toward Latin America is angering many governments in the area as much for its neglect of economic issues as for its emphasis on human rights, according to delegates to an Organization of American States meeting here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 President Carter scored one of his most important victories of his term this week on Capitol Hill, but he is still far short of forming a solid base of support in Congress to insure succes for his major programs.
WASHINGTON, June 17 The Interstate Commerce Commission, today ordered railroads to report annually who controls them, and the outside affiliations of their officers.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) Americans' personal income rose six-tenths of a percent in May, a smaller increase than the month before, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

MADRID, June 17 Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez said tonight that as a result of his party's victory in Wednesday's parliamentary elections, King Juan Carlos had told him to remain in his post and that he was proceeding with the formation of a new government.
HAVERFORD, Pa., June 17 (AP) Haverford College has received a $4.2 million bequest from the estate of a Philadelphia investment banker, the college has announced.

In a long-expected shift of power, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved the resignation of Dr. William J. Ronan as chairman and named Commissioner Alan Sagner of New Jersey to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) Much Christian understanding of homosexuals is built on "questionable interpretations of Scripture," according to a study made public today by the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ).

THE HAGUE The abortion clinic on 134 Van Beverningkstraat in The Hague is a lot quieter now than it was two years ago when the small, 20-bed clinic was performing 60 abortions a day. The number has dropped to 20 a day in the last year, but the proportion of nonDutch women among the patients has continued to rise sharply despite moves revoking antiabortion laws in other countries.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The Federal Reserve Board today took a position favoring commercial banks on the hotly contested issue of their expanded activities in the field of private placement of securities.

THE summer scene is played at Club PierreAlain (known by its nickname, Club Pierre) in Westhampton Beach. Diners framed in the picture-hat curves of wicker peacock chairs sip cocktails and wine from immense glass balloons. The soaring ceiling of the bare barn restaurant reverberates with lively chatter, table-hopping greetings and the nostalgic buzz of fans. White lace and animalprinted cottons frame windows, drape tables and cover walls. Chandeliers flicker and suntans glow in the candlelight.

VALLETTA, Malta, June 19 (Reuters) Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta will open an international conference here tomorrow that has as one of its major themes the elimination of all foreign military bases and fleets in the Mediterranean area.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 19 This is a Father's Day story about Donald Thornton and his daughters, the doctors.

Investors, vexed by public hearings last week concerning the Federal National Mortgage Association, are wondering whether shares of this company can advance as long as Washington attempts to put additional members to be appointed by the President on the board of directors.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) Doctors say they are seeing the effects of television violence on children they treat in their offices.

JERUSALEM, June 19 Foreign Ministry officials said today that Vice President Mondale's speech on the Middle East, which the White House described as an official explanation of President Carter's policy, contained nothing substantially new and was a recitation of "well known positions" that have been enunciated in recent weeks by President Carter.
A widespread pattern of ticket-fixing by New York State judges has been uncovered by the Commission of Judicial Conduct.

MADRID, June 19 Though Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's center-right coalition emerged with the largest number of seats in last week's election, the more significant victor may have been the resurgent Spanish Socialist Workers Party, ...

The entry fee for the low-tar cigarette derby is soaring. Brown Williamson Tobacco, the country's third largest cigarette company, based in Louisville, will be introducing Kool Super Lights nationally on July 5, promising to spend $50 million for advertising and sales promotion during the remainder of the year.

BODO, Norway, June 15 Recently, the Russians, only a short distance from this area of northern Norway, fired two unarmed ballistic missiles into an area of the Barents Sea where fishing rights are claimed by both Norway and the Soviet Union.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 19 (AP) Amid exceptionally tight security, Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion, wed Veronica Porche in a private civil ceremony today. The wedding, in the ballroom of the Beverly Wilshire, was attended by 200 friends and relatives.

Representative Mario Biaggi has decided not to run for Mayor of New York, friends of the Bronx Congressman said yesterday. They said he would announce the decision at a news conference he has called for this morning at City Hall.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 19 When Phyllis Wachtel tried to return to her Scarsdale home after a trip to the bakery this morning, she discovered she couldn't get back on her block.

JERUSALEM, June 19 Foreign Ministry officials said today that Vice President Mondale's speech on the Middle East, which the White House described as an official explanation of President Carter's policy, contained nothing substantially new and was a recitation of "well known positions" that have been enunciated in recent weeks by President Carter.

Elizabeth Barbara Berkowitz, a graduate student in biology at New York University, and Robert Steven Schwartz, who is completing studies for a master's degree at the N.Y.U. Graduate School of Business Administration, were married at noon yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Spevak performed the ceremony at the Electchester Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 19 A 17-month investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into possible fraud surrounding New York City's financial crisis has been delayed because the S.E.C. has had difficulties in obtaining detailed information from some of the banks that bought and sold city securities as the crisis developed, according to sources close to the investigation.

About 750 New York City police officers now holding desk and support jobs will soon be shifted to active law-enforcement duties as a result of the scheduled hiring of 1,000 civilian employees with Federal funds.
TRENTON, June 19 After a recess of nearly a month, the New Jersey Legislature returns to work tomorrow to face a possible strike by state employees and to debate a controversial energy proposal.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 19 Despite a tight news blackout imposed by the Angolan Government, it is becoming evident that an attempted coup in Luanda last month was a serious uprising that involved army units, left many dead and sharply rocked the precarious unity of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
Shortcomings in the state's administration of Medicaid are adding $400 mil- lion a year to the cost of the program in New York City, a special mayoral panel asserted yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, England Using a new arsenal of chemical manipulations, scientists here and in several other laboratories are "reading" with increasing rapidity the genetic messages that control all life processes of an organism, from its origins until its death.

Moscow, June 19 (AP) The Soviet Union accused the United States today of preparing "for a new dangerous spiral in the arms race" under the pretext of protecting the West and guaranteeing human rights around the world.

Hubert Green won the United States Open golf championship by one stroke yesterday in Tulsa, Okla. He shot a 70, even par, on the last round for a 72hole total of 278. Lou Graham was second, and Tom Weiskopf was third with 281. Green's victory gave him the first major championship of his sevenyear career.

ORANGE, N.J., June 19 (UPI) Assemblyman Richard J. Codey, Democrat of Orange, received a $10,700 check from the National Broadcasting Company this weekend, apparently mailed as a result of a computer error.

PRINCETON, June 19 The little train that once carried F. Scott Fitzgerald's jaded flappers to Princeton weekends was full of women yesterday morning. As they alighted, however, they were met not by silkly undergraduates but by a waiting taxicab driver who greeted them with cries of, "Hi, girls, are you here for the women's lib?"

Next time you get a headache, you can take any one of a number of pills, each promising more pain relief than the next one. Or you can have a cup of chamomile tea, laced with basil, lavender, rosemary flowers and a touch of thyme.

WASHINGTON, June 19 As the oil from Alaska's North Slope begins moving through the 799-mile pipeline tomorrow, two fundamental questions remained unanswered: How much will it cost to put it through the pipeline and who will get the oil?

The United States Treasury, which had expected to pay off about $2 billion of the national debt during the three months ending June 30, will end up reducing the debt by some $7 billion, credit market analysts now predict. More than $1 billion will be paid off this week alone.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 19 The record shows that Gene Francis, a former all-America golfer from Purdue, today tied Frank Strafaci's record of winning the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship five times. The 38-year-old Francis, who won for the second straight year, feels differently.

BOSTON, June 19 The Yankees restored a semblance of harmony to their dugout today, but the Red Sox shattered the peace on the field, handing New York yet another Fenway Park trouncing, this time by a score of 11-1.
Louie Ann Enos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Enos of San Rafael, Calif., became the bride yesterday afternoon of Robert Charles Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Klein of White Plains.
SEATTLE, June 17 Some mysterious cases of sudden infant death may be caused by accidental botulism poisonings, a report to a scientific meeting here suggests.

WASHINGTON (UPI) Jim Wright, the House majority leader, said today that he expected President Carter to sign a compromise bill allowing survival of a number of water projects he wanted to delete. Mr. Wright said he did not expect the President to veto the legislation, as he has threatened, when it comes out of Congress.
A widespread pattern of ticket-fixing by New York State judges has been uncovered by the Commission of Judicial Conduct.
Hanna Ellen Bloomfield, daughter of Dr. and and Mrs. Morton W. Bloomfield of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Bennet Rubins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rubins of Kansas City, Mo.

Most of the audience at the New Yorlt Philharmonic's Rug Concert Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall jumped up from their foam rubber cushions after Franck's Symphonic Variations to give the piano soloist, Ken Noda, a standing ovation. This was partly because Mr. Noda had played the tricky piece with considerable aplomb and dexterity, but also because he is only 14 years old.

Ellen Kay Schwartz, daughter of Shirley Dinitz and the late Murray Schwartz, was married yesterday to Edward Mark Spiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Spiro of the Bronx. The ceremony was performed in the Central Synagogue by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman.

To more than a million strollers it was, as Mayor Beame put it, the "biggest block party in the world." To young mothers attempting to ferry children through near-standstill crowds, it was an occasion for hysterical screaming. And for 5-year-old Bradley Smith of Chatham, N.J., it was almost as good as the circus.

Victoria Erin Towns, a staff writer with House Beautiful magazine, and Alan Harris Kupferberg, a student at the Brooklyn Law School, were married yesterday in the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, the chaplain, officiated.

WASHINGTON, June 19 Intelligence reports say that President Park Chung Hee of South Korea curtailed allegedly illegal Korean lobbying operations here early this year after a senior Korean intelligence officer defected and began talk -ing to Federal investigators, according to sources who have seen the reports.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

LOS ANGELES If and when a national market system for trading securities goes into operation, among the beneficiaries will be the regional stock exchanges that now compete relatively unsuccessfully with the New York Stock Exchange for a share of the action.

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., June 19 (AP) Firefighters held a line on the north side of a 10,000-acre blaze late today, apparently ending the threat to the research center where America's first atomic bomb was developed.
