Doctorow in his introduction to "The Crowned Cannibals": "the Lieder of victims of the state. It sings of regimes so repressive as to be fun-house mirror images of civilization. It recounts years of solitary confinement. It tells of pliers for ...

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 19 It is possible that scoring the go-ahead goal in Rockville Centre's 3-to-1 victory over the Glen Rock (N.J.) Rascals at Giants Stadium here today was not the most exciting moment in John Lamstein's life. It is also possible that the sun will not rise tomorrow or that birds will forget to sing.

HACKENSACK, June 19 A pilot project has begun in Bergen County for women who are either bored with their jobs and want to earn more money, or are eager to re-enter the job market now that their children are grown.
WASHINGTON, June 19 John Frisby Morse, a teacher and educational administrator, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

NEW DELHI, June 16 An American resident of India, calling on a government official whom he sees regularly, was surprised to discover the other afternoon that he was no longer required to stop at the desk in the lobby, fill out a form, and then be escorted down the corridor by a guard.

A recent recipe served at a "covereddish" supper was for a Texas sand wich. It consisted of grilled, tender, thin beef slices served in a white flour tortilla with a spicy salsa cruda, the Mexican raw tomato sauce with chilies.
ROME, June 19 (AP) "When he finally announced that Bishop Neumann was now St. John Neumann, it gave me the chills inside," said Michael Flanigan, 20, of Philadelphia.

HAIL, HAIL As small as it is 9.2 acres Bryant Park has a good-sized history. The park behind the New York Public Library dates to 1822 when it served as a Potter's Field. By 1853 the park had evolved sufficiently to be the site of the World's Fair. A Crystal Palace, reproduction of the London structure, was erected for the fair and stood on the site until it spectacularly burned down in 1856.

The task of choosing a successor to Clarence Kelley as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is now under way in earnest. An estimable citizens' commission headed by Irving Shapiro, the chief executive officer of Du Pont has scoured the country and produced a list of five men for the President's consideration. The question that immediately arises is whether these candidates should mark the beginning or the end of the President's own search.

Perhaps the most curious result of the quarterfinal candidates matches was the 6 -5 victory of Lev Polugaevsky of the Soviet Union over Henrique Mecking of Brazil in Lucerne. Polugaevsky won only one game while drawing 11.

American enthusiasts who visit European tournaments cannot improve their master-point holding but they can come away with cash an unfamiliar experience but not an unpleasant one. A Goren group of 20 pairs competed in the Monte Carlo tournament at the end of May and some of the Americans were rewarded for their efforts.

TULSA, Okla., June 19 In a scenario involving a "little gut-stringer" putt on the final green while aware of a telephoned death threat on his life, Hubert Green emerged today as the United States Open golf champion with a par 70 for a 72-hole total of 278, one stroke ahead of Lou Graham.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 Ted Turner's reintroduction to America's Cup yachting was a smashing success today as he sailed Courageous, the "old" 12Meter boat, to two victories over the new one, Enterprise. Turner did it the hard way both times by sailing Courageous from behind and through Enterprise on weather legs, meaning beats to windward. That's hard to do in match racing, one yacht against another.

LAHORE, Pakistan, June 19 (Reuters) Finance Minister Abdul Hafeez Pirzada, a close confidant of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, has said here that the elections agreed to by the Prime Minister and opposition leaders would be held in Pakistan in the first week of October.

CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI) The Cuban Government today declined to issue visas to two United Press International representatives who had planned to visit Cuba this week with a group of businessmen from the Midwest.
The United Negro College Fund said yesterday it had conducted a survey that showed a majority of black students preferred to attend predominantly black colleges.

NANTES, France, June 19 Showing full confidence that he will be governing France next year, Francois Mitterrand won renewed backing from his Socialist Party here today, but the support from its left wing was reserved.
Out with the new, in with the old. That was Manager Joe Torre's strategy for the Mets yesterday, as he rested his latest acquisitions and played the guys Tom Seaver used to pitch for at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission allows utilities to operate everything from a pistachio nut farm to real estate operations, despite a law designed to keep them out of unrelated lines of business, congressional investigators reported today.

PRINCETON, N.J. The Carter Administration has underscored its concerns about the spread of nuclear weapons by deferring indefinitely in the United States all civilian nuclear power activities aimed at the commercialization of a "plutonium economy." Specifically, the President has moved to halt the Clinch River Breeder Reactor Demonstration Project.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 19 (AP) The General Motors Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Company, two American business giants threatened with being blacklisted by Arab states, have been "cleared" after submitting proof they have no dealings with Israel, Arab boycott officials said today.

Wendy Nan Jacobson, daughter of Beverly Jacobson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Julius H. Jacobson of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Tom A. Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bernstein of Scarsdale and New York.

MEXICO CITY National family-planning programs are slowing birthrates in some countries of Latin America, but for the most part population pressures on limited resources of land, water and capital are increasing dramatically.
MACON, Ga., June 19 The worst drought in a quarter of a century has hit the farms of the Deep South, irreparably stunting corn and seriously endangering crops of peanuts, soybeans and hay.

Reforming the New York State tax system to make the state more attractive to business and businessmen will be more costly, complicated and politically difficult than has been assumed by many public and private sector leaders, according to a new study made for Governor Carey.

New York City has won a decision by the state Court of Appeals that averts payments by the city of more than $50 million in potential increases in Medicaid reimbursement for private methadone maintenance clinics retroactive to the start of 1973.
Beset by rival claimants, relatives of Howard R. Hughes have agreed out of court to compose their differences over their shares of the late industrialist's fortune, it was reported yesterday.

Frank Tanana was a 15-year-old high school student in Detroit in 1968 when Denny McLain won his 31 games for the Tigers. Now, almost nine years later, Tanana, also is on a 30-game victory course. The California Angels' 6-foot-3-inch left-hander, took another step in that direction yesterday, blanking the Brewers, 7-0, at Milwaukee County Stadium.
MACON, Ga., June 19 The worst drought in a quarter of a century has hit the farms of the Deep South, irreparably stunting corn and seriously endangering crops of peanuts, soybeans and hay.

Since 1961, the Duke Ellington Society has been giving an annual concert of the Duke's music, played by onetime members of the Ellington band and nonEllingtonians who play in the spirit of the Duke's men. Over the years, the musical colors, the solos and the arrangements of the Ellington repertory have been recreated at these concerts.

A Federal grand jury has begun an investigation into possible arson for fraud in the Bronx, where in recent years entire neighborhoods have been ravaged by fires, first in the South Bronx and more recently in the West Bronx.

LONDON, June 19 It is all new to Tracy Austin. Meeting Arthur Ashe and Ilie Nastase for the first time. Being interviewed on the BBC. Wearing jewelry on the tennis court, "just like all the other girls."

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) An unexpected result of a federally sponsored center for rape victims has been the arrest and conviction of more suspects, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration reported today.
WASHINGTON Why should the spirit of pundits be proud? Here, in ostentatious humility, are a few of the denials, denunciations and diatribes that have come this way in the past month.

Susan Lynn Miller and Alan Rosenthal were married yesterday afternoon in the garden of the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Miller of Little Silver, N.J. Mr. Rosenthal's parents are Mr. and Mrs. M.L. Rosenthal of Suffern, N.Y.
WASHINGTON Why should the spirit of pundits be proud? Here, in ostentatious humility, are a few of the denials, denunciations and diatribes that have come this way in the past month.

Susan Lynn Miller and Alan Rosenthal were married yesterday afternoon in the garden of the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Miller of Little Silver, N.J. Mr. Rosenthal's parents are Mr. and Mrs. M.L. Rosenthal of Suffern, N.Y.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20 Rumors concerning Uganda and its President, Idi Amin, swept Nairobi today in the aftermath of what was reliably reported as "some shooting" two days ago at Entebbe, where Marshal Amin lives.

TRENTON, June 20 The State Assembly approved today the restoration of $14.3 million in automatic raises for some 30,000 state employees, thereby easing the threat of a July 1 strike. The Senate earlier had approved a similar measure.

The people who plan programs for the New York Philharmonic's "Rug Concerts" must be wondering today if they really do understand what impels people to attend these off season events. If they have been relying heavily on the novel ambiance or the comparatively low ticket price to draw the floor-loungers, they were served notice on Sunday night that other factors must be considered.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 16 Tensions have risen throughout the Horn of Africa, spurred by major-power rivalry and a shift in political alignments in this eastern part of the continent.
Twelve nursing-home operators who have recently been convicted of felonies or misdemeanors still operate homes in New York State, health investigators said yesterday.

As a result of the nightclub fire that killed more than 160 persons in Southgate, Ky., last month, New York City fire officials plan to inspect all Manhattan nightclubs, discotheques, restaurants and various other kinds of places where 75 or more people gather for entertainment and amusement, an official said yesterday.

PARIS, June 20 Leonid I. Brezhnev received an elaborate welcome here today on his first visit abroad as President of the Soviet Union, and his first visit to the West since he came to France in December 1974.
Twelve nursing-home operators who have recently been convicted of felonies or misdemeanors still operate homes in New York State, health investigators said yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21 Declaring that the prevention of another war in the Middle East was his primary concern, Menahem Begin, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, early this morning became Israel's sixth Prime Minister.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The United States Navy, under powerful pressure from Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has quietly kept alive a controversial and expensive Navy fighter plane program it had planned to drop.
Carl Roy Keeney, director of industrial relations for the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday in Princeton, Me., where he was on vacation. He was 54 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

PARIS, June 20 The United States and other industrial countries are planning to cooperate more closely in monetary policy as part of their efforts to reduce inflation and restore stable economic growth, according to diplomatic sources.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court decided today that rulings by the Attorney General in two kinds of voting discrimination cases are not subject to direct review in the courts.
LONDON, June 20(AP) The price of gold rose by as much as $1 an ounce in European bullion markets today while the dollar closed mixed in uneventful trading.
A short while ago, George Willett, a spry 85-year-old millionaire with 60 years of investing experience, made an offhand estimate of his stock portfolio.
DETROIT, June 20 Gabe Paul, the president of the Yankees, gave Billy Martin a last-minute reprieve tonight, just when it appeared Martin was on the brink of dismissal as manager of the troubled team.
Merrill Lynch Company, parent corporation of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner Smith, announced yesterday in London an expansion of its commercial banking operations outside the United States.

TRENTON, June 20 The Assembly rejected a recommendation from the New Jersey Health Council and tonight passed by a vote of 62 to 5 a bill to legalize the use of laetrile a controversial substance used as a treatment for cancer in New Jersey. The council had recommended that the bill be defeated.
Two Suffolk County judges have been charged with improper handling of a witness by a grand jury dealing with a dispute between the county's Police Commissioner and its District Attorney.

WASHINGTON The well-dressed audience of several dozen men and women, seated informally around tables in a small meeting room of one of Washington's leading hotels, listened with obvious approval as the speaker concluded the morning's proceedings.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 Two of the five persons indicted in a million-dollar robbery of the Atlantic City post office have agreed to testify against the others in exchange for light sentences, an official said today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 After a reported personal intervention by President Carter, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has admitted Mexican workers to pick crops in southwestern Texas despite a recommendation by the Labor Department that the Mexicans be barred.

Dominick A. Spina, who headed Newark's police force during a recent period of high racial tension, died Sunday at Clara Maass Memorial Hospital, Belleville, N.J. He was 66 years old and a resident of Newark.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) A reporter today asked Zbigniew Brzezinski, head of the National Security Council, what he knew of President Amin's whereabouts. Silently, Mr. Brzezinski made a sign of a cross.
JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21 Minutes after becoming Israel's Prime Minister, Menahem Begin said that his first official act today would be to offer asylum to 66 Vietnamese refugees.

WASHINGTON The two most influential tax legislators in Congress say they are becoming intrigued by the valueadded tax a kind of national sales tax widely used in Europe as a source of money for the ailing Social Security system.

PARIS, June 20 Leonid I. Brezhnev received an elaborate welcome here today on his first visit abroad as President of the Soviet Union, and his first visit to the West since he came to France in December 1974.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 20 A state investigator acknowledged today that a rural Alabama minister who was slain Saturday in the chapel of a funeral home was a prime suspect in the murder of his stepdaughter, whose eulogy he delivered just before he was shot.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that neither the Constitution nor current Federal law requires states to spend Medicaid funds for elective abortions.
Major league baseball games from last Friday to Sunday drew a total of1,073,882 fans, an average of 28,260 fans for each of the 38 dates, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office announced yesterday.

Two sorts of rhythm-and-blues revivalism were on display Sunday at the Bottom Line, with a double bill of Frankie Miller's Full House and the reformed Booker T. and the MGs. Unfortunately neither half of the bill lived up to the highest standards of the revival.

The directors of a museum that was established in Harlem to increase blacks' participation in the city's cultural life are planning to move it out of Harlem because, they contend, the middle-class blacks and whites they had hoped to attract do not want to go there.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) The Supreme Court today rejected a suit from six members of Congress who are trying to stop any treaty between the United States and Panama that would give up United States jurisdiction over the Panama Canal Zone.

A new policy sharply limiting the size, format and type of information contained in the advertising of pornographic films in The New York Times will take effect July 1, according to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that the United States and Britain were "very close" to settling a sharp dispute over aviation rights that could abruptly halt air service between the countries Wednesday.
PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, June 20 One hour late, the trans-Alaskan pipeline opened today, unlocking the wealth of oil that lies beneath the tundra of the continent's North Slope.

Two months have passed since President Carter offered his comprehensive 10-point plan for a national energy policy without any lessening of controversy surrounding it and without any substantial clarification of the type and ...

Accepting tribute as the man who led New York City away from the brink of bankruptcy two years ago. Governor Carey last night cited the low-interest rate of recent state borrowings to illustrate what he described as a collective triumph of the "most massive self-help and self-rescue effort in the history of state and local government."
The Board of Higher Education unanimously re-elected Harold M. Jacobs last night as its chairman for the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Attributing losses of income to the spread of uncontrolled wildcat strikes by angry and often leaderless coal miners, the United Mine Workers union's multimillion-dollar health and retirement trust fund announced today a series of benefit reductions, the first in a decade.

WASHINGTON, June 20 After the reported personal intervention by President Carter, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has admited Mexican workers to pick crops in southwestern Texas despite a recommendation by the Labor Department that the Mexicans be barred.

President Carter is now confronted with the necessity for two decisions, each of which is about as important as any he will make. He has to choose a new director for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, presumably from a list of five names submitted to him by a special commission; and he has to decide whether to appoint a single director for all the various agencies loosely known as "the intelligence community."

ALBANY, June 20 After narrowly defeating an amendment that would have rolled automobile insurance rates back to January levels and frozen them for a year, the Assembly tonight reluctantly approved Governor Carey's proposed revisions to the state's no-fault law.

Shea Stadium finally became the quiet corner of the baseball world last night, far from Tom Seaver and his new teammates, far from the Yankees and their new troubles. And it became even quieter about 9 o'clock when the line of thunderstorms buffeting New York caused the Mets to postpone the opening game of their series against the Atlanta Braves.

Alice Hughes, a newspaper columnist and foreign correspondent, died yesterday at the White Plains Center for Nursing Care. She was 78 years old and had been a resident of the center for several years.

C. Palmer Bateman Sr., father of New Jersey State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, died yesterday at Somerset Hospital, in Somerville, N.J., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

Most industries become apprehensive and resentful when independent commissions are formed to examine their activities and recommend legislation that would create change. But the public broadcasting industry has greeted with enthusiasm the news that the Carnegie Corporation of New York, with the sanction of the White House, has established a commission to study a future course for noncommercial television and radio in the age of satellite communications.

WASHINGTON, June 20 G. Robert Blakey, a professor at Cornell University Law School who is a proponent of the use of wiretapping in the control of organized crime, was named today to be chief counsel and staff director of the House Select Committee on Assassination.
PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, June 20 One hour late, the trans-Alaskan pipeline opened today, unlocking the wealth of oil that lies beneath the tundra of the continent's North Slope.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that states may deny welfare benefits to the children of fathers who are dismissed for misconduct, go on strike or quit work.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Commerce Department, revising its estimate upward for the second time, said today that the economy grew at a rate of 6.9 percent in the first quarter.
TRENTON, June 20 The State Supreme Court reaffirmed today a fouryear-old ban against out-of-state garbage dumping in New Jersey that has not been enforced since the 1973 law was enacted.

The directors of BBDO International yesterday elected Bruce Crawford, the 48-year-old president, the chief executive officer. He replaced Tom Dillon, 62, who had held that title for a decade. Mr. Dillon, who continues as chairman, is still chief executive of the domestic company, Batten, Barton Durstine Osborn.

In 1975, three-quarters of our energy demand was met by oil and gas resources that will soon be too scarce to serve as the backbone of our energy supply system. The United States Energy Research and Development Administration has been spending billions of dollars to investigate alternative technologies which may be common by the end of the century.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today urged Congress to permit banks in all 50 states to pay interest on checking accounts and similar deposits, but clashed over the degree of flexibility the Federal Reserve should have in dealing with a companion provision in the Administration's principal piece of financial reform legislation.

WASHINGTON Robert L. Herbst, the Interior Department's new Assistant Secretary for Fish and Wildlife and Parks, believes that most waterfowl hunters will accept the gradually expanding ban on lead shot with good grace and understanding.

Arab League officials wound up a 12day meeting in Alexandria, Egypt yesterday, adding 12 companies to the Arab boycott list, including five American companies for the first time, according to League sources.

KINGSTON, Jamaica Men claiming devotion to Rastafarianism, a 47-yearold Jamaican-born sect espousing peace and love that is rapidly being spread to England, Canada and the United States by emigrating Jamaicans, have been trafficking in drugs and committing assaults, robberies and murder in New York City.

Strong sales of videotape recorders and the sharp increase in equity earnings of affiliates lifted the consolidated net income of the Sony Corporation 30 percent to $36 million, or 17 cents per American depositary share for the quarter ended April 30, it was reported yesterday. (Each A.D.S. represents one common share.)

LOS ANGELES, June 20 Christopher John Boyce, who was convicted April 26 of spying for the Soviet Union while operating a code room for the Central Intelligence Agency, today was ordered to undergo 90 days of psychiatric tests before final sentencing.

BELLEVUE, Wash. The drama called "Watergate" began five years ago and today it may be over and done with in a lot of places, but here on the shores of Lake Washington, it is still going on. It is here in the silence and emptiness of a 75-year-old house. It is here in the pain, and the serenity that vibrate through everything Jeanne Fisher Ehrlichman, Mrs. John D. Ehrlichman, once of Washington and Watergate, says.

PETROS, Tenn., June 20 (UPI) James Earl Ray would he in "grave danger" from those who want to keep secret the details of the Rev. Martin Luther King's assassination if he is transferred to a Federal prison, Mr. Ray's attorney said today.

Steel production for the week ended June 18 fell 2.6 percent to 2.6 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday, marking the third consecutive weekly decline since output hit this year's peak of 2.8 million tons in the week ended May 28.

The Treasury, in a move aimed at extending the average maturity of the national debt and thereby making it more manageable, disclosed yesterday that it planned to sell a 15-year, $1.5 billion bond issue next Tuesday in place of the five-year notes it has been marketing every three months.

The Boston Red Sox, just finished with a weekend massacre of the Yankees, continued their assault on the American League East contenders last night by downing the second-place Orioles in Baltimore, 4-0, behind the two-hit pitching of Rick Wise.

TRENTON, June 20 The State Senate created a special committee today to investigate the amount of natural gas that will be available for New Jersey next winter. The committee has the power to subpoena the books and records of the various utilities.

The United States Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for a new trial for a man convicted in New York of murdering two brothers during a robbery in 1968. The court ruled that the trial judge erred by not allowing the defense to call a witness who had previously confessed to the murders.

The Rev. Leon Sullivan, minister of the Zion Baptist Church in North Philadelphia, disclosed yesterday that 21 more United States companies operating in South Africa had endorsed six principles "aimed to end segregation" and to "promote fair employment practices" for their black and non-white employees in South Africa.
Bella S. Abzug urged yesterday a commitment to free tuition at the City University, but stirred some confusion about the specifics of the commitment she called for.
WASHINGTON, June 20 President Carter urged Congress today to reduce Government regulation of airline routes and fares, saying it would step up competition and make air travel cheaper.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 Ted Turner won two more races at the America's Cup trials today with Courageous beating his teammate, Ted Hood, in Independence by margins of 67 and 47 seconds after 21 miles of yacht racing under ideal conditions. Those were sound trouncings and if the America's Cup had to be defended next week rather than in September, Turner and Courageous would be the ones selected to do the job.

CHICAGO, June 20 The $47.7 million civil damage suit against police officers who participated in the 1969 raid on a Black Panther Party residence in which two Black Panthers were killed was dismissed today after a Federal jury was unable to reach a verdict in the case.
LONDON, June 20 Some British officials expressed confidence today that there would be something to sign before the present agreement expired.
MOSCOW, June 20 (AP) Arrests, searches and new fiscal regulations have almost crippled a fund established by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to aid Soviet political prisoners.

Fairfax Mastick Cone, one of the country's best known advertising men, but a frequent critic of some elements of his own industry, died yesterday after a long illness in his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 74 years old.

Operators Threaten to Shut 66 Homes for the Elderly In Dispute Over Payments The operators by 66 old-age homes in New York City and Nassau County threatened yesterday to close the homes on July 1 because state officials had failed to meet with them on proposals for increased reimbursement for residents in the Supplemental Security Income program.
JERUSALEM, June 20 Following are the names of officials taking major positions in Israel's new coalition Government, led by the right-wing Likud bloc:

Naturally George Balanchine is taken for granted, so are Fifth Avenue and the Bronx Zoo. One day we will indeed be sorry. Meanwhile, we treat this still unfinished portrait of the artist as an old man with a pleasantly surprising lack of reverence. Mr. Balanchine would want it that way yet he is remarkable, an act of nature set to choreography.

HONG KONG, June 20 As nearly every Chinese school child now knows, Hua Kuo-feng is Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. But more and more, it appears, the man who helped put him in that post and who ...

MEDFORD, June 20 State officials said today they had been swamped with offers from farmers in four communities of Burlington County who wish to sell development rights to their property to the state and thus maintain the area as an agricultural preserve.

The directors of the Council on Foreign Relations have elected Winston Lord, a close associate of former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, as the council's new president, effective this fall when Bayless Manning retires after six years in the post.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Carter Administration will shut down all 10 regional offices of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration in September, eliminating nearly one-fourth of the agency's 850 jobs.

A hearing to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has acted unreasonably or discriminated against the Concorde supersonic airliner has been set for July 12, according to lawyers in the dispute who met with Judge Milton Pollack yesterday in his chambers in Federal District Court House in Manhattan.

DETROIT, June 20 For at least three or four years, according to state and Federal wildlife officials, unlicensed "renegade" fishermen on Lake Michigan have been illegally netting lake trout contaminated by the toxic chemical PCB and selling them as table fare for unsuspecting consumers in New York, Detroit and Chicago.

JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21 Declaring that the prevention of another war in the Middle East was his primary concern, Menahem Begin, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, early this morning became Israel's sixth Prime Minister.

LONDON, June 20 Fifty years after they brought the Davis Cup to France for the first time with a victory over the United States, the Four Musketeers are well and as spirited as ever. They attended the 100th Wimbeldon celebration today "as a block."

WASHINGTON, June 20 A Senate delegation gave a divided reportt yestetron whether Israel should be permitted to buy two American nuclear reactors without first permitting international control over its top-secret facility at Dimona, which is rumored to be the source of a dozen or more Israeli nuclear weapons.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 20 A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that water rates charged by the City of Long Beach were not unreasonable, but that the manner of billing residents for water and sewage service was illegal.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that neither the Constitution nor current Federal law requires states to spend Medicaid funds for elective abortions.

Although copper futures prices rose a moderate 0.70 cent a pound yesterday, the action came as a surprise to many traders in that market. The reason was that the gain extended what traders thought was an abnormal one-day advance last Friday.

CAPE TOWN, June 20 (AP) Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, a pioneer in heart transplant surgery, implanted a baboon's heart in the body of a human tonight, but the recipient died hours after the operation, Groote Schuur hospital announced.
Richard Hyde, chief engineer of operations at CBS News, died on Sunday at the New Brunswick (N.J.) General Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in East Brunswick.

GENEVA, June 20 Arab countries today staged a new anti-Israel maneuver in the annual assembly of the Internationa Labor Organization despite warnings by the United States that continued political actions might impel it to go through with its announced intention of quitting the agency.

The sense of freedom now is in going the wrong way, in going back out on the water from Manhattan over to Ellis Island, where the cavernous immigration buildings stand turreted and tired as an old amusement park.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 19 Boatloads of Vietnamese refugees are landing along the east coast of Malaysia almost every day, and how many are pushed back out to sea by police, navy and immigration authorities will never be known.

An arbitrator has approved the New York City Police Department's plan to begin using one-man radio-car patrols and its current duty chart requiring police officers to work 10 additional days a year, despite the opposition of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, official sources said last night.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The United States Navy, under powerful pressure from Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has quietly kept alive a controversial and expensive Navy fighter plane program it had planned to drop.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Senate Appropriations Committee, taking its cue from the House of Representatives, voted today to prohibit the Carter Administration from implementing a new policy to use busing to desegregate public schools.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 Philip Griffin of the host Cedar Point Yacht Club held a one-point lead today after the first three races in the 26th annual men's Long Island Sound championship for the Commodore Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy. The competition opened in a light southerly breeze in the bay off the club.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 The leadership of the American Medical Association said today that the criticisms of their professon and warnings of more Federal controls made yesterday by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare had disturbed only a few convention delegates.
Last year, the evening fabric of the minute was tafetta. It rustled. For this fall and winter, it's satin. It shines.
LONDON (UPI) Vintage Imports, a Miami-based wine company, paid $3,816 at Christie's wine auction Thursday to import a single bottle of 1929 vintage Chateau Mouton Rothschild wine.

The Philadelphia Eagles and Mike Boryla have worked out an agreement under which Boryla, an unhappy 26year-old quarterback, will be traded. Boryla had declared that he was a free agent because an option-renewal letter had not been sent him by May 1, the deadline set up by the national Football League.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 When he was a young man in his early 70's, 15 years ago, George Morton Levy used to hustle Bobby Riggs on the golf course.
DETROIT, June 20 Just after the Yankees resolved their managerial problems here tonight, at least temporarily, they had the unenviable task of facing Mark Fidrych and the Tigers at Tiger Stadium.
ALBANY, June 20 Savings banks may or may not be for people, but their advertising campaign, in the opinion of the State Attorney Genere, is for the birds.

KINGSTON, Jamaica Men claiming devotion to Rastafarianism, a 47-yearold Jamaican-born sect espousing peace and love that is rapidly being spread to England, Canada and the United States by emigrating Jamaicans, have been trafficking in drugs and committing assaults, robberies and murder in New York City.

TURIN, Italy, June 20 (AP) Steve Williams of San Diego won the 100meter dash tonight in 10.28 seconds in pouring rain to highlight an otherwise mediocre triangular track and field meet among Italy, Britain and the United States.

ROME, June 20 With violence increasing, the Italian Government is moving to restrict the rights of suspects by proposing that the police be allowed to question them without the presence of their lawyers.

MOSCOW, June 20 A 40-ton American super magnet was flown into Moscow today and delivered to a Soviet research facility, opening a new phase of a joint effort to find more efficient ways to generate electrical energy.

BANG, POW, SOCKO! Rodolphe Topffer, a Swiss illustrator, believed that more people can look than read. He drew picture-story books and amassed a collection of drawings, "Histoires en estampes," were forerunners of the comic strip. In America, the 1890's saw the birth of the Yellow Kid, Little Bears and Tigers and the Katenzjammer Kids in Sunday newspapers.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Supreme Court today asked the Government for its view on the 68-year-old legal doctrine that Federal courts do not have jurisdiction in antitrust cases involving official actions of foreign nations.

ALBANY, June 20 The New York Legislature started what its leaders described as a final push toward adjournment today but immediately became bogged down in partisan differences that held off action on major matters.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 20 (Reuters) Japan and the Soviet Union, whose fleets together account for 75 percent of the whales killed each year, today opposed calls for a 10-year moratorium on whaling.
It is now clear that the cheating scandal that disrupted the Italian bridge scene a year ago is having a delayed reaction at the international level.
LONDON, June 20 (Reuters) Bob Woolmer served a century and led a rally by England on the fourth day of the first cricket test against Australia at Lord's today.
BELLINZONA, Switzerland, June 20 (AP) The chief executive of the Swiss canton of Ticino resigned today following public accusations that he was involved in the $880 million Swiss Credit Bank scandal.

ROME, June 20 (AP) Pope Paul VI urged bishops from the United States today to follow the example of their country's first male saint John Nepomucene Neumann and carry out "with ever greater energy" their teaching mission, especially in sexual morality.

The Harkness Theater in the Lincoln Center area has been sold and is being gutted, a victim of harsh economics of the performing arts beyond the Broadway theater district. The theater opened in April 1974 to considerable fanfare as "the first and only major theater in the United States specifically designed for the presentation of dance."

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., June 20 Nearly 1,000 firefighters today struggled for the fourth straight day to contain the stubborn, wind-whipped blaze that has blackened more than 11,000 acres and posed a continuing threat to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, a major Government nuclear research facility.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., June 20 One thing about an A.W. Tilinghast golf course is that the more some folks play on it the more they become skittish and even afraid. That feeling leads to continuous difficulties on the outstanding courses, such as Quaker Ridge, Ridgewood, Baltusrol, Winged Foot and many others constructed by Tilinghast, as golfers try to outthink this architect.

Performing artists put on a show in Bryant Park yesterday in an attempt to help rid the park of its "criminal element." The performers delighted several hundred spectators, including some of the very lawbreakers they hoped to displace.

DETROIT, June 20 For at least three or four years, according to state and Federal wildlife officials, unlicensed "renegade" fishermen on Lake Michigan have been illegally netting lake trout contaminated by the toxic chemical PCB and selling them as table fare for unsuspecting consumers in New York, Detroit and Chicago.
Stock prices advanced moderately yesterday in response to forecasts of strong growth in the United States economy this year and next.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 20 The saga of Breyten Breytenbach, a romantic poet who fell afoul of the South African security police when he joined the antiapartheid underground, developed a curious new twist today when he appeared in a courtroom here accused of having tried to subvert white rule from his prison cell.

For 10 years now, the press has watched with a wary eye the continuing Congressional efforts to enact a new Federal criminal code. The primary concern has been whether a new code would make it more difficult for reporters to cover, or uncover, the activities of government.
Doctor Omniscient answers the mail:
Taking its cue from the illegal numbers game, New York State will offer a new lottery in which players will be able to bet on three-digit numbers they choose themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Department of Justice has refused to help Victor Marchetti, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, seek to dissolve an injunction that prevents him from speaking or writing about classified material that he obtained when he was a C.I.A. employee without first having it cleared by the agency.
Geraldine Brooks, the actress, died Sunday night of cancer at the Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L.I. She was 52 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The House Ways and Means Committee today accepted with minor modifications President Carter's proposals for business tax incentives to encourage fuel conservation and conversion away from oil and gas.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 First came a parade of champions, snubbed by Jimmy Connors. Then Roscoe Tanner lost his super serve when it really counted. And finally, Hank Pfister, last wek's instant hero, fizzled under the strain of the big time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 Preparatory talks for an October meeting on European security and cooperation resumed here today with the Soviet and Western blocs confronting each other over rival proposals for an agenda.

It is probably bad form to ask a major composer who has spent more than half a century creating 39 stage scores, nine film scores, four television scores and assorted other works what he does in his spare time but someone did just that the other day to Richard Rodgers.
ALBANY, June 21 Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and the leaders of the Legislature have opened a major drive to bring the 1984 Summer Olympics to New York City.

A trade exhibit and conference designed to open direct buying in this country by Arab businesses a reversal of the eager selling efforts of American companies in the Middle East opened here yesterday.

FORT SMITH, Ark., June 21 A Federal District Court judge refused today to grant an injunction requested by four adult members of a fundamentalist church who are seeking to block their parents from taking legal custody of them.
MOSCOW, June 21 Paul C. Warnke, the Carter Administration's top arms negotiator, flew into Moscow today to open negotiations with the Soviet Union on demilitarizing the Indian Ocean.

The New York version of the "Philadelphia plan" has gone into effect, with savings bankers saying that the activity it generates will clarify the extent of unmet demand for mortgage credit in the city.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP)-Benjamin H. Anibal, designer of the Pontiac automobile, died Sunday in a suburban Royal Oak hospital. He was 90 years old.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which operates Stern's and Gertz in the metropolitan. New York area, is discussing the possible acquisition of another department-store business, but declined to identify it, other than to say several prospects were being studied, including a Lit store.

Rumors that Manager Frank Lucchesi of Texas would lose his job grew stronger yesterday, despite the Rangers' move into third place in the American League West Monday night with a victory over Minnesota. The Associated Press in Dallas reported a source in Minneapolis with the club as saying Lucchesi would not last the week.

HARTFORD, June 21 Gov. Ella T. Grasso said today that Connecticut, on the strength of a ruling yesterday by the United States Supreme Court, would cease using welfare funds to pay for abortions where there was not an overriding medical need for them.
Steve Cauthen, the riding wonder from Kentucky, was welcomed back to Belmont Park yesterday after a four-week absence from the races because of injuries.

Good times and bad, Ben Fein has been hacking in New York City for 30 years. As far as his driving is concerned, life took a turn for the better three years ago. That was when he bought his first diesel taxi. "I wouldn't trade it for the world," he said the other day.

While overt discrimination appears to have dropped sharply in the hiring of women who hold Master of Business Administration degrees, 10 who recently received their degrees from the University of Chicago reported to the university that discrmination has gone underground into more subtle areas.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) H.R. Haldeman, one of the most powerful men in Richard M. Nixon's White House, went to prison today.

M. Donald Grant made his first appearance at Shea Stadium last night since banishing Tom Seaver from the Met kingdom and lived to tell about it. He also will tell over and over again how he watched Steve Henderson, one of the unknowns he swapped for Seaver, hit a three-run, 11th-inning home run that propelled the Mets to a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
New York's 1973 drug law with its stiff, mandatory sentencing provisions neither reduced drug use nor drug-related crime, a federally financed study concluded yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 21 Hundreds of Uganda refugees were reported by the Kenya News Agency tonight to be streaming into this country, fleeing from what was described as a purge organized in the aftermath of an attempt on the life of Uganda's President, Idi Amin.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Calculations based on Government figures indicate that the industrial states of the Eastern Seaboard and the Middle West would not fare as well under the Carter Administration's proposed revision of the welfare law as would the rural states of the South and West.
THE Kissing Cooties Club, an organization of 9-year-old girls who wore boys' sneakers (the high, black kind) is now defunct.

Leaders of the American electronics industry are bemoaning what they consider a low rate of growth in productivity in the United States. They are attributing this to what they call longterm "malnutrition" of research and development in many parts of industry, including consumer electronics.

BERKELEY, Calif. There are signs here and elsewhere across the country that the youth-oriented religious sects that sprang into existence a few years ago are gaining a foothold for an enduring future.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Supreme Court unanimously rejected today an attempt by the Justice Department to limit substantially the reach of the Fourth Amendment's requirement that the police get warrants before conducting searches.
WASHINGTON, June 21 British-American negotiations for a new treaty on aviation rights were pressed in London tonight in the hopes of averting a possible rupture tomorrow in scheduled airline service.

Berne, Roger 45 June 21st Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for more than two years, suffered a further deterioration yesterday morning, and her parents remained at her bedside in the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains, N.J.

A PHENOMEN unique to the California wine scene is the rise in recent years of the winemaker as celebrity. In most of the world's wine regions, the winemakers toil annoymously among their vats and presses.

The only one of the quarterfinal candidates matches that went into overtime resulted in an 8 7 victory by a former world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, over Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia. The match was played in Iceland, where Spassky lost his title in 1972 to Bobby Fischer of the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, joined 17 teen-agers in cap and gown yesterday to celebrate a school graduation that, for many of them, meant leaving behind a life on New York City's streets.

In the discussions that may soon be held between United States and Cuban representatives, might not our man say a quiet word about Huber Matos? That it would help smooth relations if he were released from jail and allowed to leave Cuba?

Gerald Schoenfeld, head of the Shubert Organization, said yesterday he expected "a better image for Times Square and for New York" to result from a new policy of The New York Times restricting advertising for pornographic films.
Two major food companies the Beatrice Foods Company and the H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday sales and earnings increases in the latest quarter.
Richard H. West, the retired chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday at his home in the Pierre Hotel. He was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 22 Britain and the United States averted a rupture in airline service early today by agreeing on a new pact on aviation rights to replace an agreement in effect since 1946.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21 Frederick E. (Ted) Hood may be at age 50 the best racing sailor in the country, depending upon whom one asks, and he has achieved all sorts of honors on the water including one defense of the America's Cup. Today at the America's Cup trials he had a bad day, Hood and the new yacht, Independence, which he designed, dressed as to sails, and skippers.

It is probably bad form to ask a major composer who has spent more than half a century creating 39 stage scores, nine film scores, four television scores and assorted other works what he does in his spare time but someone did just that the other day to Richard Rodgers.

Governor Carey yesterday threw his weight behind opponents of any drastic street-parking ban in Manhattan. A courtordered ban, parts of which went into effect last Tuesday, "would have a terribly adverse economic impact on the city," the Governor said at an Albany news conference.
night in Memorial Stadium at Baltimore, where the Boston Red Sox smacked two homers and, with Luis Tiant pitching a two-hitter, beat the Orioles, 7-0.

TOKYO June 20 The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater is now staging two weeks of performances in Japan for the first time in 15 years, and it is getting a response unusually enthusiastic from the otherwise docile audiences.
"Brothers! Sisters! I have discovered radio! I have seen the light. Hallelujah!" "Amen! Amen!"

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 22 The Labor Party appeared early today to be retaining its control of Israel's General Labor Federation in an election that is expected to affect the ability of the new coalition of Prime Minister Menahem Begin to carry out its economic and social policies.

In the first investigation by a New York City District Attorney of bill padding and the faking of Blue Cross-Blue Shield bills by dentists, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens yesterday announced the arrest of two dentists.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) New orders for durable goods rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third advance in four months, the Commerce Department said today. The increase represented a rebound from the revised seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in April but was well off the strong 7.5 percent advance registered in March.

A sit-in and hunger strike by 26 women and two men went into its seventh day yesterday in a United Nations office Santiago, Chile. The protesters are dedemanding an investigation of the dispearance of relatives arrested by the Chilarrested by the Chilean Government.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Although he remained officially noncommittal, the Justice Department's antitrust chief took what was in effect a chilly view today of a bill aimed at preventing major oil companies from owning coal and uranium properties.
ALBANY, June 21 Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and the leaders of the Legislature have opened a major drive to bring the 1984 Summer Olympics to New York City.

The United States dollar gained slightly against the Swiss franc and Canadian dollar in brisk foreign-exchange trading in New York yesterday, and also rose against Scandinavian currencies in London, the Associated Press reported.

Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for more than two years, suffered a further deterioration yesterday morning, and her parents remained at her bedside in the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains.
PARIS, June 21 Dr. August Stern, the son of a dissident Soviet Jewish doctor, today gave The New York Times a copy of a letter supposedly written to him by Amy Carter, the president's daughter.

Governor Byrne vetoed yesterday for the second time in two months the actions of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, including a proposal to shift $240 million in mass-transit rail commitments to bus projects in both states.
WASHINGTON, June 21 Retail prices for a broad range of consumer goods and services rose in May but at a lesser rate than in recent months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Tylenol from Johnson Johnson, with only two years of consumer advertising behind it, has become the country's best-selling analgesic brand. It also has at least one angry competitor.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The House voted today to block any Government ban on the use of saccharin for the next 15 months. The bill would also require the Food and Drug Administration to spend $1 million for its own study of the artificial sweetener's possible cancer-causing effects. The vote was 45 to 35.

PETRALONA, Greece A Greek anthropologist believes that a cave discov ered outside this village in northern Greece was occupied by ancestors of modern man for more than 100,000 years, beginning about 750,000 years ago.

PARIS, June 21 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing took issue today with complaints by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the visiting Soviet leader, about Western concern over human rights, ideological tension and French defense policy.

A California study that began a decade ago indicates that prolonged use of oral contraceptives may promote the development of cancer of the cervix in women who are predisposed to the disease. Such women have a benign abnormality of the cervix called dysplasia.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Calculations based on Government figures indicate that the industrial states of the Eastern Seaboard and the Middle West would not fare as well under the Carter Administration's proposed revision of the welfare law as would the rural states of the South and West.

TRENTON, June 21 A State Senate committee reported today that the three members of New Jersey's parole board apparently had stopped squabbling among themselves and were once again granting paroles at a reasonable rate.

WASHINGTON We must take a new look at the cavalry, its traditional role and future possibilities in international military power, if any progress is to be made toward world peace and stability. A mounted military might be far more civilized than what we now have, and less dangerous to us.

I DON'T REMEMBER why I married Oliver," Virginia Grant Marbalestier, the narrator of "Raw Silk," says early on; and with that admission, Janet Burroway sets the tone of this, her fourth novel, a moving account of the alienation of two people and the disjunction of a marriage.
NEW SOUNDS The contemporary composers' series at the Downtown Whitney Museum is structured with the realization that there is more to some music than meets the ear.

WASHINGTON, June 21 President Carter will receive recommendations next week for a reduction in the number of agencies under direct Presidential control and some reduction in the 1,712 people employed in them, an Administration official said today.
Rear Adm. Robert DuBois Workman, retired, the former chief of Navy chaplains, died yesterday at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. He was 92 years old.

Good times and bad, Ben Fein has been hacking in New York City for 30 years. As far as his driving is concerned, life took a turn for the better t hree years ago. That was when he bought his first diesel taxi. "I wouldn't trade it for the world," he said the other day.

RON HOWARD, who plays Fonzie's best friend on the top-rated television series "Happy Days," is everybody's favorite All-American boy. He has reddish hair, pinkish cheeks, pale blue eyes, a slight split between his front teeth and a look of perpetual surprise on his face.

MADRID Today's least flamboyant and most interesting Spanish political figure is Santiago Carrillo, 62-year-old general secretary of the Communist Party, which was legalized only this spring after two generations of Francoist ban.

JOHN FAHEY'S solo guitar defies labeling as readily as it charms even the most jaded ear. A single piece as performed by Mr. Fahey is likely to include improvising over a drone in the manner of Indian music snatches of Protestant hymns, fingerpicked ragtime and blues, and although these elements are strung together episodically, they co-exist without a hint of strain.
WASHINGTON, June 21 Retail prices for a broad range of consumer goods and services rose in May but at a lesser rate than in recent months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Brinks Inc. and the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation were indicted yesterday by an Atlanta Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to divide customers in that area between themselves and to submit rigged bids for armored car service contracts from 1968 through August 1975.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The United States Roman Catholic bishops have voted overwhelmingly for a oneyear extension of the church's domestic antipoverty program after rejecting a move for a five-year extension.

MENDOZA, Argentina, June 21 (AP) A hijacker seized a Chilean jetliner with 78 persons aboard today, forced it to fly over the snow-capped Andes to this Argentine border city, then abandoned plans to fly to Algeria and surrendered, officials of Chile's state airline, Lan-Chile, said.

Michael J. Maye and Richard J. Vizzini will face each other in a runoff vote for the presidency of the Uniformed Firefighters Association as a result of a mailballot election yesterday that gave neither the required majority.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Foreign Minister R.F. Botha of South Africa met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today and said continued insistence on a one-man, one-vote system for South Africa would lead to a "rapid worsening" of relations between the two countries.

SUMMER: the season of beach and lawn parties, barbecues and boat trips, picnics of every sort, and alas food poisoning. Al though food poisoning is not as common as it was when every picnic was packed in a wicker basket, there's still many an outing that brings along an unwelcome guest whose presence is encouraged by poor choice and improper handling of picnic foods.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The United States in an accord covering shoe shipments from South Korea, signed today what it hopes will be the last of the socalled Orderly Marketing Agreements it has negotiated with foreign suppliers to ease protectionist pressures and temporarily aid import-stricken industries.

The parent body of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private sector's top authority on accounting rules for business, has voted to open the board's meetings to the public and to reduce the public accounting profession's influence on the rule-making body.

NORTH WILDWOOD, N,J., June 21 Joseph Evangelista, a decorated former Army platoon sergeant, wrapped his three medals in a package and dispatched them to President Carter in protest against his pardon of virtually all Vietnam-era draft evaders.
MANILA, June 21 (AP) Immigration Commissioner Edmundo M. Reyes today barred the expulsion of an American journalist accused of writing articles unfavorable to the Philippine martial law regime.

ROME, June 21 (UPI) Terrorists shot a Rome University professor in the legs and set fire to seven buses in a depot near Milan today on the third day of a wave of violence coinciding with the trial of a guerrilla leader.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to rebate to consumers money collected through higher taxes on crude oil, although it modified the Administration's proposal and limited the program to one year.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Spokesmen for several regional stock exchanges said today that progress toward a national securities market is being hampered by the New York Stock Exchange's dominance.

HOW SWEET it would be, Jackie Gleason told the Tourist Development Authority in Miami Beach, if it would kick in about $40,000 to defray the costs of videotaping two "Honeymooners" specials, to be seen on ABC-TV next season, in Gusman Hall. "It costs $40,000 to $60,000 extra to produce the shows here," said a Gleason emissary, but in return the programs would contain several plugs for the resort city.
A different kind of brokerage account, encompassing some banking services new to the securities industry, was announced yesterday by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith.

BELGRADE, June 21 If you think you're confused about the politics of New York or Washington, you should come to Belgrade. It breaks every rule in the political book. It sounds like Moscow and works like Pittsburgh. Everything runs upstream in this bustling valley but the Sava and Danube Rivers.

It now seems clear that the food processor that much-touted miracle worker which has served as much as status symbol as mechanical servant in the American home for the last several years is finally coming of age. Age, in this case, meaning sufficient competition and mass production have been generated to make the processor less of a luxury and more economically viable for a large segment of the public.

DETROIT, June 21 The General Motors Corporation charged in the United States District Court here today that Federal tax agents had "contrived a phony issue" so as to bring G.M.'s income tax affairs before a grand jury improperly and illegally.
GETTING a department store charge card in New York is not all that hard. What is hard is not getting a department store charge card.

The European team championship, which has been contested annually since 1932 except for the World War II years, promises to be of unusual interest this year. More than 20 teams will compete from July 31 to Aug. 12 in Denmark at Elsinore, no doubt oblivious of the shade of Hamlet: "A little shuffling" (Act IV, Scene 7).

DEAR DIARY: This is going to be smudgy. You're going to be smudgy. Do you have to be made of fragile newsprint, in narrow column wells with sides bleak and precipitous? Must you gorge on mechanical type rude and artless? Could you not receive the intimacies of monologue inscribed in a fine hand, on noble paper, perhaps even in a volume edged with gold?

A federation of elderly people yesterday complained to Governor Carey that some nursing-home operators "sentenced already for Medicaid rip-offs" had got increases in the "cost-plus reimbursement rate" set by the State Health Department this year.

ALBANY, June 21 A bipartisan bill aimed at curbing crime against the elderly and the physically handicapped was passed by the Assemlby today, but many of those who voted for it expressed misgivings about its potential effectiveness.

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 22 The Labor Party appeared early today to be retaining its control of Israel's General Labor Federation in an election that is expected to affect the ability of the new coalition of Prime Minister Menahem Begin to carry out its economic and social policies.

New Jersey's tourism industry, which has been lagging sadly in recent years, is expecting a revitalization from casino gambling in Atlantic City and from a possible 10-fold increase in state spending in tourism, according to inductry officials.

A REPERTORY DANCE company for two dancers really does seem to be stripping down to the barest essentials and even beyond but that is the aspiration of a company found, formed and functioned by Jane Kosminsky and Bruce Becker. It is called the 5 by 2 Dance Company and it appeared on Monday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, beginning a brief season that ends tonight.
Lee A. Pickard has told the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission that he soon plans to leave his position as director of the commission's market regulation division, he said yesterday.

NORTH WILDWOOD, June 21 Joseph Evangelista, a decorated former Army platoon sergeant, wrapped his three medals in a package and dispatched them to President Carter in protest against his pardon of virtually all Vietnam-era draft evaders.

Governor Byrne vetoed yesterday for the second time in two months the actions of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, including a proposal to shift $240 million in mass-transit rail commitments to bus projects in both states.

Now in their second year of operation around the city, farmers' markets promise to be bigger, brighter and busi- er than ever. While their main purpose is to bring freshly picked, locally grown produce to city dwellers, there are other reasons that inspire the founders. Both the Greenmarket project of New York City's Council for the Environment, and the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which operates the Jamaica farmers market, cite a de-...
