The former vice chairman of the nowdefunct Franklin National Bank pleaded guilty in the Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to falsifying records of the bank in 1974 to hide a $2 million loss.

Almost as inviolable as seniority in the canons of organized labor has been the concept that the best union leadership comes out of the workplace. George Meany, who picked up a plumber's wrench after only a year in ...

"We are working intensively to expand our contract sales by capitalizing on the oil money in the Mideast," Walter Hoving, chairman of Tiffany Inc., said at the annual meeting yesterday. "We are already involved with three major corporations there."

BALTIMORE, June 21 (UPI) The Boston Red Sox acquired today Tommy Helms, who had been given his unconditional release by the Pittsburgh Pirates, and placed Doug Griffin on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., June 21 On a course on which scores rise when the wind picks up, Doug Nelson, a 29year-old Preakness Valley golfer, shot a surprisingly strong 69 for 144 today. That total gave Nelson a share of the lead with two others at the halfway mark of the 76th annual New Jersey Golf Association amateur tournament, being held at the Shackamaxon course.

Some police officers in two Bronx precincts jammed their car radios yesterday to protest an arbitrator's ruling that the Police Department could use one-man patrol cars and continue its current duty chart requiring 10 extra workdays a year. Most officers throughout the city, however, expressed their resentment in angry comments.

Acceptance of the Cosmos by the ethnic melting pot of the metropolitan area is greatly responsible for the flood of 62,394 fans who watched the soccer game at Giants Stadium last Sunday. However, that is only part of the reason the Cosmos drew about 59,000 more people than they did for any Sunday in June three years ago.
PARIS, June 21 The Carter Administration is facing European opposition to its plans for a $1 billion international loan for Portugal, according to diplomatic sources.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, the intellectual retreat in Santa Barbara founded by the late Robert M. Hutchins, and the Aspen Institute of Aspen, Colo., are discussing the possibility of a merger.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 21 (UPI) Marine Cple, Curtis Jones Jr., 22 years old, was sentenced today to three months' confinement at hard labor and was reduced in rank three pay grades to private El on charges growing out of an attack by black marines on white marines.

TURIN, Italy, June 21 (AP) Larry Jesse and Doug Laz scored a one, two sweep in the pole vault tonight as a young American track and field team dominated the men's triangular meet with Britain and Italy.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to rebate to consumers money collected through higher taxes on crude oil, al though it modified the Administration's proposal and limited the program to one year.
Give parents a choice of whether they want their children in classes with 20 students or 35 students, and they will invariably pick the smaller class.

ANCHORAGE, June 21 In the first 12 hours that the trans-Alaska pipeline system was in operation, it was filled for about 17 or 18 miles, officials said today. The pipeline stretches from the Prudhoe Bay oil field on the northern coast of Alaska for 799 miles south to Valdez.
DETROIT, June 21 The Yankees, supposedly firm in their field management but still looking shaky at bat, lost their fifth game in a row tonight, dropping a 5-2 decision to the Tigers at Tiger Stadium.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 21 In an effort to counter the bad publicity given nuclear power by the recent demonstrations in Seabrook, N.H., the Long Island Lighting Company is offering its 5,400 employees a free one-day bus trip to Manchester, N.H., with lunch and dinner thrown in, to rally on Sunday in favor of nuclear energy.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would crack down aggressively, with heavy fines and possible criminal penalties, on major polluters failing to meet the statutory July 1 deadline for achieving clean water standards.
James R. Stokely Jr. a conservationist, poet and author who wrote primarily about the South, died Monday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Newport, Tenn. He was 63 years old.
NEW DELHI, June 21 West Bengal became India's only Communist-ruled state today as a coalition government of five Marxist parties took office as a result of last week's state elections.

The Town of North Hempstead, L.I., and three of its officials have been charged with failing to comply with a Federal judge's order to shut down an incinerator when the wind was from the east so pollutants would not be spewed over Queens and Westchester County.

Interest rates, apparently pushed too low too quickly last week, were moved back up yesterday in an effort to get investors to buy new fixed-income securities, but the effort was only partly successful. Interest rates rose in the Government, corporate and tax-exempt bond markets.
The stock market, propelled by signs that inflation has eased, advanced broadly yesterday in the heaviest trading in two months.
WELL, here we are in summertime, and while the livin' may not be easy it's a little better than it was during the last week of spring, when it comes to buying food.
New York's 1973 drug law with its stiff, mandatory sentencing provisions neither reduced drug use nor drug-related crime, a federally financed study concluded yesterday.
Ralph Hayes, director of the New York Community Trust for more than 40 years and a pioneer in fund raising efforts for charitable causes, died Monday in Wilmington, Del. He was 83 years old.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 (AP) The preparatory conference on reviewing the 1975 Helsinki accords reached an ap parent deadlock today, with wide differences between the United States and the Soviet Union on an agenda for a full meeting of the 35 member nations in the fall.

OTTAWA, June 21 The federal Gov ernment took strong issue today with a proprosal by the separatist government of Quebec to force virtually all children in that province into French-speaking schools, regardless of their linguistic backgrounds.

BUENOS AIRES, June 21 A court decision freeing former President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse from jail in a politically controversial case has helped to restore confidence in the independence of Argentina's federal judiciary. The order by a federal Appeals Court releasing General Lanusse and three other members of a former military regime harmonizes with efforts of President Jorge Rafael Videla to strengthen the rule of law against violence from left and right.
Steve Cauthen, the riding wonder from Kentucky, was welcomed back to Belmont Park yesterday after a four-week absence from the races because of injuries.

TWO of public television's more worthwhile series are on particularly impressive display this evening. At 8 o'clock, "Nova," produced by Boston's station WGBH, has "Across the Silence Barrier," a broad and remarkably informative study of deafness. At 9, WNET/13's "Dance in America" looks at "trailblazers of Modern Dance."

LOS ANGELES, June 21 Lomooc Federal Prison, where H.R. Haldeman began serving his Watergate cover-up sentence today, offers high school and college credits but few inmates bother to earn them because they already have college degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Recent actions in both Senate and House indicate that the Carter Administration is seriously out of step with Congress in its approach to several important foreign-policy problems. It is not yet clear that the White House realizes it.
SANTA ROSA, Calif., June 21 (UPI) Elizabeth Waters Burbank, widow of the famed horticulturist, Luther Burbank, died on Sunday. She was 89 years old.

ALBANY, June 21 The Senate majority leader said today that he would not allow the Senate to adjourn without deciding on what he termed the "rather weird" nomination of Peter A. Peyser to head the Public Service Commission. The announcement signaled what could become a serious battle over Governor Carey's appointment of the former Westchester Congressman.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The Food and Drug Administration announced today a crackdown on the advertising and the use of many popular daytime sedative drugs that may be purchased without a prescription.

NEWARK, June 21 New Jersey Common Cause challenged today a law that allows individuals to make unlimited donations to help candidates pay off primary campaign debts. Donors are limited to $600 contributions in the general election.

The executive director of the State Emergency Financial Control Board said yesterday that New York City should be permitted to give its employees cost-ofliving increases if they work harder, even if their increased productivity does not save the city any money.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 What makes Jimmy Connors run? Is he really the little imp who steals cookies from the jar and then says, "Who me?" Or does he need continual challenges to keep his combative juices flowing on the tennis court?

NANCY MIRANDA, a Brazilian soprano who has studied singing here as well as in her own country, and Sosio Manzo, an American-born tenor who has sung opera in Italy, were presented in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by the Brazilian Coffee Institute. The piano accompanist was Tom Schilling.

SUDDENLY, vegetables are "in". Chefs in fashionable restaurants across the country and cooks at home are featuring glowingly fresh vegetables cooked to firm but tender brightness. Rain bows of raw or barely blanched vegetables in pungent, lemony dressings are being offered as appetizers and lavish assortments of vegetables are being simmered together in succulent stews, each a potful of summer.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 Wimbledon welcomed Jimmy Connors onto the center court with a chorus of boos and hisses today, but the 24year-old American left with his pride intact after a 6-3, 6-2, 6-4 victory over Richard Lewis of Britain.

DENPASAR, Indonesia Government, academic and business leaders from the United States and five non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia have opened what organizers hope may develop into a continuing dialogue on future relationships.
CHICAGO, June 21 Bernice Henderson considered herself thoroughly urbanized. She was accustomed to the hot asphalt in the summer, the noise, sights and smells of the big city.

ONE OF THE most important things in learning to cook and in knowing how to cook is flexibility. It's the ability to adapt and alter a recipe to circumstance, to the need of a day. You can't or shouldn't be hidebound by rule, and many times personal judgment is vital whether it pertains to baking times or the use of an herb or spice.

MADRID, June 21 King Juan Carlos today received a delegation of Catalan Socialists, fresh from their triumph in last week's elections, as legislators from both Catalonia and the Basque provinces began maneuvering for the return of autonomy statutes abrogated by Franco.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The South Korean Ambassador here, Kim Yong Shik, asserted today that the State Department had assured him that a report in The New York Times on electronic surveillance of the presidential mansion in South Korea by an American intelligence agency was "absolutely false."

Governor Carey yesterday threw his weight behind opponents of any drastic street-parking ban in Manhattan. A courtordered ban, parts of which went into effect last Tuesday, "would have a terribly adverse economic impact on the city," the Governor said at an Albany news conference.
Shares of the Damon Corporation, once a high-flying stock popular with institutions, have been trading mostly below 10 since earnings peaked in 1973. There was little sign of a strong recovery.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service has given Vice President Mondale a clean bill of health on his 1976 income tax return.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 21 The Army-Princeton track squad, led by three all-Americans, Craig Masback, Curt Alitz and Dave Wiener, today repulsed the invading British of the Oxford-Cambridge track team, twelve events to four.

Of the various foods purchased by the average consumer, few pose so great a mystery as fish, both in the buying and the cooking. For that reason, all too often a family fish dinner is based strictly on fillets. Yet without too much training, anyone should be able to judge quality and freshness at the fish market, and so take advantage of more interesting and economical choices.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to ban the use of Medicaid funds for abortions except when a mother's life is endangered, in cases of rape or incest, or where serious genetic disease threatens the child.

Copper futures prices dropped 2.40 cents a pound across the board yesterday, confirming what many traders had thought was an unwarranted rise of 3.60 cents the previous two sessions on New York's Commodity Exchange.
With five major-league managers having lost their jobs already this season, Dave Bristol lost his for the second time in six weeks but again, only temporarily.

MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., June 22 Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for 26 months and who was removed from a respirator more than a year ago so that she could be allowed to die "with dignity," was reported in stable condition today at the Morris View Nursing Home here. Last night she was reported to be dying.

JERICHO, L.I., June 21 Chris Desch of Southampton, the opening-round leader with a 77, scored a triple-bogey 7 on the 347-yard final hole today at the Meadow Brook Club and fell into a three-way tie for the lead at 159 in the second round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship.
PHILIPSBURG, St. Maarten, June 22 (UPI) Oil companies have decided to abandon a $4.5 million dry hole, shattering hopes for the tiny Dutch island of Saba to become a Caribbean oil producer.

The conduct of United States foreign relations continues to be handicapped by the energy question. American dependence on a single oil supplier, Saudi Arabia, will give that country considerable leverage and the ability to impose almost singlehandedly another embargo if it chooses to do so.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The induction of Leonid I. Brezhnev as President of the Soviet Union last week and the unveiling of a new Soviet Constitution are viewed by top-ranking Administration analysts as moves aimed at rooting out entrenched bureaucracies, curbing the power of the individual republics and improving national economic planning.

Goldblatt Brothers Inc., a leading Chicago-based department store chain, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with Korvettes Inc. to take over the leases of two of the four Korvettes stores in the Chicago area.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The induction of Leonid I. Brezhnev as President of the Soviet Union last week and the unveiling of a new Soviet Constitution are viewed by top-ranking Administration analysts as moves aimed at rooting out entrenched bureaucracies, curbing the power of the individual republics and improving national economic planning.
The stock market declined moderately yesterday in slower trading, the Dow Jones industrial average slipping 2.29 points to close at 926.31.

HONG KONG, June 22 China has ousted the longtime party leader of Kansu Province in the northwest after he apparently failed to carry out the current purge of followers of the country's so-called "radicals" fast enough.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 22 At 11:14 A.M. on June 23, 1972, the Susquehanna River, swollen by tropical storm Agnes, rose to 40 feet, rushed over the dikes and flooded this former coal town, damaging or destroying 25,000 homes, forcing the evacuation of 80,000 people from the area, and leaving in its wake mud, rubble and bilterness, but not despair.

IN an unusual move, John S.D. Eisenhower, son of the late President and General Dwight D. Eisenhower, has made available a large selection of Mr. Eisenhower's World War II love letters to his wife, Mamie Eisenhower, in order to refute stories of General Eisenhower's reported wartime romance with Lieut. Kay Summersby.

Mayor Beame will renew his request to the Board of Estimate today to approve $1 million in Federal job funds for the B'Nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn, which is under investigation by three Federal departments in connection with its operation of a summer lunch program and another Federal job program.

RHINEBECK, N.Y. A few years ago, attendants at the Rhinebeck Craft Fair's main gate were startled to see three couples wheeling empty shopping carts up the asphalt path to the fairgrounds. Hours later the couples returned, their carts overflowing with purchases.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., June 22 Jimmy Dee, a 6-foot-8-inch former Holy Cross basketball player, came out of a steep bunker at the final hole and then sank a 50-foot putt today to win the New Jersey Golf Association's 76th amateur championship by one shot.

TOKYO, June 22 Dr. William J. Ronan, the outgoin gchairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, conferred with officials of Honda Motors and attended a meeting of the World Trade Centers Association during a threeday trip here at public expense.

The delicate interplay between the movement of the checkers and the position of the doubling cube can lead to unexpected complications. Even an expert player went astray in the diagrammed position, which occurred during the Phillip Morris International Championships last summer in Monte Carlo.

State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that an 11-year-old program to build New York City public schools in combination with private income-producing housing and businesses "did not adequately fulfill any of the purposes for which it was established."

The prospect of two-tiered pricing in aluminum outside the United States became a reality yesterday when Alcan Aluminum Ltd. of Canada, which traditionally sets international pricing, said that its price for aluminum ingot "still stands at 51 cents a pound."
Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home. "The Captain's House" Designer Showcase, Mystic, Conn.

CLEVELAND When a Federal judge ruled last August that the schools here were segregated by design, some members of the board of education disagreed strongly, not unlike other boards in similar situations.

WASHINGTON, June 22 A former Director of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, in the first public testimony on the Korean lobbying scandal, disclosed today that the K.C.I.A. had arranged the financing of the exclusive George Town Club here, to which President Ford, many Cabinet officers, Justices of the Supreme Court and numerous Congressmen have belonged over the years.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The House Appropriations Committee, largely at the prodding of a middle-of-the-road Missouri Congressman, has voted to place restrictions on a secret contingency fund that the Central Intelligence Agency has, in the past, used to initiate covert operations without the prior knowledge of Congress.
LIMA, June 22 (Reuters) Violence has been reported in five Peruvian cities as students have taken to the streets in protest against Government austerity measures.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The engineering company in charge of building the Clinch River breeder reactor concluded four years ago that the planned location of the project was "one of the worst sites ever selected for a nuclear power plant based on topography and rock conditions."

Folklore for years has promulgated growing marigolds for insect control. As with many old stories it involves more than a grain of truth. Marigolds have eliminated root nematodes in gardens and fields, and they are grown in the tropics as weevil repellents. The question is, why do they work that way for some gardeners and not for others?

Nothing can frighten the mayor of a large city so much as the specter of large-scale disaffection among his police. That is what Mayor Beame faces as members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association jam their patrol car radios and picket Gracie Mansion in protest against an arbitrator's decision not yet publicly announced but widely leaked upholding the city's right to have one man rather than two operate patrol cars in low-crime areas during daylight.

AT THIS LATE DATE, it seems superfluous to add to the chorus of praise for Roger Angell's "Five Seasons: A Baseball Com panion." Yet the facts are inescapable. No one currently practicing, with the possible exceptions of George Plimpton, Red Smith and Norman Mailer, brings to sportswriting quite the combination of precision, humor and respect that Mr. Angell does.

The Vietnamese refugee family of Le Thanh Hoang Dan, striving to root itself now for two years in Flushing, Queens, has lost its eldest daughter to a ocnfessed murderer-rapist and Vietnam vetran who entered a plea of insanity this week: He said he had killed her because he had thought he was interrogating a Vietcong back in Vietnam.
TOKYO, June 18 Some unusual, and puzzling, winds of change are blowing through Japan's writing community these days, igniting talk of a radical new literary era in this ancient nation.
LONDON, June 22 One of the most respected diplomats in London, a person with no time for illusions, was talking about President Carter's human rights policy.

Marigolds are perfect for potted terrace planting they are quite pollution resistant. if you want something tall and striking instead of the traditional bush-cum-blooms marigold can give you that as well. We generally picture marigold as being between a few inches and a foot tall.

ALBANY, June 22 The Republicancontrolled Senate, with some grumbling criticism of Governor Carey for not moving more expeditiously with his economic-development program for the state, gave its approval this evening to the Governor's proposed $750 million bond issue to finance job-producing construction projects.
With the personal touch of a local politician running for district leader, President Carter will "work the tables" at a $1,000-a-ticket dinner in New York City tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (Reuters) Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today he expected the economy to grow as strongly in the second quarter as it did in the first.

PARIS, June 22 The United States and of 10 other rich countries agreed today to lend Portugal $750 million just half the amount the United States had originally proposed to shore up its still shaky democratic regime.

The expected nomination of Robert H. McKinney, an Indianapolis banker, as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is stirring widening controversy. In addition to drawing fire on the ground that bankers should not regulate their own industry, Mr. McKinney is being criticized for possible conflicts of interest in Indiana.

Gardens are in a profusion of bloom everywhere, and many household objects are brightened with a sprig or two. Florals are legion on china, fabrics, wallcoverings and domestic linens. But there are some things they rarely appear on, and the fun of the decorative-horticultural chase is to find them on unexpected objects. Plumbing fixtures, for example.

ANY GATHERING of standup comics is likely to produce a mixed bag of results. In this sense, the five comics who make up the cast of "High Heeled Women" at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street, follow form. But there is a difference in that all five are women and the overall balance is tipped in their favor by the enthusiasm with which they leap into their routines.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22 John N. Mitchell, the first former United States Attorney General, to go to prison, arrived here aboard a private jet today and rode to jail in a blue Cadillac to begin his sentence for Watergate crimes.

WARSAW, June 22 (Reuters) Prime ministers at the East European economic summit here today urged a policy of selfhelp by participating states to solve their energy and raw material problems, PAP, the Polish news agency reported.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 22 Idi Amin is alive and in control of Uganda and while there is still much uncertainty about what has happened in the country in the last week, there were growing indications that earlier accounts of widespread disorder and fleeing refugees were exaggerations.

THERE ARE symptoms. Black around the eyes. A craving for hippos, lion's feet, turquoise and bangs. Egyptian fever is spreading faster than Asian flu, and by the time the Treasures of Tutankhamen exhibit arrives at the Metropolitan Museum in December 1978, the fever will no doubt have reached epidemic proportions.
WASHINGTON, June 22 Two out of every five Democrats in the House are in only the first or second term. That is unusual.

The 30th anniversary of the Marshall Plan this month has been commemorated in Europe but paid little notice in the United States as though it had been an act of generosity requiring European thanks and American blushes.
MOSCOW, June 22 (AP) Vladimir D. Timakov, president of the Soviet Union's Academy of Medical Sciences since 1968, is dead at the age of 72, Tass said today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The Senate passed by voice vote tonight and sent to the House the first unified budget covering all United States intelligence ac tivities. It was the first time in history that a vote to authorize expenditures on intelligence was taken in public.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The Senate voted today to impose fees on ship and barge owners on most of the nation's inland waterways.

Crude oil imports for the week ended June 17 dropped to 6.8 million barrels daily from the 7.3 million barrels daily in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

PARIS, June 22 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today said he had learned from his talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev that the Soviet Union's relations with the United States were going through a difficult phase.

EVER SINCE double-decker environments first sprouted in children's rooms a decade ago, there have been countless interpretations of the unit, which combines a bed, a desk, storage space and a play area.
BALTIMORE, June 22 (AP) Barbara Mandel, former wife of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, has been subpoenaed to testify at his political corruption trial, defense attorneys said.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, who returned last week from what he characterized as a "disappointing" assembly of the International Labor Organization in Geneva, said today that the United States was likely to pull out of the specialized United Nations agency this November.

MOSCOW, June 22 Recently, Irina Astakhova McClellan was informed once more by the Soviet authorities that she would not be permitted to join her American husband in the United States. The former Moscow teacher has been waiting nearly three years.

The Raytheon Company and Falcon Seaboard Inc. announced yesterday that the two an electronics producer and a coal mining company have reached tentative plans to merge in a stock swap valued at nearly $235 million.

The City University's SEEK program for disadvantaged students has been "so badly" and wastefully managed that its administration should be taken away from the university and put under New York State's Department of Education, the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 (UPI) Negotiations for the 100 percent Saudi takeover of the Arabian-American Oil Company, the joint Saudi-American venture that controls the world's largest oil reserves, were reported today to have been completed.

An American missionary doctor who was expelled from Rhodesia for having given medical advice and supplies to guerrilla soldiers said yesterday he was convinced that the insurgents had widespread support among the black population, despite allegations to the contrary by the white minority Government.

In a ruling that appeared to deal a blow to part of New York City's campaign against pornography, a Federal District Court judge yesterday barred the Police Department from using obscenity laws to harass three midtown bookstores.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 22 Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, who was convicted of murdering his wife, Sophie, will receive $60,000 worth of bonds from the total of $600,000 in securities he was convicted of stealing from her.

Joan C. Geiler, wife of Justice William R. Geiler of State Supreme Court, died yesterday in North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a lingering illness. She lived at 17 Taylor Road, Huntington, L.I., and was 54 years old.

LISBON, June 22 (AP) More than 100,000 Communist-led workers, shaking fists and shouting slogans, marched down Lisbon's main street tonight as part of nationwide labor union protests against th economic programs of Premier Soares.

LOFTY AND WAY OUT A woman who plays the clarinet and also makes all sorts of sounds with her voice in some of her compositions, two saxophonists and a cellist are performing in a loft tonight in their concert, "Voice, Wood and Metal."

MORRIS PLAINS, June 22 Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for 26 months and who was removed from a respirator more than a year ago so that she could be allowed to die "with dignity," was reported in stable condition today at the Morris View Nursing Home here. Last night she was reported to be dying.

MONTGOMERY, June 22 The Federal prison camp where Mr. Mitchell began serving his prison term today is bordered on one side by the Alabama River, where inmates often pass their time by fishing or sunning, and on the other side by a 54-hole golf course for officers assigned to Maxwell Air Force Base.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Congressional and state government antitrust lawyers drafted today a one-sentence amendment to the Clayton Antitrust Act that would overrule a June 9th Supreme Court decision limiting the right to sue for damages where there is price-fixing.

THE NATIONAL Association of American Composers and Conductors was founded 37 years ago by Henry Hadley to pro- mote American music. It was recently reorganized as the National Association of Composers, USA (NACUSA), and as such gave its first concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

SUMMER ISN'T just coming in; it arrived officially this week. It's time for light, pretty clothes and a lighter makeup to wear with them. What's the word from the experts about summer makeup? Mainly that there's a lot less of it. They advise not masking a tan with a winterweight foundation, to ease up on eye makeup and to wear lighter rouge and lipstick colors.

PHILADELPHIA, June 32 (AP) A Pentagon panel, considering charges that the World War II execution of Pvt. Eddie Slovik was unjust, agreed today to hear a witness who contends that Private Slovik was selected from among several deserters and shot as an example.

SANTA MARIA DEL MAR, Cuba, June 22 (Reuters) An American delegation of businessmen, including some from major corporations, is holding talks with Cuban officials on prospects for trade between the two countries.

A little known but critical aspect of the American health care system is the relationship between the Veterans Administration and the nation's medical schools, which work closely together to teach medical students and young doc tors to care for all Americans, not just veterans. The relationship has grown tre mendously since World War II, to a point of a mutual dependency best illustrated perhaps by the V.A.'s policy of building hospitals near medical school campuses.

There are a number of ad agency heads who have a very low regard for advertising awards and never enter their work in them. Michael G. McDonald, chairman and chief executive of McDonald Little, the fast-growing Atlanta shop, isn't one of them.

Elise Jerard, an early opponent of nuclear power and the chairman and founder of the Independent Phi Beta Kappa Environmental Study Group, died June 17 at her home, 115 Central Park West, after a long illness. She was 74 years old.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 Ted Turner, who has yet to lose at the America's Cup trials this week, was about to get his today when snap, crackle, pop, down came the mainsail of Enterprise, the boat that Turner and Courageous were falling farther and farther behind. Enterprise had to drop out and the race was stopped.
WASHINGTON, June 22 For several days Kim Hyung Wook said he had been getting ominous telephone calls from unknown Koreans warning him not to testify before a House subcommittee today.

Sophie S. Jagendorf, who began her career as an innovator in modern dance and went on to teach retarded children, died of pneumonia Monday night at her home on 110 Riverside Drive. She was 83 years old.

PARIS, June 22 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today said he had learned from his talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev that the Soviet Union's relations with the United States were going through a difficult phase.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The plan to choose the President by national popular vote rather than through the Electoral College narrowly survived its first test in Congress today, but its problems have only begun.

The methodical but deadly punching of Alexis Arguello provided the only exclamation point to Madison Square Garden's Summer Festival of Boxing program last night, a card that drew an international crowd of 7,364 and fashioned a gate of $67,143.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, out of public life for the first time in three decades since he left the Vice Presidency in January, is taking an activist, leadership role in the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, one of the major philanthropies established by his family.
Eleanor Steele Reese, singer, philanthropist and rancher, died Monday at her Salmon, Idaho, home. She was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The United States Postal Service announced today that the cost of mailing magazines, books, records and other second-class mail items will go up July 6.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 22 (UPI) Frank Lucchesi was dismissed as manager of the Texas Rangers today and replaced by Eddie Stanky, who left the major leagues nearly a decade ago after stormy stints with the Chicago White Sox and St. Louis Cardinals.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 Christine Truman Janes watched Tracy Austin walk on the court to serve for the match against Elly Vessies-Appel today.
BALTIMORE, June 22 (AP) Carlton Fisk's second home run of the game, a two-run shot in the ninth inning off Jim Palmer, gave the Boston Red Sox a 7-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

With the credit markets heading toward slightly higher bond prices and lower interest rates yesterday, Citicorp increased the size of the note issue it plans to sell today to $250 million, Trans World Airlines priced units of preferred and common stock to yield 9.50 percent and General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced a $300 million financing.

Milton Fox-Martin, an internationally prominent marketing executive who retired six years ago as president of the underwriting division of the Anchor Corporation of Elizabeth, N. J., a major sponsor of mutual funds, died Tuesday in Amsterdam after a short illness. He was 64 years old.

BELGRADE, June 22 Nine neutral nations today suggested inserting some hyphens between clauses of a proposed draft agenda for the conference on EastWest cooperation, hoping to resolve a conflict in the Soviet and Western positions.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The Federal Power Commission predicted today that interstate supplies of natural gas would again decline in the coming winter, raising the possibility of renewed gas shortages. Although gas supplies are relatively easy to predict, shortages are not, because weather is a major factor.

Sustained demand for jeans and other casual wear, increasing overseas growth plus higher average selling prices helped Levi Strauss Company raise earnings in the quarter and six months ended May 29, it was reported yesterday.

Elsie De Wolfe, as almost everyone knows, was the mother of interior decorating the first recognized authority in the field, and the most prominent designer in New York in the first quarter of the 20th century. She died in l950 in her 90's.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Ten years after the enactment of Medicaid's health screening and treatment program for children, too few of the intended recipients are receiving adequate medical attention, according to a report released today by the Children's Defense Fund.
The agreement on a new British-American air treaty yesterday made alterations in the pattern of airline routings that will significantly affect traps-Atlantic travel habits.

Dr. Bruce C. Heezen, a pioneer in mapping the ocean floors, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, aboard a submarine that was about to explore submerged, mid-Atlantic mountains that had been a focus of his career. He was 53 years old.

BRASILIA, June 23 (UPI) Brazil and Iran today signed a five-year, $6.5 billion trade agreement calling for the exchange of Iranian oil for Brazilian agricultural and manufactured products.

Mayor Beame and the Board of Education, locked in a dispute over school spending for more than a year, reached an agreement yesterday in which the school board would receive $13.5 million in new city funds in return for dropping its claim to more than this sum under the Stavisky-Goodman Law.

WHILE THE SEARCH for a new team to run the Metropolitan Museum of Art continues, Philippe de Monte bello, vice director for curatorial and educational affairs, has been named acting director, effective July 1. His appointment will enable Thomas Hoving, slated to retire from the director's post on Dec. 31, to withdraw from day-today activities.

TEL AVIV, June 22 Israel's Labor Party has bounced back from its crushing defeat in the parliamentary elections of May 17 to win a clear majority yesterday in the General Federation of Labor, retaining control of its administration.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) On a tie vote in closed session, the Senate Appropriations Committee refused today to prohobit production of the neutron bomb despite arguments that no one knows enough about the weapon to add it to the arsenal.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) The United States balance of payments, a key indicator of the nation's international economic standing, fell to a record deficit during the first quarter when it sank into the red by $4.3 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The Defense Department, citing "security reasons," has abruptly turned down a proposal for the co-production by an American concern and one in Israel of an elaborate military communications system.

Prices of the old-crop soybean futures contracts tumbled about 20 cents a bushel yesterday, bringing the near July delivery down to a six-month low of $7.20. The near August delivery, the last of the oldcrop contracts, closed off 19 cents at $7.21.

The attempt to find a fruitful symbiosis between the controlled intelligence of written music and the spontaneous flow of improvisation is perhaps the most difficult task faced by the contemporary jazz musician. Jazz themes are no longer brief written passages that bracket lengthy improvisations. In the new jazz, written material is likely to be scattered throughout a performance, lending direction and substance to the improvising.

EDISON, June 22 Contaminated water supplies, rats, flies and other environmental hazards were forecast today if a new sanitary landfill operation was permitted to operate in this suburban Middlesex County community.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Calling it the wrong approach at the wrong time, a Senate committee rejected today a House-passed proposal to block any Government ban on saccharin for 15 months.

About 23,000 southern Appalachian coal miners stayed away from work in a wildcat strike yesterday, protesting reductions in union health benefits that were caused by financial problems in the United Mine Workers health and retirement funds, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, June 22 A former Director of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, in the first public testimony on the Korean lobbying scandal, disclosed today that the K.C.I.A. had arranged the financing of the exclusive George Town Club here, to which President Ford, many Cabinet officers, Justices of the Supreme Court and numerous Congressmen have belonged over the years.

Thomas Appleby, New York City's Housing and Development Administrator, has been named by the Carter Administration to a major post affecting New York and New Jersey regional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

COLOGNE, West Germany, June 22 (AP) Houston McTear sped to a 10.13second clocking in the 100-meter dash tonight and beat Don Quarrie of Jamaica and four other Americans in an international track and field meet before a crowd of 20,000 at Cologne Stadium.

A 40-year-old yeshiva, K'han Adas Kashau, announced plans yesterday to move from Brooklyn to the former Hillcrest Center for Children in the Westchester County community of Bedford. The yeshiva bought the center, which was once owned by New York City, at auction for $1.6 million.

Saying it was virtually impossible to conform with some provisions of the court-ordered ban on parking in midtown Manhattan, the city yesterday urged the Federal District Court to discard the parking plan that went into effect last week or to grant a six-month stay that would allow the city and the state to come up with a better plan.

WASHINGTON, June 22 The House Appropriations Committee, largely at the prodding of a middle-of-the-road Missouri Congressman, has voted to place restrictions on a secret contingency fund that the Central Intelligence Agency has, in the past, used to initiate covert operations without the prior knowledge of Congress.

ALBANY, June 22 The Assembly tonight approved an amendment that would add premeditated murder and murder committed during other crimes to the list of murders subject to the death penalty in New York State.
CHICAGO, June 22, (AP) One of seven soybean brokers accused of illegal commodity dealing on the Chicago Board of Trade has pleaded guilty to one count in a Federal indictment.

Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of New York State Supreme Court appointed his son-in-law as an arbitrator and a referee in two cases that came before him in 1967 and 1974, positions for which the son-in-law received $33,500 in legal fees.

Mayor Beame yesterday promoted Joseph P. Davidson from deputy commissioner to Commissioner of Parks and Recreation effective July 1, to succeed Martin Lang, a career civil servant who recently announced his retirement.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22 John N. Mitchell, the first former United States Attorney General to go to prison, arrived here aboard a private jet today and rode to jail in a blue Cadillac to begin his sentence for Watergate crimes.

SPENDING PART of my summers in the vicinity of Tanglewood a bucolic region seasonally infested by musicians I have frequent occasion to practice my somewhat elementary skill in making live recordings. Impromptu renderings of madrigals around the kitchen table or backyard readings of a Haydn quartet, captured on cassettes, remain living mementos of some of my happiest hours.
VOORHEESVILLE, N.Y., June 22 "He ought to act like a Governor or get out," Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, said yesterday of Governor Carey.

ALBANY, June 22 Constitutional amendments to reorganize some elements of the state's court system today seemed almost certain to appear on this fall's ballot as the Assembly's Democratic leaders abandoned their insistence that the proposals be presented to the voters as a package.

LOS ANGELES IT is easy to think, that the most real place in all of Southern California is that vast complex up the Hollywood Freeway known as Universal City. Here, sprawling across 450 acres of North Hollywood, there are rows of storefronts, bodies of water, and one suburban street.

The protracted takeover battle involving the bid by Anderson, Clayton Company to acquire the Gerber Products Company saw two more skirmishes yesterday. Anderson, Clayton would appear to have made points in both, but no decisive victory or defeat seemed likely soon.

WASHINGTON Economic spokesmen for the Carter Administration are currently suggesting that depreciation allowances may be liberalized under tax reform proposals headed for Congress this summer. Businessmen, meanwhile, welcome the moves but maintain they are long overdue.

DETROIT, June 22 "Are you real police?" Frank Nazar, Felix Kirk and John Pietrzak kept getting asked that question as they strolled the streets of downtown Detroit this morning, drawing surprised double takes and delighted grins.

The City University's SEEK program for disadvantaged students has been "so badly" and wastefully managed that its administration should be taken away from the university and put under New York State's Department of Education, the State Commission of Investigation said yester- day.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) President Carter, saying foreign boycotts go "to the very heart of free trade between all nations," today signed compromise legislation aimed at limiting the involvement of United States corporations in the Arab boycott of Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Organized labor, locked in a growing struggle for influence on legislation and other Governmental action, is turning from its traditional lobbying tactics to new sources of political power.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 It was a three-ring circus at staid old Wimbledon today. Brian Gottfried and Adriano Panatta were beaten, Ilie Nastase turned clown and then threatened to attack a newsman and Billie Jean King and Bjorn Borg were extended to the limits.
HOBOKEN, June 22 Tamby and Skelly had a reunion of sorts today in the reading room of the public library here and reminisced about 1935, the Hoboken Four, and their old friend Slats.

CHICAGO, June 22 After adopting constitutional changes that free its chief executive officer from the restraining grip of the chairman of the board, the National Hockey League surprised no one this afternoon by unanimously electing John A. Ziegler Jr. as its next president. He will be the first American to head the Canadian dominated league and will be its fourth president.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Despite the ravages of coyotes, snowstorms and a naturally high infant mortality rate, the whooping crane took a giant step away from the brink of extinction this spring, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service reported today.

The dollar, damaged by news of a record first-quarter balance of payments deficit for the United States, closed broadly lower against most other currencies in foreign exchange trading here yesterday, the Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON AFTER four months on the job, Patricia Derian has become official. She was sworn in as the State Department's co- ordinator for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs at a White House ceremony last Friday.

The Lorillard division of The Loew's Corporation said yesterday that it had sold rights to make and market its cigarettes outside the United States and American posessions to a British concern for $141 million in cash.

WASHINGTON, June 22 Her Britannic Majesty's Ambassador to Washington took a once-over-lightly glance today at the country where he has spent seven of his 29 years as a diplomat and then said to a group of Americans. "I think you are in for a good time."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 23 Paul Oppenheim, noted philosopher of science, died yesterday in his home here. He was 92 years old.

DETROIT, June 23 The United States automobile industry reported today that mid-June sales increased 14 percent from last year to give it a second consecutive 10-day selling record.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 23 Williwaw, the new Peterson 47-foot sloop raced by Seymore Sinett of Plainfield, N.J., won in Class A around Block Island in light northwesterly winds today in the fourht race of the Storm Trysail Club's race week.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 23 (UPI) A.J. Foyt upstaged Johnny Rutherford with a late qualifying start today and won the pole position for Sunday's Pocono 500-mile race with a two-lap average speed of 189.44 miles per hour.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 23 Ted Turner put on a show at the America's Cup trials today for his baseball team, the Atlanta Braves, who were watching from an excursion boat on a day off, and also for the New York Yacht Club's Selection Committee.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) Agatha Christie's 16-year-old detective story "The Pale Horse" saved the life of a 19-month-old girl dying of a condition that baffled London doctors, the British Journal of Hospital Medicine reported today.

Sander Vanocur, television editor of The Washington Post and former network correspondent, has been named vice president in charge of special reporting units of ABC Television, supervising political and investigative reporting from Washington.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development is coming under increasing pressure to ease its environmental review requirements for projects that use Federal community development funds.
Do you find reading new material in your field difficult to understand, become confused by new concepts, find new assignments very difficult and realize your advice is not taken by others?

FAIRFIELD, Conn. I tried to walk to the far side of the Williamsburg Bridge, but they've taken the sidewalks away. A cabdriver found the place easily the almost empty street, the boarded-up house, waiting now for the wrecker's ball. With the key that's been in my pocket all these years, I quietly let myself in. Surely, I thought, if I'm silent enough some shadow will show itself, a long-ago echo will be heard.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The National Cancer Institute will start clinical trials in the near future of the purported anticancer chemical, laetrile, Federal scientists told Congress today.
People who like their nostalgia spiced with a twist of fright might look into Coney Island on Sunday, where the Cyclone is celebrating 50 years as a roller coaster.

ALBANY, June 23 The Legislature gave final passage today to a bill requiring dog-owners in New York City and Buffalo to clean up after their pets on streets or in any other public places, under penalty of a $100 fine for each violation.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has landed a 500-year old sculpture of a winged boy hugging a slippery fish done by Andrea del Verrocchio and, before it gets away on July 3, you can see it in the central court of the Lehman Pavilion.
The Newport-New York Jazz Festival, which begins today, is not the only jazz festival in town. Four musicianrun lofts are presenting festivals of their own during part or all of Newport's 11-day run.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Barry Bosworth a 34-year-old economist at the Brookings Institution who believes in an interventionist role by the Government in the wage-price sector, was reported today to be President Carter's choice for director of the Council on Wage and Price Stability.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously last night to give the B'nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn $1 million in new Federal job funds, although the institute is under investigation by three different Federal agencies for its operation of summer job and lunch programs last year.
The uniforms and equipment have all been bought, the name tapes affixed, the trunks packed and shipped and all that remains are the farewells before the big separation of sleepaway camp.

To those who believe, it was Krishna the god whose domain included the dance who set the world in motion, and motion has moved the world and the people in it ever since. In the lands touched by Hindu faith, past or present, the dance reflects the sensuous beauty of religion, the employment of body to describe man and god, good and evil.

THE television schedule has slipped quietly into a typical pattern of summer sluggishness, but it is not without occasional offbeat forays that, for good or ill, can leave the viewer startled. One unusual project, scheduled for this afternoon at 3:15 on Channel 13, is called "Docu menta 6."

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The United States Geological Survey said a gas blowout occurred today at an offshore well being drilled by the Continental Oil Company about 100 miles south of New Iberia, La., in the Gulf of Mexico.
Two pedestrians were wounded by gunshots from a policeman who opened fire on a stolen car whose driver the officer said, was attempting to run him down in crowded Union Sqare yesterday morning.

Commercial and industrial loans from major New York City banks increased $600 million in the week ended Wednesday, their largest gain since they rose by a record $1.2 billion in early July 1974, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Spear, Leeds Kellogg, the largest specialist unit at the New York Stock Exchange, has received approval to begin competing in the 19 stocks registered with the specialist unit of Blair S. Williams Company, the exchange announced yesterday.
A new era begins today in the supply of the nation's most widely used and essential commodity, drinking water.
A 40-year-old New York City Fire Department official was killed early yesterday when a wall of a burning discotheque in Brooklyn collapsed.

Sussman Sugar Advertising has resigned the Grove Press account partly, it said, for fear that "My Story," the Judith Exner book being published by Grove, might involve it in litigation. The book concerns the "relationship" that Judith Campbell Exner says she had with the late President Kennedy.

MARK TWAIN called the human species "the only animal that blushes or needs to." In the same spirit H.L. Mencken discovered a certain subspecies that he named the "boobus Americanus." He was our own G.B. Shaw: the American in charge of outrage. All through the Roaring Twenties and Depression Thirties he helped to keep the country going with epigrams and attacks upon censorship and sham.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) A strong demand developed for soybean, soybean meal and oil futures on the Chicago Board of Trade today after two days of declining prices, and the three commodities in the complex closed sharply higher.

LONDON, June 23 Shell and the Esso subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation announced jointly here today that they had made a "potentially commercial" oil strike in the North Sea in relatively shal low water about 170 miles east of Dundee, Scotland.

The Zero Population Growth organization held news conferences in nine cities yesterday to announce its national policy, which includes proposals to change the Federal tax code, eliminate illegal immigration and reduce the number of legal immigrants allowed into the United States.

AKRON, Ohio, June 23 (UPI) Three thousand gallons of volatile naphtha, believed poured into the city sewer system by striking rubber workers, exploded here today, sending manhole covers into the air, shattering the stained glass windows of a cemetery chapel and leaving a twomile scar.

KANSAS CITY, June 23 (AP) Craig Reynolds's single to left field scored Dan Meyer, and when Fred Patek bobbled a soft liner by Jose Baez another run scored, as the Seattle Mariners defeated the Kansas City Royals, 8-6, in 10 innings tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 23 A settlement reached in a Federal court in Chicago this week could pave the way for about 145,000 persons, many of them Mexicans, to immigrate to the United States or, in the case of some already in the United States without visas, to legalize their status as resident aliens, Government sources said today.

ALBANY, June 23 Peter A. Peyser today tried to convince a Senate panel that despite a confessed lack of technical knowledge about utilities, or regulation and in some ways because of it he was qualified to be chairman of the state's Public Service Commission.

When Joe Torre was named manager of the Mets, he received a telegram from Tom Lasorda, manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers. "One more Italian manager in the majors," Lasorda told Torre, "and we'll hold the winter meetings in Rome".

DOUAI, France, June 23 (AP) A 36year-old farmhand was put to death by guillotine today for having drowned an 8-year-old girl in a marsh in 1975. He was the second killer of a child to be guillotined in the last 12 months, and his death set off new denunciations of capital punishment.
Wide open spaces are the logical sites for launching your rockets. But there are traditional spots in the area, as well as some words of caution for other sites. Here is a brief selection:
LAS DELICIAS, Mexico When the Mexican Army water truck is a few days late, the villagers of Las Delicias drink from a watering place used by cattle and goats and, almost overnight, they fall ill.

JERICHO, L.I., June 23 Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks won her third championship in three weeks today as she captured the 36th Women's Long Island Golf Association title with a 54hole total of 235 at the Meadow Brook Club. She had previously won the 1977 Women's Cross-County Golf Association and Women's Metropolitan Golf Association titles.

ALBANY, June 23 Governor Carey today signed into law a major revision of the jury-selection system. It is expected to enlarge jury pools and requires the random picking of grand jurors from the same pool that provides trial jurors.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Carter Administration today barred an American company from selling an advanced computer system to the Soviet Union for use in weather research because, it said, the system could also be used for military purposes.

New York City's Traffic Department said yesterday that it had finished covering parking meters and erecting no-parking signs in the "core" area of Manhattan as set out in the parking restriction plan imposed on the city by a Federal court last week.
GREENWICH, Conn. A year and a half ago this town of 63,000, one of the wealthiest and safest communities in the country, was shocked by the murder of a 15-year-old girl.
The Sunshine Mining Company, operator of the nation's largest silver mine in the Coeur d'Alene district of northern Idaho, has an ally at least indirectly in the Idaho Attorney General.

LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) Guy Edwards, a British racing driver, was awarded Queen Elizabeth's gallantry medal for extricating Niki Lauda, a fellow driver, from his burning Ferrari during the West German Grand Prix last year.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Justice Department's antitrust division is making "a preliminary investigation of possible anticompetitive behavior in the international crude oil market," the division's acting chief said today.

METUCHEN, N.J., June 23 Rail service for at least 30,000 commuters and longdistance travelers on Amtrak's busy Boston-to-Washington corridor remained disrupted today because of a freight-train derailment at the southern tip of the business district here last night.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The House today approved a $6.7 billion foreign aid appropriations bill, but only after placing Cuba, Angola and Mozambique on a list of nations excluded from receiving any American aid, directly or indirectly.
Steve Cauthen returned to center stage at Belmont Park yesterday, and in keeping with his stature as a matinee idol, the jockey made his first-act entrance a winning one.

NANCHANG, China At first it seemed like another one of those heroic accomplishments of the new Maoist man. Here was a commune that had transformed itself in just eight years, building a network of big dams, reservoirs and aqueducts and achieving huge increases in the rice crop.
In a contest held yesterday morning at Shea Stadium, the Junior Yankees defeated the Junior Mets, 10-4, in the 37th annual Greater New York Sandlot Alliance all-star game.

It was over in an instant, and Christopher Lloyd still isn't sure how it happened. One moment he was striding about the stage at Brooklyns' Chelsea Theater Center, whipping a gang of thugs into line in his role as Bill Cracker, the No. 1 gangster in the Brecht-Weill musical, "Happy End."

WASHINGTON, June 23 (Reuters) The securities industry is not making enough progress in creating a national stock market system and more Government action may be needed, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

SPECIALTY museums are proliferating now, thanks in part to enthusiastic collectors who spend decades amassing comprehensive materials relating to a single interest. This month one of the most interesting of these new institutions, the United States Tobacco Company Museum, opened in Greenwich offering an abscrbing assemblage of rare, superbly crafted and curious pipes, cigar store figures, snuff boxes and bottles and spittoons.

Herbert Threlkeld Edwards, former director of the Motion Picture Service in the State Department's Overseas Information Program, died Tuesday evening of an apparent heart attack at the home of friends here. He was 76 years old and lived in Greenbrae, near San Francisco.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 23 For the children, even Vietnamese children who have long experience of the worst, the boat trips are frightening and remain alive in nightmares. But the refugees' receptions wherever their boats arrive if they arrive are incomprehensible.
Rust Craft Greeting Cards Inc. the owner of valuable radio and television properties disclosed yesterday that it had received a $46 million takeover bid.
A new era begins today in the supply of the nation's most widely used and essential commodity, drinking water.
NEW ORLEANS, June 23 (AP) The Gulf Oil Corporation bid $378 million to buy oil and gas rights in the Gulf of Mexico, setting the pace for unexpectedly high prices in today's sale of offshore leases.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 The hungry Americans had their day in the sun at Wimbledon today. And what a day it was for Billy (the Kid) Martin, Tim Gullikson and John McEnroe.

In the ongoing discussion about the "nationalization" of American medicine, it usually goes unnoticed that the largest single centrally directed medical system in the country is already run by the Federal Government. With a budget of around $4 billion a year, the Veterans Administration operates 171 hospitals and employs about 200,000 persons, including 16,000 doctors and more than 58,000 nurses. On any day, about 80,000 patients occupy V.A. beds.

David Summers has a mouth that is as cavernously gleaming as Carol Channing's and eyes that can project a variety of vivid emotions. At the Ballroom, West Broadway just below Houston Street, he is presenting himself as a singer, but his physical attributes give his work an added dimension that can range from comedy to thoughtful characterization.

Twenty-six hunger strikers have forced Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the iron ruler of Chile, to give a little ground but not much on the question of the approximately 1,500 persons who have "disappeared" in Chile.

WASHINGTON, June 23 A major policy review in the Carter Administration has concluded that the sale of United States military technology to China would lead to a "fundamental reassessment" of Soviet policies toward the United States and an increase of tension between Moscow and Peking.

MOSCOW, June 23 The Soviet Union, using a personal rebuke of the Spanish Communist leader Santiago Carrillo as a platform, today made a broader attack on so-called Eurocommunism, saying that this concept of independent parties in Western Europe was designed to split the international Communist movement.

New York State's highest court yesterday unanimously upheld a lower-court decision affirming the landmark status of Grand Central Terminal and denying the Penn Central company permission to build a 55-story tower atop the terminal.

The northern Queens region of Flushing has not, except for recurrent melodrama at Shea Stadium, had its name in lights as a performing arts center. A small and fortunate move in this direction has been started, since last September, by the Stage Company, a professional acting troupe that is at once regional and Off Off Broadway.

The General Tire Rubber Company, the nation's fifth largest tire maker, reported yesterday profit increases of 29.3 percent for the second fiscal quarter ended May 31 and 35 percent for the half-year period. It also noted that the proposed spinoff of its RKO General subsidiary to shareholders has been deferred.
The dollar made a comeback on New York foreign-exchange markets yesterday, but had a mixed and uneventful day in Europe, The Associated Press reported.

METUCHEN, N.J., June 23 Rail service for at least 30,000 commuters and longdistance travelers on Amtrak's busy Boston-to-Washihgton corridor remained disrupted today because of a freight-train derailment at the southern tip of the business district here last night.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The Senate passed today a new mass transit bill to allot an additional $5.8 billion to transit construction and operating programs over the next five years, but none of the new money could become available until after Oct. 1, 1978.
TO MAKE A theater evening out of those Cole Porter songs that are more or less forgotten some of them dropped from his musicals before their openings is a double-edged venture.

WASHINGTON, June 23 A major policy review in the Carter Administration has concluded that the sale of United States military technology to China would lead to a "fundamental reassessment" of Soviet policies toward the United States and an increase of tension between Moscow and Peking.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 The International League for Human Rights has protested to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, saying that it has evidence of mass arrests and torture of Iranians as well as harassment by the Government's secret police of Iranian citizens living abroad.

JOHANNESBURG, June 23 Hundreds of young blacks mounted an audacious protest in downtown Johannesburg today and thousands more rioted in the black township of Soweto, provoking clashes with the police in which at least one youth died.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Administration officials said today that arguments had been going on in several Government agencies for more than a week over three proposed agricultural loans to Chile by the Agency for International Development.
Milton Young, a lawyer who specialized in tax law, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 303 East 57th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission today revoked a decade-old set of firstaid instructions for persons who accidentally swallow alcohol-based antifreeze, saying the advice could be fatal.

GALLAGHER'S, the 44-year-old steak house on 52d Street just west of Broadway, is one of the local landmarks we tend to take for granted But a few weeks ago, leaving a theater at 10:30 completely starved, we remembered that Gallagher's stayed open late and so a group of six walked in unrecognized and without a reservation. The total experience that followed was altogether felicitous and satisfying.
Fred Corcoran, whose 60 year association with golf as a promoter and an executive helped build the sport to its present stature, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Representative Donald M. Fraser, chairman of the subcommittee that heard testimony yesterday from Kim Hyung Wook, a former chief of the Korean Central Intelligence agency, said today that his evidence was "consistent" with information gathered from other sources.

MOBILE, Ala., June 24 (UPI) Eddie Stanky returned to Mobile today after a one-day stint as manager of the Texas Rangers and explained that "after the excitement calmed down I started getting lonesome and homesick." So he quit.
The House Select Committee on Assassination is seeking to appoint as its senior investigator a New York City police detective who is an authority on organized crime.

Lee Laimbeer Cornell, a civic leader and a former assistant to Helen Rogers Reid late president of The New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 66 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

New York is the only city in the world where you can get deliberately run down on the sidewalk by a pedestrian. Off your guard for an instant, and they smash head-on into you, or more commonly, they clip you blindside on one shoulder and send you skidding out of control into an oncoming mass of pedestrians who batter your hipbones and dent your sternum. It's a sidewalk demolition derby.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 24 A judge turned down today a father's plea to have his 23-year-old diabetic son, a member of the Hare Krishna religious sect, placed under a permanent guardian.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24 Independence, the yacht that has been the least impressive of the three at the America's Cup trials this week, broke down twice today, or once and a half, while racing Courageous. The observation committee of the New York Yacht Club, which eventually will select one yacht to defend the Cup, called off the races, which in both instances had only begun, so very little was accomplished.

PARIS, June 24-In an effort to curb high unemployment, the United States and other major industrial nations in the non-Communist world committed themselves today to achieve a higher average rate of economic growth next year that they are expected to attain during 1977.

DRUMMONDVILLE, Canada, June 24 (AP) Andre Fortin, leader of Canada's Social Credit Party, was killed early today when his car plunged into a river near this city in Quebec, the police said. He was 33 years old.

The House of Representatives has voted by a lopsided margin to prohibit any international institution from using American money for aid to seven countries Cuba, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Angola, Mozambique and Uganda. In a fit of uncomprehending pique, liberals, centrists and conservatives made common cause thus to undermine President Carter's attempts to re-establish some decent relationships with Indochina and Cuba, and to cloud the future of the international aid agencies.

Here are two impressive books that turn the laser beam of modern historical scholarship on the institution of slavery in the United States and pierce the magnolia-scented fog that has all but blotted out the true dimensions of the bondage system in the South.

PARIS, June 24 After an hour-long report from President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on the recent French-Soviet meeting, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance changed his assessment of United States-Soviet relations today and acknowledged that there were "strains in certain areas."

WASHINGTON, June 24 President Carter offered today to make a voluntary payment of $6,000 to the Government after his 1976 income tax return showed that, because of investment credits and deductions, he owed no tax on a gross income of almost $55,000 for that year.

The first thing to be said about the Stuttgart Ballet's new production of "The Sleeping Beauty," which had its New York premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night, is how pretty it looked. The second thing is to inquire how pretty "The Sleeping Beauty" should look, Might not a case be made for magnificence, rather than prettiness?

WASHINGTON, June 24 In a ruling that strengthens the power of states to aid parochial education, the Supreme Court held today that states may finance therapeutic, remedial and guidance coun seling services for parochial schoolchildren as long as the services are provided at "neutral" sites off the school premises.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) The biggest stock offer in British history opened and closed in one minute today as the Bank of England announced that its sale of more than 66 million shares of the British Petroleum Company had been oversubscribed.

Steve Cauthen, feeling his way through his second day of riding after a month's absence because of injury, scored twice in six starts at Belmont Park yesterday, thereby assuring his followers that he had not lost his winning touch.
In a cap and red gown, 18-year-old Kevin Carro awaited the first graduation ceremony of his experimental school yesterday and thought himself lucky.

WASHINGTON A new analytical instrument patented this week is intended to save the lives of victims of poison or drug overdose by instantaneously identifying toxic substances in fluids. The instrument, called a video fluorometer, was invented by James B. Callis and Ernest R. Davidson, faculty members at the University of Washington, in Seattle. They were granted Patent 4,031,398.
ALBANY, June 24 The Assembly gave final Legislative approval today to a bill setting up a nine-member commission to study the problem of property assessment end report back by the end of next year.
State lawmakers generally are voting for the status quo on marijuana and alcohol restrictions, rejecting efforts to ease penalties for possession of the drug and raise the legal drinking age.

A principal who fought the Board of Education over an order to reinstate a girl he had suspended was cheered and applauded by students and their parents at his high school's commencement exercises yesterday.

Two sons of Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator convicted of Medicaid fraud, were replaced yesterday as administrator and controller of the Park Crescent Nursing Home by the trustee appointed to take over five operation of the home from Mr. Bergman.

If Il Y. Chung were Chinese and he had immigrated here, he might well have gone into the laundry or restaurant business. If he were Greek, he might have gone into a coffee shop or delicatessen. But Mr. Chung is Korean and so he entered the newly popular Korean-American enterprise: he opened a fruit and vegetable store.
BLOCK ISLAND, June 24 Obsession clinched first place in the cumulative standing of the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Week racing regatta today by winning her final Division F race of the series.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The Commerce Department said today that within certain limits it would let American-flag ships built with Federal subsidies and intended for foreign trade carry crude oil from Alaska to the Pacific end of the Panama Canal.

HONG KONG, June 23 In contrast to the cataclysmic style of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, Peking's new leaders seem to be moving methodically, with a thoroughness characteristic of their bureaucratic background, taking each problem in turn.
WASHINGTON, June 24 Rejecting appeals to "heal the wounds" of war, the Senate refused today to give the Administration money to carry out President Carter's pardon of Vietnam draft resisters.

SAN SALVADOR ISLAND, the Bahamas, June 18 Bored above sea level and undaunted by sharks and other creatures below it, growing numbers of Americans are bubbling into the deep in search of recreational thrills.

Bridge-players, like Gaul, are divided into three parts, at least when it comes to leading from a worthless three-card holding. The traditional choice is the high card, the "top of nothing." Many tournament players favor "MUD," which means that they begin with the middle card, then play up and finally down. And a substantial number of experts, especially on the East Coast, lead low from three small cards.
A black activist bishop from Tanzania yesterday became the first African and the first of his race to head the 58 million-member Lutheran World Federation.

WASHINGTON, June 24, President Carter intends to submit his budget for the fiscal year 1979 to Congress next January with a substantially reduced deficit. As part of the budget review process to meet this goal he has just established lean preliminary projections covering spending by agencies and departments.

Some telephone users who have been called from a coin station have been able to simulate additional coin deposits and continue to talk free. Bell Telephone Laboratories has developed a way to prevent fraudulent signals from being accepted.
Soybeans and soybean oil prices moved wildly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, closing above the preceding day's level after having taken an early morning plunge.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 Chris Evert remembers nothing about her endless summer of '71, but she will never forget today's first meeting with Tracy Austin on the center court at Wimbledon.
Bill Greeley, one of the-most respected television critics and reporters, died yesterday, while on assignment in Los Angeles for Variety. He was 56 years old and lived at 95 Christopher Street.
The New York City Police Department will soon supply all its highway patrol cars with radar in a move to tighten enforcement of speed limits and reduce accidents.

ALANTIC CITY, June 24 The City Commission adopted an interim zoning ordinance early this morning that establishes 11 areas as sites for gambling casinos.

The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday unanimously approved New York City's financial plan and budget for the fiscal year beginning Friday and a policy for granting cost-of-living raises to 200,000 city workers. It then formally requested a $750 million seasonal loan next month from the United States Treasury Department.
OAK BROOK, Ill., June 24 (AP) Tom Watson shot a 69 and Andy North a 70 today as the two close friends tied for the lead in the Western open golf tournament with 36-hole scores of 139 five under par.

A principal who fought the Board of Education over an order to reinstate a girl he had suspended was cheered and applauded by students and their parents at his high school's commencement exercises yesterday.

CAIRO, June 24 The Government of President Anwar el-Sadat, which has been feuding with the Soviet Union for the last five years, declared today that the time for reconciliation between the two countries was not yet at hand.
CHICAGO, June 24 The struggling Mets stepped smack into the intensity of the, National League East pennant race today and got flattened by the Chicago Cubs, 5-0.

JAKARTA, Indonesia A debate has erupted in Indonesian Government circles over when the country will run out of oil and therefore over its continuing ability to attract investment and borrow on world financial markets.

Last summer's Newport-New York Jazz Festival began with a concert by a pop singer, Tony Bennett, a choice a number of observers found inappropriate. This year's festival began yesterday with a free concert in Washington Square Park by Eddie Palmieri and his Latin orchestra. There will be more free Latin concerts throughout the jazz festival's 11-day run, all of them on the Jazzmobile's traveling stage, at various locations around the city.

KINGSTON, St. Vincent Island, June 24 (AP) An ax-wielding assailant attacked a former New York executive aboard his sailboat early today, the police said. The victim, Carl E. Schuster, died a few hours, later in a hospital here.

Four men were convicted of second-degree murder and robbery yesterday in the 1976 holdup of a Times Square movie theater in which two armed guards were slain with shotguns.

A police officer was given a conditional discharge following his conviction in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday of attempted assault, harassment and menacing a cab driver who, in defense, swung his umbrella at another police officer, hitting him in the eye and killing him.

With motors in cars and boats being revved up for vacations at the shore, the New Jersey State Safety Council is offering a lot of sound advice on how to avoid accidents.
