CHICAGO, June 24 The National Hockey League finally extended its hand today to the beseeching World Hockey Association and agreed to negotiate a consolidation of the two rival leagues.

Roxy Music was about the most interesting rock band from Britain in the early 1970's. But it was always wracked with tensions between its members, and ever since Bryan Ferry, the lead singer, put out his first solo disk in 1974, he seems to have devoted more energy to his own career than to the band.

The Federal Reserve decided at a midMay meeting to nudge short-term interest rates higher in order to slow the growth of the nation's money supply, according to minutes of the meeting released in Washington yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The Supreme Court ruled today that stockholders of corporations chartered in Delaware were not subject to having their shares seized as part of a lawsuit against them in that state when both they and the stock were situated elsewhere.
PARIS, June 24 Three Dutchmen and the international organization's they head are maneuvering for a major role in helping the world pay for its soaring oil bill.

CINCINNATI, June 24 A standingroom crowd of 51,864 welcomed Tom Seaver "home" to the banks of the Ohio tonight. But the longtime hero of the New York Mets was outpitched by Tommy John as the Los Angeles Dodgers edged the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, in the opening round of the battle for the National League's Western Division.

MADRID Whether Spain has already been significantly transformed since Franco died in November 1975 is a topic of intense debate among many people here, but not for the provincial Communist Party leader in San Sebastian.

The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday unanimously approved New York City's financial plan and budget for the fiscal year beginning Friday and a policy for granting cost-of-living raises to 200,000 city workers. WASHINGTON, June 24 With high stakes involved, the Senate Commerce Committee opened the starting gate today on a battle to determine if Congress should prevent state-operated offtrack betting parlors mainly those in New York from accepting bets on out-of-state races.

PARIS, June 24 In an effort to curb high unemployment, the United States and other major industrial nations in the non-Communist world committed themselves today to achieve a higher average race of economic growth next year than they are expected to attain during 1977.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 (AP) Lebanon has decided for the first time in 10 years to allow new banks to be established in the country, Finance Minister Farid Raphael said today.

MONTEREY, Calif., June 26 (AP)Don Breidenbach, a 27-year-old driver from Oakland, Calif., flashed to a startto-finish victory today in the second 1977 sports Car Club of America CanAm Challenge race. Ccmpeting at Laguna Seca Racaway, he averaged 108.60 miles an hour in his Tropicana Lola before 18,000 fans.

ALPINE, June 26 At a little before 11 o'clock last night, Edward Verso of Oakland was standing on the stage of the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack acknowledging the applause and bravos for his performance as the lead dancer in the New Jersey Ballet's new production, "Emperor Waltz."

COLUMBIA, Tenn., June 26 Fortytwo persons died today in a fire that poured choking smoke through the Maury County Jail here. Most of the victims were prisoners who were either locked in their cells or behind a security screen in the visiting area of the jail.

PARIS, Ky., June 27 (Reuters) Fanfreluche, a broodmare in foal to Secretariat whose worth is estimated at $500,000, was stolen from a paddock at Claiborne Farm here over the weekend; the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today. Ziegler, the N.H.L.'s president-elect, who was running the high-pitched meetings in Chicago.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 It was a match Chris Evert wanted to win badly, a challenge, she said, at a time when new challenges are scarce in her tennis career. Win it she did, 6-1, 6-2. The margin was so big that Billie Jean King, her opponent, got only one more game against the top-seeded defending champion on the center court than 14-year-old Tracy Austin did.

Moscow, June 27 An officially sanctioned exhibition by a prominent Soviet artist was indefinitely postponed today following a dispute over one controversial painting that portrayed the exiled writer Aleksandr I. ROME, June 27 Pope Paul VI appealed anew today to the rebellious French Archbishop, Marcel Lefebvre, to abandon his plans to ordain 14 priests and 22 subdeacons Wednesday at his unauthorized seminary in Switzerland.

Joe Torre ended his first month as manager of the Mets last night with a rude reminder of the headaches that go with the job: The Philadelphia Phillies scored two runs in the seventh inning to tie the Mets, then two more in the ninth to defeat them, 4-2.

SOUTH CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 27 (UPI) A fifth former employee of the Union Carbide chemical plant here has died of a rare form of liver cancer believed to be linked to long-term exposure to vinyl chloride, a company spokesman said today.

At a time when supposed baseball experts are expecting the Chicago Cubs to revert to their also-ran status of the last 30 National League seasons, the leaders of the Western Division are playing at the top of their stunning form.

WASHINGTON, June 27 Lower imports of oil and coffee, plus higher exports of manufactured goods and soybeans, helped the United States record its smallest trade deficit of the year last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

BUFFALO, June 27 A Rembrandt stolen in France in 1971 and valued at $250,000 was recovered when officials smashed a fence operation here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. F.B.I. agents along with state and local policemen arrested 23 suspects throughout western New York and other suspects still were being sought.
The most ambitious and extensive advertising program ever undertaken to make New York State a tourist mecca broke last night on TV in 20 markets in and around the state.

One of the best-played deals of the recent Spring Nationals in Pasadena, Calif., was executed by Mark Blumenthal of Schaumberg, Ill., and it helped his team to win the final of the Vanderbilt Cup. Blumenthal and his partner, Mike Lawrence of Berkeley, Calif., form one of the country's strongest partnerships.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday included all 22,000 Civil Service workers in Nassau County in a lawsuit brought by three of them to challenge 1 percent kickbacks allegedly demanded by county officials for appointment or promotion.

ALBANY, June 27-Governor Carey said today he would veto any bill permitting the use of laetrile, the purported anticancer drub, because "I believe it's not only quackery, it may be fraud and, indeed, profiteering on a worthless drug."
JONES, Mich., June 27 (AP) Piece by piece, Jones fell to the auctioneer's gavel over the weekend as a Kitty Litter magnate gave up his dream of turning this tiny town into a tourist attraction.
SALISBURY, Md. June 27 (AP) Arthur W. Perdue, founder of Perdue Inc., one of the nation's largest poultry producing companies, died today at Peninsula General Hospital here. He was 91 years old.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 27 A funeral mass for Walter Kennedy, the former commissioner of the National Basketball Association, who died yesterday, will be held Thursday at 11 A.M. at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The battle lines over trans-Alaska pipeline rates were drawn today as companies that own the pipeline said they might have to shut it down if the Interstate Commerce Commission did not approve their oil transport charges and the Government called that a bluff.

The scarcity of adoptable Caucasian infants has become so critical in this country that prices paid for them on the illegal market now run as high as $20,000, with brokers getting most of the money. The black market, so extensive that it includes international networks for procuring infants, is under investigation by prosecutors in New York and several other major cities.

WASHINGTON Negotiating with Cuba is no longer inevitable, it has begun. My purpose is not to question the wisdom of talking to Fidel Castro, but to suggest how we should go about it. What's important is that the Carter Administration's mindless moralizing about human rights is likely to gain us nothing. In fact, it is more likely to worsen the lot of the Cuban people.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A report by the National Academy of Sciences has raised questions about the effectiveness of some of the Environmental Protection Agency's regulatory programs but found that the overall economic and energy cost of antipollution regulations was relatively low and manageable.
ROME, June 27 The Italian Government has decided to bar foreign students from Italian universities for the next two years.
Lenora Walker Holloway, a former teacher and club woman, died Saturday at the Sheridan Manor Nursing Home in Buffalo. She was 85 years old and a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

HONOLULU, June 27-Gov. George R. Ariyoshi and Mayor Frank F. Fasi of Honolulu are on a collision course in the latest development in Hawaii's controversy over efforts to control the rising population.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27-It was a match Chris Evert wanted to ivin badly, a challenge, she said, at a time when new challenges are scarce in her tennis career. Win it she did, 6-,1 6-2. The margin was so big that Billie Jean King, her opponent, got only one more game against the top-seeded defending champion on the center court than 14-year-old Tracy Austin did.

JAKARTA, Indonesia-International population experts concluding a census here have discovered significant evidence that the growth rate has slowed in eastern Java and Bali, the most densely populated region of the fifth most populous country.

MADRID, June 27 Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, said today that the Soviet Union might attempt to set up a rival Spanish party to battle the emerging doctrine of Eurocommunism.

Jerome Kurtz, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, is taking a hard look at taxing fringe benefits. There are indications that everything from personal use of the corporate jet to company-paid taxi rides for late-working employees will come under scrutiny.
Nina Simone, who was scheduled to perform in New York for the first time in three years Sunday night at the Newport Jazz Festival, failed to appear at Carnegie Hall for her midnight concert.

TRENTON, June 27-Assembly Dmocrats, using all the pressure at their command, tonight brought out of order and passed a bill creating a state energy office.

The Avco Corporation, a conglomerate whose operations range from insurance to aircraft equipment, reported yesterday that net income rose 6.1 percent in the May quarter, although first-half net was down 13.1 percent. CHICAGO, June 28 The Illinois Appellate Court today apparently ended the threat of a Nazi march on the Fourth of July in the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie.

President Carter has been pictured as wading through a 1 -inch stack of reports on the strategic implications of the B-1 bomber plus a thick book of engineering evaluations. The New York State Department of Social Services has turned over the names of 80 physicians to the Manhattan District Attorney and to the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York for prosecution of suspected Medicaid fraud.

President Carter's willingness to challenge the Soviet Union politically and ideologically in the world's trouble spots strikes a number of America's friends in allied, neutral and friendly governments as a worthy but slightly unrealistic position.

Dr. Jacob I. Migden, who conducted a private medical practice in New York City since 1937, died Monday in Beth Israel Hospital, where he was a member of the staff. He lived at 70-20 170th St., Flushing, and had offices at 216 East 12th Street, Manhattan. His age was 66.

One of the features of this summer's Newport Jazz Festival is a five-event series called "Salsa en la Calle," or salsa in the street. What it means is that leading salsa groups perform around New York City from the Jazzmobile, a truck that has been converted into a movable platform for music.

HONG KONG, June 28 Peking has rebuffed an effort by American academic organizations to expand the scope of scholarly and scientific exchanges with China, saying that such action must await full normalization of relations between the United States and China, the president of the American Council of Learned Societies disclosed today.

Barry, president of Circle Lines, and Stanley S. Shuman, executive vice president of Allen Company, an investment banking firm.

It's a long way from the parlor of Aggie Shelton's sporting house in Baltimore to the elegant Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of the RCA Building. Burton H. White, formerly senior partner in the New York City admiralty law firm of Burlingham, Underwood, Wright, White Lord, died at his home in Charleston, S. C., Monday. He was 77 years old.

Undaunted, evidently, he went on to produce some of the most popular operas: "Aida,' "Rigoletto," "II Trovatore,' "La Traviata" and "Don Carlo."

LONDON, June 26-Rudolf Nureyev's completely new staging of Prokofiev's ballet "Romeo and Juliet" is very different from its predecessors and is absolutely fascinating. It is fresh and original, and considering that this new work for the London Festival Ballet is the first time he has created a completely original ballet on such a scale, the certainty of the achievement is all the more remarkable.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 Attorney General John Hill of Texas has requested a California court to compel a personal aide to the late Howard R. Hughes to answer questions regarding Mr. Hughes's use of drugs and how they were obtained.

JOHANNESBURG, June 28-South Africa's official white opposition group disbanded today in preparation for forming a somewhat wider organization tomorrow in the hope of better challenging the governing National Party of Prime Minister John Vorster.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) Operators of a $76 million oil drilling tax shelter, whose investors included professional athletes Larry Csonka and Brooks Robinson, have agreed to stop allegedly fraudulent activities, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

Mary Astor, Lauren Bacall, Ingrid Bergman, Gladys George, Lee Patrick and Claire Trevor shiver at the end of the fog-shrouded San Francixo pier ("It is always foggy in detective stories," says Neil Simon) and coil themselves around Humphrey Bogart for warmth.

A study commissioned by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, conducted by two academic economists and released yesterday showed that exchange-traded options had no negative effect on the market for low-priced new stock issues.

The Help Wanted Advertising Index, the Conference Board's barometer of employment trends, rose in May.
THIRTY-ONE states now permit wine to be sold in grocery stores, the way it is in France and Italy. A bill that would add New York State to that list has been pigeon-holed in Albany.
A national amateur sports festival bringing together all of America's top athletes is under consideration for the summer of 1978.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 The president and two top officers of the land-rich Irvine Company announced their resignations today effective with the July 25 sale of the company to Taubman-Allen Irvine Inc., a group of investors that includes Henry Ford 2d.

TORONTO, June 28 Reggie Jackson, who once again aroused Manager Billy Marin's ire, played a significant role tonight in one of the Yankees' worst defensive performances of the season. WASHINGTON, June 28 The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to deny a cost-of-living pay increase to members of Congress, Federal judges and other top Government officials. A fencing operation that dealt in guns, counterfeit currency, stolen checks, typewriters, sneakers, suits and even a Gucci fur coat was closed and its owner and 15 customers were indicted, District Attorney Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 29 The Henley Royal Regatta, rowed since its inception in 1839 on the same stretch of the Thames River that flows through this idyllic town, begins tomorrow. WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Federal courts have issued restraining orders prohibiting the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from withholding Medicaid money from at least four of 20 states faced with a cutoff of funds by this Friday.

SARASOTA, Fla., June 29 (AP) A 15year-old girl who was abducted from a Girl Scout camp by a man who ripped through the back of her tent at dawn today telephoned her father late tonight and said that she was all right and would be released soon, the authorities said.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Supreme Court told lower courts today to take another look at school desegregation orders requiring extensive busing in Omaha and Milwaukee.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 29 The Harrison Town Board voted unanimously tonight to reject a Nestle Company petiiton to build its headquarters on a 53-acre site in the center of the town's Purchase section. Its headquarters are now in White Plains.
WASHINGTON Though bitter political battles are not unusual in this capital, the intensity of the fight over natural gas pricing has startled even veteran observers.

International trade benefits the United States and its trading partners. Free trade, unfettered by tariffs or quotas or other interventions, allows each country to specialize in goods it produces most cheaply, thereby increasing the income of all. That's what the textbooks say, and for the most part, they are right.

PEKING, June 29 (Reuters) Three disgraced Chinese officials have been subjected to mass criticism at a rally attended by a roaring crowd of 1.1 million in the troubled southwestern province of Yunnan, according to a radio report.

WASHINGTON, June 29 President Carter today ordered studies of how the Federal Government could better perform its functions in four major areas-law enforcement, local economic development, human services and administrative services through what he called "desperately needed" government reorganization.

At Jerry's in Bergdorf Goodman it may be Andrew Stein, a retired textile manufacturer, while at Ann Keane's facial emporium, one finds Warren Mirabile, who works in a delicatessen. At Georgette Klinger it's a constant stream of men, who have a facial area all to themselves.
NEW HAVEN THE NEWTOWN BEE held an open house on Sunday to celebrate its 100th birthday, and about 1,400 well-wishers came from all over to toast its obviously good health.

ALBANY, June 29 The State Senate tonight gave final legislative passage to a measure that would allow the death penalty for virtually all murders.

When the shares of a company fall below book value the theoretical breakup value of the company they are often regarded as attractive. This is particularly so if such a company has recorded substantial earnings over the years.

PARIS, June 29--The mounting intensity of the quarrels between the uncomfortably allied French Socialists and Communists has given new heart to Government supporters that they may win the next elections after all.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate voted tonight to bar Federal funds for abortions except when the mother's life is in danger, in cases of rape or incest or in certain other cases when it is considered "medically necessary."

Three officers of an agency that conducted a summer food program for needy children were indicted yesterday on charges of billing the Government for food that was never served and of serving it sometimes at unauthorized sites and sometimes to adults instead of children.

The former general counsel of Gulf and Western Industries, whose sentence for check forgery had been delayed more than a year while he cooperated with authorities, was ordered yesterday to begin serving immediately a prison term of up to three years. But later in the day he was given a two week reprieve.

WASHINGTON, June 29--President Carter met today with Defense Secretary Harold Brown to discuss the controversial B-1 strategic bomber amid a growing belief in Pentagon and Congressional circles that the President would authorize production of the plane at a limited rate.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation voted yesterday to discontinue the company's "step down at 60" policy. The program, which provided that the top management committee would be required to retire at the age of 60, has been in effect since 1972. The new retirement age reverts to the pre-1972 level of 65.

AKRON, Ohio, June 29 (AP) Most of the nation's major tiremakers will raise prices by 3 to 5 percent early next month, the companies said today. They said the increases were necessary because of rising costs, including wage increases won in last year's rubber workers' strike.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 Chris Evert, drained by the emotional drama of the last two weeks and the determination of Britain's revitalized tennis heroine, Virginia Wade, was beaten in the semifinals at Wimbledon today.

An experimental vaccine against gonorrhea will be tested later this year on a small group of human volunteers by a University of Pittsburgh research team, the head of the group announced yesterday.

The Mets put together a mixture of good pitching, opportune hitting, fine fielding and adventuresome baserunning last night at Shea Stadium to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-3, and break their six-game losing streak.

New and in most cases slightly higher ceilings on rent increases for rent-stabilized apartments were adopted yesterday by New York City's Rent Guidelines Board for apartments whose leases are signed over the next 12 months.

WASHINGTON, June 29 A former Army chaplain testified today that Pvt. Eddie D. Slovik, the only American soldier to be executed for desertion in this century, had come from a pool of six deserters being considered for the firing squad, and that Private Slovik was chosen on the basis of his psychological profile.

Steve Cauthen continued to enthrall his followers yesterday at Belmont Park in his new role as a journeyman jockey.
Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French Government-owned automotive company, like the American automotive producers, made a sharp recovery in operating results last year.

LONDON, June 29 (UPI) The Davis Cup tennis nations voted today to impose automatic one-year suspensions on countries that refused to play matches on political grounds. The proposal was carried by 40 votes to 12.

In popular music, a raucous, mockviolent sound rapes the eardrum: "punk rock" it is called or snarled. "Groove with me in the gutter, girl," is the message of such groups as the Sex Pistols, who blaze their dumdums through the filigree of old Elvisthe-Pelvis establishment-rock minuets.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Here is the roll-call by which the House defeated today by a vote of 241 to 181 an amendment that would have cut off funds for the pay rises for members of Congress, high Government officials and top civil servants that went into effect earlier this year. A yes vote is a vote to roll back the pay increases. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 29 Richard Sorkin, a former agent for many professional athletes, was arrested by the Nassau County District Attorney's office today and charged with the theft of more than $600,000 from 30 players he had represented.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 She has always been "Our Ginny," to the British, and the country seemed to rise and fall each summer with Virginia Wade's trying tennis fortunes at Wimbledon.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Tne Senate approved by voice vote today a $12.5 billion appropriation for the Department of Agriculture in 1978.
George M. Waugh Jr., who retired in 1944 as executive vice president of Borden Inc., died Wednesday night in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

YONKERS, June 30 The City Council tonight approved a $144 million budget for the fiscal year that begins tomorrow. The budget did not include anticipated, but still unapproved, state aid that Yonkers hoped could be used to meet wage demands of its policemen, firemen and sanitation workers.

Five years ago, Max Roach, the most influential young drummer to develop in the ferment of the be-bop era of the 1940's, left the active jazz scene to join the music department of the University of Massachusetts. He is back in town this weekend, on leave from academia, and will appear with his quartet tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival.
HOUSTON, June 30 A county grand jury in Austin today indicted Donald B. Yarbrough, an Associate Justice of the Texas Supreme Court, for perjury and forgery of an automobile title.

HONG KONG, June 30 The eightmonth campaign against followers of China's "radicals" appears to have reached a crescendo that, in the view of analysts here, may signal an effort by Peking to conclude it before a national congress of the Chinese Communist Party is held later this year.
PHOENIX, June 30 (UPI) Unions representing 45,000 workers in the United States copper industry voted today to strike all the major producers when contracts expired early tomorrow.

Dr. Charles C. Chang, assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, and a former president of the pediatrics section of the Kings County Medical Society, died Wednesday in Brookdale Hospital Medical Center after a short illness.
Foote, Cone Belding, aware of the growing shortage of young creative people, has taken the unusual step of establishing a structured, eight-week course to train them.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Justice Department has revoked an order authorizing the Federal Bureau of Investigation to go ahead with a computer project that had been rejected by the Ford Administration as a threat to individual privacy and civil liberties.
ECONE, Switzerland, June 30 The 14 priests ordained in a controversial ceremony yesterday at this center of Roman Catholic conservatism offered their first masses today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 (UPI) Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss and his Cabinet decided today to give up the emergency powers by which they governed Lebanon in the six months since the civil war ended.

James Lee Meadows "Captain Meadows" says the black lettering across the back of his pale yellow T-shirt climbed out of the well of his tiny boat yesterday, and talked about sailing his 13-foot-10inch vessel 1,700 miles up the Eastern Seaboard from Florida.
Soviet authorities are accusing Anatoly Shcharansky of high treason and of being a C.I.A. accomplice. President Carter calls him a "scapegoat" and denies Mr. Shcharansky had C.I.A, ties.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The cruise missile, which President Carter is seeking to deploy on the nation's bombers, promises to emerge as one of the most versatile weapons in the American arsenal.

Pedro Archuleta, a former member of the Protestant Episcopal Church's National Commission on Hispanic Affairs, was ruled in contempt of court and ordered to jail yesterday for his refusal to answer a Federal grand jury's questions about the 1975 bombing of Fraunces Tavern.

Governor Carey, acting on a request from the Order of the Sons of Italy in Queens, yesterday called upon news organizations and members of the criminaljustice system in New York State to "refrain from using the term 'Mafia.'"

The man at the bar at the Biltmore Hotel finished his last martini it may have been the bar's last one, too surreptitiously stuffed a wad of monogrammed napkins into a pocket of his pin-striped suit and walked out the door with his memories.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 The Security Council decided unanimously today to ask member countries of the United Nations to give "material" assistance to Mozambique to help it depend itself against border attacks by forces of Rhodesia's white-minority Government.

WASHINGTON, June 30 President Carter, in a surprise move, announced today that he was opposed to production of the B-1 strategic bomber and said that the United States would depend on existing weapons systems for its nuclear deterrent.

Irving H. Saypol, who served as Federal prosecutor in the sabotage and conspiracy trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and then sat as a New York State Justice for 26 years, died yesterday of cancer at his home. Justice Saypol, who was active on the State Supreme Court until a few days ago, was 71 years old and lived at 152 East 94th Street.

LONDON, June 30 The three Beaverbrook newspapers in London, The Daily Express, The Sunday Express and The Evening Standard, were taken over today by Trafalgar House Investments, the owner of the Cunard Line, London's Ritz Hotel and other interests.

SOME WORKS OF ART reach out to everybody; others speak more privately to the initiated. It is a virtue of "The Illustrated Journal" which runs for two more weekends, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays at 9 P.M. at the Shared Forms Theater that it can speak directly to the followers of a particular cult and still be of interest to a more general audience.

For those who hanker after a glorious Fourth of July in the old style, many small towns, villages and communities in the metropolitan area are offering fireworks, picnics, parades and patriotic observances over the weekend.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 In the insecure world of the aerospace industry, some had feared the worst. But, today's decision by President Carter against production of the B-1 bomber nevertheless hit workers at the Rockwell International Corporation plant here like a shell burst.

GENE SAKS is a prosperous, rapturously respected director, the recipient of a Tony for his staging of the musical "I Love My Wife" and a man who truly loves his off stage wife, Beatrice Arthur. Success, of course, is nothing new to him; he's the whiz who whipped "Same Time, Next Year" and "California Suite" into diamond-smooth shape, thereby assuring them long runs on Broadway.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 The American crews rowing in this year's Henley Royal Regatta came through today's opening round with flying colors. Six of the United States' eight eight-oared shells advanced.
The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, founded by Ted Shawn, opens its 45th summer season tomorrow in Lee, Mass., with a previously unscheduled gala benefit that seeks out the roots of American dance.

THE FOURTH OF JULY begins on television with an ending. The 325th and final episode of "Mary Hartman, Mary Hart man" will be shown on WNEW/Channel 5 at 11 P.M. Television's most spaced-out characters are winding up their off-the-wall escapades in typical Fernwood fashion.

NEW HAVEN, June 30 The Department of Justice said today that it was asking the Federal Bureau of Investigation to reopen its inquiry into charges that F.B.I. agents were involved in an extensive illegal wiretap operation by the New Haven Police Department.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (UPI) Former President Gerald R. Ford said today the decision by President Carter to cancel the B-1 bomber was a mistake.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 (AP)) Samson Kimombwa of Kenya set a world record in the 10,000-meter run today with a clocking of 27 minutes 30.47 seconds.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Senate apparently decided today that President Carter had it over a pork barrel and voted to compromise with him and kill nine of the 18 major water projects he wants eliminated.

The oil pricing split within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been settled with agreement that there will be no further price rises this year, Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez said yesterday.

FLEETWOOD MAC's debut Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden the first of two performances there-was a confirmation of its newly won status as this country's most popular and best poprock band except for, maybe the Eagles. And by and large it was a superior show to the group's outing earlier this year at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. With one crucial exception.

FORT SMITH, Ark., June 30 (AP) The parents of four young members of a religious group say they will return to their homes in California and New York and abandon efforts to gain custody of their children.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Asserting that Soviet-American relations were not in trouble, President Carter said today that he hoped to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev this year so that the two leaders could "get to know one another."

WASHINGTON, June 30 President Carter's decision not to build an expensive fleet of B-1 bombers shows vividly that he is a pragmatist not bound by ideology and an atypical politician who seems to prefer the role of manager.

Silver futures closed down 4.50 to 4.80 cents an ounce on an estimated volume of 11,500 contracts. Traders cited market pressure as a result of of nervous moves in the copper market based on the outcome of labor-management negotiations.

Confusing reports continued to circulate in the Middle East yesterday as to the oil-pricing intentions of Iraq and Libya. Of the 11 OPEC members that increased their prices by 10 percent last Jan. 1, only Iraq and Libya refused to join in the announcement in Vienna this week of an abandonment of an additional 5 percent price rise scheduled for July 1.

Twelve school construction projects were abruptly suspended in 1975 on the recommendation of the Emergency Financial Control Board to produce a "projected net cash savings" for New York City of $90 million.

ALBANY, June 30 Under its policy of getting polluters to clean up rather than just pay fines, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation said today that it had reached an agreement with an upstate fertilizer company to pump millions of gallons of ammonia-contaminated water from the ground around its Olean plant.

BRUSSELS, June 30 (Reuters) The world's largest industrial free trade area will be created tomorrow when the 16 nations in the Common Market and European Free Trade Association remove almost all customs tariffs and duties.
Now that a new Government presided over by Mr. Menahem Begin is installed in Israel, it would be useful to reiterate the position of Egypt regarding a peaceful settlement of the Middle East problem.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 30 The expected duel between Oil Burner, who recently was syndicated for $2.7 million, and Shadyside Trixie, the track's record-holder, in the $50,000 Hackensack Pace at the Meadowlands tonight failed to develop.

TRENTON, June 30 The head of the State Commission of Investigations said today that three of his 12 investigators who had applied for jobs with Resorts International Inc., which plans to open New, Jersey's first gambling casino in Atlantic City later this year, were being "separated" from the agency to protect its "integrity."

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, June 30 The Foreign Minister of Kenya today surprised the meeting of the Organization of African Unity here by reporting that his country had been invaded by thousands of armed men from Somalia.

Thomas Mullany, the personnel director of the New York City Parks Department, has been reassigned to other duties by Martin Lang, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation. The reassignment was made after Mr. Lang learned that Mr. Mullany had quietty hired his son as a summer park foreman.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 30 Harry Edwards, an outspoken black sociology professor here who protested racism in the 1968 Olympics, has been granted a permanent position on the University of California faculty, ending six months of controversy over whether he was qualified for tenure.

YOUNGSTOWN Ohio, June 30 (AP) The Republic Steel Corporation and the United States Steel Corporation signed pollution control agreements today in what was described as a major step toward solving water-pollution problems in the Mahoning River.
For the first time in the last five years, there has been a decline in uncollected real-estate taxes in New York City, Finance Commissioner Harry S. Tishelman reported yesterday.
BRASILIA, Brazil, June 30 (AP) President Ernesto Geisel expelled a leader of Brazil's only legal opposition party from Congress today and stripped him of political rights for 10 years.

THE SWIFTNESS with which the late John Cranko made his ballets sweep forward was perhaps the special lift he brought to a full evening of narrative ballet. Even when working with a story like "Romeo and Juliet," which is so intimately tied to its musical program, he found ways to leave his personal mark on the production.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) A coalition of parents, minority groups and consumer organizations sued the General Foods Corporation for $1 billion today, contending that its Post Cereals division "exploits trusting children in order to sell sugar concoctions as nutritious breakfast cereals."

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 (UPI) President Augusto Pinochet, declaring that Chileans are not "beggars," today rejected $11 million in United States aid that had been tied to Chilean observance of human rights.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Department of Commerce announced today a 12-month pilot program of labeling products to provide consumers with information on the products performance.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Transportation Secretary Brock Adams issued an order today requiring that air bags or automatic lap and shoulder restraints be installed in all standard and luxury automobiles by the 1982 model year and in all smaller cars by the 1984 model year.
The green light of tax exemption flashed for CBS Inc., for Barclays Bank, for a Staten Island beer distributorship and for Kit Tzing Lee Kuan the other day.
SPINAGAR, Kashmir, June 30 A hotly contested election, something new for Kashmir, began today in this Indiancontrolled part of the Himalayan state.

A strike threatened for tomorrow on the Long Island Rail Road was averted yesterday when most of the line's 17 unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to submit their disputes to a board of inquiry.

MOSCOW, June 30 The Soviet Union, in a terse announcement, said today that the United States had proposed a meeting between Leonid I. Brezhnev and President Carter and there had been preliminary discussion about the matter.

Five members of a Mafia-controlled ring that allegedly offered an undercover agent a shopping list of stolen securities worth $2 million were arrested this week as "a sample sale" was about to be consummated. They were charged with possession of stolen property.

An X-Ray of Adolf Hitler's head was purchased at auction for $375 last night by an unnamed collector, identified only as "a doctor interested in the medical details of famous people," according to a spokesman for the Charles Hamilton Galleries.

TOKYO, June 30 (UPI) The yen continued to appreciate sharply against the dollar in heavy trading today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market. The market finished at 266.50 yen to the dollar, down 2.40 yen from yesterday's closing price of 268.90 yen. The Japanese Government, thought to be bowing to pressures from the United States and Europe to reduce Japan's huge balance-of-payments surplus, shows no sign of intervening at the present level.

A police commander who was disciplined last fall for reportedly ignoring orders to arrest off-duty police officers who were noisily demonstrating outside Gracie Mansion will be promoted today to post of chief of organized crime control.

With the sale of Avis Inc. stock to Norton Simon Inc., out of the way, Federal District Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld turned his attentions in Hartford yesterday to finding a buyer for the Levitt Corporation, the homebuilder.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 Already the owner of two Rails-Royces, a Mercedes and a Porsche, Vitas Gerulaitis has his sights set on yet another car from another country.

Employees at The Village Voice voted yesterday to be represented by a union, for the first time in the paper's history. By a vote of 86 to 21, they voted to join the publishing local of District 65 of The Distributive Workers of America.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30 After more than two years in a refugee camp at Aranyaprathet, on the Cambodian border, where more than 4,000 Cambodians live, an elderly carpenter and his wife spoke with the resignation that distinguished the millions of displaced persons in Indochina during three decades of war.

General Mills Inc. reported yesterday earnings gains for the final quarter and fiscal year ended May 29 in each of its major business areas led by nonfood items, particularly worldwide craft, game and toy operations. Foods and specialty chemicals had "excellent sales gains," yesterday's report said, noting that more than three-fourths of the gain came from volume increases, rather than inflation.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Farmers are expected to harvest 70.8 million acres of corn this year, only four-tenths of 1 percent fewer than in 1976, when they produced a record crop of the foodproducing gain, the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Asserting that Soviet-American relations were not in trouble, President Carter said today that he hoped to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev this year so that the two leaders could "get to know one another."
The National Observer, the 15-year-old national weekly newpaper published by Dow Jones Co., will cease publication with its July 4 issue.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Several liberal and moderate Senators who changed their positions yesterday and booted to limit Federal funds for Medicaid abortions said today that they had been influenced by the Supreme Court, President Carter, public sentiment and especially by what they considered the liberal language of the bill.

Dr. Esther Haar, a psychiatrist who was in private practice and an assistant professor in psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Tuesday at the North Shore Hospital. Her age was 53.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 30 Larry O'Brien, Pete Rozelle and Bowie Kuhn, the commissioners of basketball, football and baseball, respectfully were among the 1,500 people attending the funeral mass for J. Walter Kennedy today at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

THIRTY YEARS ago, when George Shearing was the intermission pianist at the Three Deuces on 52nd Street and Erroll Garner was the club's star, Mr. Garner, who liked to drop in and play at other clubs on the block during his intermissions, was frequently late getting back to the Deuces.

TRENTON, June 30 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today in two cases that prosecutors had the power to require witnesses to testify against themselves in grand jury investigations even though their testimony could not be used against them at a subsequent trial.
GENEVA, June 30 Switzerland is not applying for membership in the United Nations at this time because most Swiss would not endorse the move, the Government said in a statement today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 Officials of four New Jersey coastal counties sought today to join a Federal Court suit aimed at forcing an end to dumping of sewage sludge in the New York Bight off Sandy Hook.

The jazz combo performing Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall bills itself simply as The Quintet. It assembled last summer for a "V.S.O.P." Very Special One-Time Performance at the Newport-New York Jazz Festival, and, explains Herbie Hancock, the pianist who is the group's nominal leader, "it felt good."

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30 The Southeast Asia Treaty, Organization, one of the last vestiges of the cold war in Asia, dissolved itself today. There was only a brief flash as the colors of the remaining member countries were lowered at dusk to mark its end, as contrasted with the enthusiasm amid which it was born nearly 23 years ago as a bulwark against the further spread of Communism in Asia.

Palmer K. Leberman, former board chairman and chief executive officer of Family Circle Magazine, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and a resident of Manalapan, Fla.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A House-Senate conference committee completed action today on a compromise strip-mining bill that would establish tough new reclamation standards for 60 percent of the nation's coal mine operators.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee completed action today on President Carter's energy tax package, approving a bill projected to save less energy than Mr. Carter had asked but not the drastically reduced program that some had feared.

State officials hope work will begin in January to rid the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City of two dozen abandoned piers like those that burned here Wednesday night and yesterday morning.

The spectacular finale to this year's Harbor '77 and Fourth of July in Old New York festivals will be a giant fireworks display courtesy of Macy's that will light up the western sky from 85th Street to 105th Street along the Hudson River.

Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president of The New York Times Company, announced yesterday that C. Raymond Hulsart, president of the New York Times Foundation since 1974, would retire on July 31 at the mandatory age of 65.

WASHINGTON, June 30 President Carter, seeking to prevent the rift between his Administration and Israel from growing, today imposed a moratorium on further comments about the details of a projected Middle East settlement before Prime Minister Menahem Begin visits Washington on July 19.

ALBANY, June 30 Recipients of Federal Supplemental Security Income benefits who live in homes for the elderly or other "congregate care" facilities will receive personal-care allowances as a result of a legislative agreement that will add state funds to the Federal payments.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Trying to stay out of the line of fire in the Democratic mayoral primary in New York City, President Carter said today that he would not get involved even though Mayor Beame was one of his first major supporters in New York.

LONDON, June 30 (UPI) European Common Market leaders ended a meeting here today with an expression of concern over crises in Africa and the Middle East and with a pledge to keep fighting unemployment and inflation.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that Federal controls over banks involved in the stock market be tightened to assure investor protection.

The Supreme Court's decision to lift the ban on the advertising of fees by lawyers was a major victory for consumers. It should lower the cost of some routine legal services. It may also lead to similar cost-cutting advertising in other professions.

While investigators into the "Son of Sam" killings sought clues in every direction, Lieut. James C. Power of the special homicide task force warned yesterday that the gunman had chosen women with a variety of hair colors as victims.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) The Federal Energy Administration today told 18 utilities and 28 factories to switch from oil and natural gas to coal as their primary energy source.

Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. conceded from the witness stand at his perjury trial yesterday that he had signed documents listing himself as a partner in a law firm and that a reasonable person, having listened to the evidence and examined the documents, might conclude that he had represented himself as a partner.

The Bulova Watch Company, the nation's largest producer and importer of jeweled lever watches and movements, reduced its yearly loss to $7 million from the $25.6 million deficit in its previous fiscal year ended March 31. The loss for that year included $12.6 million for inventories and other writedowns relating to a corporate restructuring program. Sales were $207.5 million, up 1.4 percent from $204.7 million the year before.

After six years in New York, the Newport Jazz Festival will move to Saratoga Springs next year. But New York will still have a jazz festival during the 11-day period at the end of June and the beginning of July now occupied by the festival, said George Weirs, producer of the Newport Festival, in announcing the change yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Carter Administration is developing a contingency energy conservation program, including such mandatory provisions as gasoline rationing, import quotas and forced closings of service stations, Administration officials said today.

DETROIT, June 30 The automobile industry today expressed attitudes ranging from resignation to scepticism to condemnation in the wake of the Federal Government's decision to require air bags or automatic seat belts in all passenger cars.
LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) The leader of an Irish Republican Army group that planted nine bombs in central London was was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 30 Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin has hinted that South Korea could develop nuclear weapons if the country's security was severely threatened.

CHARLES MINGUS'S quintet grew into a 15-man band between the printing of the Newport Jazz Festival New York pro gram and Mr. Mingus's appearance Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. In contrast to last year's Mingus program, which was a kind of retrospective of some of the composerbassist's extended works for small groups, Wednesday's concert featured all-new music.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 It will be Jimmy Connors versus Bjorn Borg in the men's singles final of the centennial Wimbledon championships Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, June 30 Roy Pace of Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, Conn., and Austin Straub, assistant pro at Ridgeway C.C., White Plains, won two matches each today and will meet for the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship tomorrow. Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, Philadelphia, after a long but tireless search, has decided to split the advertising responsibility for its product lines between Compton Advertising and Isidore, Lefkowitz, Elgort. The company spent about $4.5 million in measured media last year.

Crude oil imports for the week ended June 24 were up sharply to 7.2 million barrels a day, compared to 6.8 million barrels in the preceding week, and well ahead of the 5.5 million barrels imported daily in the year-earlier level, according to the latest weekly supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) Inventories, rose by 1.2 percent in May for the biggest increase in more than two years and a signal of a potential sales "explosion" that could fuel economic growth, the Commerce Department reported today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30 More than 80,000 Indochinese refugees are killing time in camps throughout Thailand waiting for other countries to open their doors to them or Thailand to resettle them in this country. More arrive from Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam every day than leave for new homes.

The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply increased $1.5 billion in the week ended June 22. and the credit markets, caught by surprise, tumbled sharply late in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Carter Administration, rejecting repeated pleas from industry, urged Congress today to keep a 1983 deadline for cleaning up the nation's water supply to the point where it is "drinkable, swimmable and fishable."

MONTREAL, June 30 The grand battle for last place in the National League East began tonight, and the New York Mets lost the bottom spot by coming back in the seventh and ninth innings and winning their game against the Montreal Expos, 4-3.

It's almost too pretty, too ideal." And of the horse racing fever that grips, Goshen, the birthplace of trotting, this holiday weekend and all next week, Mr. Gilroy said: "I'm fascinated by the colors, the earnest huddles; those grim, weathered faces..."

The oil pricing split within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been settled with agreement that there will be no further price rises this year, Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez said yesterday.

THE MICKEY MOUSE collecting mania of the late 1960's has spread to include virtually all comic art and popular, culture memorabilia. Now the stunning success of "Annie," the Broadway musical, has sent what were record prices for, among others, Little Orphan Annie decoders, mugs, wind-up toys and saltand-pepper shakers soaring to new highs.

For those who missed it, Wednesday was Miss Universe Day in New York City, Mayor Beame made it so, with an official proclamation and some good-natured remarks, as he stood on the steps of City Hall surrounded by 47 of this year's contestants.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Transportation Secretary Brock Adams issued an order today requiring that air bags or automatic lap and shoulder restraints be installed in all standard and luxury automobiles by the 1982 model year and in all smaller cars by the 1984 model year.

WASHINGTON, June 30 America's Bicentennial ended today after 200 years of history, eight years of planning, one day of partying, a year of cleanup and 38 minutes of waiting for some of its chief backers to attend its wake.

Frank E. Barnett will retire Aug. 1 as chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Pacific Corporation. Mr. Barnett, who will be 65 years of age on July 14, joined the railroad in 1951 as Eastern general counsel. He was elected a director in 1953 and became a vice president in 1955. Before becoming chairman in 1969, he was chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 The Security Council decided unanimously today to ask member countries of the United Nations to give "material" assistance to Mozambique to help it defend itself against harder attacks by forces of Rhodesia's white-minority Government.
Dr. Luvia M. Willard, one of the first women to have practiced as a physician in Queens, died Wednesday in Hollispark Gardens Nursing Home, Hollis, Queens. She was 95 years old.
The dollar was narrowly lower against most other major world currencies in New York foreign-exchange trading yesterday. It closed mostly higher abroad in quiet trading.
City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., was acquitted yesterday of a perjury charge in State Supreme Court in Queens.
The stock market, which typically moves higher in the session preceding Independence Day, broke with a treasured Wall Street tradition yesterday to show a grudging retreat.

Treasury bill rates rose slightly yesterday in the Government's sale of threemonth and six-month securities, an auction that took place yesterday instead, of on Monday as usual because of the Independence Day holiday.

The United States Treasury, which has been reviewing volumes of New York City financial material all week, has found "no reason" to deny the city's request for a loan to meet its cash needs next week, Treasury officials said yesterday.

Judge Joseph P. Sullivan of State Supreme Court yesterday vacated a State Athletic Commission ruling that said Madison Square Garden Boxing Inc. had a binding agreement obligating Earnie Shavers to fight Muhammad Ali in the Garden next fall.

After a very rough start, President Carter is making some progress in selling an energy plan to Congress. The House Ways and Means Committee has approved a "wellhead" oil tax to raise the price of fuel to its true replacement cost. And the House Commerce Committee has endorsed by a one-vote margin the Administration's proposed adjustment in the maximum price of newly discovered natural gas.
BUFFALO, June 29 (UPI) Paul E. Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic chairman from 1944 to 1953, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

SARASOTA, Fla., July 1 (AP) Charlotte Grosse scrambled through a window to freedom today, 52 hours after she was dragged screaming from a tent at a Girl Scout camp.

SOCHI, U.S.S.R., July 1 (AP) Brenda Morehead, an 18-year-old American, upset Lyudmila Maslakova in the 100meter dash as a young United States track team today made a surprisingly strong showing against a Soviet powerhouse, trailing by 102-97 after the opening day of the two-day meet.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) The exchange of diplomats by the United States and Cuba, after 16 years of hostility and tension, will take place on September 1, the State Department announced today.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 1 (Reuters) Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and leaders of the opposition met today in a final effort to seek a formula for resolving a four-month-old political crisis.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) Bolstered by strong spring sales, United States automakers plan to build a record 1.97 million new cars during the third quarter, 14 percent more than a year before, a trade journal reported today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 1 (AP) The California Angels said today that Bobby Grich, one of the free agents the Angels signed last winter, was suffering from a herniated lumbar disk that would require surgery and probably keep him out of baseball the rest of this season.

HONOLULU, July 1 (UPI) Rear Adm. Chester Ward, retired, an outspoken conservative who frequently warned of growing Soviet military strength, died Wednesday night at a Honolulu hospital. He was 69 years old.
LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) Britain's shipbuilding industry, formally came under state ownership today against a background of acute crisis in the world's shipyards.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 (AP) President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt says he told President Carter the Arabs could not accept diplomatic or trade relations with Israel as part of an overall Middle East settlement.
CLEVELAND, July 1 (UPI) A retrial has been ordered by Cuyahoga County Court of Appeals in a $67,000 jury verdict in favor of Julie Heldman against Uniroyal Inc., of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The United States is preparing to offer Panama as much as $50 million a year in tolls from the Panama Canal as a financial settlement pending complete transfer of the waterway to the Panamanians by treaty in the year 2000, Administration officials said today.

PHOENIX, July 1 (UPI) Workers went on strike nationwide against seven of the eight major copper producers today, but a new contract offer from the Kennecott Copper Corporation raised hopes for a quick settlement.

Anne DeRenzo, a teacher at the village Community School in New York, was married yesterday to James Ashby Graves, a merchandiser with Oxford Industries Inc., manufacturer of women's and men's apparel.

MILWAUKEE, July 1 (AP) Mike Morley, Keith Fergus, Fuzzy Zoeller and Gary McCord, all of whom teed off after morning winds had tapered, forged three-under-par 69's today and shared the first-round lead in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 1 (Reuters) In a series of nationwide raids, Rhodesian policemen have arrested a number of officials of a black nationalist political organization that is linked with guerrillas operating from outside the country.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that its commissioners would meet next Thursday, a week ahead of schedule, and that its court-challenged ban against the Concorde supersonic jetliner's landings in New York was expected to be on the agenda.

The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company has been awarded an initial contract for full-scale development of a Precision Location-Strike System that could eventually be valued at $120 million. The program is an electronic system designed to detect and strike a wide variety of targets in all kinds of weather.

NEW ORLEANS, July 1 (UPI) Richard Tonry, who said he had entered politics because of his disgust with Watergate but resigned from Congress because of allegations of vote fraud, pleaded guilty today to charges of campaign finance violations.

To be biddable, a four-card suit had to be headed by the queen-jack or, in a pinch, just the queen. Nowadays serious players have no inhibitions about bidding a suit consisting of four small cards, or even three small cards if the suit is a minor.
Eugene Corey, a former vice president of the Hartz Mountain Corporation, received a one-year prison sentence yesterday on charges that he had defrauded the corporation, which manufactures pet food.

WASHINGTON, July 1 With a major extension of service today, the capital's smooth-running but financially and politically troubled subway system is finally getting a chance to show whether rapid rail transit can reshape and help revive the nation's ninth largest metropolis, as planners here have promised. But the main interest of the evening centered on his solo playing.

United Merchants and Manufacturers said yesterday that the disposition of inventories of the closed Robert Hall clothing chain would be handled by independent professional concerns and would be coupled with the sale of fixed assets and leasehold interests. The announcement was viewed in the retail trade as a further indication that United Merchants has no plans to reopen the stores again as a companyoperated division.

JERSEY CITY Puffs of clouds hover over the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. The towers, silvery and glistening even at this distance, seem to rise out of the trees lining the perimeter of Roosevelt Stadium.

FREMONT, Ohio, July 1 (AP) National Guardsmen were on duty here today to prevent looting and help supply emergency power after a tornado-carrying storm crossed northern Ohio, injuring 19 people and causing over $1 million damage.

The first Moscow International Book Fair, which begins Sept. 6, has divided segments of the American book publishing community. ATLANTIC CITY, July 1 Claques for both candidates kept busy today as Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman staged the first debate of the 1977 gubernatorial election before the annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Counties. Each had a large number of supporters in the audience of 400, at the Howard Johnson Regency Hotel. Bursts of applause, laughter and cheers punctuated every comment.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 1 Britain's London Contemporary Dance Theater made its United States debut last night at the American Dance Festival and roused the audience at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium into an exuberant standing ovation.

A Long Island technician has invented an apparatus for short-term weather forecasts based on the current direction of the wind. James C. Bedard of Westbury was granted Patent 4,031,754 this week for the prediction apparatus.

LISBON, July 1 (AP) Magda Lupescu, widow of former King Carol of Rumania, may be buried in a commoner's grave, family sources said today.

Harold L. McClinton, a retired advertising executive who had continued to be active with the International Executive Service Corps here, died Wednesday in his home, 25 East End Avenue, after a short illness. His age was 79.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) This desert city of three million people, which outstripped its locally available water supply at the turn of the century, began mandatory water restrictions today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 1 For the first time in many years, there will be no Independence Day celebration in this stately old town, where British troops and local militia fought through the long day of April 27, 1777.
MONTREAL, July 1 The Mets recaptured last place tonight....overwhelmingly.

SAN FRANCISCO July 1 A new state sentencing law took effect today with no one quite sure whether it would, as intended, make the criminal justice system here more equitable and more of a deterrent, or whether it would merely confuse those issues.

Tonight, Grace DiGioia, Martin Bergman, Augustine Moscatello and nearly 100 other students are scheduled to board a jetliner at Kennedy International Airport bound for Rome on a flight they all hope will take them a little closer to the fulfillment of their collective dream: to become doctors.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) Construction spending rose 2 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $169.6 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

MOSCOW, July 1 When President Carter conceded recently that he had not anticipated the extent of Moscow's unhappiness with his human rights policy, he identified only part of a problem souring Soviet-American relations. Redemptions of all types of mutual funds, excluding money-market funds, exceeded sales by $110 million in May, compared with net sales of $89 million in April and net redemptions of $349 million in May 1976, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
BEIRUT, July 1 Members of rival right-wing Christian factions fought each other for several hours here today using machine guns and grenades.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 1 (UPI) One more piggyback flight of the space shuttle-orbiter Enterprise aboard a 747 is scheduled for July 28, a National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 In a bid for a leadership role in revision of the tax laws, Senator Edward M. Kennedy issued a 41-page list of tax "reform" proposals today.

Margery Ann Tabankin, former president of the National Student Association, has been appointed director of the Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) program, it was announced yesterday. THE BIRD Bottle Inn had a fine reputation long before anyone thought restaurants were fair game for reviewers. HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 All the American victories of the 138th Henley Royal Regatta went to the University of Washington today, as the Huskies' pairs, rowing as a four without coxswain, won the Visitors' Challenge Plate, and the varsity heavyweights captured the Grand Challenge Cup.

WASHINGTON, July 2 A small nuclear materials processing plant in Pennsylvania has continued to receive Government contracts worth millions of dollars even though inspectors have repeatedly found the facility violating stringent safety and security regulations.

HOW IT WAS It's one thing to watch today's briny, panoramic sweep of the New York Harbor Festival, as vessels ply waters in a holiday salute. DIJON, France, July 3 (AP) Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., trailing John Watson for much of the race, overtook the Briton on the final lap today and won the French Grand Prix auto race.

WASHINGTON, July 3 Senator Mark O. Hatfield dismissed as "sewer journalism" today a published report in which a $420,000 loan he received from a West Coast bank to buy a house here was linked with help his office gave to the bank shortly afterward in dealing with a Federal agency.

RINGWOOD, N.J. Back when the Indians roamed this valley in the foothills of the Ramapos, they called the region Wyanockie, which meant "sassafras place." Later, with the coming of the settlers and their big country homes and small sum mer bungalows, the place was renamed Lakeland, after all the rivers, streams, ponds and lakes that dot these rolling hills of northern New Jersey.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 3 (UPI) Surgery to remove a surgical screw from the wrist of Bill Walton, the Portland Trail Blazers' center, was termed a success, by the team's trainer, Ron Culp.

WASHINGTON, July 3 A study commissioned by the Department of Justice has recommended an end to the secrecy surrounding plea bargaining in the nation's courts, both to help end public skepticism of the process and to curb some of the abuses the practice has led to.
MADRAS, India, July 3 (Reuters) Gopalan Narasimhan, managing editor of The Hindu, one of India's leading Englishlanguage newspapers, died here today following a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
