Saul Kies, a founder and past president of the National Association of Immigration and Nationality Lawyers, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

Mabel Greene Bean, a feature writer and fashion editor of The New York Sun, died of cancer yesterday in the Ozanam Hall Nursing Home in Bayside, Queens, at the age of 79. She was the widow of Edgar R. Bean, who was acting managing editor of The Daily News when he died in 1942.

The health, present and future, of the volunteer Army is under continuing review in the Defense Department, according to senior officials, and, although the force has current problems and will encounter others, there is no tendency now to consider a return to the draft.

The battle over two national issues abortion and the equal rights amendment to the Constitution shifts to Albany this weekend, where more than 3,000 persons are expected to attend the New York State Women's Meeting.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 Dr. Robert Magoon, the peripatetic eye surgeon from Miami, was supposed to arrive here today by speedboat from Rota, Spain, having set a record for the fastest trans-Atlantic crossing by boat, 72 hours. Instead Magoon arrived last night by limousine and commercial airplane, having left the boat at Ponta Delgado in the Azores 2,500 miles from here.

Besides the sun, the fireworks and the celebrations, there is also a grim tradition associated with the annual Fourth of July weekend holiday: As we count our nation's birthdays, we also count our traffic dead.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) "We're the victims of our own success," an official of Metrorail, the new Washington subway system, said of a holiday crush today.

Lower Manhattan teemed with the hungry, the curious, the friendly and, before it was over, the weary and the indigestive as the Fourth of July in Old New York/1977 celebration turned the Wall Street area into an ethnic cornucopia.

With millions of dollars at stake, as well as control over much of the nation's future oil imports, a fierce battle is being waged over crucial Government restrictions on the nation's first deepwater terminals proposed for the Gulf of Mexico.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) Quick Card, owned by John M. Schiff of New York, closed with a rush today to win the $59,400 Stars and Stripes Handicap before a crowd of 21,849 at Arlington Park.

WASHINGTON, July 4 In the unfolding account of the covert and allegedly illegal South Korean lobby here, a retired United States Navy captain named Spencer E. Robbins has emerged as the righthand man to Park Tong Sun, reportedly the Korean Government's main agent of influence in Washington.
Bishop John Michael A. Fearns, auxiliary bishop to Terence Cardinal Cooke, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

PHRA PRADAENG, Thailand, July 2 Two-year-old Samreng Muonthongsuk passed out in her rickety wooden home more than a year ago. It was the first hint of trouble in this tiny village on the outer fringe of Bangkok. The doctors thought it was just a virus and gave her some antibiotics, but it happened again, then a third time, until, in convulsions, she died.

The professionals on Wall Street who usually predict a summer rally are anticipating another one this year which should bring joy to harried tape-watchers who have been suffering from declining prices through most of 1977's first half.

A gunman who diverted a Vermontbound bus with more than 25 passengers from the Bronx to Kennedy International Airport and killed two hostages surrendered on a runway late last night, ending a daylong siege of terror and gunfire.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 4 (AP) A car apparently packed with explosives exploded today in the street between the Syrian Air Defense Command headquarters and the American School in Damascus, killing at least six persons and wounding 11, authorities and witnesses reported.
The Yankees dropped Jim Wynn from their roster yesterday to make room for Dell Alston, a left-handed hitting outfielder whom they recalled from their Syracuse farm club before last night's game.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 4 Opposition and pro-Government legislators submitted a bill to the National Assembly today asking the Government to pardon imprisoned dissidents and religious leaders.

Fourteen years ago, when Pat McComiskey was asked by a priest to start a youth soccer league in Massapequa, L.I., he had to travel across town to the football coach at Our Lady of Lourdes grammar school and plead for players who had been cut from the football team. He had no choice; he needed 11 players for a team, and he could get only eight or nine on his own.

The final day of the city's Harbor Festival '77 began yesterday morning with tiny multicolored sailboats scurrying about the base of the Statue of Liberty, and wound up last night with one mile of swirling, exploding fireworks 1,000 feet above the Hudson and with exuberant, extemporaneous bursts of rockets and flares all over the city.

An apparently fictitious report by a Bronx woman that she had been raped and her two small children abducted by a group of eight men yesterday sent police on a pointless eight-hour search by land, air and water.
GENEVA, July 4 (UPI) Most members of President Carter's Cabinet want the United States to remain a member of the International Labor Organization, Andrew Young said today.

OTTAWA, July 4 The National Energy Board of Canada announced its approval today of an application by a CanadianAmerican consortium, Foothills Pipes (Yukon) Ltd., to build an $8.6 billion natural gas pipeline across western Canada to connect with the proposed Alcan project in Alaska, giving American consumers access to large reserves of the fuel at Prudhoe Bay.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 4 Dr. William J. Ronan, the former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said today at the end of his controversial Asian tour that the authority was in the midst of crucial competition to attract Japanese manufacturers and Asian shippers to the New York metropolitan area.

Rises in personal income taxes caused a major part of the increase in living costs last year in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey metropolitan area, according to the latest budget calculations of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) President Carter said today that he was awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., "the conscience of his generation," and to Dr. Jonas E. Salk, whose vaccine helped wipe out polio epidemics.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4 A new law imposing tighter restrictions on the Lebanese press has brought strong protests from editors here who said that if it was applied, it would end the freedom that the press in Lebanon has enjoyed for many decades.
Four and a half years ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed to the most sweeping corporate effort ever to eliminate racism and sexism on the job.

Now that it's winter in Rio (What a fetching introduction!) it is appropriate to announce that Young Rubicam, the well known international advertising agency, is on the verge of forming a new Brazilian company that will be sort of a holding company. Sort of a Latin American Interpublico.

This has been a Fourth of July weekend for fireworks, lying in the sun, eating hot dogs, watching via satellite a great men's finals from Wimbledon, mourning the loss of Seattle Slew's invincibility, and keeping an eye on relatively close races in all four major league divisions (even the National League West, where, though 9 games behind, the Cincinnati Reds still can't be counted out).

MOSCOW, July 4 The United States ambassador to the Soviet Union was not allowed to deliver a traditional Fourth of July speech over Soviet television today after he had declined to delete a section alluding to the human rights policy of the Carter Administration.

COLUMBIA, Tenn., July 4 (UPI) Blood samples taken from 10 of the 42 victims of the June 26 Maury County Jail fire showed that they died from carbon monoxide asphyxiation and not from cyanide fumes as originally thought.
Government employment in the United States Federal, state and local has more than doubled in the last 20 years, rising from 7.4 million to 15 million, according to a study by the Conference Board.

It may have resembled a scene from "A Bridge Too Far" to the people of Brick Township, but for 33 parachute enthusiasts it was not far enought by a couple of miles when they blew into that pleasant Ocean County town yesterday morning, on the wrong side of the Garden State Parkway.

When they got around this year to focusing on abortions, the three branches of the American Government achieved a rare degree of unanimity. With certain differences in shading, the Administration, the Congress and the Supreme Court decided against paying with public funds for abortions for poor women.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 Old Home Week started at its usual leisurely pace this afternoon in this homey Orange County village as the country-fair-flavored Historic Track, 60 miles from midtown Manhattan, opened its gates for its 139th year of harness racing. About 5,000 people attended.

A Vermont-bound bus carrying a score of passengers was diverted from the Bronx to Kennedy International Airport yesterday by a gunman who shot and killed two hostages, wounded at least two others, rode wildly around on the runways and held off the police in a tense siege that continued until 11:33 P.M., when the gunman was captured. His 11 remaining hostages were freed unharmed, the police said.

Ernst Oster, a musicologist who taught at the Mannes College of Music in New York City and at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston, died last Thursday while walking on Skunemunk Mountain, near Mountainville in Orange County, N.Y. Mr. Oster, who was 69 years old, was said to have suffered a stroke.
Thirteen firemen were injured yesterday in a three-alarm fire on the top floor of a six-story apartment house on Macombs Road, in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.

DANVILLE, Calif. Last September, Robert and Judith Kretz moved into a new house on Piedras Circle in White Gate, a development of expensive houses in this town east of San Francisco Bay. Their house, which was valued at about $250,000, looks fairly similar to many other houses in White Gate comfortable, sprawling ranch houses of standard design, often fancied up with a few Spanish, Georgian or French details.
At the musicals that Guy Lombardo has been staging on Jones Brach for the last 25 years, everything distracts equally.

WEST BERLIN, July 4 Some months ago, an East German clothing company won an order for 50,000 pieces of women's apparel. But the deal fell through on the delivery date because the company had not adhered to specifications and had made only one type of suit, each the same color and the same size.
TRENTON, July 4 Governor Byrne is expected to name this week the five members of the Casino Control Commission, which will supervise casino gambling in Atlantic City.

Rises in personal income taxes caused a major part of the increase in living costs last year in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey metropolitan area, according to the latest budget calculations of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Horse players received another major shock to their wallets yesterday when the great Forego was beaten at Belmont Park a day after Seattle Slew suffered a first defeat in California.
TRENTON, July 4 Governor Byrne's election-year budget for the state government, which went into effect last Friday, spends $63 million more than the state expects to take in.
When Jimmy Carter set out to be the Democratic candidate for President, he decided to do it by running against the Democratic Party.

LEBANON, N.J., July 4 At precisely 8 o'clock this morning, volunteer fire trucks of this borough roared out of their station on Main Street, their sirens shattering the silence of a warm summer day in the country, and telling everyone to get out of bed and prepare for the Fourth of July parade.
NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, July 4 (AP) A guerrilla attack here last night left three soldiers injured and caused some slight damage to buildings, residents reported today.

The streets of New York were dotted over the weekend with men in maroon fezzes, and yesterday 7,000 of them Shriners from the United States and Canada converged on Broadway for a four-hour march under a hot summer sun.

Ah, yes . . . the obsession of housebuilding. Peter Matson, a literary agent when he's in the city, describes it very well in "A Place in the Country." "Surely I am not unique in believing I can contain the complexities of our time by physical effort," he muses when his converted barn in the Berkshires is nearly completed.
Mary Hemingway will return to Cuba this week to do research for a movie based on the life of her late husband, Ernest Hemingway.

SKY AND STARS The 12th summer season of open-air concerts in Central Park's Wellman Skating Rink Theater, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, will begin tonight at 7 with 31 programs scheduled through August and a lively lineup of performers, starting with the Manhattan Transfer and the swing-style Stan Rubin Big Band. The first group is well known for its galvanic sounds of today and yesterday and for its offbeat humor.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 (UPI) John McEnroe, the youngster from Douglaston, New York, who was a Wimbledon semifinalist last week, advanced in the opening round of the $50,000 Hall of Fame grass tennis tournament today. Seeded seventh, he ousted George Hardie of Long Beach, Calif., 6-3, 6-2.
The following article was written by Maurice Carroll with the assistance of E.J. Dionne Jr., Charles Kaiser, Pranay Gupte and Emanuel Perlmutter.
Two years ago, Louis Van Leeuwen, then 32 years old, decided that his seven-year-old agency, Van Leeuwen Advertising, could never grow to greatness in New Haven, so he opened an office in New York.
LIMA, Peru, July 5 (UPI) Four Chileans hijacked a domestic Chilean jetliner to Lima today and surrendered and released their 60 hostages for the promise of political asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy.

Planning camping trip this year? Or a weekend hike in the mountains? If so, and particularly if you're a novice at that sort of thing, you'll want to pack along the answers to some tough questions, the kind that begin with What if...

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) A police firearms expert told the Hanafi Moslem murder-kidnapping trial today that a shotgun blast that left a hostage at the District Building paralyzed was fired from a range of six feet or less.

WASHINGTON, July 3 A Federal investigation of alleged influence peddling at the Interstate Commerce Commission has burgeoned into a widespread inquiry into organized crime activities on Capitol Hill, according to Congressional and law enforcement sources.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 5 Twenty-three African heads of state, numerous government representatives and leaders of many competing liberation movements were welcomed to their summit meeting here with a pomp seldom seen anywhere on this continent.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Economic growth in the rest of the industrialized world continues to trail the strong growth of the United States economy, the Commerce Department reported today.
"Dennis the Menace," John Tricoche of South Brooklyn was explaining with patience, is a very simple game, sort of "like hide-and-seek backwards."

WASHINGTON, July 5 President Carter met today with James R. Schlesinger, his energy adviser, and ordered the preparation of a comprehensive, standby gasoline rationing proposal to be presented soon to Congress, according to an Administration source.

ALBANY, July 5 Legislative leaders, yielding to Governor Carey's threat of a veto, agreed today to remove all the pension increases and special deals they had tried to hide in a bill designed to implement the state's labor agreements with 150,000 employees.

A Federal judge rejected New York City's plea to eliminate the courtordered parking ban or suspend it for 10 months, but gave the cit y10 days to carry out the order aimed at Manhattan air pollution.[A1:2.]
TACOMA, Wash., July 5 (AP) Most of 29 persons arrested for allegedly trespassing on the Trident submarine base were released today, but at least one refused to leave jail, the authorities said.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 Last night, the Philadelphia Phillies had skyrockets and fireworks at Veterans Stadium for the Independence Day holiday. Tonight, against the Mets, they had cannon shots as they buried the New York visitors, 12-1, under a barrage of long homers.

YONKERS, July 5 The State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, today approved this city's $144 million budget for 1977-78. Under legislation that rescued the city from default two years ago, Mr. Levitt has broad powers over Yonkers fiscal affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The Allied Chemical Corporation allowed Canadian and European subsidiaries to kick back more than $4 million to foreign customers over a five-year period, previously secret government records showed today.

ANGRA DOS REIS, Brazil The stunning scenery that surrounds this historic colonial port town, which is crammed between lush green mountains and the tranquil sea of Brazil's South Atlantic coast, has always been one of its major attractions.
ROME, July 5 The Vatican for the first time called today for government financial support of the world's Roman Catholic schools.

WITH GARDENS fairly bursting with the good produce of summer, what this country needs is a good book on home canning and preserving. What this country soon will have is the 30th edition of what I consider the definitive work, the bible of canning and preserving for home kitchens.

Pakistan's army, having seized power in a bloodless coup, imposed martial law and promised new elections in October. The chief of staff, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, announced the end of the regime of Prime Minister Zulfika Ali Bhutto in a nationwide broadcast.
BREWSTER, N.Y. The competitive reach of Putnam County is extending outward to possible corporate relocatees these days and the results have begun to show.
MADRID, July 5 (AP) King Juan Carlos swore in the new Cabinet of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez today and abandoned the practice of having the members kneel when pledging loyalty to the crown.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Scientists and their organizations are making a strong effort to influence pending legislation under which the Federal Government would, for the first time, regulate an important field of basic biological research.

Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Ambassador to the United Nations, was among several Soviet officials given some inkling of the workings of a basic capitalist institution on a visit the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as guests of its chairman, William M. Batten.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 5 African leaders today bestowed something just short of exclusive recognition upon the Patriotic Front, the Rhodesian nationalist movement headed by Joshua Nkomo and Robert Mugabe, as they ended the annual summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity.
VIENNA, July 5 (Reuters) The Rumanian Communist Party today issued a spirited defense of independence for Western Europe's Communist parties in disagreement with Soviet views.

WASHINGTON, July 5 The White House has decided to nominate Roberta S. Karmel as the first woman to serve on the Securities and Exchange Commission, Administration sources said. The decision was made today, they added, but is not expected to be announced for about three weeks.
Michael Dominico, a dancer-singeractor, died yesterday at Veterans Hospital in Buffalo after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

NEW BRUNSWICK, July 5 Officials at Cook College, which emphasizes the training of teachers in environmental education, criticized today a recent advertisement in a business publication by a group cosponsoring a workshop with the college that appeared to attack environmental education in the public schools.

A controversial inventor from Michigan, Stanford Ovshinsky, announced at a scientific conference in Edinbugh last week and a news conference in London yesterday a technical advance he asserted could dramatically reduce the cost of electricity-generating solar cells.

Trading on four New York commodity exchanges took place yesterday in a red-ribbon, red-carpet setting as they shared for the first time the same floor in a new $10 million facility at No. 4 World Trade Center.

The dollar declined again yesterday in foreign exchange trading in New York and abroad. The price of gold, which dropped as much as $1.50 an ounce Monday, made a slight recovery in the major European bullion trading centers.

MARY HARTMAN, Mary Hartman" is dead but her spinoffs have begun to linger. Mary is being re placed on WNEW/Channel 5, week nights at 11, with "Fernwood 2-Night," a summer series described as the first totally fictional talk-variety show on television. This latest Norman Lear production is set in Fernwood, Ohio, home of "Mary Hartman," but most of the guests passing through the talk show studio have not appeared on the former series.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 A dispute set off by problems arising from the drought here has apparently ended, with Mayor George Moscone telling Water Department officials that he sets policy while they merely administer it.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) Corn futures prices were sharply higher on the Chicago Board of Trade today, some advancing to the daily allowable limit, as hot, dry weather blanketed the Middle West at a crucial time for corn crop development.

Gersh I. Budker, widely regarded as among the most innovative designers of high-energy physics experiments, has died in the Soviet Union at the age of 59, according to a report by the Soviet press agency Tass.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 5(AP) Twelve white legislators who split with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith to form a new right-wing party said today they envisioned a multiracial government for Rhodesia in the future, but "completely reject the principle of black majority rule at this stage."

Stephen R. Aiello, a 34-year-old former social studies teacher from Brooklyn, who became the president of the Board of Education yesterday, said he would seek to "re-evaluate the entire process by which students are promoted from grade to grade in New York City."

TRENTON, July 5 The State Election Law Enforcement Commission decided today to ask the New Jersey Supreme Court to review an Appellate Court decision that could make fund-raising more difficult for the state's gubernatorial candidates.
Retail sales of New York City's largest stores, after enjoying a major surge in May, reverted in June to their normal l977 state just so-so.

TEL AVIV, July 5 Prime Minister Menahem Begin today welcomed a statement by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt accepting an Israeli proposal to convene the Middle East peace talks at Geneva in October.

MOSCOW, July 5 Leonid I. Brezhnev received Ambassador Malcolm Toon of the United States today and told him, according to Tass, that "a number of aspects" of the Carter Administration's policies did "not accord with the aim of a constructive development" of SovietAmerican relations.
WASHINGTON, July 5 President Carter is increasingly doubtful that an early conference with Leonid I. Brezhnev can be arranged in view of conditions laid down by the Soviet leader for such a meeting.

Chessie System Inc., the nations's leading coal hauler, reported a 32 percent increase in second-quarter earnings but a 2.6 percent decline for the half-year. The report issued yesterday explained that the six-month drop reflected this year's first-quarter $7.4 million loss "caused by the worst winter in history."

President Carter told his energy adviser, James R. Schlesinger, to prepare a comprehensive standby gasoline rationing proposal for presentation shortly to Congress, according to an Administration source. They met as White House and Congressional officials raised the possibility that Congress night not complete action on Mr. Carter's energy package until its next session beginning in January.
ANCHORAGE, July 5 (AP) The $7.7 billion trans-Alaska pipeline has been shut down, the result of a glas leak apparently caused by failure of a 1 -inch drain plug.

The biggest antitrust challenge in many years was filed by the Department of Justice to block the takeover of the Babcock Wilcox Company by United Technologies Corporation for $510 million. The diversified aerospace company was accused of embarking on a course that might substantially reduce competition or tend to create a monopoly.[D1:5-6.]
Natural gas end energy-related issues were the strongest sector of the stock market yesterday as overall prices showed a slight advance in the first session after the Independence Day weekend.

MY FAVORITE summer drink is no longer available at least not where I used to drink it, at The Blue Ribbon on West 44th Street. When heat and exhaust fumes smothered Times Square on a sultry August afternoon, there was no more pleasurable experience in the world than slipping into the air-conditioned darkness of the Blue Ribbon bar for a stein of Wurzburger dark.
STOCKHOLM, July 5 (AP) Dick Quax of New Zealand broke the world record for 5,000 meters in track today with a time of 13 minutes 12.84 seconds.

STUDENTS of Soviet affairs often comment on the remarkable con tinuity in Russian life, whether under czars or commisars. NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 (UPI) Twelve big sailing vessels will race from New York to Newport this weekend in a sprint reminiscent of last year's England-to-United States Tall Ships race.

Military takeovers of civilian governments are never a cause for rejoicing. The new "Interim Executive Government" of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq says that it seized power only to assure "free and fair" elections next October.

JERUSALEM Both Israel and Greece typify a gradually developing trend in foreign policy relationships by plainly relying almost as much on the success with which they address themselves to the United States Congress as on that with which they hope to convince the United States President.

HONG KONG, July 5 (UPI) China's Deputy Prime Minister says the nation will not renounce the use of force in resolving the Taiwan issue and that it is no other nation's business how the issue is settled.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) A Federal court jury deciding the fate of two nurses accused of poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor concluded a seventh day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation has proposed a $2.5 billion refinancing of outstanding city and M.A.C, securities held by the major banks and municipal pension funds a step designed to ease the city's budget problems and speed its ability to sell its own securities to the public for the first time since 1975.

William E. Hasenstab, a former office supply supervisor for Pan American Word Airways Inc., was indicted yesterday on charges that he had accepted $45,000 in "secret cash kickbacks" from a company that supplied Pan Am with computer paper and other paper products.

WASHINGTON, July 5 A Federal grand jury here is investigating a new allegation of an illegal Federal Bureau of Investigation wiretapping and a possible illegal entry, sources familiar with the case said today.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 5 (Reuters) Former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel, trying to form a new government, was offered support today from the party that holds the balance of power in the divided Parliament.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 5 Justice Donald B. Yarbrough of the State Supreme Court, who was indicted last week on perjury and forgery charges, called newsmen to his chambers today to "confess" his "wrongdoing." The conference preceded an announcement that the Texas House of Representatives would meet to consider his removal.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 5 (UPI) The Claridge Hotel is inviting prospective buyers to inspect hotel furnishings for three days beginning tomorrow, in hopes that they will be ready for the goods at auction Saturday.

The Book-of-the-Month Club and Time Inc. announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge.

About 8 percent of the members of the Greater New York Bridge Association have reached the lofty rank of life master. Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company, said it had reached an agreement in principle to buy the Armour Pharmaceutical Company and affiliated pharmaceutical companies from Armour Company for $90 million in cash. Armour is a subsidiary of the Greyhound Corporation.

HELP ME! Help me!" shrieked a small boy pursued by a pack of his peers as he took shelter in the arms of a passerby. "Where do you live and I'll walk you home," the woman said. Said the boy, "Don't you have a car?"

Led the coup that toppled government of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto ... a short, dapper, cavalry officer, described by a senior Pakistani diplomat as "a very professional person," with "no sort of political vices...very much a technical man" ...

Luis Robinson, a 26-year-old Panamanian enlisted man in the United States Navy charged with-hijacking a bus to Kennedy International Airport and killing two hostages during a 10-hour chase and siege, was remanded yesterday to Kings County Hospital for psychiatric examination.
Maurice E. Chernowitz, former professor of fine arts at Yeshiva University, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 91 Payson Avenue.

Prices of fixed-interest securities were marked down yesterday in slow postholiday trading. Brokers said the overall tone of the Treasury, tax-exempt and corporate markets was one of concern over a possible tightening of credit.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UPI) The six leaders in the 2,225-mile Los Angeles-Honolulu yacht race got the benefit of brisk winds today and reported averages of better than 200 miles a day, which could mean a new elapsedtime record.

LISBON, July 3 In neighboring Spain, Santiago Carrillo, head of the Communist Party, has been excommunicated by the Kremlin for preaching the heresy of Eurocommunism. But there seems no danger of the doctrine spreading across the frontier for Alvaro Cunhal, secretary general of the Portuguese Communists, remains the Soviet Union's best friend in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON By its decision to cancel production of the B-1 bomber, the Carter Administration has resolved all doubt about its perception of the Russian threat, and the character of its approach to peace and security.

TRENTON, July 5 Governor Byrne, comparing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to a candystore owner who takes a child's quarter and refuses to hand over the ice cream, vowed today to continue vetoing actions of the bistate body until it either shopped taking higher motorist tolls or handed over a new rail mass-transit plan.

Ruhrgas AG, Salzgitter Fernagas AG, and NV Nederlandse Gasunie have signed contracts with the state-owned Sonatrach of Algeria for delivery of liquefied natural gas over a 20-year period beginning in 1984, Ruhrgas announced in Essen, West Germany. The contracts call for delivery of liquefied natural gas currently valued at $3.4 billion.

SO STRONG is tradition in the Italian neighborhood in which I live, around Houston Street and Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, that there is still a sign at the southeast corner of Houston and Macdougal that says, "Biaggi For Mayor."

William E. Norgren, a shareholder in the Southern California Edison Company, filed suit in the Superior Court in Los Angeles seeking to enjoin Southern California Edison from issuing and selling more common stock at a price below the book value of its shares.

Luis Robinson, a 26-year-old Panamanian enlisted man in the United States Navy charged with hijacking a bus to Kennedy International Airport and killing two hostages during a 10-hour chase and siege, was remanded yesterday to Kings County Hospital for psychiatric examination.

WASHINGTON IT APPEARS to be a rather simple, two-story townhouse perched on the sidewalk of a narrow Georgetown street. But when one walks through the door, it is another world of peach and tangerines and shades of cocoa, opening to a spectacular vista of a four-storied, glass-enclosed rear addition with decks and balconies at each level and a 40-foot spiral staircase overlooking the ever-changing panorama of the Potomac River.
A Federal judge yesterday gave New York City 10 days to come up with specific plans to carry out a controversial parking ban aimed at combating air pollution in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON PEOPLE AROUND town are employing a new gambit for awkward lulls in cocktail and dinner-table conversations. They simply ask, "And how is the book coming?"

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 5 Shotgun, a mount of undistinguished credentials, was the class of the field in the intermediate jumper competition, the feature event of the opening day of the Lake Placid horse show today. The show, at the Lake Placid show grounds, runs through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Envision this scene: In a press room provided by the Government, a newspaper reporter leans back in his Government-owned chair and props his feet up on his Government-owned desk. He reaches for the telephone, also paid for by the taxpayers, and calls his office with an article. It is an account of a public official who has been using Government money for private business.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 5 As hundreds of his supporters gathered noisily at the courthouse here, Huey P. Newton, leader of the Black Panther Party, had his bail set today at $100,000 in connection with charges of murder and assault.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) VicePresident Mondale says the Carter Administration will support a 15 percent increase in Federal spending for education if differences with Congress on other issues can be resolved.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) A proposed court settlement of more than $15 million between the National Football League Players Association and the N.F.L. clubs is being held up by objections from 17 players who are not happy with the agreement.

ALBANY, July 5 Legislation to reshape the state's vast Department of Mental Hygiene stalled since the beginning of the session because of conflicting demands of special interests has been worked out and legislative leaders, once doubtful that any reorganization could be accomplished this year, are hopeful now of quick approval.

ALBANY, June 5 The opposition of four of the state's chief medical examiners has effectively killed a bill that the physicians warned would place cumbersome restrictions on the conduct of autopsies in cases of suspicious or unexplained deaths.
One night recently, Anton Griscom was ambling along Madison Avenue. Anton Griscom's real name is Antoinette, just so you know.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Citing what it called civil-rights violations by New York City's schools, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it would not give $19.3 million in special Federal aid to the city's central Board of Education and to 18 of its 32 community school districts.
MANKATO, Minn., July 5 (UPI) Parker Brothers, which markets the game of Monopoly, supervised the dumping of at least 7,000 Anti-Monoploy games and materials at a landfill here today.

Gene Fowler was a newspaperman who started in his home town of Denver and, by dint of his feats as a star reporter, drinker, saloon brawler, roisterer, womanizer and socializer, created a constant stir and excitment in his adopted home town of New York, where he rose, often grudgingly, from reporter to managing editor in the Hearst organization.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The Government ordered six states today to begin desegregating their state college systems and issued guidelines to monitor racial imbalance at college systems in other states.

TRENTON, July 5 Residential tenants renters of most apartments and one-family homes may begin as early as Aug. 1 to share in the real-estate tax benefits granted property owners under the state income-tax law, the state's Department of Community Affairs announced today.

A. Federal judge rejected New York City's plea to eliminate the courtordered parking ban or suspend it for 10 months, but gave the city 10 days to carry out the order aimed at Manhattan air pollution.

Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Suffolk County Democrat who is on the House Armed Services Committee, charged yesterday that one of the reasons the West Point cheating scandal had "reached the proportions and seriousness it did" was that the West Point Board of Visitors and the United States Military Academy itself had "operated in a vacuum."

Johannes U. Hoeber, one of the founding members of the Americans for Democratic Action who also served with the Agency for International Development in directing its programs for refugees and social welfare activities in South Vietnam, died June 26 at his home in Washington. He was 72 years old.
LONG BEACH, L.I., July 5 A controversy over the legality and esthetics of a sexually segregated beach in this City was settled at least temporarily over the Fourth of July weekend.
LONDON, July 5 Post Office workers chose to be suspended without pay today rather than handle mail for a private company that is in a bitter dispute over union recognition.
WASHINGTON, July 5 President Carter is increasingly doubtful that an early conference with Leonid I. Brezhnev can be arranged in view of conditions laid down by the Soviet leader for such a meeting.
After several years of poor results for casualty insurers brought on by rapid inflation and limits on rate increases, a number of specialty insurance companies are leading the way to higher profits.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The Labor Department directed employers with Federal contracts today to take "affirmative action" to hire alcoholics and drug abusers, provided they are able to perform their work.

The biggest antitrust challenge in many years was filed by the Department of Justice to block the takeover of the Babcock Wilcox Company by United Technologies Corporation for $510 million. The diversified aerospace company was accused of embarking on a course that might substantially reduce competition or tend to create a monopoly. [D1:5-6.]
The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that the parents of two men who drowned in Round Valley Reservoir in Hunterdon County cannot sue the state.

LOS ANGELES FRIDAY AFTERNOON arrives, and whether it is the Long Island Expressway or the Hollywood Freeway, the queues of outbound cars these days soon become as solid, and seemingly as mobile, as a glacier.

While the Cosmos practiced on the burning AstroTurf at Giants Stadium yesterday, Pele and Franz Beckenbauer spent the morning in the trainer's room, each nursing a groin muscle pull and questionable for tonight's North American Soccer League game against San Jose.
THIS IS THE time of year that fosters belief in the existence a character named Al Fresco. His avocation is outdoor cook ing. His vocation is arranging meat sales.

SPOLETO, Italy THE SPOLETO FESTIVAL of Two Worlds is now 20 years old. Time it seems, waits for no man and certainly for no fes tival, and what started as a dream in Gian Carlo Menotti's eye has now become a dream 20 times fulfilled.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 Two men, acknowledged homosexuals, were arraigned today on two counts of murder, and the police said the men may be responsible for at least 26 other murders. Ten bodies have been found so far.
Herman Franks, the manager of the slumping Chicago Cubs, is an optimist either that or he's whistling in the dark.
TOKYO, July 5 The yen rose today to its highest value in almost four years against the United States dollar in heavy trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market.
Mayor Beame said yesterday that he favored the death penalty for certain types of murder and the abolition of parole for all convicted felons.

Long Island Rail Road commuters, accustomed as they are to vicissitudes of service, were startled the other evening at Penn Station to hear the disembodied voice of the public address system announce scattered delays due to "lost air."

WASHINGTON, July 5 Twenty-eight organizations, including major labor, religious and civil rights groups, have joined in a letter to President Carter deploring the President's decision not to spend additional money for welfare and employment programs.
Steel production fell 2.2 percent to 2.54 million net tons in the week ended July 2 from the preceding week's 2.59 million net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported Today.
WASHINGTON, July 5 After intercession by Rosalynn Carter, the Administration is reviewing a decision to block the sale to Ecuador of 24 Israeli fighterbombers equipped with American engines.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 5, (Reuters) Iraq has decided to forgo a 5 percent increase in the price of crude oil scheduled for July 1, the Iraq press agency said today.

PARIS, July 5 France, West Germany and several other Western European nations today signed accords here for further research and development of nuclear breeder reactors and their eventual sale abroad.

CAIRO, July 5 (Reuters) Moslem extremists tried to lure the police into a booby-trapped apartment by telling them the body of a kidnapped former Cabinetminister was there, police sources said today.

ALBANY, July 5 Gordon M. Ambach, the new State Education Commissioner, said today that the tap priority of his administration would be the improvement of student performance in the New York City public schools.

OTTAWA, July 5 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, declaring in the Parliament that the country's integrity has come under severe threat from proindependence forces in Quebec Province, said today that his Government was willing to consider constitutional changes, among other measures, to advance the cultural aspirations of the disaffected French-speaking minorities in predominantly English-speaking provinces.
Rollin C. Bush, a securities specialist, died yesterday at his Princeton, N.J., home. He was 65 years old.

Citizens who are most concerned with protection of the American environment are rightly disturbed by a threat to the Council on Environmental Quality. President Carter's reorganization crew is about to submit a list of options that includes a proposal to transfer the council's major functions and perhaps the council itself to other agencies of government.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The 1.8-million-member United Church of Christ gave the Protestant unity movement renewed hope here today in the final hours of its five-day, biennial general synod.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The United States Geological Survey reports that the use of underground water could be more than doubled in the drought-plagued Great Basin region of Nevada and Utah.
WASHINGTON, July 5 After intercession by Rosalynn Carter, the Administration is reviewing a decision to block the sale to Ecuador of 24 Israeli fighterbombers equipped with American engines.

J. Walter Swenson, a recently retired partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Vilas Hickey, died Monday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 127 Heller Way, Upper Montclair, N.J.

The Yankees reached the halfway point of the season last night, and their 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians on Reggie Jackson's run-scoring double in the seventh inning left them with 46 victories and 35 defeats for the first half.
"Dennis the Menace," John Tricoche of South Brooklyn was explaining with patience, is a very simple game, sort of "like hide-and-seek backwards."

Federal lawyers have charged that the Carnation Seafood Inc., of Magnolia, Mass., has been mislabeling fiveounce packages of frozen fish fillets in court papers filed in Brooklyn on July 1. The papers moved to impound 550 pounds of the fillets.

TULSA, Okla., July 5 (UPI) A Federal judge today dismissed a Watergate-re lated conspiracy indictment against the Phillips Petroleum Company, its board chairman and two former officers, saying the Government had violated its own plea-bargaining agreement.

ROME, July 5 The Vatican for the first time called today for government financial support of the world's Roman Catholic schools.

WASHINGTON, July 5 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had upheld the decision by one of its administrative law judges that permanently bars Charles W. Steadman from any affiliation with mutual funds or investment advisers. In addition, Mr. Steadman is to be suspended from the securities business for one year.

LET ME AGAIN TRY to catch up with questions received in the mail. One reader asks if stereo is better than high fidelity. My first impulse was to dismiss the query as ingenuous. On second thought, the question seemed altogether legitimate and indicative that even those with professed interest in sound and its devices are sometimes none too clear about the basic concepts.
MOSCOW, July 6 A leading Soviet foreign affairs weekly today denied the existence of any campaign to excommunicate Western Europe's independent Communist parties.

Jay Grodman of 277 Moore Avenue, Freeport, L.I, an account executive with the Allstate Insurance Company for 2. years, died Monday at South Nassau Communities Hospital after a brief illness He was 56 years old.

IORGIO DI SANT'ANGELO became plain Giorgio Sant'Angelo a year ago. It was just to make life simpler. At about the same time, he took a larger step in the same direction. He moved. But before he left his old apartment in Greenwich Village, he got rid of most of the possessions he'd picked up in his travels around the world.

Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday that it had lowered its ratings on Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company bonds. Specifically, Youngstown's 4 's of 1990, 10 's of 2000 and 9 7/8's of 1991 were lowered to Ba from Baa.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday a gain of 6.3 percent in net income for the first fiscal quarter ended May 28 on a sales gain of 2.9 percent. The figures were about in line with the estimates of John L. Scott, chairman, at the annual shareholder meeting in Chicago last June 17.
Priscilla Dowd Reilly, a retired junior high school teacher, died Tuesday at the home of her daughter in Manlius, N.Y. She was 79 years old and a resident of Manlius.
WASHINGTON, July 6 Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar proposed today to increase first-class postage rates to 16 cents for businesses but to allow individuals to continue paying 13 cents.

ALBANY, July 6-Employers in New York State would be prevented from forcing any worker to retire solely because of age under terms of a bill passed by the State Assembly today with only three dissenting votes.
BIG APPLE SERENADE There will be a variety of summer tones across town this evening, including a do-it-yourself songfest for Savoyards in Greenwich Village at 7:30.

NEW BRUNSWICK, July 6 From Benjamin Franklin to Woody Allen unflattering comments have been made about New Jersey. The state has been pictured as a haven for gangsters and corrupt politicians, a cultural wasteland and a crowded, pollution-choked industrial state.
SAIDA, Lebanon, July 6 (Reuters) Artillery duels were reported today from three fronts in southern Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Environmental groups are rallying to defend the Council on Environmental Quality in the face of a recommendation by President Carter's reorganization advisory group that the White House agency be eliminated or stripped of its most important functions.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) The Federal Government today granted preliminary approval of applications to open two national banks to be managed and directed primarily by women.
Exactly six years ago the New York City Transit Authority started building a subway line under Central Park and since then an acre of trees and grass has been dug up.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6 U.N. Secretary General Kurt Waldheim is urging governments to create all International Energy Institution but he advises that such a body avoid involvement in negotiating international price fixing.

New York City's long-delayed alternative air-pollution-control plan, based on stricter enforcement of existing parking regulations and relying on the auto industry and the Federal Government to produce cleaner cars, was submitted to the state yesterday.

"Belshazzar" is an oratorio of such operatic potential that it has occasionally been staged. LOS ANGELES, July 6 At a spot 16 miles east of San Juan Capistrano, the quaint mission town where swallows return every March, a mutilated body encased in a plastic trash bag was found abandoned near State Highway 74 on April 13, 1975.

A court rule aimed at curbing political patronage and nepotism in the appointment of lawyers as guardians, receivers and referees will be imposed shortly on State Supreme Court justices in Manhattan and the Bronx.

LONDON The New York Times correspondent in Bonn, Craig Whitney, wrote the other day:

WILLIAMSTOWN, MASS. ISALLIANCE," one of Shaw's later plays, is one of his most free and unexpected. It has its themes love, youth and age, parents and children but it is not really about them. There are moments when it doesn't seem to be about anything, but it is. With its twirling shifts, its paradoxes, its sometimes incoherent ramblings, it is about movement itself. It is Shaw writing his sword's-point comedy as music rather than prose.

NEW HAVEN ARNEY AND Tabby have moved to our town and they are eager to have me as their friend. They keep sending me letters to tell me how wonderful they are, and how available. If this sounds immodest, it is. Yet I am always looking for new friends, and I have seldom been approached so openly and with such candor.

In celebration of Louis Armstrong's birthday, which fell on July 4 (he would have been 77 years old), Ruby Braff is leading a quintet at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, this week and next, that is playing nothing but tunes that, in one way or another, are associated with Mr. Armstrong.

Federal prosecutors in New York City said yesterday that they would stop holding news conferences to announce indictments, but would continue giving copies of indictments to the press and answering questions from reporters.

WASHINGTON, July 6 President Carter's advisers on government reorganization have suggested to him that the White House staff be partly restructured and cut 30 percent by Sept. 30, and that officials developing domestic policy emulate the machinery already in use to prepare foreign and defense policy.

KANSAS CITY, July 6 (AP) The formation of a six-city professional rodeo circuit was announced today at a news conference in Kansas City. The league will begin operation next year in Los Angeles, Denver, Kansas City, Mo., Tulsa, Okla., Salt Lake City and San Antonio, Tex.

Three passengers' accounts of how two persons were shot to death in a hijacked bus at Kennedy International Airport on Monday differed sharply yesterday from the explanation offered by the man seized in the hijacking.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company announced yesterday that they were cutting their prices for copper cathodes by 3 cents to 68 cents a pound, effective today. The two announcements followed that of the Phelps Dodge Corporation by a day.

TEL AVIV, July 6 The state ruled today that former Foreign Minister Abba Eban could not be prosecuted for breaches of foreign currency regulations in connection with bank accounts he maintained in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The Carter Administration is considering a major reorganization of the Federal Government's policy on management of oceans as the animal and mineral harvest from the sea has produced new economic and political problems.

MINEOLA, L.L, July 6-Designating petitions containing 14,000 signatures to enable Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes to run for Nassau County Executive were taken overnight from the Democratic Party's county headquarters here, the county police reported today.
LUXEMBOURG July 6 West Europe's postwar quest for unity appears to be flagging, even as the Continent is at a milestone on the road to closer economic cooperation.

A Mobil Oil Corporation subsidiary yesterday asked a Federal court to set aside an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling that would supplant company-requested tariffs on the transAlaska pipeline with substantially lower rates.

VIVA LA REPUBLICA!" which opened at the Jean Renoir Cinema yesterday, is an effective, hard-hitting Marxist his tory of Cuba from the Spanish-American War, by which the United States came to dominate Cuban affairs, until the successful 1959 revolution led by Fidel Castro. The film is composed of newsreel footage supplemented by political cartoons, footage from fiction films and from television films and commercials.

Ron Leibman, who recently played Richard III in Shakespeare's play at the Actors Studio, will next portray a standup comic in "The Last Analysis," the only full-length play by Saul Bellow. The production will be staged at the Berkshire Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., from July 20 to July 31. The cast will also include Doris Belack and Jill O'Hara.

The final report of the Temporary Commission on City Finances established by the New York City Council in 1975 and headed by Owen McGivern, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court tells us how New York got into financial trouble, how it can get out of trouble, and how it can stay out of trouble.

ALBANY, July 6 Governor Carey said today that Senate Republican leaders had ccepted his definition of when an accident victim could bring suit for pain and suffering under the state's no-fault automobile insurance law, bringing all sides "very close to an agreement."
Ken Singleton, born and raised in the Metropolitan area, plays for the Baltimore Orioles now after tours with the Mets and the Montreal Expos.

CAMDEN, July 6 Last year the nation celebrated its Bicentennial and the 200th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. Today academicians, students and the general public gathered on the Camden campus of Rutgers University to celebrate the tricentennial of another remarkable document dedicated to democracy.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Last Friday, a half-dozen columnists lounged around the White House swimming pool, having what was billed as an informal chat with President Carter.

SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 6 (AP) The flow of illegal aliens has increased since President Carter announced his amnesty plan for foreigners illegally living in this country, the United States Border Patrol said today.

Environmental conditions in the ocean off New Jersey have improved since last year when 70 percent of the surf clams died, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said yesterday. The agency called the situation "cautiously encouraging."

MADISON, Wis., July 6 Negotiators for thousands of striking state employees and for the state returned to the bargaining table here this afternoon for the first time since the strike began four days ago. WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, said today that the Administration did not intend to intervene in labor negotiations.
Chief Elton Greene, a spokesman for the Tuscarora Indians in their struggle to acquire and maintain landholdings in New York State, died Tuesday at his home near Niagara Falls. He was 87 years old.

WATERLOO VILLAGE, N.J. THE NEWPORT Jazz FestivalNew York's Blues Picnic on Monday on the grounds of this restored colonial village opened with an appropriate Fourth of July bang actually an electronic and vocal shout but then settled down to a simmer for the rest of the afternoon.

THE Lombardo home was the last one on the block to be equipped with an intercom. A system was not installed at the time of construction five years ago because, as Nancy Lombardo admitted frankly, "We ran out of money."

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) About 1.2 million persons in Washington's Maryland suburbs were urged today to stop washing dishes, clothes and themselves today after an early morning fire in a filtration plant cut pumping volume.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 5 Despite efforts by the Carter Administration to allay fears that it intends to press for a one-man, one-vote solution to the racial impasse here, South African officials maintain a strongly antagonistic attitude toward the Administration, insisting that its pronouncements are hindering black advancement by generating a backlash in the dominant Afrikaner population.

The condominium apartments of Galleria, which cost up to $1.2 million each for an unfinished, unfurnished but breathtaking swath of glass-walled duplex rooms in the sky over East 57th Street are Stanley Thea's to market to the very rich.

I have noticed for some time that a few of the lamps in my house "flicker" after they have been on for a while. We have aluminum wiring in the house, but it was "pig-tailed" by an electrician recently. Is there anything that should be done about this? M.P., Merrick, L.I.

Bob Fultord, who recently resigned as coach of the Los Angeles Kings, was named coach and general manager of the Chicago Black Hawks yesterday. The 41-year-old Pulford, who led the Kings to the hockey playoffs the last four seasons, replaced the interim coach, Bill White, who took over in midseason after the dismissal of Billy Reay.

Selling pressure on such blue-chip issues as the papers, steels and chemicals pushed the stock market broadly lower yesterday as some of these basic industrial issues dropped to their poorest prices of 1977.

AS NEARLY as Sidney Milstein can tell, the fire started in the electric garage-door opener. It fed on the door itself, some boxes and papers that were stored in the garage, got to the gasoline tank of the station wagon with an explosive roar, and raced through two bedrooms and the living room of the ranch house Mr. Milstein owns in Closter, N.J. before the firemen got the flames out.
Nat N. Dorfman, veteran press agent, who represented more than 300 Broadway plays and musicals over the last half century, died in New York on Sunday of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

NEW HAVEN, July 7 Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation identified by local policemen as having been witnesses to an extensive illegal wiretapping operation were ordered by the Justice Department today to testify on their knowledge of the operation.
How lucky can you get? Today is the seventh day of the seventh month of the 77th year of this century. It's 7/7/77.

Auditors of State Comptroller Arthur Levitt have uncovered instances in which officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took expense-paid out-of-town trips at economy rates, but were reimbursed at first-class rates.

TEL AVIV, July 6 (AP) A pipe bomb apparently planted by Arab terrorists exploded beneath a vegetable stand in a crowded open-air market in a Tel Aviv suburb today, killing one person and injuring 20 others.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 The Mets, who have had trouble playing on dry fields lately, found tonight that they do no better on a wet one as they lost again to the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-3, at Veterans Stadium.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reuters) High ranking British and Guatemalan officials met here today in a secret session aimed at avoiding an armed confrontation over the British territory of Belize.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) A Federal grand jury today reopened its investigation of tax fraud charges against the General Motors Corporation following a Federal judge's decision not to halt the investigation.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus has taken a step toward nullifying a permit his predecessor granted the Exxon Corporation to operate a controversial floating oil-processing facility and shipping terminal off Santa Barbara.

IMLAY CITY, Mich., July 6 (AP) The Hamill Manufacturing Company has agreed to stop rquiring assembly line workers to raise their hands for permission to go to the bathroom, a union spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Cocaine, the stimulant drug that has acquired an aura of status, wealth and glamour, has been shown to be a "serious drug of abuse" whose side effects can include anxiety, insomnia, paranoid delusions and even death in rare instances, according to a Government report made public today.

OVER the years, New Yorkers have come to expect that they can find anything in the world they might need right here. And it's true that from A-frame houses and abdominal supports to zipper repairs and zoos, everything is here for the finding if one looks hard enough.

A reporter recently interviewed a business manager about corporate bribery, kickbacks, international boycotts, illegal political contributions, personal use of stockholders' property, class-action lawsuits, charges by consumers' organizations, and sex discrimination.
WASHINGTON, July 6 The Atlantabased Coca-Cola Company's long-term investment in Jimmy Carter has begun to pay off.

WASHINGTON, July 6 President Carter, who last week called for a threeweek halt on comments about the Middle East, broke his own moratorium today and told leaders of American Jewish organizations that as part of an overall Middle East settlement the Arab nations should establish full diplomatic relations with Israel.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 The issue of anti-Semitism in Argentina is now being openly debated here. It is being taken seriously by the Government of President Jorge Rafael Videla because of unrest created in the Jewish community by acts of violence against Jews, and because of the effects this has on Argentina's international image.

WHITE PLAINS, July 6 The State Health Department moved today to impose its own plan for closing maternity wards in a seven-county area north and west of New York City after the regional health planning body failed to devise its own plan.

EAST ORANGE, July 6 The long holiday weekend and start of the summer vacation season has created a shortage of stored blood in the state, and officials at the North Jersey Blood Center today issued an urgent appeal for donors.
The Department of Sanitation has mounted a "War on Litter" in New York City streets, and to implement its campaign has issued a list of the cleanest and dirtiest streets in the five boroughs.

LUXEMBOURG, July 6 A strong call for Western Europe to insure that substantial progress is made toward freer world trade this year in the Geneva talks to liberalize trade came today from two prominent European leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UPI) A Municipal Court judge fined the Gulf Oil Corporation today $37,000 for more than 100 violations of the city fire code at its South Philadelphia refinery, the scene of an August 1975 blast that killed eight firemen.

IN MINNETONKA, Minn., 14 years ago, a tall young man named Robert Taylor decided that what this country needed was a cake of soap shaped like a snowball. He didn't know much about soap, but he wanted to go into business for himself (he had been a salesman for Johnson Johnson) and thought that an unusual soap might be a good start.

CAIRO, July 6 (AP) A former Egyptian Minister of Religious Affairs, kidnapped three days ago by members of a fanatic Moslem cult that preaches "sacred terror," was found murdered today in a villa near the Giza pyramids, the police said.

Like characters in an urban disaster movie, that could be called "Sweat," the nearly 1,500 tenants of 800 Third Avenue, a 40-floor office building, have spent the last two days trying to cope with no lights, no electricity, no incoming phone service and with temperatures around 90 no air-conditioning.

OTTAWA, July 6 The Canadian Government ordered a full-scale inquiry today into charges that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police had resorted to illegal break-ins and other activities in carrying out security investigations.
If you need some help with your trees and plants once you take them home, consider a quickie course at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

The days of wine and roses may be on their way back for Calumet Farm, the Kentucky-based stable that dominated racing 15 to 20 years ago. At least that was the impression Alydar, a rangy, chestnut colt, gave many in a crowd of 17,255 at Belmont Park yesterday as he scored by 3 lengths in the $36,825 Great American Stakes.

BONN, July 6 The West German Government has reportedly received new evidence of Soviet displeasure with the Carter Administration's stress on human rights, adding to the concern here aver the possible effect of Soviet-American frictions on straegic arms talks and detente in general.

A court rule aimed at curbing political patronage and nepotism in the appointment of lawyers as guardians, receivers and referees, wilt be imposed shortly on State Supreme Court justices in Manhattan and the Bronx.

SPOLETO, ITALY WHEN THEY CALLED the concert that took place over two nights at the Festival of Two Worlds' open-air Roman Theater a "Dance Marathon," no one was joking. The first night threatened by rain at first opened at 8:45 and when they called it a night at 12:45, because the humidity was making the stage treacherously damp, we were only halfway through the second part.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 6 Rodney Jenkins scored his first jumper triumph of the Lake Placid horse show today just as the clouds disappeared and the sun emerged.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 6 With Pele missing a game for the first time since last July 23 and with Franz Beckenbauer sitting out the second half, the Cosmos rebounded from a two-game losing streak and defeated the San Jose Earthquakes, 3-0, at Giants Stadium tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) T ehCarter Administration plans to ask Congress to cut taxes for families with incomes of $25,000 and less, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 After heated discussions between the State Department and a Congressional subcommittee, a Congressional observer will apparently be allowed, to attend secret meetings under way in Paris to discuss Zaire's troubled finances.

Taking advantage of an increasingly popular delaying tactic, the Inmont Corporation, a large printing ink company, succeeded yesterday in further putting off an unwanted takeover bid from Esmark Inc. for nearly $200 million.

EVERAL MONTHS AGO I started a diary, thus quietly joining a long line of men and women who seek to find wisdom, perspective, and insight by jotting down the thrust of their daily life. It was not my first attempt.

WASHINGTON With little fanfare, the yen is currently floating at its highest level in four years and Japan's Ministry of International Industry and Trade, has just acted to liberalize import restrictions.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 6 (AP) South Korea's National Assembly adopted a resolution today urging President Park Chung Hee to free violators of his 1975 decree banning dissent.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP)-Two ultra-light displacement yachts were waging a bow-to-bow battle for first place today in the trans-Pacific race from Los Angeles to Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reuters) The chief United States disarmament negotiator Paul C. Warnke, said today that President Carter's decision to deploy the cruise missile in place of the abandoned B-1 bomber was unlikely to provoke heavier Soviet spending on air defense.

HOUSTON, July 6 Only a month ago, Liz Carpenter was bemoaning the slovenly state of affairs into which she perceived Texas politics to have sunk. In a newspaper column, the former press secretary to Lady Bird Johnson wrote:

BEYOND providing temporary relief from the blight of rerunitis, fresh summer programming can occasionally offer some distinctly positive assets. Tonight at 8, for example, NBC is presenting an attractively packaged "Highlights of the Russian Dance Festival." And tomorrow at 9. Channel 13 will begin a weekly series of British adaptations from the short stories of Graham Greene.

The Hertz Corporation's superstar, O.J. Simpson, tripped himself slightly when he issued an invitation recently to one William Schechter of Garden City, N.Y. to join the Hertz No. 1 Club. As it turned out, Mr. Schechter is director of public relations at archrival Avis Inc. The Avis executive declined the offer.

The urge to be a head coach had been inside him ever since the New York Jets won Super Bowl III, but one night four years ago Walt Michaels stared into his glass of beer and made fists with those big thick hands.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today it had in effect overcharged purchasers of its securities by $2 million to $10 million during the last five years and was planning to make restitution to some 1,400 institutional investors.

WASHINGTON, July 6 A new and novel coalition that includes environmentalists, state and city officials and sewer builders urged Congress today to forgo sweeping changes in the Water Pollution Act this year and to concentrate instead on "emergency" clean water measures.

TOKYO, July 6 (UPI) The dollar reversed an early decline and gained against the Japanese yen today after the Japanese Central Bank stepped in to support it. Trading was heavy on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange market.

Insiders at the Cummins Engine Company have recently sold shares in this leading independent manufacturer of diesel engines for trucks, but there is little indication that their selling indicates disenchantment with company prospects.

Auditors of State Comptroller Arthur Levitt have uncovered instances in which officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took expense-paid out-of-town trips at economy rates, but were reimbursed at first-class rates.

ALBANY, July 6 A controversial bill that, while outlawing the use of children in pornographic movies would also make illegal some legitimate sex education books, was recalled from Governor Carey's desk today by its sponsor.

TRENTON, July 6 A new state drive against illegal disposal of dangerous chemical and poisonous wastes has resulted in the indictment of two Morris County men on charges of having deposited large amounts of toxic substances on a Jersey City pier and having dumped others in an abandoned mine pint in Sussex County.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reuters) The Federal Aviation Administration proposed today a rule that would make it illegal to carry weapons into airline terminals.

Summer wouldn't be summer without daisies, though the common field daisy, known to almost every man, woman and child, is sometimes called Farmer's Curse. Ask any farmer and he'll tell you why. Daisies beautify rural roadsides, but they invade meadows, pastures and all kinds of cultivated fields. Most farmers smile at picnicking youngsters who gather handfuls of daisies, but they gasp in utter bafflement at summer visitors who actually pick them to arrange in vases.
For the third consecutive trading session, old-crop July soybean futures dropped the daily limit of 30 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

RICHARD PECK, a saxophonist from Louisiana, plays in the ensemble of Philip Glass, the composer. One would never have suspected from his contributions to Mr. Glass's minimalist music that Mr. Peck is a voluble improviser with the technique of a jazz musician and something of the sensibility of a rocker.

The Young at Heart Senior Citizens Club for retired persons from Far Rockaway, Queens, likes to have its members get around. Next week they are taking a trip to the Westbury Music Fair; soon they will leave for California. They have already sponsored trips to Nova Scotia and to Israel, and yesterday they went to Broadway, which was nearly as great an expedition, as far as they were concerned.

The Catholic Church in the United States has a long and deserved reputation as a bulwark against sexual permissiveness. Even in recent years, while many Catholics have been getting divorced, employing artificial contraception, yielding to unsanctioned pleasures and playing their part in the worldwide "sexual revolution," the Church hierarchy has remained unyielding.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 The Los Angeles school district's integration plan was held unconstitutional today by a Superiod Court judge who said that it was too modest to desegregate effectively the 593,000-pupil district.
DETROIT, July 6 (AP) The Ford Motor Company is recalling 295,000 recentmodel vans and wagons to add padding to intsrument panels that could shatter and injure an occupant in a collision.
DETROIT, July 6 American new-car sales set a record in June, according to reports released by the domestic companies today. Domestic sales were up 10.9 percent from June 1976.

James L. Sullivan, 79 years old, was assaulted and robbed of $150 as he waited for the elevator in the basement of his apartment building in the Inwood section of Manhattan at noon on Monday, Dec. 20, 1976. He appeared unharmed at the time, but a blood clot on the brain has since been discovered. His assailant escaped.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6 Two unemployed men from Stamford who were arrested by the Greenwich police in connection with a weekend burglary have also been charged with the May 13 and May 18 rapes of two middle-aged Greenwich women.

PARIS, July 6 The smell of stale cigarette smoke hung heavily in the drab, poorly ventilated union hall. Men of a dozen, nationalities, dressed in flowing African robes, Middle Eastern fezzes and bleached blue jeans, mingled in the aisles trying to communicate with each other in rudimentary French.
Robert L. Fine, a retired advertising executive, died Monday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 38 East 85th Street.

CAIRO, July 6 The increased fighting in southern Lebaaon has aroused new fears that the confrontation between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Lebanese right-wing Christians may turn into another Arab-Israeli war.
ALBANY, July 6 The State Senate passed a bill today to stimulate the use of generic drugs instead of brand-named ones that are now routinely prescribed by physicians.

HERE is a new kind of customer knocking on the doors of home sellers these days Americans who aren't married. In this year's booming housing market, many real estate agents say they are encountering more and more buyers who are not married couples with children, their traditional clientele.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (Reuters) The increase in consumer prices in the industrial world rose to an annual rate of 8.1 percent in May from 8 percent in April, the International Monetary Fund said today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) A Small Business Administration official today defended the agency's dealings with a former $36,000-a-year executive of the agency who was awarded a Government contract under a program for disadvantaged businessmen.

The New York Nets' basketball team, intent on moving to New Jersey, filed a lawsuit against the Knicks yesterday, challenging a key part in the structure of professional sports that allocates franchises and protects, "territories."
How lucky can you get? Today is the seventh day of the seventh month of the 77th year of this century. It's 7/7/77.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) President Carter will decide whether to recommend production of neutron weapons, which are designed to kill by radiation rather than heat and blast, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today.

Unaudited net asset values of close-end investment fund shares, reported by the companies as of Friday, July 1, 1977. Also shown is the closing listed market price or a dealer-to-dealer asked price of each fund's shares, with percentage of difference.

Four coal ventures involving more than $90 million were announced yesterday. The Seaway Coal Company said in Cadiz, Ohio, that it had been sold to the Shell Oil Company for $65 million. Seaway's R F Coal Company subsidiary mines about three million tons a year of soft coal.

The Young at Heart Senior Citizens Club for retired persons from Far Rockaway, Queens, likes to have its members get around. Next week they are taking a trip to the Westbury Music Fair; soon they will leave for California. They have already sponsored trips to Nova Scotia and to Israel, and yesterday they went to Broadway, which was nearly as great an expedition, as far as they were concerned.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 6 (AP) Eight players, including Jimmy Connors, will start competition tomorrow for a top prize of $30,000 in the World Championship Tennis Tournament of Champions.
WASHINGTON, July 6 The Carter Administration rebuffed today a second attempt by Israel to sell to Ecuador 24 fighter-bombers equipped with American engines.
DETROIT, Thursday, July 7 Union bargainers reached a tentative contract agreement with the city of Detroit early today, apparently ending a one-day strike by nearly 8,000 municipal employees.

The marriage of Peggy Ann Benenson of New York to Frederic R. Coudert 3d of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., a member of the internation law firm of Coudert Brothers, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Lipson, brother and sister-in-law of the bride. Justice Myles J. Lane of the State Supreme Court Appellate Division, performed the ceremony.

ILL PUBLIC relations people never run out of stunts? Promotions like this really shouldn't be encouraged, but, be that as it may, the hype-of-the-year award goes to Horizon Carpet Company of Calhoun, Ga.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) A Federal judge in Massachusetts has ordered the Four Seasons Cooperative, an agricultural cooperative, to turn over its records to the Interstate Commerce Commission, the I.C.C. announced today.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (UPI) A prosecution witness in the murder trial of two American Indian Movement members, Paul Skyhorse and Richard Mohawk, testified yesterday that she was forced into making statements against the defendants.
