DETROIT, Thursday, July 7 Union bargainers reached a tentative contract agreement with the city of Detroit early today, apparently ending a one-day strike by nearly 8,000 municipal employees.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 7 The West Course at Winged Foot Golf Club has been too exacting for many golfers, including some of the best and strongest young men in the game. But it was just right today for Ken Gordon, a 61year-old official of the United States Golf Association, and his 37-year-old partner, Eric Gleacher, as they won the medal in the 41st, annual John G. Anderson Memorial tournament.

The site of the Ken Norton-Jimmy Young heavyweight boxing match on Nov. 5 was announced yesterday as Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev. The purse, an estimated $3.25 million, will be the largest in history for a nontitle fight.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Suzy Park Thomson, who worked for former House Speaker Carl Albert for five years, said today that she was not an agent for the South Korean Government and had never received either money or instructions from Tongsun Park or the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.
Two measures of consumer attitudesa consumer confidence index and a buying plans index-turned up sharply in June, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

Competition is an unquestioned facet of business life, but there have been some recent incidents that raise the issue of whether a few companies-in their desire to close a sale may have carried the competitive spirit beyond the business community generally considers the bounds of acceptable corporate behavior.

WHAT WILL BECOME of Crystal Gayle? For a while she both benefited and suffered from the fact that she is Loretta Lynn's younger sister. Benefited in the sense that she got valuable exposure touring with Miss Lynn and publicity from the fact of her relationship; suffered in that she had to work doubly hard to prove herself on her own.

WASHINGTON, July 7-The inquiry into the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has collapsed, Federal officials close to the case said today. The investigation has cost the Federal Bureau of Investigation more than $1 million over the last two years.
Ten journalists have been selected as Walter Bagehot Fellows in Economics and Business Journalism at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism., the university announced yesterday.

The gentle ladies with their parasols who once favored the spas, avenues and racecourses of fashionable Saratoga Springs, N.Y., would probably feel at home gazing across the sloping, sunlit lawns of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. What they would have made of the New York City Ballet's astringent neo-Classicism is hard to guess.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 A new mystery in the affairs of the late Howard R. Hughes has come to light with the disclosure in court documents filed in Wilmington, Del., that about $600 million in cash went out of the industrialist's liquid assets account in the last 10 years of his life.

THE FLAG EXPERTS Boleslaw and Marie Louise D'Otrange Mastai reviewed the history of the American flag and their own formidable collection brilliantly in a book published in 1973. For many readers, however, the book seemed an appetizer for the sort of museum show the couple had proved should now be possible.

A luncheon at the Pierre Hotel honoring Empress Farah of Iran was interrupted yesterday by a woman screaming, "Down with the Shah," while outside more than 1,500 demonstrators slowed Fifth Avenue traffic.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 7 M. Halsey Thomas, the first man to serve as archivist at Princeton University and a noted historical editor, died today at the Princeton Medical Center after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would appeal Tuesday's ruling by the Canadian Federal Court that I.B.M. had infringed on five Xerox Corporation copier patents.

Unexpected rains over 65 percent of Iowa and showers also in Minnesota and Wisconsin led to further heavy selling of soybean futures contracts yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. For the fourth session in a row, the old-crop months of July and August dropped the daily limit of 30 cents a bushel.

THERE seem to be two models of political autobiography coming off the line in this country. The first might be called the Statesman, even though the author rarely is one. It is a dull, dignified, sensible four-door sedan.
Luck beat the odds at Belmont Park yesterday, 7/7/77, when three horses carrying the number seven made it to the winner's circle.

SKOKIE, Ill., July 7 The handful of swaggering Chicago Nazis who keep planning to march in this peaceful suburb may not look like much of a threat, but to the large Jewish community in Skokie they are seen as a clear and present danger, a menacing and painful reminder of the deaths of six million Jews at the hands of Hitler's Germany.
DETROIT, July 7 Domestic auto plants are scheduled to build 167,354 cars this week, 14 percent fewer than a week earlier, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

Basically, kids come in three camping models: carry-along, anchored and catch-me-if-you-can. There is a form of camping suitable for each stage of the youngster's mobility, and the secret of harmonious outdoor living lies in keying your camping style to what your kids can handle.

WASHINGTON, July 7 W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that business leaders were less opposed to taxing capital gains at ordinary income tax rates than was commonly supposed.

Seeking to dramatize a claimed comeback from a first term in which he presided over a city that tottered close to default, Mayor Beame filed more than 100,000 signatures in support of his reelection yesterday.

In the January 22, 1975 edition of The New York Times, an article appeared dealing with Bernard Bergman, a nursing home operator, and his appearance before a Senate subcommittee. The article noted, among other things, that Mr. Bergman was represented by Nathan Lewin, a Washington attorney.
DANBURY, Conn. July 7 "I saw smoke coming out, and I saw all the heads at the windows, and my mind was saying: This can't be happening, this isn't real."

In spite of pressure from a Federal appeals court to fix Concorde noise standards "with dispatch," the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to extend indefinitely its 13month-old "temporary" ban on Concorde landings at Kennedy International Airport.

HISTORY Belize, the former British Crown Colony of British Honduras, has been a sore spot in British-Guatemalan relations since the 19th century. Spanish sailors were the first Europeans to see it in the early 16th century, but British loggers, who arrived more than a century later, became the permanent settlers.

The Dow Chemical Company, the first in the chemical industry to report indicated results for the second quarter, said yesterday earnings would be about the same as the $155 million, or 84 cents a share, realized in the June quarter of 1976. Sales are estimated at about $1.5 billion, up 10 percent from the $1.4 billion for the three months ended June 30, 1976.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Scientists reviewing nonprescription pain relievers said today that although aspirin did relieve pain and inflammation caused by arthritis, the labels on such products should not say that they were for the treatment of that disease because that could lead people to self-diagnose their illnesses incorrectly.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Top officials of Action, the volunteer agency of the Federal Government, are believed to have recommended the appointment of Dr. Carolyn Payton, director of counseling at Howard University, as director of the Peace Corps.

The United States and the Soviet Union are roughly in strategic balance, according to the Carter Administration's first comprehensive study of the global power relationships. Future trends, the study has found, are more favorable than had been anticipated by the Ford Administration. The study concluded, highly placed sources said, that the Soviet buildup in strategic arms was being effectively offset by measures taken by the United States and its allies. [Page 1, Column 6.]

JULY IS THE MONTH of Ron Kovic's "Born on the Fourth of July." His searing personal Vietnam and anti-Vietnam story comes out in a paperback edition from Pocket Books, a year after its hardcover publication by McGraw-Hill.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Fundamental changes in the way that Americans communicate are forcing the Federal Government to make policy decisions that could alter the fortunes of the nation's largest communication organizations and the lives of most citizens.

Rick Reuschel, bidding to become the National League's starting pitcher in the All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium on July 19, gained his 12th victory yesterday as the Chicago Cubs opened a four-game series at home against St. Louis with a 2-0 triumph.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 7 Gary Jeter, the defensive lineman who is the Giants' No. 1 draft choice, signed three one-year contracts with the National Football League team today and said he was happy with what I got."

WASHINGTON, July 7 A Republican member of the House ethics committee, Representative Bruce F. Caputo of Westchester, said today that he would ask the committee to seek access to White House tapes in search of information on an alleged cover-up of the Korean bribery scandal here.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)-The United States Geological Survey reported today that 70 percent of the nation's streams and rivers had less than normal flows of water in June, although there were fewer record lows than in May.

New York enthusiasts, accustomed to a July tournament, will find the one beginning today slightly different. It will be a sectional instead of a regional tournament and play will be at the Statler Hilton Hotel instead of the New York Hilton.
DOVER, Del., July 7 (UPI) The Democrats triumphed in their first major confrontation with Gov. Pierre S. du Pont, but only after pulling a senator from a vacation in Ohio to cast the deciding vote.

NEW DELHI, July 7 The speaker of the lower house of Parliament appeared assured today of election as President of India as the governing Janata Party nominated him and all opposition parties concurred.

THIS IS THE SORT of week that makes us wish we had half-stars for ratings between those usually given. That way we could give a star and a half to the new uptown restau rant that is one flight down, and a half-star to the new downtown restaurant that is one flight up.
While controversy over a parking ban continues in Manhattan, the neighboring city of Newark has been successfully limiting its parking for two years, according to Newark and Federal officials.

A recently compiled collection of photographs of earthquake light flares in the sky in Japan, combined with reports from visiting scientists of the strange lighting-up of the sky during the massive earthquake in Tangshan, China, last year, have led researchers to begin scientific investigation of the phenomenon.

TURNBERRY, Scotland, July 7 Except for the warm, windless weather, it begins to look again like the Open. The one-day wonders have vanished, as expected, after the second round of the 106th British Open golf championship and, also as expected, the established American pros have reclaimed their turf.

The San Juan Racing Associationowner of a $45 million race track in Puerto Rico, eight radio stations in the United States and a professional soccer team known as the Washington Diplomats disclosed yesterday that it was discussing the sale of one or more divisions.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) A Federal District Court ruled today that the tional Labor Relations Act does not apply to lay teachers in religious schools.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 7 From obscure colleges and places whose names appear only in the sport pages, rookies and free agents trickled to the opening of the Jets' training camp today.
Stock prices edged higher yesterday as selected energy issues continued to gain and a smattering of strength appeared in the recently battered blue chips.

DETROIT, July 7 The jury of nine men and three women in the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital case began on June 29 to consider the fate of Leonora M. Perez and Filipina B. Narciso, who are charged with poisoning nine patients in the summer of 1975.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Officials in two suburban counties declared today that a water shortage had reached emergency proportions and ordered major businesses and industries to close.
Alaskan ail production is apparently beginning to show up in United States crude oil output figures, according to the latest weekly report released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
A loan shark and three henchmen were arrested yesterday at the home of a Bronx dentist who was being shaken down for a gambling debt, the police said.

Sentences of 45 weekends in jail were imposed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on a former bank official and an accountant who had admitted their involvement in akickback scheme involving $2.3 million in fraudulent bank loans.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 7Larry O'Brien, the commissioner, has called the National Basketball Association owners into an emergency session regarding the territorial controversy that has developed between the Knicks and the Nets. The meeting will be held next Wednesday at the O'Hare Hilton Hotel in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, July 7 Over 100 bills and resolutions that would affect women have been introduced in the 95th Congress. Legislation that is still pending includes:

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, July 7 Britain's system of voluntary wage restraints, the instrument with which the Labor Party Government has tried to restore economic well-being, lay in ruins today as a result of rebellions by several major trade unions.

The American Jewish Committee, after operating for 29 years in Argentina, is closing its office in Buenos-Aires and protesting anti-Semitic and anti-American threats against its chief representative and his family.
PARIS, July 7 (AP) Eleven major creditor countries of the African nation of Zaire said today they had agreed to stretch out the nation's payments on the largest part of the debt.

PERTH AMBOY, July 7 This city of a 39,000 across the Arthur Kill from Staten Island may have to take "drastic action" I soon unless its water supply is restored, Fredy J. Mazurek, the community's Director of Economic Development, said today following the state's closing of the city's wells last Friday because of contamination.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 Los Angeles County deputy sheriffs went to a home in the suburb of Culver City today and, beside a garage, they found the skeletal remains of what appeared to have been a man.
MADISON, Wis., July 7 Martin James Schreiber, the man who has been in the shadow of former Gov. Patrick J. Lucey for the last six and a half years, was sworn in today as this state's 40th Governor.

ALBANY, July 7 Governor Carey today signed into law a bill that nullifies any franchise arrangement under which an oil company forces one of its gasolinestation operators to sell that company's tires, batteries or automobile accessories or prohibits him from selling the products of another company.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it would review and modify its expense-account policies, which have come under criticism in the last few days.

Just 12 days ago, Norman A. Carlson, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, ordered a national review of measures aimed at preventing fires such as the one at the Danbury penitentiary yesterday, an aide said.
While controversy over a parking ban continues in Manhattan, the neighboring city of Newark has been successfully limiting its parking for two years, according to Newark and Federal officials.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The country's crime rate dropped 9 percent in the first three months of this year as against the same 1976 period, the largest quarterly reduction in the 19 years the Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued crime reports, the bureau said today.

DANNY O'KEEFE and George Fischoff, who are performing at the Other End this week, are about as unlikely a pairing as anyone could imagine. Mr. O'Keefe is a singer and songwriter with a poetic bent, while Mr. Fischoff is a songwriter turned piano entertainer.

ALBANY, July 7 A bill that would raise the ceiling on interest rates paid by people who borrow against the cash value of their insurance policies won narrow approval in the Assembly early this morning.

This summer's Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival, which began Wednesday and continues through Aug. 27, is a shorter, blander descendant of the Schaefer Music Festival. The Dr. Pepper format represents a grudging compromise between the forces that have battled over pop concerts in the southeastern corner of Central Park for several years.

Eddie Firmani, who has had a love affair with soccer on three continents, was named coach of the Cosmos yesterday. He replaces Gordon Bradley, who relinquished the position to resume his duties as vice president in charge of player personnel and development.

DANBURY, Conn., July 7 Fire and fumes swept through a locked, overcrowded cellblock at the Federal mediumsecurity prison here early today, killing five inmates and leaving 71 others injured in a nightmare of confusion and panic. Authorities said the fire was believed to have been set deliberately.

THE SCHAEFER Festival of popular music in Central Park is no more, but the Dr. Pepper Festival, which began Wednes day evening, bears more than a passing resemblance to it. Ron Delsener is still the producer, the tickets are still cheap though at $4 for orchestra seats, they are reflecting the inflationary spiral and the concerts still begin early, at 6 or 6:30 P.M.

A 70-piece symphony orchestra will be performing in Madison Square Garden tonight and tomorrow night. Each of the instruments is individually amplified with a special pickup, and the sound, projected out into the hall by the state-of-the-art public-address system used at the Montreal Olympic Games, should be both the loudest and the clearest of any symphony orchestra in the world.
Raymond J. Burns, who with his father founded Burns International Security Services, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 91 years old.

ALBANY, July 7 Governor Carey informed legislative leaders today that he would accept only three of the 22 pension items that had been buried within a bill intended to implement the state's labor agreements with its employees.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Carter Administration, in its first comprehensive study of global power relationships, has found the United States and Soviet Union in rough strategic balance and sees future trends as more favorable and less ominous than the Ford Administration thought.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) Sir Michael Tippett, widely considered Britain's greatest living composer, was given a rapturous ovation here tonight after the world premiere of his opera "The Ice Break," a work with a sizable American flavor both in theme and production.
When he's talking about what he's doing with his magazine, Carll Tucker, the 25-year-old president of the Saturday Review Magazine Corporation, uses the word "aggressive" a lot.

A recently compiled collection of photographs of earthquake light flares in the sky in Japan, combined with reports from visiting scientists of the strange lighting-up of the sky during the massive earthquake in Tangshan, China, last year, have led researchers to begin scientific investigation of the phenomenon.
Rainbows are appearing in the old United States Custom House on Bowling Green these days, and sculptures are starting to climb the marble walls.

MARY STEENBURGEN was saying the other day that they are thinking of establishing the "Mary Steenburgen memorial locker" in the waitresses' changing room at the Magic Pan, a creperie on East 57th Street. And why not? Mary has moved on, gone to Hollywood.

MONTAUK, L. I. THE BRISK northwest wind dropped to a zephyr with the setting sun, an osprey's rasping cry sounded from the twist ed oaks on the far shore, and a muskrat plowed a furrow through the calm water at the edge of the reeds before me.

Former Assemblyman Michael J. Capanegro of Queens was convicted late yesterday on Federal charges that he had embezzled $29,000 from Local 1101 of the Communications Workers of America in 1971 and 1972 when he was a lawyer for the union.

The dollar continued to slide against most other world currencies in foreign exchange trading yesterday in New York and abroad, according to the Associated Press. However, it did manage to continue a slight comeback in Tokyo against the Japanese yen for the second day.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Federal Power Commission today charged Texaco Inc. with violating the Natural Gas Act of 1938 in using gas from Federal offshore leases in a refinery. It ordered the company to halt the practice.

DETROIT, July 7 (UPI) Bus service and garbage collection returned to nearly normal today when 8,000 city workers ended an unexpected one-day strike and prepared to vote on a tentative three-year contract agreement.

THE "PHIL OCHS Memorial Celebration" took place at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum in May of last year, one month after the folk singer-composer's suicide. The warm tribute by friends and fellow musicians was taped by public television station WHYY-TV/PhiladelphiaWilmington, and a 90-minute television treatment of the event can be seen tomorrow on Channel 13 at 9 P.M.
MOSCOW, July 7 The security police with the unusual step today of announcing the arrest of a suspect charged with having set off a bomb outside a Moscow hotel last month.

The so-called air-pollution and autocontrol plan that was finally put forward by the city this week after more than three years of litigation is only the latest-and most transparenteffort by Mayor Beame to delay and if possible to evade altogether any really effective city action to clear up the intolerable traffic mess that is contributing so severely to the strangulation of New York.
The Atlantic County Prosecutor's office said organized crime might have been involved in the execution-style slaying of a tailor in Pomona.

UPTON, L.I., July 7 Brookhaven National Laboratory took the wraps off a piece of Isabelle today. It evidently hopes that a glimpse of her will spur Congress to provide $173 million more to see the rest of what could become the world's most powerful subatomic proton smasher.

The United States and the Soviet Union are roughly in strategic balance, according to the Carter Administration's first comprehensive study of the global power relationships. Future trends, the study has found, are more favorable than had been anticipated by the Ford Administration. The study concluded, highly placed sources said, that the Soviet buildup in strategic arms was being effectively offset by measures taken by the United States and its allies. [Page 1, Column 6.]

IN ITS MOVE from Lincoln Center to Central Park, Richard Foreman's version of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill "Threepenny opera" emerges lightened and somewhat simplified. In a way, this to the good. The original indoor production had a number of virtues but it was heavily mannered, frequently choked and only partly successful.

OTTAWA, July 7 The dismissal of the head of the Government nuclear agency, Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., was announced today in the aftermath of heavy financial losses on the sale of reactors in deals involving mysterious payments of millions of dollars to agents abroad.

The Federal Government has directed Mayor Beame to dissolve and take over the functions of the Council Against Poverty, the central agency responsible for coordinating the city's antipoverty program. It has threatened to cut off all support to the entire $39 million program.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (Reuters) The Defense Department today notified Congress of a proposed $1.2 billion sale of seven controversial radar planes to Iran, setting the stage for a bitter legislative battle.
LAUTERBRUNNEN, Switzerland, July 7 (AP) An American fell 600 feet to his death while trying to scale the western face of 13,036-foot Mount Eiger in the Bernese Alps.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., July 7 The "spite fence," which has kept the Alexander's store here in virtual quarantine from the adjacent Green Acres Shopping Center for a decade, came down today.

In spite of pressure from a Federal appeals court to fix Concorde noise standards "with-dispatch," the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to extend indefinitely its 13month-old "temporary" ban on Concorde landings at Kennedy International Airport.

A luncheon at the Pierre Hotel honoring Empress Farah of Iran was interrupted yesterday by a woman screaming, "Down with the Shah," while outside more than 1,500 demonstrators slowed Fifth Avenue traffic.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 7 An Ohio Senate investigating committee has charged Columbia Gas System Inc. with mishandling natural gas supplies during 1976 and contributing to the energy crisis in Ohio last winter.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 7 A Chinese Air Force pilot broke away from the squadron he was leading on a routine patrol mission today and defected to Taiwan, outracing pursuing jet fighters into Taiwanese airspace.
Plans to build a $2 million open-air market under the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge were unanimously approved yesterday by the New York City Council.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Britain and Guatemala confronted each other in both Central America and Washington today in their continuing dispute over the British territory of Belize, but by the end of the day their latest crisis appeared to have dissolved into an amicable cocktail party.

WHITE PLAINS, July 7 Prisoners at the Green Haven Correctional Facility struck today to protest prison conditions and the Legislature's asserted inaction on measures that would change the parole and temporary-release program and the method of computing time off for good behavior.

"No one wishes to admit that Section 8 was merely an old error one more time." Irving Welfeld, a housing analyst in the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, concludes an analysis of the nation's current subsidy program for low-income housing with those words in the forthcoming summer issue of the periodical The Public Interest.

A 12-member delegation from the Chinese People's Institute of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in China is here this week for tours and meetings as part of a 22-day visit to the United States.

Margaret Corbin took over her husband's cannon after he fell mortally wounded, and vainly tried to defend Fort Washington against the British 200 years ago, then faded into oblivion and was nearly forgotten.

The Danbury Federal Prison has held some notable prisoners in recent years, including several of the men convicted in connection with the Watergate break-in and the Revs. Daniel and Philip Berrigan, who gained prominence for their opposition to United States involvement in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Penthouse magazine is preparing an article for its August issue alleging "intimate ties" between the Copley News Service and the Central Intelligence Agency, it was learned today.

Laurindo Almeida, the Brazilian guitarist, is something of a stranger in New York jazz circles. This is partly because he lives and works primarily in California, but even more because he is basically a Classical guitarist whose relationship with jazz stems from a period in the late 40's when he was a featured soloist with Stan Kenton's orchestra.

GENEVA, July 7 (Reuters) The United States and the Soviet Union began a round of private talks here today on a possible joint move toward an international agreement banning the most dangerous chemical weapons.

Mayor Beame has asked Governor Carey to get permission from the Federal Government to call off an "onerous" court-ordered parking ban in midtown Manhattan. A spokesman for the Governor said the Mayor's letter was "being studied."

WASHINGTON, July 7 Fundamental changes in the way that Americans communicate are forcing the Federal Government to make policy decisions that could alter the fortunes of the nation's largest communication organizations and the lives of most citizens.
The fourth and final suspect in the kidnapping and murder of the 19-yearold nephew of Mayor Steve Cappiello of Hoboken has turned himself in, the police said.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Carter Administration, which concedes that it did not expect the sharp reaction its policies evoked in the Soviet Union, believes that it is entering a crucial period that will test the United States' contention that, despite continuing problems, the two superpowers can still make progress in a number of key areas.
Some signs of erosion in retail sales appeared last month, particularly women's apparel and men's wear, according to reports issued yesterday by 15 of the country's largest retailers.

The best way to succeed in camping, is to get there before the kids do. If at all possible, stalk out a new place before you let the family loose in it. That way, you'll become aware of any local hazards, convenient rest spots for the hike and the perfect frog pond to camp near -or stay away from in mosquito season.

Charles A. Carlson Jr., who has been president of the Lukens Steel Company for the last year, was elected yesterday vice chairman of the Coatesville, Pa., company. At the same time, William E. Mullestein, chairman and chief executive officer, announced that he would retire from active company management in August 1978.

ALBANY, July 7 Negotiations on the major remaining issues of the legislative session stalled today as the Senate Republican leadership continued to hold out for a $40 million program of state aid to the 57 non-New York City counties.

The Yankees are streaking, the Catfish is winning, and Thurman keeps on catching. All was right last night with the stormy world of George Steinbrenner, Billy Martin and their firstplace ball club, which joined the Red Sox in exceeding one million in home attendance this season.

The Federal Government has taken over rent regulation at one of New York City's largest apartment developments, Lincoln Towers in Manhattan, and is prepared to authorize sharply higher rent rises in lease renewals than many of the tenants would have faced under the city rent rules, which have been superseded.
"Journey over all the universe in a map, without the expense and fatigue of traveling, without suffering the inconvenience of heat, cold, hunger and thirst," Cervantes wrote in "Don Quixote."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Siamese twin girls, joined by what doctors called "an extremely rare connection" from near the breastbone to the pelvis, were successfully separated at Children's Hospital June 23 in an operation apparently without precedent.

The main obstacle to insuring that only highly qualified persons are appointed to the office of United States Attorney was summed up recently by Attorney General Griffin Bell when he told the American Law Institute: "The law places the nomination responsibility and power with the President. The power to advise and consent rests with the Senate. In practice, however, the Senate proposes and the President advises and consents."

There may well be a special emotional flavor to tonight's opening concert of the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass, Leonard Bernstein, who will lead the Boston Symphony, soloists and chorus in Bach's Magnificat and Haydn's "Lord Nelson" Mass, is dedicating the evening to the memory of Serge Koussevitsky a conductor whose long association with the symphony, its summer home at Tanglewood and Mr. Bernstein as well has already become something of a Berkshire legend.

EDISON, July 7 Officials of the Federal Environmental Protection Administration today enlisted the aid of Representative Edwin B. Forsythe in their fight with the Army to retain a Huey helicopter for use in beach and coastal waters surveillance programs.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Juy 7 Pakistan's new military rulers announced some key appointments today as they moved to restore a national confidence shaken by the turmoil of recent months.
LAUTERBRUNNEN, Switzerland, July 7 (AP) An American fell 600 feet to his death while trying to scale the western face of 13,036-foot Mount Eiger in the Bernese Alps.

WASHINGTON, July 7 In rulings with consequences for thousands, perhaps millions, of women, the Supreme Court in its 1976-77 term handed down decisions counter to the thrust of women's rights advocates on critical matters ranging from abortion to seniority. The rulings will especially affect prospects of women in the job market, making it harder both to get jobs and to keep them.

Reversing an earlier appellate ruling, a Federal appeals court has decided that the Federal Power Commission lacks the authority to help pay legal fees incurred by conservationists or other parties who intervene in proceedings before the regulatorty agency.

ON A SUNNY day, the New Yorker, yearning to escape the city's immensity, will find a glimpse of another era waiting just a short drive north to the tiny riverfront village of Piermont, in Rockland County.

Admiral Stansfield Turner, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is reliably reported to be proceeding at flank speed with his efforts to persuade Congress to create a "czar" with direct control over the entire intelligence community, including agencies now a part of the Defense and State Departments.

Janet Alexander Witter, a naturalist and photographer who made her home in San Anselmo, Calif., died Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital. Mrs. Witter, the wife of Wendell W. Witter, a retired investment banker, and the widow of Henry Clay Alexander, who was chairman of the board of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, was 67 years old.

NEW BRUNSWICK, July 7 The Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, which has probed the political awareness of New Jerseyans for several years, is now attempting to hold a mirror up to the many other facets of life in the state.

A consultant's report commissioned by Mayor Beame's special panel on city finances recently recommended the sale or leasing of all the city's public hospitals a highly controversial step but the mayoral panel went out of business last week without adopting the recommendation.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Carter Administration, in its first comprehensive study of global power relationships, has found the United States and Soviet Union in rough strategic balance and sees future trends as more favorable and less ominous than the Ford Administration thought.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Carter Administration, which concedes that it did not expect the sharp reaction its policies evoked in the Soviet Union, believes that it is entering a crucial period that will test the United States contention that, despite continuing problems, the two superpowers can still make progress in a number of key areas.

Gerald Sprayregen, a New York businessman, was indicted yesterday for allegedly carrying out a scheme to misappropriate more than $2 million from a now-bankrupt company that operated 200 John's Bargain Stores.

JOHANNESBURG, July 7 South African laws that forbid sex and marriage between whites and blacks have become a source of division within the Government, with senior officials clashing publicly over calls for their repeal.

THE MUSEUMS are serving summer fare again, collations consisting mainly of salads with little meat and no potatoes. Salads can be refreshing, of course, and if you don't expect a full-scale meal, you'll enjoy "Childe Hassam as Printmaker: A Selection in Various Media,' on view (through Sept. 11) in the delightfully air-conditioned prints and drawings gallery of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Rear Adm. Robert R.M. Emmet, who helped plan the logistics for the invasion of North Africa in World War II, died Wednesday at the Keesler Air Force Base Medical Center, Biloxi, Miss. He was 89 years old and a resident of Miami Beach.

The Federal Government has directed Mayor Beame to dissolve the Council Against Poverty and to take over the functions of the agency, which is responsible for coordinating the city's antipoverty program. The Government has threatened to cut off all support to the entire $39 million program.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 7 Despite the disappearance of his designating petitions with 14,000 signatures, Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes today submitted what appeared to be the requisite number of signatures to qualify as a candidate for Nassau County Executive.

ANCHORAGE, July 7 (AP) Oil resumed moving through the trans-Alaska pipeline today, about 64 hours after a section of pipe broke Monday and forced a shutdown of the 800-mile line. The mishandling of frigid liquid nitrogen apparently caused the break in an L-shaped section of pipe, according to sources at the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company.

Environmentalists' jubilation over the accession of the environmentally minded Carter Administration is now being matched by their dismay over proposals of the President's reorganization team to downgrade the Council on Environmental Quality.

ABANO TERME, Italy, July 7 (AP) A reporter for the Venice newspaper Gazzettino was shot and wounded in the legs today in the fourth such attack on an Italian journalist in two months, the police reported.

TRENTON, July 7 Startled by an unexpected migration of gypsy moths from northern Pennsylvania, the State Department of Agriculture is about to canvass 60 to 80 municipalities in New Jersey to determine whether they want to take part in a spraying program next spring to protect their trees.

DES MOINES, July 7 (AP) Federally chartered out-of-state banks can legally charge their Iowa BankAmericard customers higher interest rates than state law allows, Polk County District Court Judge Harry Perkins has ruled.

ONE WAY to celebrate the 90th birthday of Marc Chagall (yesterday) if you're so minded, is to drop into the Little Carnegie Theater (57th Street off Seventh Avenue) and see "Homage to Chagall: The Colours of Love," a feature-length film about the maestro, written, pro duced and directed by Harry Rasky.
Luck beat the odds at Belmont Park yesterday, 7/7/77, when three horses carrying the number seven made it to the winner's circle.
The first man shot in last Monday's 10-hour bus hijacking said yesterday that he had no desire for revenge and that he hoped nothing in the incident would serve to "spread hatred."
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 The Mets tonight reached some depths reminiscent of their hapless beginnings in the early 1960's as they lost again to the Phillies, 6-4, for their eighth straight defeat.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Carter Administration is getting "excellent vibrations", about Governor Byrne's re-election chances, and the President may go into Jersey to help him, New Jersey's Democratic state chairman, Richard J. Coffee, said today after a series of White House meetings.
The nation's basic money supply-made up of currency and checking account balances-rose a modest $100 million in the week ended June 29, the Federal Reserve reported yestrday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Clark Equipment Company has uncovered questionable payments totaling $301,375 in addition to the $85,000 it reported last summer, according to a company filing made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Ludwig Kaphan, a retired high school principal, died Wednesday at his St. Petersburg, Fla. home. He was 90 years old.

CAIRO, July 7 Members of an underground organization of religious extremists who killed a former cabinet minister Monday and set off two explosive charges in public places last night, proclaimed a "campaign of terror" today against the Government and against President Anwar el-Sadat.

In an opinion that some prosecutors said would hamper their investigations into white-collar crime, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a grand jury could not compel a witness to surrender possession of business records to a prosecutor.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Defense Department plans to deploy in Europe within the next 18 months the so-called neutron bomb, a tactical nuclear weapon designed to kill enemy troops with radiation, if Congress and President Carter give their approval for production of the device.

MOBILE, Ala., July 7 (AP) Shiriff Tom Purvis, cheered as he entered a Federal courtroom, pleaded not guilty along with nine of his officers today on charges of plotting the "ambush slaying" of an inmate shot down in a jail escape. Trial for the 10 was set for Sept. 12.

PARIS ANY JOURNEY across Europe for an American balletgoer is bound to be a rediscovery of George Balanchine, or at the least a fresh realization of Mr. Balanchine's commanding influence on European dance. His ballets are everywhere.

In the January 22, 1975 edition of The New York Times, an article appeared dealing with Bernard Bergman, a nursing home operator, and his appearance before a Senate subcommittee. The article noted, among other things, that Mr. Bergman was represented by Nathan Lewin a Washington attorney.

CANAPLES, France When Jean Gaffet inherited his 120-acre farm almost a generation ago, he cast a cold, hard look at his holdings "the land, some animals, a tractor and that was about it" and decided he would have to reorganize things drastically if he was going to carve out a better living than his parents had.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 7 The talk among horsemen at the Meadowlands this week has been "the sky's the limit." It came as no surprise, therefore, that post positions for next Tuesday night's $425,000 Meadowlands Pace were picked tonight from a helicopter.
BLANTYRE, Malawi, July 7 (Reuters) President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malawi has dismissed his entire Cabinet and all deputy ministers and parliamentary secretaries, the Malawi News Agency reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Britain and Guatemala confronted each other in both Central America and Washington today in their continuing dispute over the British territory of Belize, but by the end of the day their latest crisis appeared to have dissolved into an amicable cocktail party.

PARIS, July 7 (AP) Two young gunmen fired six bullets at the Mauritanian Ambassador to Paris through the back window of his chauffeur-driven car near his residence this morning and fled on foot. The 36-year-old envoy, Ahmed Ould Ghanahallah, was hit in the jaw, arm, shoulder and thigh but was reported out of danger at the American Hospital in Neuilly.

The National Semiconductor Corporation, long troubled by ccmpetitive pricing in major product lines, surprised the stock market with earnings in excess of Wall Street estimates in the final quarter of its fiscal year ended May 31.

WASHINGTON-Outside the massive gray Executive Office Building on Pennsylvania Avenue, the weather was sultry earlier this week. Salubrious conditions, by contrast, prevailed inside the ancient structure of high-ceilinged rooms that houses the hierarchy of the Office of Management and Budget.

The following dispatch, by Bernard Edinger, was submitted to the Israeli military censors, who requested under Israeli law that 166 words be deleted on the ground that they disclosed army interrogation techniques. The rest is as submitted to the censor.

DANBURY, Conn., July 7 Fire and fumes swept through a locked, overcrowded cellblock at the Federal mediumsecurity prison here early today, killing five inmates and leaving 71 others injured in a nightmare of confusion and panic. Authorities said the fire was believed to have been set deliberately.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 7 Under a steel blue sky and into a five-knot breeze, 46 yachts plowed acros the starting line today in The New York Times New York-New London Invita tional Sail Regatta, the final event in the East Coast Harbor Festival.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 7 (UPI) A cart piled high with petitions containing 97,248 signatures for Francis T. Purcell, Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead, was presented to the Nassau County Board of Elections today.

The marriage of Joyce Spence Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Levin of Great Neck, L.I, to William Cleveland Kuhn 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kuhn of Costa Mesa, Calif., took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Genevieve Henderson of the nondenominational Unity Church in New York.

THE CAPOEIRAS of Bahia, with their raw, colorful energy, will undoubtedly become familiar to larger and larger audiences in the near future. On Wednesday evening, this rhythmic group of singers and dancers appeared at the Graduate Center Mall of City University at 33 West 42d Street, as part of the Clark Center for the Performing Arts' summer festival.

TEL AVIV, July 8 A military inquest into the death of 54 Israeli servicemen in a helicopter crash found today that pilot, Capt. Moshe Witner, was responsible because he had flown dangerously low in the darkness.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 8 The Chinese fighter pilot who defected to Taiwan yesterday said today that the China he had left behind was a land of widespread discontent and disillusionment over frequent purges and political shifts.

Tolstoy notwithstanding, some families are happy, at least in recollection. Among them must be counted Willard R. Espey's immediate forbears in the village of Oysterville, Wash., of whose lives and relationships he has written this engaging soft-focus chronicle. The family's center was a rain-drenched peninsula at the southwestern corner of the state of Washington that guarded an estuary notable for its oyster beds.
WHITE PLAINS, July 8 The bright red hair of Bonnie Jean Garland was a familiar sight in front of the Yale Glee Club, as she often stood crafting the notes of the solo parts that she was given.

TEHERAN, July 8 High on the list of probleans of Americans living in Iran is the new United States tax reform law. Its provisions affecting Americans abroad have made many think twice about staying on in Iran.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The United States and the Soviet Union renewed today an agreement on scientific and technological cooperation for a second five-year period.

KUWAIT, July 8 (AP) Twelve hijackers seized a Kuwait Airlines jet today and forced it to land in this Persian Gulf sheikdom. They were reported to have insisted that six Arab ambassadors negotiate their demands, which included freedom for 300 prisoners held in various Arab countries.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The Carter Administration plans to endorse next week legislation that would provide Government subsidies to families that adopt hard-to-place children.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The price of natural gas used for home heating and cooking rose by 16 percent in the New York metropolitan area last winter, and residents of New York now pay the highest prices among major metropolitan areas in the nation, according to a new study.

HONOLULU, July 8 Hawaiian sugar industry executives, joined by officials from a union representing 9,600 cane plantation workers, have gained support of the state government and the islands' Congressional delegation for an all-out lobbying effort to avoid subsidy limitations on the 1.2 million-ton crop.

When the American Electric Power Company came to market recently with $198 million worth of common stock, the utility accomplished a notable feat on two counts. It was the largest sale of electric utility common stock ever, as well as being the biggest such sale ever made through a rights offering to stockholders.

TRENTON, July 8 One of the longest disputes over highway construction in the state's history ended today when New Jersey was granted a Federal permit to complete a section of State Route 18 in Middlesex County and to build a bridge over the Raritan River in New Brunswick.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Consumer credit expanded by $2.53 billion in May, a moderate slowdown from the preceding two months but still the thirdbiggest increase ever, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
PITTSBURGH, July 8 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that efforts to settle out of court antitrust suits filed against 29 uranium producers had not produced any meaningful proposals.

JERUSALEM Israel's ballot-box revolution is not yet wholly over. Having attracted to his rightist cause the famous Gen. Moshe Dayan, Gen. Ezer Weizman, air force star and nephew of the first President, and Gen. Ariel Sharon, former Prime Minister Rabin's gung-ho military adviser, Prime Minister Begin is now trying to solder an alliance with Gen. Yigael Yadin's Democratic Movement for Change.
SUPERIOR, Wis. "They think I set that fire," Andrew Zinmer, sounding surprised and anguished, told his mother and his lawyer from his hospital bed in Nashville the other day.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Agriculture Department raised the eligibility limits today for about 45 percent of the 5.37 million households receiving food stamps. The department also raised the monthly allotment of coupons by $2 for recipients living alone, to $52.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 8 Four of this city's seven wells have been closed because their water was found to contain suspected carcinogens, and Mayor Vincent Suozzi said the minor emergency measures, instituted yesterday, would be continued.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPA) Penthouse magazine said today that the California-based Copley newspaper group and its domestic and Latin American news service for two decades "acted as intelligence arms of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation."

Sandra Oakes Schoellkopf, daughter of Mrs. J. Frederick Schoellkopf 4th of Buffalo and the late Mr. Schoellkopf, was married yesterday to David Plowden, son of Mrs. Roger Stanley Plowden of New York and Putney, Vt., and the late Mr. Plowden.
The former general counsel of Gulf and Western Industries Inc. has appealed his sentence for check forgery and will remain out of prison until at least next fall.

LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) A 10-nation Commonwealth working group to examine ways of tightening sanctions against Rhodesia, particularly in the supply of oil and petroleum products, was set up today, the Commonwealth secretariat announced.
WASHINGTON, July 8 It's pretty obvious now that Otis Pike could never become a member of Jimmy Carter's "kitchen cabinet."

CHICAGO, July 8 A three-judge appellate court panel promised today to rule quickly, possibly as soon as Monday, on whether to lift a ban on a Nazi march through the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie.

FULL BLOOM SoHo, with several estimable jazz lairs, now has itself a real beauty in the restaurant, bar and music niche called W.P.A. This is a classy, comfortable place, where everything works, including a cavalcade of jazz musicians by the baby grand at the front window.

LONDON, July 8 The spectators at Wimbledon, who had been polite and customarily quiet for nearly two weeks, hollered and stomped like a football crowd at Ole Miss when Virginia Wade won the women's singles tennis championship last week.

New York City's Fire Commissioner acknowledged yesterday that the Fire Department had screened and then declined to respond to more than a thousand street alarms in Brooklyn during more than 24 hours over the three-day Fourth of July weekend.

SCARSDALE, July 8 A 20-year-old Yale senior, the daughter of a Manhattan lawyer, was fatally bludgeoned with a claw hammer in a bedroom in her family's sprawling Tudor home early yesterday. A young man described as her boyfriend, a Yale graduate who had been staying at her home and who was depicted as an outstanding student and an "all-American boy," surrendered later to an upstate priest and confessed, the authorities said.
Does anyone want to buy a church? If so, the Village Presbyterian at 139-145 West 13th Street can be had for a mere $750,000.

MOSCOW, July 8 Leonid I. Brezhnev advised foreign ambassadors today to report Soviet policies to their governments "Objectively" so as to create an atmosphere of good will. While he criticized no ambassador of country by name, Soviet broadcasts during the day Sharply stepped up their attacks on the United States.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 8 Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, called today for a reopening of the 277,000-member union's contract in an apparent attempt to force the Bituminous Coal Operators Association to agree to a reallocation of money within the union's Health and Retirement Fund. He said that a reallocation would allow the fund to rescind major cutbacks in miner medical benefits.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 8 With his new petitions for the Nassau County Executive race properly submitted, Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes continued to fight on two fronts today for the acceptance of copies of his original petitions, which mysteriously disappeared from the Democratic campaign headquarters.
Dr. Barbara J. Logan, a specialist in gynecology and obstetrics, died yesterday at her Manhattan home. She was 62 years and lived at 1080 Fifth Avenue.
TRENTON, July 8 The possibility loomed today that last year's major rivals` for the Presidency would be involved in another campaign this fall the New Jersey Governorship election.

Only two prisoners remained on strike at Green Maven Correctional Facility at Stormville, N.Y. The strike, which involved a third of the 1,800 inmates, according to officials, collapsed after strikers were confined to their cells Thursday afternoon and 40 of the alleged leaders of the action were transferred.

NICE, France, July 8 Marc Chagall, the most renowned living painter, celebrated his 90th birthday here last night at a concert sponsored by the French Government and played by some of the world's leading musicians.
QUEBEC, July 8 (UPI) The government of Quebec withdrew today language legislation that English-speaking Quebecers say was designed to suppress the uese and teaching of English in the province.

MOSCOW, July 8 The accession of Leonid I. Brezhnev to the presidency last month has confirmed the Communist Party chief as the most powerful man in the Soviet Union, but it has thrown almost no light on the persistent question of who will one day succeed him. Indeed, the move may have complicated the problem of succession since it consolidates the party and government leadership in a way that could be increasingly difficult to disentangle.

DANBURY, Conn., July 8 Three separate agencies conducted inquiries today in an effort to sort out conflicting reports on the cause of the fire that killed five prisoners Thursday morning at the Federal prison here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 (UPI) Albania has sharply criticized its ally, China, warning that closer ties with the United States are a mistake and lecturing Peking on Marxism-Leninism.

ALBANY, July 8 Legislative leaders and Governor Carey announced agreement this evening on a measure giving economic incentives to businesses, raising unemployment and disability benefits and mandating disability payments to pregnant workers.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI) The California Air Resources Board has banned the gasoline additive MMT on the ground that it damages automobile anti-smog devices and endangers health. California is the first state to do so.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, carrying buzz saws, sledgehammers, crowbars and search warrants, entered offices of the Church of Scientology here and in Los Angeles this morning in an attempt to recover hundreds of documents allegedly stolen by church operatives from Government files.

Ambassadors in Moscow were advised by Leonid I. Brezhnev to report Soviet policies to their governments "objectively" so that an atmosphere of good will might be established. He criticized no ambassador or country by name, but Soviet broadcasts sharply stepped up their attacks on the United States. Mr. Brezhnev appeared in robust health as he spoke at a Kremlin reception at which the Moscow diplomatic corps presented congratulations on his recent accession to the Presidency.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to reopen on July 25 the trial challenging segregation at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens and to widen its scope to include evidence that communities in Nassau County were responsible for the segregation.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The Treasury Department said today that it would take the first legal action ever to recover Federal revenue-sharing funds from a North Carolina town that refused to provide water service to a black family.
Larry O'Brien, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, came to the support of the Knicks yesterday regarding the Nets' contention that exclusive territorial rights are illegal.

The Inmont Corporation, up to now vigorously battling a $200 million takeover by Esmark Inc. as "inadequate," has agreed to discuss the possibility of a merger between the two companies, Esmark disclosed yesterday in Chicago.

Mr. Ellison, a novelist and essayist, is Albert Schweitzer Professor of the Humanities at New York University.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 8 The Curtis Publishing Company has sold Holiday magazine to Sheldon Shane, a Floral Park, L.I., publisher of another established travel magazine called Travel.

A renewed appeal to the public for help in capturing the "Son of Sam" was made yesterday by Mayor Beame, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd, the city's chief of detectives, the District Attorneys of Queens and the Bronx, the Borough President of Queens and other high city officials at a news conference in a police station in Flushing, Queens.

ATHENS, July 8 The failure of Bulent Ecevit and his Social Democrats to form a new government in Turkey could seriously hamper efforts to settle the problem of Cyprus, according to analysts throughout this region.

ALBANY, July 8 Legislative leaders and Governor Carey announced agreement this evening on a measure giving economic incentives to businesses, raising unemployment and disability benefits and mandating disability payments to pregnant workers.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The head of the Small Business Administration, acknowledging that whites have profited from a Government program designed to help blacks begin in business, today ordered a temporary halt in the program.

SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, July 9 (AP) Heavy rains caused floods and landslides that have taken at least 111 lives in an around the South Korean capital, the police reported today. Seventy-three people were reported missing.
BEIRUT, July 8 Palestinian guerrillas have reportedly scored gains in fighting with Lebanese Christian forces in southern Lebanon.

Wall Street's bag of worries outweighed positive news on the wholesale price front yesterday to send the Dow Jones industrial average slightly lower. But natural gas stocks boomed in a bull market all their own.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Although the number of Americans with jobs increased for the eighth straight month in June, the unemployment rate edged upward to 7.1 percent of the labor force from 6.9 percent for May, the Government reported today.

WHITLEY CITY, Ky., July 8(AP) About 300 miners, relatives, union-officers and sympathizers gathered today on a picnic ground to hear United Mine Workers officials promise victory in a strike that has lasted almost a year. The U.M.W, presented a check for $5,000 to the 153 striking miners.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Kidder, Peabody Company, a major New York securities firm, with negligently underwriting two securities issues it had not thoroughly investigated.

Empress Farah of Iran, continuing her New York round of accepting awards and honors, told an interviewer yesterday that most of the demonstrators who had been plaguing her public appearances were not really Iranians. The protesters include groups opposed to the Iranian monarchy and to the reforms begun by the Shah, the Empress said.

LYNDHURST, July 10 Firefighting forces in 13 communities abutting the Hackensack Meadowlands have appealed to Bergen County and state officials for help in combating fires that start in the gaseous marshland.

ATHENS, July 10 (UPI) An eastern Mediterranean heat wave today boosted temperatures to the highest levels ever recorded in Greece and caused hospitalization of several people in Turkey. One tourist died of sunstroke in Crete.

TRENTON, N.J., July 10 Freehold Raceway, a 128-year-old daytime harness track, would be included in New Jersey's plan to purchase some of the state's race tracks, reports indicated today. DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 (Reuters) Arab hijackers who had commandeered a Kuwaiti airliner, then forced it to fly to Damascus after hours of negotiations on the ground at Kuwait's airport, surrendered today to Syrian authorities.
