SPANISH LOOKOUT, Belize, July 10 Not far from a British Army outpost, established near the Guatemalan border to protect this former British colony from invasion, gently rolling fields of grain and shoulder-high corn grow thickly on the edge of the jungle.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The National Science Foundation has awarded $762,750 in grants to 16 colleges and universities to plan centers to help g more members of disadvantaged minority groups get advanced science education.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 10 (Reuters) At least two people were killed and 53 wounded when a bomb explosion rocked the center of Damascus today.

TUXEDO, N.Y. The roses are blooming at Sterling Forest Gardens. The huge bronze "Time and Fates" sundial near the center of the 60 acres of lawn, flower beds and interconnecting ponds tells the time. It is peace and beauty in this isolated enclave in southeastern Orange County. There is only one big difference this year. There are no people.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 10 (AP) Fred Dixon regained the lead by winning the javelin, then withstood a challenge by John Warkentin in the 1,500meter run to win the Amateur Athletic Union national decathalon championship today by 6 points.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 (AP) Four Thai soldiers and a villager were shot and seriously wounded during a three-hour clash with Cambodian troops in eastern Thailand, the border police headquarters in Bangkok said today.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 10 The Can-Am series (1966-1974) did not rest in peace. This motor racing series, looking suspiciously like the Formula 5000 series that died last year, returned to the Glen today, and lots of spectators left early.
STOCKHOLM, July 10 (AP) The Swedish Government is considering making an apology to the film director Ingmar Bergman, who left the country after a tax dispute, a Government spokesman says.
LOVELLS, Mich., July 10 The Kirtland's warbler, whose world population totaled only 400 last year, may be pulling back from the brink of extinction.

PRINCETON, N.J. The central issues in Regents of California v. Bakke have been discussed widely, and recently were argued in this newspaper. One pertinent consideration though has been overlooked, and deserves a sort of a footnote maybe more. It concerns the element of uncertainty (chance, measurement error) in selecting strong applicants for post-graduate study.
Norman Paris, the arranger and pianist, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He had been hospitalized about a week, suffering from diabetes and a heart ailment. He was 51 years old.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 10 Taiwan's ties with Saudi Arabia have become increasingly important at a time when the Carter Administration appears to be moving closer toward switching its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Peking.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 (AP) Narong Kittikachorn, the son of former Prime Minister Thanom Kittikachorn and one of three leaders exiled when Mr. Thanom's Government fell in 1973, returned to Thailand today, an airline spokesman said.

Daytime television is geared to accompany the woman 18 years or older with situation comedies and game shows as she performs her morning household chores and then, according to a major advertising agency, to sit her down for concentrated viewing of the afternoon soap operas.
The Hollywood-versus-New York battle within the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is over. Henceforth, there will be two organizations and two sets of Emmy awards.

Tim Weaver, a former Fordham University runner, won the third annual Steve Prefontaine Memorial Run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The 23-year-old winner, who also triumphed in the two other Prefontaine races, covered the 5,000-meter course in 15 minutes 22.9 seconds, finishing 85 yards ahead of Victor Idava of the Philippines, who was second in the field of 280 starters.
In their fifth appearance on national television, yesterday and their fifth without a victory the Cosmos proved again that well-known names don't win games in the North American Soccer League.
HONOLULU, July 10 (AP) Merlin and Drifter were engaged in a close duel as they headed for the finish line today, and the victor was assured of breaking the record in the trans-Pacific yacht race.
TOKYO, July 10 (UPI) More than 1,300 people who ate box lunches today at a trade fair in Osaka, Japan's second largest city, were stricken with food poisoning.
American chess is finally pulling out of its post-Bobby Fischer depression. Recovery appears imminent.

There he was the young writer fighting the gentlemen's agreement that fosters anti-Semitism, the man in the gray flannel suit, the earnest lawyer of the to-kill-a-mockingbird case, the Captain Ahab of "Moby Dick" Gregory Peck, himself.
ALBANY New York State is asking hunters, fishermen and hikers to turn in poachers and any colleagues who break the rules.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 10 Realtors here say that unrealistically high asking prices for property may be holding down a real-estate boom in this resort city.

Helen Finegold, chairman of the music department at Hunter College High School, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Franklin Friedman, a vice president and investment officer with the Dreyfus Corporation. The ceremony was performed at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., by Rabbi Martin Rosenberg. He was assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron.
HELSINKI, Finland, Monday, July 11 A Soviet airliner carrying 72 people on a domestic flight was hijacked last night by two men, armed with grenades and pistols, who forced it to land at Helsinki.

As children, television directors are taught that if they permit viewers a glimpse of a golfer walking between shots in a tournament or studying his lie or committing harakiri by falling on his putter, they will surely go to hell. In screen credits shown by American Broadcasting Companies after its coverage of that extraordinary final round in the British Open championship, Chuck Howard was identified as producer and Jim Jennett as director.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 10 (Reuters) British and American representatives conferred today with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and sources familiar with the situation said that efforts toward a peaceful transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia had made considerable progress.

The special state prosecutor, John F. Keenan, has been looking into allegations that criminals in New York City's jails have received special privileges. The charges, which were first made in 1972, were inherited by Mr. Keenan when he succeeded Maurice H. Nadjari as special prosecutor a year ago.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 10 The money changed hands freely yesterday as crowds of buyers bid on the faded furniture that once gave the Claridge Hotel its glamour and grace.

Candace Brown Lerman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel L. Lerman of Springfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Lerman, was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Howard Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cohen of Huntington Station, L.I.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 10 Realtors here say that unrealistically high asking prices for property may be holding down a real-estate boom in this resort city.
A dramatic plunge in soybeans dominated the commodity markets last week. The July contract fell a total of $1.32 a bushel in five trading sessions on the Chicago Board of Trade.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. Proposed legislation on a revised national security wiretap bill, enthusiastically supported by the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the military, would require the Government to obtain judicial warrants before tapping the phones or bugging the premises of foreign powers or foreign agents.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF BARENTU, Ethiopia After nearly 16 years of fighting, the war for independence in Eritrea has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a major offensive by Ethiopian troops.

CAIRO, July 10 The ritual murder of a respected Moslem dignitary and onetime Cabinet minister and the explosion of a few dynamite sticks in public places have jolted Egyptians, who thought that urban terrorism was the monopoly of young revolutionaries in Western societies the Weathermen in the United States, the Baader-Meinhof gang in West Germany, the urban guerrillas in Argentina and ultraleftist students in Italy.

The owners of the Crossroads pornographic bookstore and peep show at 42d Street and Broadway converted in May into a travelers' information center operated by the police after a transaction in which the owners were bought out for $81,000 are reported planning to resume business less than a block from their old location.

TOKYO, Monday, July 11 Japan's ruling Liberal-Democratic Party, which has dominated politics in this island nation since 1955, appeared on the verge here today of losing its control of the upper house of Parliament.

DICKINSON, Tex., July 10 Despite fresh warnings from the Vatican, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre continued his open defiance of Pope Paul VI today by consecrating a Roman Catholic chapel here and celebrating an unauthorized mass in Latin.
CHICAGO, July 10 Chicago police commanders, supervisors and patrolmen will begin training tomorrow in the handling of civil disorders, according to department officials.

ALET, Ethiopia The border crossing into Eritrea, from the point of view of formalities, is the easiest in Africa. There are no visa forms, no customs declarations, and, on showing of one's passport, only a grunt from a Sudanese policeman who waves a flashight beam into the cab of a Land-Rover.

WASHINGTON, July 10 A survey of the House of Representatives by the House ethics committee has turned up a pattern of South Korean favors for senior House members that was more extensive than had been reported, according to Congressional sources.

Astronomers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics believe that, through X-ray observations from space, they have found a "significant fraction" of the mass needed to reverse expansion of the universe before it becomes infinitely dispersed.
ROCHESTER, July 10 (AP) Pat Bradley shot a three-under-par 70 today and won a $75,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament with a 54-hole total of 213.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, July 10 The Lucerne International rowing regatta concluded today with more surprises than had been anticipated. What had been heralded as a "battle of the giants," between the Soviet Union and East Germany turned into a one-sided affair for the East Germans.

About 500 black residents of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn demonstrated peacefully in front of the 71st Precinct station house on Empire Boulevard Saturday to protest alleged brutality by an Orthodox Jewish civilian anticrime patrol in the area.

Here is Louis Auchincloss's 27th book at least, his 20th work of fiction, his 12th novel. And like the pen that keeps turning them out while its energetic master sustains a full-time law career, helps raise a family, presides over the Museum of the City of New York, and does God knows what else the plot of "The Dark Lady" goes lickety-split.

When Trude Heller opened the club bearing her name at Ninth Street and Avenue of the Americas 20 years ago, the first performer to appear there was Morgana King. To celebrate a mutual anniversary, Miss King returned to Trude Heller's last week and will be there for two more weeks.

MOSCOW, July 10 The Soviet press warned today that every new United States weapons development would be matched in kind and it charged that Washington had embarked on an "old, bankrupt policy of imperialism."
Loren Eiseley, anthropologist educator and author, died Saturday of cardiac arrest following a recent series of operations at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 69 years old.
NORWOOD, July 9 Representative Harold C. Hollenbeck, Republican of Bergen County, broke ground today for the first private solar-heated home development in the state.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 Tim Gullikson, a 25-year-old tennis player striving to become a somebody on the pro circuit, won the Hall of Fame tournament today on the center court of the Casino.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF BARENTU, Ethiopia After nearly 16 years of fighting, the war for independence in Eritrea has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a major offensive by Ethiopian troops.

Eritrea's 16-year-old fight for independence from Ethiopia has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a major Ethiopian offensive. The rebels have grown far beyond the roving bands of guerrilla fighters who harassed Ethiopian soldiers a decade ago. They have formed a full-fledged, highly trained army of 700 strong battalions, according to the first of three articles. [Page 1, Columns 1-3.]
A 25-year-old fireman, Martin Celic, died early yesterday of injuries he suffered July 2 fighting a fire on the lower East Side that marshals have said was a result of arson.
COAL VALLEY, Ill., July 10 (AP) Mike Morley overtook Victor Regalado with four straight birdies today and won the $125,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament by 2 strokes with a 17-under par 267.
If the hectic pace of the first six months is any guide, 1977 may well go down as the year of the dividend.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 10 The Iranian Government is working out emergency plans to deal with Iran's serious shortage of electric power before it drags down this oil nation's ambitious development program.
Eighty-three children died last year in New York City "as a result of parental abuse," officials reported yesterday, warning that child abuse has become "an alarming problem."
"Of course, I am dead, but ..." is a frequent introduction by the Argentine grandmaster Oscar Panno to one of his numerous escapes.

BALTIMORE, July 10 In the space of 18 hours in this heat-struck city, the Yankees showed everyone why they weren't ready to start a streak that would turn the American League's Eastern Division race into a one-team attraction.
LONDON, July 10 Punk rock, the socio-musical phenomenon that is now spreading in the United States, seems to be in trouble in the land of its birth.
When you're hot, you're hot. The Mets won again yesterday, beating the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium, 2-1.

The owners of the Crossroads pornographic bookstore and peep show at 42d Street and Broadway converted in May into a travelers' information center operated by the police after a transaction in which the owners were bought out for $81,000 are reported planning to resume business less than a block from their old location.

Last Friday, after winning four games from the Pittsburgh Pirates and then four from the New York Mets, the Philadelphia Phillies seemed ready to put some pressure on the Chicago Cubs, the season-long leaders of the National League's Eastern Division.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 10 (AP) Bernard King, the Nets' first draft pick and a former University of Tennessee basketball star, was arrested early today on charges of breaking into a campus athletics building and stealing a television set, the police said. A July 19 trial date in General Sessions Court was set after King was released from Knox County jail on $5,000 bond.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., July 10 The Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia upset the Potomac and Vesper Boat Clubs in the elite eight-oared final of the national rowing championships on the Cooper River today. The Penn crew, under Coach Dietrich Rose boated four members of the 1976 Olympic team and overtook the leading Potomac shell in the last 500 meters, crossing the line with a half-length victory in 6 minutes 32.1 seconds against a strong headwind.

CONCORD, N.H., July 10 (AP) After calling the New Hampshire legislature back in special session to pass a budget, Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. now says he may veto the only budget that the lawmakers have seriously considered.
The shareholders of Needham, Harper Steers voted on Friday in Chicago to go private, with the outside owners getting $13.50 for each share of common stock.

"You Light Up My Life," a feature film about the world of pop music, written, produced and directed in New York by Joseph Brooks, has been acquired for distribution in the United States and Canada by Columbia Pictures.

PEKING, July 10 (Reuters) A European Common Market team leaves tomorrow after six days of exploratory talks that apparently have cleared the way for negotiations on a trade agreement with China, delegation sources said today.

Carol Rinzler, writer and editor, enrolls in law school. Rosemary Masters, already a lawyer, begins studying for a degree in social work. Margaret Lewin, former aerospace engineer, decides to be a doctor. Carol Reich turns from interior design to child psychology.

WASHINGTON, July 10 A survey of the House of Representatives by the House ethics committee has turned up a pattern of South Korean favors for senior House members that was more extensive than had been reported, according to Congressional sources.

James George Schaefer, a former president of Private Brands, a subsidiary of the Uniroyal Tire Company, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., after a heart attack. He was 73 years old and a resident of Bronxville, for 40 years.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 10 A long, slow day of golf on Winged Foot's West Coast ended with the perfect execution of a most difficult and delicate shot as Marty West and Gerald P. Nye Jr. beat Peter Van Ingen and Stephen Smith, 6 and 5, in the final of the 41st annual John G. Anderson memorial four-ball tournament.
A Government suit brought last week in a Federal court its Hartford involv ing the fight by United Technologies to obtain control of Babcock Wilcox raises imponderables for investors.

ATLANTA, July 10 Although the Ku Klux Klan, or, more accurately, the Ku Klux Klans, since there are more than a dozen generally competitive groups, has become highly visible after a decade of obscurity, there is no hard evidence that its membership or influence is significantly expanding.
Laker Airways, which plans to institute a no-frills $135 bargain fare to London this fall, is running into tough competition tougher perhaps than it originally bargained for.

ALBANY, July 10 A platform supporting the Equal Rights Amendment and the right of women to choose legal abortion was voted by participants in the first New York women's conference today in the concluding sessions of the three-day conference here, one of 56 such meetings mandated by Congress in connection with the International Women's Decade.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 10 Balbuco defeated 15 rivals in a jumpoff to win the Adirondack Grand Prix today at the concluding session of the six-day Lake Placid horse show.

WASHINGTON "Nissms," they used to be called, from the acronym for National Security Study Memorandum. These detailed analyses sometimes led to historic changes in policy, in the Nixon Administration, NSSM-1 was a reassessment of policy toward China.

The exotic sounds of spoken Armenian have been spreading in the homey sidestreets of Sunnyside, Queens. ArmenianAmerican scholars have been turning to the riches of Armenian literature at Columbia University. Armenian folk-dance rhythms have been pulsing in a Manhattan meeting hall.
Thora Kathryn O'Keefe and Matthew Ivan Zale were married yesterday afternoon by Criminal Court Judge Jerome Vale at the St. Regis Roof.
LISBON After one year in power together, President Antonio Ramalho Eanes, an unsmiling soldier, and Prime Minister Mario Soares, an ebullient Socialist, have brought a stagnant stability to Portugal.
American chess is finally pulling out of its post-Bobby Fischer depression. Recovery appears imminent.

JOHANNESBURG Two Years after they left Broadway with Tony awards as the best actors of the 1974-75 season, John Kani and Winston Ntshona are back on the South African stage, performing in the legal twilight zone reserved for black actors, particularly those who use their talents to mock the country's racial laws.

WASHINGTON, July 10 President Carter has decided against attempting to sell some of the new Alaska pipeline oil to Japan in exchange for oil more readily available to the East Coast and the Middle West.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 10 (AP) Nearly four years after the military assumed power, President Augusto Pinochet has announced plans for a slow return to civilian rule under which Chileans would not be likely to vote before 1985.

TRENTON, July 10 (AP) The Legislature returns to Trenton tomorrow with a list of 97 bills waiting for action, but most attention will be focused on Governor Byrne and his expected appointments to the Casino Control Commission.

CAIRO, July 10 (UPI) President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan agreed today to assure a Palestinian role in Middle East peace talks by an "explicit link" between Jordan and the guerrillas, Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy said.

Eritrea's 16-year-old fight for independence from Ethiopia has reached a decisive stage, with rebel forces braced to meet a major Ethiopian offensive. A New Jersey expert emerged from retirement to win the open pair championship at the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Manhattan Saturday. Alan Messer of Upper Montclair, N.J., who once made headlines for calling Pancho Gonzales for foot-faulting at Forest Hills, won the title with Ken Gorfkle of Redmond, Wash., who has recently settled in New York City.
Katherine Stinson Otero, a pioneer in American aviation, died Friday at her home in Sante Fe, N.M., after a long illness. She was 86 years old.

ALBANY-Clifford E. Wilson, who ceases being a freshman legislator any day now, has acquired some scars in the course of his maiden session, and he has already decided that his polit-. ical future does not lie in the Assembly.

More rain late Friday and yesterday over the Middle Western growing areas apparently induced heavy selling of soybean contracts yesterday. The price of the old-crop deliveries of July and August plunged the daily 30-cents-a-bushel limit on the Chicago, Board of Trade.

Now that the Municipal Assistance Corporation has called some of the 10year, 8 percent bonds issued in late 1975 in exchange for New York City notes, holders of the called bonds are wondering how to treat the so-called original-issue discount on their tax returns.

HELSINKI, Finland, Tuesday, July 12 (AP) The last three hostages aboard a hijacked Soviet airliner slipped away from their captors early today, and a few hours later the two hijackers surrendered to Finnish authorities.

OAKLAND, Calif. July 11 Attorneys for the three men accused of kidnapping 26 school children and their school bus driver in the central California town of Chowchilla a year ago this week said today at a pretrial hearing that they would fight to suppress 4,800 items of prosecution evidence.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Despite the good news of the June drop in wholesale prices, the Carter Administration apparently has yet to come to grips with breaking a deeply entrenched price-wage spiral that has been running 6 to 7 percent a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 Football is "a form of legalized combat" said Willie L. Brown Jr., lawyer for George Atkinson of the Oakland Raiders, whose suit for slander against the Pittsburgh Steelers and Coach Chuck Noll began today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 The Carter Administration confirmed today that it would support legislation designed to insure that more of America's oil imports are carried in American-flag tankers. The decision is intended to benefit the United States merchant marine and the maritime unions, both of which have been suffering from foreign competition.
Prices in the nation's key credit markets edged downward slightly in extremely quiet trading, dealers reported yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I, July 11 In an effort to make the Nassau County Police Department "more representative of the community it serves," Commissioner Daniel P. Guido announced today a drive to recruit minority-group members and women to police work.

STOCKHOLM, July 11 Ministers of the recently reunited Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were assembling here tonight for their semiannual meeting at a time when the industrial oil-importing nations are showing more concern about the cartel's future power than its current strength.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11 (Reuters) President Fidel Castro says he will never agree to withdraw Cuban troops from Angola as a condition for Washington's lifting its blockade of his country or resuming diplomatic relations with Havana.

BRUSSELS, July 11 (AP) Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's trade negotiator, laid down a timetable with Common Market leaders today for worldwide trade negotiations and said he hoped they would be concluded by spring with an agreement that would last a decade.

Max Rheinstein, professor emeritus of comparative law at the University of Chicago, which last year named a chair for him, died Saturday in Bad Gastein, Austria, where he was vacationing. He was 78 years old and had moved to Palo Alto, Calif., last December.

The Federal Highway Administration has deducted $327 million from the estimated $1.16 billion federally aided construction cost of Westway, with the result that New York City or the state could end up having to pay part of the difference for the planned new West Side superhighway.

The Administration's acceptance of the cruise missile as a substitute for an advanced manned bomber has accelerated the Air Force and Navy development programs but failed to still doubts within the defense community over the weapon's effectiveness.

SARASOTA, Fla., July 11. (UPI) Wilfred Bannister pleaded not guilty today to charges of kidnapping 15-year-old Charlotte Grosse from a Girl Scout camp and sexually molesting her during the 52 hours before she escaped July 1.

The Natomas Company of San Francisco announced yesterday a management reorganization of its subsidiary, the American president Lines, in which Dorman L. Commons, Natomas president and chief executive officers, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the ocean-cargo carrier.
After a few losing entries in the fashion doll category, Hasbro Industries now feels it has a winner in Charlie's Angels.

Will this latest news have much impact on smokers? We are skeptical.

MOUNT VERNON, July 11 It used to be something that happened only south of the Bronx County line, but the plague of widespread arson long considered an urban phenomenon has spread in this and other Westchester County cities.

PARIS, July 11 (AP) The kidnapped head of the Fiat automobile company's operations in France and Brazil was freed today after nearly three months in captivity. A group calling itself the "Committee for Socialist Revolutionary Unity" said it had been responsible for his abduction.

HONOLULU, July 11 (UPI) The 67-foot yacht Merlin smashed the trans-Pacific yacht race record time by almost a full day yesterday, crossing the Diamond Head finish line 2,225 miles from Los Angeles in eight days. 11 hours 1 minute 46 seconds.

BASEL, Switzerland, July 11 (Reuters) Concern about sharp and rapid fluctuations in the foreign exchange market in recent weeks dominated the monthly meeting today of central bank governors, banking sources said.

David Givens, general counsel for Indiana National Bank, creditor of the team's assets, signaled the apparent demise of the Racers, who led the World Hockey Association in attendance last season.

Jerome Kurtz, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, is bemused by the furor over his proposal that corporate and wealthy taxpayers flag questionable items an their returns. All he intended, he says, is more disclosure of already public information.
John Chancellor, the leading anchorman of NBC News, has negotiated a new contract with the network and will continue to be a co-anchorman of the."NBC Nightly News," network officials said yesterday.

In a brief but caustic letter, Osborn Elliott, the city's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, has criticized the publisher of The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch, for his newspaper's coverage of last week's blackout.

GORDON HEIGHTS, L.I., July 18-- Thelma Hall was a young woman from the big city when she came out to the countryside of Long Island for the first time in 1930 and when night fell, she recalls. "I thought maybe somebody had left the steam heat on, because the crickets and animals were making so much noise."

Although a majority of the American public says it tolerates job rights for homosexuals, the same public is evenly divided over whether homosexual behavior should be legal, according to a new Gallup poll.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--Arthur Ashe, trying to play in his first tournament since undergoing heel surgery, was forced to withdraw today from singles play at the $125,000 Washington Star event. However, he will attempt to play doubles with his partner, Stan Smith.
A drop of $504 million in comercial and industrial loans by leading New York banks for the week ended last Wednesday was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A 200-ton granite sculpture by a Japanese artist for the World Trade Center was the reason for at least four trips to Japan by officials and guests of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, travel records disclose.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18--The Trans Alaska oil pipeline system, crippled and shut down since an explosion and fire on July 8, is resuming operations, but it is clear from statements of oil company executives that prospects for a West Coast oil glut disappeared amid the smoke and flames of the blast that destroyed Pump Station No.8 near Fairbanks 10 days ago.

TRENTON, July 18--The state argued in Federal District Court here today that a New Jersey law barring Medicaid payments for abortions except to "preserve the woman's life" conformed both with the United States Constitution and Federal Social Security laws.

President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France says he has decided on specific retaliatory action against the United States if a "permanent" decision is made to keep the Concorde from landing at Kennedy International Airport.
Carter Winter, a graphic designer, photographer and writer, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital of lung cancer. He was 60 years old and a resident of Manhattan.
SUMMER SOUNDS Two free music sessions today in the Washington Square area and at Lincoln Center should provide some welcome in hotweather diversion.

A relatively unnoticed business--the food-wholesaling industry--is receiving some favorable notices these days in Wall Street. Companies in this field, operating in various parts of the United States, function mainly as purchasing and warehousing agents for independent grocers, chain stores and convenience stores.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18--On hundred years after his death in South America, Henry "Honest Harry" Meiggs has been exonerated of stealing nearly half a million dollars from this city in the crash of 1854.
The Knicks took a major step yesterday toward having their territorial dispute with the Nets transferred from a Federal District Court in New Jersey to one in New York.
Citing "differences in management style and approach," the Bowery Savings Bank said yesterday that H. Clifton Whiteman had resigned "on completely amicable terms" as its president, effective Friday.

A State Supreme Court justice in Queens ruled yesterday that Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo had not offered sufficient justification for an order last year prohibiting real estate people from virtually all methods of soliciting houses for sale throughout Brooklyn and Queens.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 18--The Long Island Lighting Company asked some of its major customers to conserve energy today as its system hit a new peak for consumption. The utility did not request similar conservation measures from residential customers.

TRENTON, July 16--Joseph P. Lordi, the Essex County Prosecutor who was named by Governor Byrne to head the Casino Gambling Control Commission, said today that organized crime might already have infiltrated some businesses in Atlantic City, and that law-enforcement officials would fight "to keep them out and chase them out."

Not long ago, Prime Minister Morarji Desai of India aroused female ire around the world when he denigrated the performances of women prime ministers in Israel, India and Sri Lanka, and added that if Margaret Thatcher, the Conservative leader in Britain, ever came to power, she'd be "just as bad." The protesters' flak must have been heavy, for yesterday Mr. Desai sought to polish his male chauvinist image.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 18--Venezuela's dominant political party has chosen its secretary general as its candidate for the presidency, making him the favorite to win the election due next year.

Don Sutton, who grew up pitching "mental shutouts" in Yankee Stadium, will pitch at the Stadium for real tonight, and not even Sparky Anderson, his manager will know if Sutton has his sanopaper with him.
WASHINGTON, July 18--The House Banking Committee opened hearings today on legislation designed to make the Federal Reserve more responsive to Congress.

United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., obtained Federal court permission yesterday to continue the top executive compensation at the levels in effect prior to its filing of a voluntary bankruptcy petition last Tuesday.

Despite numerous and complex political and economic problems throughout the world, many American companies are stepping up capital-spending programs at their foreign subsidiaries and affiliates this year.

Joe Grimaldi has decided he must move to California because of a bad foot and, naturally, he notified us in his usual way, by getting down on his knees and chalk-printing on the asphalt at Church and Barclay Streets, the intersection where he daily panhandles while his red dog flops and snoozes in the shade.

Operating earnings at the BankAmerica Corporation, the San Francisco bank that is the nation's largest, advanced 18.2 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, it was reported yesterday, while income at New York's Chase Manhattan Corporation, the third largest bank holding company, declined 5.2 percent.

Just before the lights went out in New York the other evening President Carter gave us a disquisition on the innate unfairness of capitalism. The moneyed classes, he said, enjoyed many luxuries unavailable to others, but this did not oblige the Government to provide matching luxury service to the impecunious.
WASHINGTON, July 18--President Carter has quietly approved the formation of an interagency committee under the State Department to coordinate policies toward the Soviet Union.
All the Meyers at Edward M. Meyers Associates, accustomed to the long lead times and flowery language of fashion advertising, are experiencing a real change of pace.

She started smoking when she was 12 in hopes of stunting her growth. It didn't work. By the time she got out of high school she was six feet tall and smoking two packs a day. She is now 32. For 10 years, she has smoked more than three packs a day.
STEARNS, Ky., July 18 (AP)--Heavy gunfire echoed through the hills of the rugged Cumberland Mountains as miners marked the first anniversary of a strike at the Steams Coal Company's Justus mine.

New Jersey's largest electric utility said yesterday that it had been proposing for five years to increase the capacity of transmission lines linking it with Consolidated Edison in New York City, and that it was Con Edison that had so far held up the plan.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 17--The decision to broadcast the American-produced series "Roots" during the first week of local programming over the new Government-operated television station seemed, on the surface a natural choice.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 18 (UPI)-A Chinese Air Force pilot who defected to Taiwan on July 7 in his MIG-19 jet plane said today that food shortages in China were so extensive many people were near starvation and some were even giving away their children in exchange for food coupons.

With a desperate leap, Willie Mays crashed into the wall at Ebbets Field in 1952 and caught a line drive off the bat of Bobby Morgan of the Brooklyn Dodgers, then the New York Giants' center fielder crumpled into the dirt of the warning track.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. July 18 (Reuters)-Benazir Bhutto, the 24-year old daughter of the deposed Pakistani Prime Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, today began a campaign to rally her father's political supporters.

Strictly speaking, Meyer Schapiro's first volume of selected papers is for serious students of the Romanesque-- that stylistic period, so-called for its source in the buildings of the Roman Empire, that prevailed throughout Europe from the mid-11th to the mid12th centuries. WASHINGTON, July 18--Two Democratic Senators said today that the Administration's decision to sell seven advanced airborne radar warning systems to Iran would threaten United States national security.
Applications for emergency loans to owners of small businesses are being accepted by the Federal Small Business Administration at 201 Varick Street in Manhattan.
Josef Korbel, a diplomat, author and educator, died yesterday at General Rose Hospital in Denver. He was 67 years old and a resident of Denver.
WASHINGTON,July 18 (AP)--The most commonly used dry cleaning fluid causes cancer in mice and may be harmful to laundry patrons and workers, according to the National Cancer Institute.

The traditional stand of the American steel industry that it is the world's lowcost producer and is being severely injured by subsidized foreign steel operations and unfair competition, was attacked yesterday both in Japan and on Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Internal Revenue Service revoked the tax-exempt status of the $1.4 billion Central States pension fund of the teamsters' union last year because it had found wide-ranging abuses in the handling of assets and benefit payments, Congressional officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Two candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City today called for the immediate publication of a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the city's fiscal difficulties, which they said the panel had delayed in an effort to help Mayor Beame.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Representative E.G. Shuster, Republican of Pennsylvania, announced today that a move was I under way in the House to overturn the Administration's plan to require that new automobiles be equipped with air bags.

A legislator investigating overseas trips by officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that he had found that about 500 people had traveled to some 40 countries at the authority's expense over the last five years amounting, he charged, to "junketeering" and "blatant waste of public monies."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--The 14member blue-collar caucus of House members reluctantly endorsed today the new proposed Federal minimum wage of $2.65 an hour with automatic increases in the future.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Members of the New York City's congressional delegation reacted with anger, disappointment and sarcasm to the preliminary decision by the White House that New York would not qualify for emergency disaster aid.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--The nation's economy had another strong quarter, growing at about the same rate as the first quartet's 6.9 percent the Commerce Department said today.

TEL AVIV, July 18--Israel,'s newly announced anti-inflation program spurred organized labor today to its first confrontation with the Government of Prime Minister Menahem Begin since he took office last month.

The Mobil Corporation has withdrawn its financial support of a fellowship program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism because it does not like the economic views of the director of the project, the school said yesterday.
Looters who destroyed businesses all along Third Avenue in East Harlem were in for a suprpise when they attempted to hit the block between 102d and 103d Streets.
MADISON, July 18--Sixty high-school sophomores and juniors with impaired vision are spending this month at Drew University, living in dormitories on the school's 150-acre campus.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 18--The Rhodesian Parliament will be dissolved immediately and a general election will be held Aug. 31, Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced in a television broadcast tonight.

With 5,000 police officers standing at attention outside a Manhattan church, funeral services were held yesterday for Officer Edward Mitchell, who was shot to death Friday while trying to arrest a robbery suspect. The services, at the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church on Cumming Street in the Inwood section were held only a few blocks from the site of the slaying of the 34-year-old officer.

WASHINGTON, July 18--President Carter was authoritatively reported today to have chosen S. David Freeman, one of the principal designers of the Administration's energy conservation proposals, to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

GORDON HEIGHTS, L.I., July 18-- Thelma Hall was a young woman from the big city when she came out to the countryside of Long Island for the first time in 1930 and when night fell, she recalls. "I thought maybe somebody had left the steam heat on, because the crickets and animals were making so much noise."

WASHINGTON, July 18--Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he expected prosecutions as a result of the Justice Department's current investigation of South Korean influence-buying on Capitol Hill.
Col. Dudley Warren Watkins, a retired Air Force officer, died Sunday at the Buffalo Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 84 years old and a resident of Williamsville, N.Y.

Nearly a hundred Panamanian aliens in the New York City area, evidently seeking to improve their chances for citizenship, used fake diplomas and birth certificates to enlist in the Marine Corps in recent months, a corps spokesman said yesterday.
QUINCY, Mass., July 18 (AP)--Twenty-six strikers were arrested here today when pickets scuffled with the police and stopped nonunion workers from entering the General Dynamics Fore River Shipyard.

CHAMONIX, France, July 18--Dietrich Thurau, leader of the Tour de France bicycle race from its July 1 start until yesterday, rallied today to win a grueling stage through the Alps. Bernard Thevenet, the new leader, finished in the same time to maintain his 11-second margin.

E.I. duPont de Nemours Company reported a 25.8 percent gain in secondquarter earnings on a 14.6 percent increase in sales. For the first-half, net income was up 6.2 percent on an 11.4 percent sales gain.

FULLERTON, Calif., July 18--Radiating charm, sincerity and team spirit, Joe Namath joined the Los Angeles Rams in their first workout this morning, then skipped lunch to attend a news conference staged in his honor. But he shared the platform with Pat Haden, his new roommate and occupant of the quarterback position Namath hopes to win.

This is the year of serious tax reform--or so President Carter and his advisers would have us believe. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said yesterday that it was seriously concerned about the orderly liquidation of the spot green coffee futures contract that expires on July 22.
WASHINGTON, July 18--President Carter gave Congress today a series of broad proposals to make enforcement of the National Labor Relations Act "fairer, promoter and more predictable."

A combination of surging June-quarter profits and strength in computer issues sent the stock market higher with brisk gains yesterday. Advancing issues outpaced the losers by a 9-to-5 ratio on the New York Stock Exchange.

MOSCOW, July 18 (UPI)--The Kirov Ballet's new chief choreographer has reached preliminary agreement to stage a ballet by the Russian-born American choreographer George Balanchine, according to a report today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
The RCA Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 58-year history and record results for the half, according to the secondquarter statement, issued yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 18 (AP)--North Central Airlines has asked the Civil Aero-- nautics Board for authority to provide nonstop service between 11 United States cities and 20 destinations in the Caribbean, including Cuba.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 18 --Wellwood Hanover, No No Yankee and Keystone Topper led the 12 qualifiers tonight at the Meadowlands into next Monday night's $280,500 Woodrow Wilson Pace, richest 2-year-old event in harness racing history.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18--The Damascus radio confirmed today that Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization had reached agreement on a plan aimed at pacifying the southern Lebanese area where fighting has persisted between Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese right-wing Christian militiamen.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus has approved the immediate resumption of the flow of oil through the Trans-Alaska oil pipeline, shut down since a July 8 explosion and fire.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--President Carter asked his Cabinet today to investigate the possible use of a national power grid and the National Guard in the event of a blackout similar to last week's in New York.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 18 (AP)-- Most officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including those of Saudi Arabia, its most powerful member, are convinced there will be an oil price increase next year, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel said today on arrival here that he hoped his talks with President Carter in the next two days world produce progress toward "real peace" between Arabs and Israel.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 18-- Pleased with the speed in yesterday's three $300,000 Gold Rush elimination trials that produced winning sub-2minute miles in each of the heats, Monticello Raceway officials showed lots of speed in setting the stage for next Sunday's final showdown.

Eliot Fette Noyes, the industrial designer who was responsible for, among other things, the I.B.M. Selectric typewriter and the Mobil Corporation's round gas pumps, died Sunday night at his home in New Canaan, Coan. He was 66 years old.

The Metropolitan Opera yesterday warned the 14 unions with which it is trying to negotiate new contracts that the 1977-78 season would be cancelled unless agreements were reached by Sept. 9. The Metropolitan's season of 27 performance weeks is scheduled to open Oct. 10 with Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov."

During the recent Congress of the International Olympic Committee, approval was given to the concept of regionalizing future Olympic Games, whereby several cities, rather than one, would serve as major sites.

WASHINGTON, July 18--The Securities and Exchange Commission today put a brake on the booming trade in stock options by announcing that it would not approve any new or expanded options trading pending completion of a review by the commission.

MADISON, Wis., July 18 (AP)--The state and the 23,000-member Wisconsin State Employees Union reached tentative agreement on a new contract early today to end a 15-day strike. Workers began returning with the day shifts.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--The Administration today urged Congress to continue most-favored-nation trade treatment to Rumania to encourage its growing political independence and its role in reducing East-West tensions.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 19--Vietnam and Laos have concluded a series of sweeping military and economic agreements that tie Laotian development even more closely to the future of Vietnam.

NASSAU, Bahamas, July 19 (UPI)-- Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling's Progressive Labor Party rolled to a comfortable victory tonight in the Bahamas elections, the first since the nation of 700 islands won independence from Britain four years ago.

TAMMY WYNETTE, who brought her traveling show into Central Park for the Dr. Pepper Festival on Monday, is working hard to prove that she can make it on her own. For a number of years she performed principally with George Jones, now her former husband.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19--Two personal aides to the late Howard R. Hughes have been ordered by a Los Angeles probate judge to answer questions about the reclusive industrialist's use of medications and his source of supply.

WASHINGTON, July 19--"Could I have everybody's attention, please," President Carter said as members of his Cabinet took their seats around the long table.

TEL AVIV, July 19--At a desert rendezvous in the United Nations-controlled buffer zone between the ceasefire lines in Sinai today, Egypt transferred to Israel 19 coffins said to contain the bodies of soldiers killed during the war of October 1973.

The baseball world thronged Yankee Stadium last night with 56,683 persons and with all manner of celebrated New Yorkers on the field, from Pearl Bailey to Cardinal Cooke. CHICAGO, July 19 (AP)--Old-crop soybeans posted limit advances on the Chicago Board of Trade today while new-crop bean futures closed sharply higher, buoyed by forecasts for a week of mostly hot dry weather over the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, July 19--President Carter and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, opening their two-day White House meeting in an air of cordiality, agreed today to give priority to the convening of a new Geneva conference this year and the attainment of a "just and durable peace in the Middle East."

Institutional investors responded strongly yesterday to the World Bank's marketing of $750 million in notes and bonds on a day that also had the Treasury auctioning $2.5 billion of two-year notes. In secondary trading, prices of corporate and Government issues moved higher.
HUDSON, N.Y. There was bad news for pie-eaters here last week as the sour cherry harvest in New York State started. The crop was down and the price was up.

And few remedies are more effective than a sampling of the afternoon soaps. As the man says, if you think you've got troubles, bubela, get a load of the citizens inhabiting daytime drama.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--The House opened debate today on national policy for farm, programs and food stamps through 1981, with Carter Administration officials still fighting bids for higher crop price supports.

Temperatures that reached a record 102 degrees at 2 P.M. yesterday sent New Yorkers scurrying for whatever vanishing bits of coolness they could find and prompted stronger warnings on watersaving from officials increasingly concerned about maintaining water pressure to fight fires.

WASHINGTON, July 19--President Carter agreed today to seek an increase in Federal gasoline taxes of up to 5 cents to finance transportation or other Government programs, according to Administration officials.

His dissolution of Rhodesia's parliament and his call for a general election on Aug. 31 can only have this meaning.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)--Housing starts fell 6 percent in June from the previous month, but stil maintained an annual construction rate of 1.83 million units, the Commerce Department said today.

PEKING, July 19 (Reuters)--Teng Hsiaoping, the Chinese leader who was toppled in last year's power struggle, has been given back all his former posts, according to wall posters here tonight.

WASHIGTON, July 19--President Carter agreed today to seek an increase in Federal gasoline taxes of up to 5 cents to finance transportation or other Government programs, according to Administration officials.
Two of the more important trials in Africa's history ended last week in Pretoria, South Africa; one was a trial of Africa's past, the other of its future.

AFTER 14 years of telling almost a million people every day how Joe Namath blew an easy completion, how a grounder was bobbled, how a runner folded in the stretch run, I was going to be a competitor myself.

Classical European departments of electrical engineering often were divided into two courses of study-strong current for the students planning a career in electric power and weak current for those interested in communications.

A $200,000 granite and limestone fountain complex, a gift to the city from George T. Delacorte, the publisher, to emphasize the simplicity, elegance and the historic nature of the site, will be constructed at the southern tip of City Hall Park.

When historical events are analyzed in terms of the productive forces and relations that precipitated them, much becomes clear that is otherwise shrouded in mystery. This is the point of view adopted by Prof. David B. Quinn of the University of Liverpool in describing the European exploration, settlement and ultimate penetration of North America and in depicting the native American (or Indian) response to this incursion.
Shares of Citicorp traded heavily yesterday and closed up at 29 as investors interpreted positively slightly improved earnings for the second quarter.

REO SPEEDWAGON, a rock band that originated in Champagne, Ill., has been playing to large crowds in the Mid west for seven years. Like Z.Z. Top, which makes its living playing massive stadium shows in the Southwest and South, REO Speedwagon is the kind of group the rock press tends to overlook or ignore.

The dollar plunged to record lows against the West German mark and Swiss franc and hit its lowest level in months against other currencies in European money markets yesterday, The Associated Press reported. But in New York, urged on by profit taking, the dollar managed to gain a bit over its Monday prices against the mark and Japanese yen.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19--The United States voiced restrained support today for Vietnam's admission to United Nations membership, declaring in the Security Council that it looked forward to a "new era of peace, cooperation and friendship."

Protective devices to cut off electricity automatically for 50 percent of New York City and Westchester County should have saved the Consolidated Edison system from its massive electrical blackout July 13, the heads of the utility and the State Public Service Commission testified yesterday.

L'ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 19-- Bernard Thevenet retained his overall lead in the Tour de France cycling race today, finishing a strong second to Hennie Kuiper on the most demanding Stage of the 24-day endurance test.

DEE BROWN'S "Hear That Lonesome Whistle Blow" is in the old-fashioned muckraking tradition of business history. His Robber Barons are rascals and crooks, not geniuses who showed the world how to wed technology to a balance sheet. The profit motive, he suggests, can lead as well to rape of a nation's resources--and the gypping of millions of its citizens--as to economic development and rising living standards.
Edwin M. Schwenk, former Suffolk County Republican Party chairman, is being investigated by the Suffolk District Attorney for possible misuse of party funds, it was learned yesterday.

DURHAM, N. C., July 19--The sun is beating down on North Carolina's shimmering and drought-parched tobacco fields as it is on all of the South's field crops. But the worry here is not entirely about the lack of rain; it is about the future of tobacco farming itself.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Transportation Secretary Brock Adams suggested to President Carter today that 700 persons be transferred from the Secretary's staff and assigned elsewhere in the Department of Transportation.

LEXINGTON Ky., July 19 (AP)--A filly by Secretariat was one of four yearlings to reach the $300,000 mark tonight at the Keenland summer sale. The daughter of the Triple Crown winner, out of Libro d Oro, was sold for $300,000, the same price reached by a daughter of Graustark-Natural Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Justice Department sources said today that Attorney General Griffin B. Bell recently had an informal interview with a sixth possible candidate for the job of Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The sources said, however, that this did not mean the five original candidates had been rejected by Mr. Bell and President Carter.

"AND we meet with champagne and a chicken, at last." Those words were written by Lady Mary wortley Montagu in England in 1749. Now, I have never read the works of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu. But I like that line and I have my own visions of the lady and her lover sitting in some ant-free, leafy, sun-dappled glade, munching on that cold roast bird between sips of a bottle of well-chilled brut.

The Consolidated Edison Company was adjudged liable yesterday for $1.5 million for emergency services it received from the Atomic Energy Commission during a New York City power crisis in the summer of 1970.
One could practically furnish a home, or at least the dining room cupboard, with all the copies of glassware, china and silver that museums have been reproducing and offering for sale.

People who like to look snappy have had "best-dressed" list to compete for; now the Sanitation Department has given the city a "cleanest streets" list for residents to aspire to. The ingredients for success are pride, effort and most of all, a good rapport with one's sanitationmen.
The nation is broiling in what weathermen say may be the hottest July since Dust Bowl days.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 19 (Reuters)-- Prime Minister-designate Suleyman Demirel said tonight that he had reached agreement with his coalition partners on the makeup of a cabinet--a success that will enable him to return to power at the head of a right-wing coalition.

There are those who insist that food tastes better when seasoned with a Little fresh air, it is for them that the picnic was created. And their legion is increasing judging from this summer's offerings of picnic accessories, with motifs that run from futuristic Space Age to down home country.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19--The head stay let go aboard Courageous today in the middle of her race against Enterprise, forcing Courageous to quit immediately before her mast came down during the America's Cup Observation Trials.
TEL AVIV, July 19 (AP)--Two American brothers, Ken and Buddy Kring, won the gold and bronze medals in the decathlon at the Maccabiah Games today.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Senators Adlai E. Stevenson 3d and Harrison Schmitt, the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate ethics committee, reported to the panel today that a three-month inquiry into Korean lobbying had as yet disclosed no impropriety by present or former senators.

PARIS In the days when neon was unknown, Paris boutiques lured customers with richly gilded signs, painted pastoral scenes on storefronts and glittering mirrored interiors. The importance and delights of these shops as elegant and often amusing street art at the turn of the century has been painstakingly documented and jauntily recreated in a large exhibition here, "Paris Boutiques d'Hier," at the Musee National des Arts et Traditions Populaires.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 19--Twentythree years after Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark Supreme Court school desegregation decision in which this state's blacks were among the successful plaintiffs, Delaware is still arguing bitterly over how to end public school discrimination in this city, where the classroom population is 85 percent black.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--Two seeded players, Stan Smith and Cliff Richey, were ousted in the first round of the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament today. Raul Ramirez, another favorite, was knocked out last night by Brian Teacher, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6.
WASHINGTON, July 19--The Carter Administration is seriously considering the sale to Saudi Arabia of 60 F-15 supersonic fighters, the most advanced interceptor in the Air Force inventory.
LONDON, July 19--David Basnett's whole life, with the exception of a World War II stint as a pilot of Sunderland flying boats, has been spent in the trade union movement.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Henry A. Kissinger said today that North Vietnam's violations of the Paris peace agreement of 1973 had relieved the United States of its promise to provide up to $4.75 billion for the postwar reconstruction of that country.
SACCO AND VANZETTI The 50th anniversary of the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti next month will be a somewhat less melancholy occasion thanks to Governor Dukakis of Massachusetts.

Brenda Tubbs lives in Grenada, Miss., but, by her lights, a town farther north needs her support right about now. That's why Mrs. Tubbs sent a check for $31.13 to Mayor Beame to restore parts of the city affected by the blackout, or, as she put it in her letter, "to help y'all out."

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--President Carter, as expected, announced today the nomination of S. David Freeman, an architect of the Administration's energy conservation program, to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)--Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, today accused Defense Secretary Harold Brown of not taking a strong enough stand against military unions.

KEARNY, Ariz., July 19 (UPI)--Negotiators for the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America reached agreement last night on local issues that had blocked a return to work by 9,000 striking employees.

The four musicians who last year were the first to win the Avery Fisher Prizes, will be presented by the New York Philharmonic in a special series of four programs in Fisher Hall from Sept. 7 to 10. They are Ani Kavafian, violinist; Heidi Lehwalder, harpist, and Ursula Oppens and Paul Schenley pianists.

WASHINGTON, July 19--A search for new partners in the troubled Seadock project to build a deepwater port off the coast of Texas will be extended for up to 90 days, a spokesman for the group said today.
CHICAGO, July 19--Two Chicago experts who made headlines in 1954 were the news again here last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.
Allan M. Siegal, assistant to the executive editor for news technology at The New York Times, has been appointed news editor of The Times, A.M. Rosenthal, the executive editor, announced yesterday.

Charles H. Blitman, the son of a poor upstate farming family who rose to become one of New York City's most prominent building developers, died Monday at his home, 650 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old and had remained active until recently as chairman of the board for the Blitman Construction Corporation, which he founded in 1922.
While most North American Soccer League teams rely heavily on foreign players and coaches, the main ingredient of the first team to clinch a playoff spot in the league has an American flavor.

PARIS, July 19--France announced last night its second military Intervention in a black African trouble spot this year. While visiting the Ivory Coast, Foreign Minister Louis de Guiringaud said French military transport planes provided "lobistical support" earlier this month to Chad Government forces fighting Libyanbacked rebels in the former French colony.
If you can't stand the heat, get out of the buses. Many of New York City's 2,813 air-conditioned buses aren't, according to a spot check in midtown.

The State Commission of Investigation yesterday called for the ouster of the head of the State Office for Vocational Rehabilitation, declaring that earlier evidence of abuse in the training program had been greeted in ho-hum fashion by its top administrators.

In winning the Paul Keres Memorial Tournament in Tallin, Estonia, Mikhail Tal, the Latvian grandmaster who was world champion in 1960, produced a fine blend of positional, combinational and excellent end-game play.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 19 (UPI)-- Saying that intense heat had kept tourists away, the owner of the former Presidential yacht Sequoia decided today to pull up anchor and leave India Point Park a week early.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Under strong pressure for action from younger members of the House, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. pressed today a search for a new special counsel for the Korean influence-buying investigation.
NEWARK,July 19--A Federal judge reserved a decision today on whether a New Jersey or New York court had jurisdiction in the territorial dispute between the Knicks and the Nets.

WASHINGTON, July 19(AP)--A special committee of the General Tire and Rubber Company recommended today that Michael G. O'Neil be retained as president of the company although he started a political-contribution program that it said was probably illegal.

VISALIA, Calif.--In this city of 38,000 people in the heart of California's agriculturally bountiful Central Valley, if the baseball team doesn't start winning soon, the owners of the team may not get rid of the manager but they might try to recall the City Council.
Bolstered by strong earnings gains for the June quarter, stock prices surged across a broad front yesterday in the heaviest trading this year on the New York Stock Exchange.
Despite published research and widespread anecdotal evidence to the contrary, a college degree is still a solid economic investment, according to a new study by the Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, July 19-Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan urged Mayor Beame and New York State welfare officials attending a Senate welfare hearing today "to show some indignation" about waste and fraud in the distribution of welfare benefits in New Fork.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Administration's tax proposals probably would include a combination of incentives for capital investment.

OTTAWA, July 19--After several years of sometimes heated debate, the House of Commons approved a gun control law last night that will require purchasers of firearms to obtain a form of permit for the weapons.

ESSINGTON, Pa. July 19--Leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation from eight Eastern states met here today to map strategy for dealing with what the big farm organization called a "real threat" of unionization of farm workers.

ALBANY, July 19--Governor Carey said today that he would make available $500,000 "to assist the city's shopkeepers in any way that we can" in recovering from the damage caused in New York during last week's blackout.
Although the city's heat wave is expected to last at least through Friday, one can stay relatively comfortable by following the advice of medical and weather experts.
WASHINGTON, July 19-"Could I have everybody's attention, please," President Carter said as members of his Cabinet took their seats around the long table.

In the late 1960's, South Korea devised a perpetual motion machine. It was started with food aid and other assistance to Korea voted by the United States Congress. The Koreans would deal only with American rice merchants who agreed to pay commissions to a chosen agent. The agent, in turn, would use the funds, energetically, to ingratiate himself with members of Congress. And they, in turn, would vote to continue sending assistance to Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 19--A former employee and the head of trading for the Investors Diversified Services Inc., the nation's largest mutual funds complex, were charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with fraud involving the use of inside information for their personal benefit.

State Senator Roy M. Goodman moved yesterday at the New York City Board of Elections to invalidate the designating petitions of Barry Farber, a prospective opponent in the Republican mayoral primary, and thus deny Mr. Farber a place on the primary ballot.

TRENTON, July 19--Robert J. Del Tufo, 43-year-old director of the State Division of Criminal Justice and the first assistant state attorney general, was described by national law enforcement officials today as the "leading contender" to succeed Jonathan L. Goldstein as United States Attorney for New Jersey.

PETER was fishing from a river bank. Georgina was picking wild strawberries, John and his father were cutting dead trees for firewood. Grace was collecting rocks for her garden. Along with what they went for, all came away with an unexpected "gift" from a native American--poison ivy.
George Morton Levy, founder and president of Roosevelt Raceway and pioneer of modern night harness racing, died yesterday of a heart attack at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 89 years old.

HERE were dozens of practical and fascinating objects among the thousands of kitchen gadgets, electrical appliances and cooking and table implements on dis play last week at the trade show of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association in Chicago. Many, however, will require careful testing before recommendations can be made.

After more than two years of muddled conflict over rents, the tenant leaders of Co-op City in the Bronx and New York State housing officials have reached a tentative settlement. Its main virtue is that no one likes it.

PARIS--It is tragic that so beautiful an object as the Concorde supersonic plane should be at the center of such a hopeless international mess involving bad feelings among three old allies. The affair is particularly sorry because all parties involved, including France and Britain, the aircraft's manufacturers, know that whatever happens, Concorde can never pay for itself.

Don Sutton of the Dodgers, one of the major leagues' fastest talkers, was a little overwhelmed by his work last night at Yankee Stadium. He played in the place that was at the center of his boyhood dreams, was the winning pitcher for the National League with three scoreless innings and was named the most-valuable player in the 48th All-Star Game.

DURHAM, N. C., July 19--The sun is beating down on North Carolina's shimrnering and drought-parched tobacco fields as it is on all of the South's field crops. But the worry here is not entirely about the lack of rain; it is about the future of tobacco farming itself.
BEIRUT, Lebanon July 20 (AP)--The Carter Administration and Palestinian guerrilla leaders are involved in secret high-level contacts, the Beirut newspaper Al Anwar reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)--The Senate, after voting to kill funds for production of the B-1 bomber, overwhelmingly approved today more research and development for the bomber as an "insurance policy" in the event the pilotless cruise missile is a failure.

Protective devices to cut off electricity automatically for 50 percent of New York City and Westchester County should have saved the Consolidated Edison system from its massive electrical blackout July 13, the heads of the utility and the State Public Service Commission testified yesterday.

Three Brooklyn youths were arrested last night and charged with starting Monday's seven-block blaze in the Bushwick section that destroyed 23 buildings and forced the evacuation of more than 250 people.
Edward H. Granville, who built champion aircraft in the old barnstorming days, died Monday at his home in Madison, N.H. He was 64 years old.

NEWARK, July 19--Clara Allen of Union City, the top vote-getter among the state's 40 newly elected delegates to the National Women's Conference in Houston, Nov. 18 to 21, expressed gratification today over the success of last month's New Jersey International Women's Year meeting at Princeton University.

WASHINGTON--The fever charts that tell the country whether its two most persistent economic maladies, inflation and unemployment are getting better or worse are themselves about to undergo, extensive surgery.

EVERY so often it becomes necessary to remind people once again about Alsace. Why this is so is a mystery. Some of the finest wines in France, which means in the world, are produced in the beautiful Alsace region. Still, three of every four wine drinkers in this country usually cannot remember the last time he had a bottle from there.

Temperatures that reached a record 102 degrees at 2 P.M. yesterday sent New Yorkers scurrying for whatever vanishing bits of coolness they could find and prompted stronger warnings on watersaving from officials increasingly concerned about maintaining water pressure to fight fires.

LIMA, Peru, July 19 (UPI)-Peruvian policemen and marines opened fire today on rioting demonstrators supporting a strike prohibited by the Government. At least six persons were killed and dozens of others were injured, authorities and news reports said.

In a policy reversal, the Federal Government agreed yesterday to hold "in abeyance" its plans for big rent increases at Lincoln Towers and other housing projects in New York City that it had previously determined would need the increases to remain economically stable.

New York City improved its offer to the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in the hope of obtaining a labor contract, and the union sent it to the rank-and-file membership without recommendation yesterday for a vote by mail."

In a hot summer of power failure and looting, it may be reassuring to the residents of Wave Crest Gardens to recall that their own season of greatest discontent is past. It is a reminder that a turnaround in troubled real-estate situations is possible. Wave Crest Gardens, 37 six-story buildings sprawling across 29 acres in Far Rockaway, seems to have "turned around."

WASHINGTON, July 19--President Carter and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, opening their two-day White House meeting in an air of cordiality, agreed today to give priority to the convening of a new Geneva conference this year and the attainment of a "just and durable peace in the Middle East."

An agreement has been signed between a private American research institute and a Soviet institute to explore collaborative testing of a fusion-based power system that also breeds fuel for fission reactors such as those now in wide use.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced unexpectedly late yesterday that it would immediately ask its bondholders for permission to build rail mass-transit projects in both states.
Citicorp, the nation's second largest commercial banking company, reported yesterday a relatively modest 4.1 percent increase in second-quarter operating earnings.

Honeywell Inc., manufacturer of control instruments and data-processing systems, had a 52.6 percent rise in second-quarter earnings and an 83.9 percent jump for the first half of this year, the company reported yesterday in Minneapolis.

The nation is broiling in what weathermen say may be the hottest July since Dust Bowl days. Yesterday, temperatures pushed past 90 degrees in 44 states, public officials called for water conservation, at least seven heat-caused deaths were reported in St. Louis, and meteorologists saw no relief soon.
TOKYO, July 19 (Reutors)--Japan announced today a massive $1.49 billion visible trade surplus for June despite increased foreign criticism of its export drive.

A ROMAN CATHOLIC nun who directs Vermont's Human Services Agency, Sister Elizabeth Candon, may face church discipline for her support of using Government funds for abortions. The Bishop of Burlington, the Most Rev. John Marshall, warned Sister Elizabeth she faced trouble after she said the state should not discriminate against poor people by denying them medical services available to others.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, July 19 (AP) --West Germany continued its domination of the world whitewater canoeing and kayak championships on the Lieser River near Spittal An Der Drau today, as its women won the wildwater team event in the kayak competition.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, stripped his regional directors of their titles and much of their authority over his department's field offices today in a shakeup of the regional bureaucracy.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)--A bill to increase the Federal minimum wage of $2.30 an hour by 35 cents next Jan. 1 was approved today, 29 to 7, by the House Education and Labor Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (Reuters)--A Pentagon study has recommended the sale of more than $8 billion in arms to South Korea to make up for the planned withdrawal of United States ground troops, Government sources said today.
WHITE PLAINS, July 19--A joyous Joseph F. Leonard said today that he was gardening outside his home in Byram, Conn., when a neighbor brought word of today's court decision.

Charges by a convicted forger, who has vanished, that certain commodity traders faked deals involving some $5 billion of crude petroleum futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to evade taxes are being investigated by a New York grand jury, it was learned yesterday.

HACKENSACK, July 19--A State Senate committee holding hearings on the alleged anti-cancer agent laetrile were told today that a physician on the staff of Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch had had his privileges to admit new patients suspended because he allegedly treated a terminally ill cancer patient with the controversial substance.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced unexpectedly late yesterday that it would immediately ask its bondholders for permission to build rail mass-transit projects in both states.

Three of the nation's top 10 steel producers had discouraging news yesterday for their shareholders. The Republic Steel Corporation, the Armco Steel Corporation and Allegheny Ludlum Industries Inc. each disclosed declines in secondquarter earnings.

Arthur L. Litke, one of the two members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board who objected to the group's proposed accounting rules for the oil and gas industry, has been informed by the organization's trustees that he will not be reappointed to his $125,000a-year post when his five-year term expires Dec. 31.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 14 (UPI)--Joseph E. Keenan, a retired professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an internationally recognized authority on thermodynamics, died Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital. He was 76 years old.

SOUND IS WHERE you find it, and since the advent of batterypowered, portable cassette recorders of reasonable quality, vacation travelers have come to look upon such machines much as they regard their cameras as devices to hold last impressions gathered on their journeys. Often the sonic "snapshot" evokes the atmosphere of a place or the memory of an event more vividly than a photograph.

TRENTON, July 20 Rocco D. Ricci took the oath of office today as the new State Commissioner of Environmental Protection and pledged that he would work for an "effective and realisic" program for preventing toxic and carcinogenic substances in the environment.

Paine Webber Inc., parent company of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis Inc., the nation's fifth-largest investment banking house, announced yesterday that profits for the June quarter rose 12.3 percent to $2.3 million from $2 million a year earlier. Revenues rose 24 percent to $67.2 million from $54.4 million.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Carter has offered the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities to Joseph D. Duffey, who has been serving as Assistant Secretary of State for Cultural Affairs since January.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Carter said today he believed, as a result of discussions with Arab leaders, that the views expressed to him by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel in the . last two days would produce a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East as early as October.
