A temporary stay was issued yesterday against moves by the State Department of Environmental Conservation to close 2,600 acres of Suffolk County clam beds lying in polluted water.

PARIS, July 20 The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that unemployment would rise and economic growth would slow over the next year in most of the 24 nations that belong to the organization.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The House ethics committee today chose Leon A. Jaworski, the former Watergate special prosecutor, to take charge of its investigations of Korean influence-buying and help revive public confidence in the inquiry.

The United States Trust Company, the largest single holder of bonds of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, welcomed yesterday an authority campaign to win bondholders' agreement for financing new rail transit projects in both states.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 20 Kenya and Somalia have pledged to maintain peace along their border and agreed to set up a border commission to "normalize and restore tranquility" in the region, it was announced today.

LIKE most other big stores, Hammacher Schlemmer (147 East 57th Street) was closed to customers the day following the big blackout. But for buyers and executives, it was business almost as usual. Nothing could be done about the heat, but considerable illumination was provided by the array of non-electric lighting devices that are one of the store's specialities.

RICHLAND TOWNSHIP, Pa., July 20 A nightlong seven-inch rainfall caused severe flooding and killed at least 10persons in Johnstown and surrounding communities, leaving Johnstown an island today, reachable only by helicopter from this suburb five miles away.
Life has been plaintive and inexorable for the last week, with darkness giving way to heat and with New Yorkers showing one another looks of crankiness and wonderment.
Alcan Aluminum Ltd., the world's second-largest aluminum producer, reported yesterday a rebound from its strike-riddled earnings of a year ago.
Clark C. Sorensen, a retired management consultant, died Monday at the Lakewood, Ohio, Hospital. He was 62 years old and a resident of Lakewood.
The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading yesterday in the stock of Frigitronics Inc. and the Vernitron Corporation until 10 A.M. Monday.

The trial in the territorial dispute between the Knicks and the Nets is scheduled to start tomorrow in Federal District Court in Manhattan under Judge Robert L. Carter. The issue is whether the Nets can move from the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., to New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The Central Intelligence Agency conducted a 14-year program to find ways to "control human behavior" through the use of chemical, biological and radiological material, according to agency documents made public today by John Marks, a freelance journalist.

Stockholders of the Todd Shipyards Corporation yesterday gave their permission for a reduction of the par value of the common and preferred stocks to $1 from $10 a share and an increase in the authorized preferred to 5 million from 1 million shares.

BABY, it's hot outside. One feels sticky and limp, nerves fraying. Head for water, the most soothing of the ele ments. It not only gets you clean, it helps you to recharge. You may not have a mountain stream at your door, but you do have a bathroom. With a little thought, you can turn it into a blissful retreat.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Carter said today he believed, as a result of discussions with Arab leaders, that the views expressed to him by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel in the last two days would produce a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East as early as October.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The Central Intelligence Agency conducted a 14-year program to find ways to "control human behavior" through the use of chemical, biological and radiological material, according to agency documents made public today by John Marks, a freelance journalist.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Carter is preparing to use a trip into the South tomorrow to deliver an address on Soviet-American relations, with the aim of creating a more positive atmosphere for dealing with Moscow.

MIAMI, July 20, (UPI) Howard French, listed as the world's oldest commercial pilot and the holder of a flight certificate signed by Orville Wright, died yesterday at a nursing home here. He was 92 years old.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) Starting at a take-out restaurant allegedly offering fish and chips and cocaine, Federal agents struck today at a ring that they said combined the sale of cocaine with traffic in prostitution.

ALBANY, July 20 Predicting "more effective relief to the 'battered spouse,'" Governor Carey announced today that he had approved a bill giving the victim of family violence the choice of seeking reconciliation in the Family Courts or punishment for the assailant in the Criminal Courts.
ANCHORAGE, July 20 Young mountaineers are descending this week from Mount McKinley, the highest mountain in North America, after helping a scientific expedition to chart its position precisely.

At the recommendation of District Attorney John Santucci of Queens, a 25year-old drug addict received a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison yesterday for a fatal stabbing, The Associated Press reported.

AS A young sailor on a ship bound for China in 1843, Frederick Law Olmsted wrote his letters home on both sides of very thin paper. "Trying to transcribe one of these can boggle the mind," said Charles Capen McLaughlin, who is editing 60,000 pages of letters and manuscripts of the pioneer landscape architect who co-designed Central Park in 1856.

LONDON, July 20 (AP) British Airways said today that its four supersonic Concorde flights to Washington each week were so full that there would be six flights a week beginning Aug. 21. The airline also announced that it had taken delivery of a fifth Concorde.

THE ELECTRONIC MAGAZINE sweepstakes gets another entry tonight at 10 on ABC-TV. This one is called "ABC News Closeup: On Camera." William Peters is the senior producer. Peter Jennings and Sandy Hill are the hosts and chief correspondents. And the content is exceedingly dull.

MORGANTON, N.C., July 20 (UPI) A former inmate at the McDowell County prison unit, where a fire killed nine prisoners last year, said yesterday that inmates had set the blaze to lure guards into the cellblock as part of a mass escape plan.

Though perhaps his most popular, Sibelius's first two symphonies are transitional works, weakened by stretches of repetition and melodrama. Even so, they are full of good things, and a canny conductor can subdue the occasional banality of the style by stressing affinities to the starkness and concision of the composer's mature works.

MINNEAPOLIS IT IS NOT JUST a question of size. Through some complex relation of space, angle and proportion, the thrust stage of the Tyrone Guthrie Theater quite dominates the spectators. The floor plans don't show it, but the theater seems to be twothirds stage, one-third audience; whereas at New York's Vivian Beaumont it seems to be the other way around.
WASHINGTON, July 20 A jury of 10 women and two men began deliberations late today in the trial of 12 Hanafi Moslems accused in the takeover of three buildings here in March.

LONDON, July 20 (UPI) The Clyde Yard of Yarrow has received a contract to build four more support ships for the Imperial Iranian Navy, a spokesman for Yarrow said today. The contract is estimated to be worth about $93.5 million.

Despite his standing as one of England's foremost players, first place in international competition had eluded him since before World War II. WHEN IT COMES to kitchen storage, there are two schools of thought. The Good Housekeeper approach is to hide everything behind closed doors. Nothing is allowed out except perhaps a toaster and if there's a way to build that in, the architects who have encouraged this look will find it. In these kitchens the cabinets are paramount. At their best and costliest they can be made to accommodate the most ungainly items.

PEKING, July 21 (Reuters) The socalled Gang of Four-Mao Tse-tung's widow, Chiang Ching, and three other disgraced Chineseleaders have been expelled from the Communist Party, wall posters here announced today.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 21-President Carter said tonight the United States wanted a new treaty that would let this country help operate the Panama Canal for the rest of this century and allow American warships to protect it after the year 2000.
Fears in Western Europe of possible economic deterioration and radical change apparently have given new impetus to the flow of investments into the United States.

PARIS, July 21 Many European bankers and monetary officials are now saying that the dollar's sharp fall in value on foreign exchange markets may signal the opening of a new period of currency unrest, after the relative tranquillity of recent months.

TOKYO, July 22 Kenji Osano, Japanese hotel executive, pleaded "innocent of perjury," denying his involvement in the Lockheed payments scandal at the first hearing of his trial at the Tokyo District Court today.
A cooperative computer at the Strategic Planning Institute in Cambridge, Mass., provides 150 companies with invaluable information from facts collected on an anonymous basis.
NEW CITY, N.Y., July 21 Some New York City school teachers who live and pay taxes in Rockland County are taking public stands against contract demands of teachers in their local school districts.

DETROIT, July 21 The American Motors Corporation, continuing to show signs of emerging from its-financial crisis, today reported a profit for its third fiscal quarter, ended June 30, of $1.6 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $580 million. That was in contrast to a year-earlier loss of $3.9 million on sales of $602 million.

Governor Carey gave final approval yesterday to an agreement that requires Co-op City residents to pay an average of 20 percent more in their monthly maintenance charges and increase their equity though additional payments to the huge Bronx development.

Takashi Ishiara, president of the Nissan Motors Company, Japan's second largest auto maker (after Toyota), said yesterday at a news conference in Nagoya that his company had sounded out the possibility of establishing an assembly plant in the United States.

They are being called the "invulnerable children" because, despite the most stressful lives, they don't break down. In fact, they thrive, even though their parents may be deranged, even though they may live in poverty or have suffered profound bereavement and pain. CHICAGO, July 21 Frank Collin, the fuehrer of the National Socialist Party of America, is troubled these days.
DETROIT, July 21 (AP) Four firemen were overcome by smoke battling a threealarm fire today in an uncompleted 39story office tower in the new $337 million Renaissance Center.
The busiest actor in New York this weekend is Charles Ludlam, founder, director and artistic inspiration of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company.

New York City officials estimate that the July 13-14 blackout cost businesses $135 million to $150 million in theft and other property damage out of a total bill in the "hundreds of millions of dollars," including a generally lost work day.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit today ended a temporary stay of a Federal Communications Commission order opening the way for unrestricted resale and sharing of private-line leased telephone and telegraph circuits in the United States.

John Robert Powers, creator of what is believed to be the world's first modeling agency, which led to an aura of glamour and affluence that drew thousands of women, men and eventually competitors to what is now a billiondollar industry, died Tuesday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Glendale, Calif. He was 84 years old and had been ill for many months.

Amid concern that consumer spending, which has powered the economy forward for the last 28 months, may soon slow down, the upturn is getting new impetus from a little-noticed source: invigorated government spend-...

Fears in Western Europe of possible economic deterioration and radical change apparently have given new impetus to the flow of investments into the United States.

WHY SO MUCH ATTENTION being paid nowadays to the Mandarin, Shanghai, Szechwan and Hunan kitchens of northern China, the food of the southern pro vince of Canton is all too often accorded short shrift. Yet the wide variety of that cuisine, along with its subtly enticing and soul-soothing flavor and textural counterpoints, makes it one of China's most popular and satisfying, even among the Chinese themselves.

After laughing their way to a 7-0 victory behind Catfish Hunter in the first game of a doubleheader with the Milwaukee Brewers, yesterday, the Yankees saw the second contest turn into anything but a laugh as they lost, 5-4, in 10 innings.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The assignment of one of this country's highestranking career diplomats as United States Ambassador to Greece apparently has been jeopardized by the use of the word "unusual" to describe the proximity of Greek islands to the coast of Turkey.
Despite increasing competition, the Xerox Corporation yesterday reported a 10.2 percent gain is second-quarter net income and an 11 percent gain for the first half.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 21 (AP) Herbert G. Fales, an aviation pioneer and retired metal company executive, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 George Atkinson's libel suit against Chuck Noll and the Pittsburgh Steelers will go to the six-person jury tomorrow morning, as attorneys for both sides completed their final arguments today.

BRIELLE, July 21 Fishermen along the New Jersey shore today reported polluted water running in a band along the coast from Sandy Hook to Cape May. Their reports were not confirmed by the State or Federal Environmental Protection Agencies.

Billy Taylor, who is appearing at Storyville through Sunday with his trio, seems wholly unaffected by the violent change that overtook jazz in the 1960's. He is still the urbane, essentially conservative, Bud Powell-rooted pianist who led similar trios around New York 20 years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 21 Despite objections of the Carter Administration that it would add millions to the cost of farm supports, the House set the 1977 wheat subsidy at $2.90 a bushel today.

Increased profits were posted by two leading oil producers, the first in the industry to announce mid-year results. Texaco Inc., the nation's second largest, after the Exxon Corporation, realized an 18.4 percent rise in the second quarter and 13.1 percent in the half-year. The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) had profit increases of 7.2 percent for the quarter and 10.7 percent for the six months.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Charles L. Schultze, President Carter's chief economic adviser, today denounced price increases announced by United States Steel, the nation's largest steel manufacturer. Calling the steel price increases "inconsistent with the Administration's effort to control and reduce the nation's inflation rate," Mr. Schultze said he had discussed the steel price increase with President Carter, and that the President specifically expressed "sharp disappointment" with the price increases.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 21 Heavily armed Thai and Cambodian troops fought a battle across their border today, the first since the Communists assumed power in Cambodia more than two years ago.
New York City suffered through a blistering 104 degrees yesterday the second-highest temperature ever recorded here with wilting discomfort but no disaster.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The House passed and sent to the Senate today two foreign assistance bills that contain restrictions on military aid to Ethiopia, Argentina and Turkey.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 21 Mal Galletta of Glen Cove, the Long Island open champion, defeated 37-year-old Jim Albus of Staten Island, 4 and 3, today in the semifinals in the 42d annual Long Island Professional Golfers' Association match play championship at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.
ALBANY, July 21 The 90-degree heat in Albany today failed to deter the state and a local supermarket from building the world's largest salad in the middle of the Empire State Plaza.

JERUSALEM, July 21 Prime Minister Menahem Begin's first meetings with President Carter earned praise today for the Israeli leader from politicians and editorial writers who, at the same time, pointed out that substantive policy differences remained between Israel and the United States regarding the search for peace in the Middle East.

CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., July 21 Vice President Mondale visited New Jersey today for the first time since his election to fulfill a pledge of the Carter Administration that it would stump for Governor Byrne's re-election.
New York City suffered through a blistering 104 degrees yesterday the second-highest temperature ever recorded here with wilting discomfort but no disaster.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 A four-man honor guard half-stepped through the dimly lit ballroom of the Pittsburgh Hilton last night, stacked four rifles on the stage and draped an American Legion cap over the weapons' muzzles.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 Amid Arab denunciations of the peace-talk proposals of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, indications have also appeared that moderates led by Egypt and Jordan want to cintinue pressing for the reconvening of the Geneva conference on the Middle East.

CLIFFSIDE PARK, July 21 Vice President Mondale visited New Jersey today for the first time since his election to fulfill a pledge of the Carter Administration that it would stump for Governor Byrne's re-election.

WASHINGTON, July 21 An official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is being considered for head of the bureau oversaw an internal investigation of possible corruption in the bureau in 1975 that was rejected as incomplete by Edward H. Levi, then Attorney General, and was characterized privately as a "whitewash" by several Justice Department officials.

Take a big-city neighborhood an hour or so from Broadway and a community college with an idle auditorium and a strong commitment to the arts. Stir in a couple of persuasive directors. In Bayside, Queens, this adds up to the QCC (for Queensborough Community College) Theater Company, which is billing itself as the only Equity stock company in the city this summer.
The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday contributed $250,000 to the fund to help small businesses damaged by looting and arson during last week's blackout.
COLOMBIO, Sri Lanka, Friday, July 22 Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike headed for a stunning defeat today in Sri Lanka's national parliamentary elections.
Money-market temperatures moderated late yesterday afternoon when the Federal Reserve reported a decline of $1.7 billion in the nation's money supply in the week ended July 13.

LONDON, July 21 Peter Jay, Prime Minister James Callagnan's son-in-law, flew to Washington today to take up his appointment as ambassador to the United States, but not without setting off yet another controversy.

Emily D. Meyer, the wife of Matt Meyer, who was former president of both The New York World-Telegram and The Sun and The World Journal Tribune, died Wednesday at her home at 69 Chase Road in Scarsdale, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 71 years old.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 21 As this city struggled to begin the job of digging out from the devastating floods of Tuesday night the death toll here and in surround ing communities rose to 45 today, with hundreds of persons still missing, and an estimated 50,000 displaced.

TRENTON, July 21 Electricity reserves in New Jersey were almost nonexistant today, but because of an expected break in the 10-day-long heat wave, there should be no need for emergency measures, Joel R. Jacobson said after being sworn in at noon as the first Commissioner of the new Department of Energy.

The Peter Schaufuss New York knows best is the self-effacing principal dancer of New York City Ballet, the impeccable exponent of such Balanchine roles as the leads in "Raymonda Variations" or "Scotch Symphony." Yet the Danish star does have a quite different persona, best known in Europe, as a classic ballet prince, the hero of "Giselle," "La Sylphide" or "Swan Lake."

A large green tent has sprouted near the Battery, signaling perhaps a new institution in New York. It's the Big Apple Circus and its promoters say this circus has come to town to stay.

BUFFALO, July 21 (AP) Ray P. Whitman, an aviation pioneer and the last surviving founder of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, now the Bell Aerospace Company, died Thursday at the age of 83 in his suburban Williamsville home. He was a native of Washington, D.C., and was associated with American military aviation almost from its start, before World War I.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Vernon Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, who is one of the black leaders closest to President Carter, says that the Carter Administration "has fallen short on policies, programs and people."

Chalk up another milestone in New York banking history. Thanks to last week's massive power failure, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York kept its "discount window" open until 8:30 P.M. last Friday to aid banks uncertain of their reserve position as their computers, as well as their lightbulbs, only slowly started working again.

Three real-estate appraisers who share office space have received more than $1 million in fees in the last three years by acting as expert witnesses for the city in tax assessment cases, according to a study prepared by Assemblyman Charles Schumer, chairman of the Assembly Subcommittee on City Management.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 21 Meadow Blue Chip set a world mile record of 1:54 3/5 for a pacing mare tonght as she won the $75,000 Bergen County Pace at the Meadowlands.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Consumer prices rose in June by six-tenths of 1 percent with food, services and sundry other retail items continuing to climb, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The rise in the Consumer Price Index was just equal to May's, less than the full 1 percent surge that occurred in February and considerably more than the monthly advances of three-tenths of 1 percent in the second half of 1976.
ROME, July 19 Amid a wave of crime and violence, Italian officials are discussing plans for an amnesty to ease overcrowding in prisons.
David Susskind's successful 25-yearold television producing company, Talent Associates Ltd., has been purchased by Time-Life Films for Time Inc. stock reportedly valued at about $3 million.
NAIROBI, Kenya. July 21 Ethiopian troops are battling Somali-backed insurgents in southeastern Ethiopia, with both sides claiming substantial gains.

THE MORNING IS SOUR and dark. Ferdinand Rieche, a security policeman demoted for overzealousness, is having breakfast. With a mournaful countenance, a prominent nose and a face that resembles both mousetrap and mouse, he devours raisin cake. The radio announces a tropical storm approaching Wiesbaden.

Robert W. Stock, editor of the Sunday Travel section of The New York Times, will become an assistant business and financial editor responsible for the Sunday Business and Finance section, it was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor.

WASHINGTON, July 21 President Carter described last week's looting in the New York City blackout as an "additional indication" of the need to channel Federal programs for housing, health, education and jobs opportunities to rundown urban areas "neglected too long."

WASHINGTON, July 21 Vice Adm. Bobby R. Inman, head of the National Security Agency, said today that his agency had made what he called "inadvertant pickups" of the telephone conversations of United States citizens.
PARIS, July 21 Iran has withdrawn $500 million it had deposited earlier with the French central bank, French officials reported today.

The United States Steel Corporation caught the steel industry by surprise yesterday and announced that it planned to raise prices on structural shapes by about 6 percent and tin mill products by about 7 percent on Sept. 4. These products account for approximately 15 percent of the company's total steel shipments.
An attempt by a peddler to sell fake Omega and Seiko watches to an investigator with the Manhattan District Attorney's office two weeks ago led to the arrest of four men yesterday.

Three of five Croatian nationalists who hijacked a Trans World Airlines passenger jet last Sept. 10 were sentenced in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to 30-year terms for air piracy and conspiracy.

AUGUSTA, Maine, July 21 (AP) Gov. James B. Longley has vetoed a bill that would have ended the practice of forcing public employees to retire at a certain age.

It is designed to assure that workers attempting to organize a company, or unions trying to negotiate a first contract, will not be tied up in endless litigation.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Putting Leon A. Jaworski in charge of the House ethics committee investigation of Korean influence buying appears to solve the committee's immediate problem of public skepticism, at least for the time being.

CAIRO, July 21 Egypt reported a major border clash today with Libya, saying that the Libyans had carried out an armored and aerial attack across the border but that they had been beaten back with the loss of 40 tanks and two planes.

THE OLD DO-OR-DIE, idealistic school of summer-theater apprenticeship overnight discovery on the legendary "straw-hat circuit" is as faded as that old Judy Garland movie, "Summer Stock." These days, if a star breaks a leg, another star is quickly hired to take her place or the entire tour is canceled. Summer theater is now big business. Shows are prepackaged in New York, marked commercially digestible and shipped on a road tour of major summer theaters.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) Limited advances in nearby soybean oil deliveries bolstered prices, enabling soybeans to close firmly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The Commerce Department reported today that the national economy grew at an annual rate of 6.4 percent in the second quarter, an expansion that was somewhat slower than had earlier been indicated but was said to be better balanced.

CHICAGO, July 21 The Spingold knockout team championship, the prestige event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, continued here this afternoon with 64 teams surviving out of a record-breaking entry of 160 teams.

A Queens grand jury has voted to indict the Warner-Lambert Company and four employees for reckless manslaughter in connection with the explosion and fire in its chewing-gum factory in Long Island City last Nov. 21 that killed six workers and burned dozens more.

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 The Consolidated Edison Company and the Long Island Lighting Company have been laying a cable to link the two utilities that, if completed, might have given Con Edison greater flexibility in dealing with last week's blackout, according to officials of both utilities.

PARIS Winding up a European tour largely devoted to acquainting himself with the United Nations' subsidiary organizations in Geneva and Paris, Ambassador Andrew Young passed through here Thursday and unloaded some very sensible and far-sighted observations about this complex and highly charged world and the role therein of the United Nations and the United States. His long-range views included the following:
PALMA, Majorca "Truly, in all conscience, I can only recommend this excursion to artists, both robust in body and of ardent spirit," wrote George Sand of her visit to Majorca in 1838.

CHASKA, Minn., July 22 Hollis Stacy, a sparkling profsesional golfer, was not expected to lead any round of the 32d annual United States Women's Open championship. She might have been picked to finish well down the list behind the more familiar troopers on the women's tour if anyone really thought of her as a threat at all.

CAMDEN, July 22 Joseph Kallinger, the Philadelphia shoemaker convicted last fall of killing a nurse in Leonia, was found guilty today of robbing two homes in Lindenwold and attempting to rape a housewife in one of them.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 Ten years ago while a quarterback at the University of Wisconsin, Jim Delich became enamored with golf. Yesterday, the 33-year-old native of Milwaukee who developed into an outstanding golfer in Florida, won the 42d Long Island Professional Golfers' Association match play championship at Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Carter Administration's first effort to turn back an industrial price increase by a public expression of disapproval appeared to have failed today barely 24 hours after it occurred.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that it had awarded $131 million in work for the orbiting space telescope that will be launched in 1983 to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the PerkinElmer Corporation.

Coffee futures contract prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange contined their long decline yesterday. Most contracts were down the daily limit of 6 cents a pound, and the current-delivery month of July, in which limits do not apply, lost 8.50 cents a pound.

PRAGUE, July 22 (AP) New prices take effect tomorrow and Czechoslovaks are going to pay 50 percent more for coffee, 33 percent more for chocolates and 34 percent more for some cotton and wool products.

Guy F. Tozzoli, the director of world trade for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said Thursday that the world trips he and other officials and their wives had taken at the authority's expense were entirely proper and had developed millions of dollars of business for the port area.

SAN SALVADOR, July 22 Jesuit sources said today that the campaign of threats and intimidation against progressive Roman Catholic priests in El Salvador reflects conservative anger at the church's support for a much-needed land reform program here.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Denying the Administration the power it sought to set natural gas prices, a Senate-House conference committee agreed today on details of legislation to create a new, 20,000-employee Department of Energy.

PROSPECT, Conn., July 22 A mother, her seven children and her niece, some of the children bound and gagged, were found dead in the early morning hours today presumably murdered in the burned-out interior of their home.
The Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead modestly yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as stocks generally ground out small but steady gains.

An official of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey says he "wouldn't be critical" of decisions by the Consolidated Edison Company in recent years to delay expansions of powertransfer links across the Hudson that some people say could have helped avert last week's blackout.
Aliza Begin, wife of the Prime Minister of Israel, has to admit she is impressed.

TOKYO, July 22 Japan's women's liberation movement has folded. After enduring five years of frustrating struggle and ridicule, which can be immensely powerful in group-conscious Japan, the only major women's liberation group and its affiliates have shuttered their offices and admitted defeat at the hands of an overpowering male chauvinism and a wide generation gap among women seeking to change their social status.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 Everyone has been having his day at the America's Cup trials lately and this one belonged to Ted Hood, the beleaguered skipper of the new yacht, Independence. Twice today she beat the other new 12-Meter, Enterprise, the second time with considerable help from the latter.
Cranford Township has been cited by the American Automobile Association for "superior achievement" in the prevention of pedestrian traffic fatalities.

WASHINGTON, July 22 State Department officials expressed concern today that an off-the-cuff response yesterday by President Carter in Yazoo, Miss., to a question about the Panama Canal would seriously complicate the delicate negotiations for a new canal treaty.

The busiest battlefield in professional sports these days stretches across 588 acres of landfill in New Jersey, four miles west of the Hudson River and eight miles south of the George Washington Bridge.

A leading conservation group has accused the electric industry of unfairly promoting atomic power and ridiculing critics of the industry in a purported educational game being placed in thousands of classrooms around the country. The industry says it is not so.

Soviet scientists, according to a report from Moscow, have started to build an experimental fusion reactor that, by using superconducting magnets, will be able to sustain a plasma at a temperature of 50 million degrees for more than one second.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Martin Diamond, a political scientist and professor at Georgetown University, collapsed today moments after he testified before a Senate subcommittee and died of a heart attack two hours later, despite the efforts of two Senators to revive him.

The business and financial community came away from the latest session of the New York Legislature with a number of major gains, including elimination of the New York City stock transfer tax, a reduction in personal income taxes and the likelihood of $750 million in state bond money to finance economic development projects over the next three years.
BALTIMORE, July 22 A 34-foot authentic black Venetian gondola named Gina was added to Baltimore's motley fleet of dockbound vessels today.
SAN DIEGO, July 22 The mystery man of the New York Mets this year, Jon Matlack, shed some more light on the mystery tonight when he pitched the Mets to a 5-0 victory over the San Diego Padres.

OAKVILLE, Ontario, July 22 It has been two years since Lee Trevino, the most celebrated member of the golf tour's walking wounded, has been nine under par, and Super Mex attributes that happy status to a hot putting streak and a "tremendous amount of luck."

NEW ARK, July 22 Joel R. Jacobson, the new Commissioner of Energy, was assured today by the state's largest supplier of natural gas that there would be ample gas supplies for both industrial and residential use next winter provided it were not so severe as last winter. In that case, he said, industrial users might be affected.

Vincent D. McDonnell, for the last 15 years New York state's chief mediator between unions and management, said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation as chairman of the State Mediation Board. Mr. McDonnell, who joined the board in June 1962 as its executive secretary, had indicated some time ago that he planned to resign. He declined to elaborate on the reasons for his resignation.

The show Alice Cooper brought to Nassau Coliseum on Thursday night, his first touring show in more than two years, was a case of the tail wagging the dog. The theatrical elements that Mr. Cooper introduced into arena rock and theatrical means the full panoply of Hollywood and Las Vegas show business, from lights to choreography to elaborate costuming have swallowed up his music.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee decided today to summon Bert Lance, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to explain the circumstances involved in a $3.4 million loan he obtained in January from the First National Bank of Chicago.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22 Thailand's Foreign Minister said today that his country would "strongly" protest the movement of Cambodian troops into Thailand that led to the border clashes of the past two days between forces of the two countries.

Top officials of President Carter's Administration became embroiled in the volatile politics of New York City rent control yesterday as several New York politicians clashed over who should take credit for a Federal action favorable to some New York City tenants.
Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel urged Secretary General Kurt Waldheim yesterday to try to arrange the departure of the 800 Jewish families still living in Syria.

William Accorsi has been tickling smiles out of people for years with his zany wood cutout sculptures. A short time ago he decided he wanted to try his hand at designing, and he liked the idea of kitchenware.

BASS RIVER TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 22(AP) Four volunteer firemen were burned to death tonight while fighting a forest fire here that engulfed more than, 1,000 acres in the Pinelands 15 miles north of Atlantic City and raged out of control for several hours, the state police said.

CLOSE HARMONY There's an easy way tonight to do some musichopping in SoHo in quest of cool sounds on a warm evening. Three major showcases in the downtown area are close together, within two short blocks of one another, all with air-conditioned comfort and with entertainment policies commended in The New York Times.
The Exxon Corporation, the world's leading petroleum enterprise, yesterday reported a 3.4 percent drop in earnings in the second quarter.
A two-tier market appears to be developing in new-issue preferred stocks. Institutional investors, after a long while on the sidelines, have become buyers mainly of high-quality preferreds.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (Reuters) William Schaufele, a target of criticism by Greek politicians and the Greek press, will not take up his post as United States ambassador there for the time being, the State Department said today.

NEW ORLEANS, July 22 President Carter said today that he was willing to go along with a proposed doubling of the current 4-cent tax on gasoline but that he wanted "more flexibility" in allocating money from such an increase so that rural areas would not be shortchanged.
MOSCOW, July 22 (Reuters) Moscow gave unusual publicity today to a study by Soviet specialists about the power they said was wielded by Jews in the United States.
MILLINOCKET, Maine, July 22 (AP) Strong winds impeded firefighters today in their efforts to control a sixday-old fire that has charred more than 2,000 acres of timberland in Baxter State Park.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) A Federal grand jury today indicted four corporations and two individuals on charges they conspired to fix prices for paint resins.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., July 22 "Hello, Mr. President, I am Jeff Davis." That greeting from the young man with a name as Southern as magnolias was a vivid reminder that Jimmy Carter was back for his first real swing through Dixie since he entered the White House on a crest of regional pride and support that formed the springboard for his election victory last November.

PEKING, July 22 (Reuters) China officially announced tonight that the purged leader Teng Hsiao-ping had been returned to power and that his ultraradical opponents, the so-called Gang of Four, had been expelled from the Communist Party.
RIVERHEAD, L.I, July 22 Edwin M. Schwenk, a former chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Party, was indicted here today on charges of embezzling nearly a quarter-million dollars in party funds.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 The authority of William R. Lummis over Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation was upheld in an opinion filed today by the Delaware judge who appointed Mr. Lummis 15 months ago to act temporarily as owner in the place of Mr. Hughes.

P/E refers to price-earnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12-month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are in dollars. The letter u-stands for new annual high and d-indicates new low.

Bruce Llewellyn, who runs one of the nation's largest black-owned businesses, said yesterday that, despite problems created by looters and vandals during the blackout, he was "more than 50 percent sure" that he would accept President Carter's offer that he become head of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.

Plagued by years of low earnings in its photographic business, the GAF Cor poration announced yesterday that it would drop its consumer lines of cameras, films and color print papers leaving the Eastman Kodak Company with little domestic manufacturing competition in amateur photography except in instant pictures.
CAIRO, July 22 Egyptian planes bombed and strafed a Libyan air base today, the second day of major military clashes between the two countries, a military spokesman here announced.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Denying the Administration the power it sought to set natural gas prices, a Senate-House Conference committee agreed, today on details of legislation to create a new, 20,000-employee Department of Energy.

TRENTON, July 22 (AP) Alfred A. Neuschaefer Sr., an award-winning swimming coach at Trenton High School for 28 years and a member of the International Swimming Hall of Fame, died yesterday at Mercer Medical Center. He was 79 years old.
GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 Youths in this North Shore community accused of violating bicycle regulations will be judged and sentenced by a jury of their peers under a program that begins tomorrow.
BNEI BRAQ, Israel For several weeks violence has marred the Sabbath in this mostly Orthodox town near Tel Aviv as ultra-Orthodox Jews have sought to keep a road closed.
In support of a broad range of cultural activities New York City will shortly send $1.1 million to cultural organizations in all five boroughs, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.
Dr. Joachim Weyl, former acting president and dean of sciences and mathematics at Hunter College, died Wednesday at his home, 331 West 20th Street. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The officers of the United Mine Workers apparently reduced the threat of a national coal strike today by overwhelmingly rejecting demands for a walkout to protest pension and health benefit cuts by the coal industry.

July 31 is the last day on which New York City may file a formal request to be designated by the United States Olympic Committee as host city for the 1984 Summer Games. Michael Johnson, 19 years old, a $3-an-hour Manhattan liquor-store delivery boy, won $1,000 a week for the rest of his life yesterday in New York's million dollar lottery.

SALTAIRE, L.I, July 22 After two recent incidents in which police vehicles ran over sunbathers, the Mayor of this Fire Island community has asked the Suffolk police to stay off its beaches.

Virginia Wade, the queen of Wimbledon's women singles, was very, very perturbed at the Felt Forum last night. The usually reserved English star, who won the women's crown at Wimbledon this year in her 16th attempt since 1962, lost her temper and her match to Martina Navratilova, 6-1, as the Boston Lobsters downed Miss Wade's New York Apples, 24-21, before a crowd of 3,148.

LORDSTOWN, Ohio, July 22 (AP) The world's fastest auto production center, slowed by lack of demand for the Chevrolet Vega and Pontiac Astre subcompacts it produced, rolled to a halt today as the General Motors Corporation prepared to restyle and rename the economy cars.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Democratic Finance Council, the party's new fund-raising arm, collected more than $1.5 million in the first six months of 1977, raising total Democratic income for the year to $2.8 million.

WINDBER, Pa., July 22 James DeBiase looked up at the clear blue sky, bright with sunshine and ornamented with occasional fleecy clouds, and said, "Things look so pleasant, you can't believe it." But the view at closer range was reality, and reality in Windber, where two persons died in Tuesday night's flood, was not pleasant at all.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said bulk-rate discount service to large-scale communications users, such as networks or wire services, would continue, but conflicting appellate court decisions have left the situation in doubt.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 22 Brad Van Pelt was not here today. He probably won't be here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The House of Representatives amended the new farm bill today to require the Agriculture Secretary to establish a new system of domestic sugar price supports at 14 cents a pound, a move that opponents said could cost consumers and industrial sugar users an additional $1 billion a year.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 22 The defeat of Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Sri Lanka in yesterday's general election has all but ousted her Freedom Party from Parliament.

GEOGRAPHY The Somali Democratic Republic, situated on the Horn of Africa on the east coast of the continent, is bordered by Kenya, Ethiopia and Djibouti. About the size of Spain and Portugal combined, its 270,000 square miles comprise the territory of the former British and Italian Somaliland.

JANIE SELL, who made a Tony-winning Broadway debut three years ago in the Andrews Sisters' musical, "Over Here," is breaking in a cabaret act as the Grand Finale this week that is a showcase for her theatrical flair.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. As Secretary of State Cyrus Vance prepares to visit Peking in August, let us note how China-policy misconceptions have twice led us into warfare and disaster. China remains so incomprehensible we fall back on the high school debater's axiom: When you don't know the facts, assert the principles. Principled ignorance led us to fight China in Korea and to fight Chinese puppets, as we assumed them to be, in Vietnam.

EARLIER this year, the Knickerbocker Liquor Corporation, one of the larger distributors of fine wines in the area, held several seminars for the retailers who are its customers. The idea, and a very good one it was, was to upgrade the retailers knowledge of wine.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 A beanball war broke out in Candlestick Park tonight as the New York Mets defeated and, at times, nearly battled the San Francsico Giants.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The Carter Administration, in a show of support for President Anwar el-Sadat, privately informed key members of Congress today that it would like to sell Egypt more than $200 million in military reconnaissance and transport planes.

On the first night of what could be a brief remainder of his Yankee managerial career, Billy Martin received a heart-warming reception from Yankee Stadium fans last night, then got a heart-stopping victory over the firstplace Baltimore Orioles.
Senator Ribicoff and his Governmental Affairs Committee seem oddly anxious to have things both ways in the case of Bert Lance, President Carter's budget director.

JERUSALEM, July 26 Three controversial Israeli settlements on occupied lands of the West Bank of the Jordan River were given official approval today by Prime Minister Menahem Begin, a move that touched off a swift negative reaction from the Carter Administration.
One of the developments that highereducation officials seldom discuss openly is the demise of selectivity at many of the nation's small private, liberal arts colleges.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The arrangement for an Atlanta business man, David N. Smith, to buy Bert Lance's entire block of 200,767 shares of National Bank of Georgia stock was put together by an Arkansas financier who was an early and generous supporter of his Naval Academy classmate, President Carter.

LONDON, July 26 The Government reported today that unemployment in Britain surged to postwar records in midJuly, prompting angry comment in the House of Commons and putting further political pressure on Prime Minister James Callaghan.

ROM THE tip of the toe to the top of the boot, Italy offers a compelling and highly diversified kind of cookery. Here are an assortment of dishes sampled recently in the restaurants of Genoa, Torino, Milan, Recco and Portofino.

WEST BERLIN, July 26 Carl Lutz Wieschenberg, a West German who was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Florida last week along with Carl John Heiser,an American, on charges of having supplied electronics and computer data to Communist governments, was involved in Germany two and a half years ago in a case involving allegedly illegal transactions with the Russians.

Noting that there are thousands of special permits allowing parking on city streets, environmentalists yesterday at- tacked a city-supported plan to reduce on-street parking because, they said, it failed to cope with special-permit abuses.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 26 The United States, responding to a plea by the South Korean Government, announced today that the bulk of the American combat soldiers stationed in Korea would remain here until the final year of the planned troop withdrawal.
The following article was reported and written by Selwyn Raab and Nathaniel Sheppard Jr.

Oskar Morgenstern, one of the giants of modern economics and a pioneer in the development of mathematical economies and game theory, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 75 years old.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 26 The most expensive flop of modern times, or heroes of one of the great stretch drives of baseball history? As one or the other, the 1977 California Angels will be remembered, and the threegame series they opened here tonight had symbolic overtones.
Chester H. Roth, chairman and chief executive officer of the Kayser-Roth Corporation, died yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 75 years old and lived at the Hotel Pierre.

Mayor Beame lashed out at President Carter yesterday, charging that the President's program of welfare revisions would not include a Federal takeover of local welfare costs, which the Mayor said the President had pledged himself to.

PARIS, July 26 The first bravos of the fall couture showings resounded today in the Cercle Interallie on the Faubourg St. Honore where JulesFrancois Crahay presented his collection for Lanvin. It was done in a brilliant haute peasant style, ranging all over history and the globe and the names of the dresses give some indication of the scope: Petrograd, Katmandu Marrakech, Salome.
Los Papines, an Afro-Cuban percussion ensemble, will make its United States debut on Sunday in a concert at Avery Fisher Hall at 8 P.M.

These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record.

SOMETHING LOOKS different at Bonwit Teller, Lord Taylor, and Macy's these days. It is not so much new merchandise as new housing for merchandise, an extensive redesign that has altered the physical appearance of these three venerable institutions and their spirit as well.

WASHINGTON, July 27 A record $2.82 billion deficit in American trade in June was reported today by the Commerce Department, foreshadowing further weakness in the dollar and adding to gloom on Wall Street.
LIMA, Peru, July 27 The Roman Catholic leadership has warned Peru's military regime against trying to solve this country's severe economic crisis by using repressive methods against labor protest.

WASHINGTON Not long ago, President Carter's brother, Billy, had a few well-chosen words for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Using somewhat more colorful language, he told officials of the agency to jump in a lake when they required him to install a couch in his ladies' washroom.

CHICAGO The all-white room with its Mickey Mouse telephone and its dozens of Napoleon figurines would hardly be judged an ideal working setting by most authors. "Outrageous? Far from it, I call it serene," insisted Richard Himmel, the interior designer who is also the author of "The Twenty-Third Web," a highly successful whodunit published by Random House last April. "Tell me, why do writers have to work in seedy rooms?"

VALDEZ, Alaska, July 27 Faulty welding, a problem that has plagued the Trans-Alaska Pipeline system for two years, spoiled plans to bring the first oil into the pipeline terminal here today in preparation for loading the first tanker this weekend.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries borrowed $4 billion in international markets during the first seven months of 1977, compared to $4.1 billion during all of 1976, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported.

Wall Street analysts, watching the Dow Jones industrial average experience its worst one-day drop in more than two years and reach its lowest point since January 1976, offered explanations yesterday playing down the negative implications of the slide.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 27 More than 185 homes, each worth upward of $100,000, were destroyed by an explosive brush fire last night that devastated large parts of one of the nation's most scenic residential communities.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 27 Ground was broken today for the first gambling casino hotel, to be operated by Resorts International.

Vincent C. Papa, a major narcotics dealer who was linked to the theft of $70 million worth of drugs from the Police Department property clerk's office in 1972, was stabbed to death late Tuesday in the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta, Federal Officials disclosed yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 A traditional distrust of foreign countries, coupled with an official ideology other Communists view as verging an fanaticism, seems to be weening Albania away from its sole friend China.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Mayor Beame found his hands tied tonight in his latehour campaign to win more Federal aid for welfare costs after the Carter Administration said it had an aid package, but declined to disclose its specifics.

WASHINGTON, July 27 A Federal judge ruled today that a raid by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Church of Scientology office here July 8 had been conducted with an improper search warrant and ordered the bureau to surrender hundreds of documents it had seized.
The New York Civil Liberties Union charged in a lawsuit that the city and state were illegally confining 350 New York City youngsters in institutions out of state.

TOKYO, July 27 The Japanese Government, worried about the planned withdrawal of United States ground forces from South Korea, was assured today by Secretary of Defense Harold Brown that the Carter Administration intended to maintain "strong military forces" in Asia and play an active role there.
Several hundred youths will soon be hired by New York City to board up abandoned buildings in slum areas to combat the rising incidence of arson.

The perjury trial of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court ended in a mistrial yesterday, after Presiding Justice Leon B. Polsky decided it would be prejudicial for the prosecutors on the case to have to testify, as it appeared they might have to do.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 27 The New Jersey Sports Authority could become the owner of the Nets' basketball team.
AVELLA, Pa. Chill autumn winds howled across a massive rock overhang sheltering the ledge where a little band of Stone Age hunters huddled around a campfire.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 27 With Franz Beckenbauer playing brilliantly in midfield and Giorgio Chinaglia in high spirits on attack, the Cosmos trounced the Washington Diplomats, 8-2, at Giants Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee asked President Carter today for a month's delay to consider more fully the proposed $1.5 billion sale of a highly secret air defense system to Iran.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Italian Government has rescinded a ban on new foreign students entering Italian universities during the coming academic year, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said here today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 27 (AP) With Lawyers and a judge gathered around his hospital bed, Groucho Marx, the 86-year-old comedian, today accepted the appointment of his grandson as his conservator.
If a bill now making its way through Congress does become law, diplomatic license plates will no longer be a license to park illegally in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 27 President Carter is considering possible changes in his welfare revision plan that would make the package more palatable politically but would violate his mandate to hold total welfare costs at the current level.

The Mobil Corporation, the nation's third largest oil producer, which also operates Marcor (Montgomery Ward and the Container Corporation, reported yesterday a 14 percent increase in secondquarter earnings and 8 percent in the half year.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 27 More than 185 homes, each worth upward of $100,000, were destroyed by an explosive brush fire last night that devastated large parts of one of the nation's most scenic residential communities.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. July 27 Despite two sore ankles and an overabundance of stomach, Steve Ramsey showed the Giants for the first time today that he was not just a throw-in to the Craig Morton deal.

A selling wave engulfed the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 19.75 points in its biggest one-day drop in more than two years. Only 261 issues showed a gain, while 1,309 stocks declined.

WASHINGTON The enforcement of the Federal antitrust laws seems at a crossroads. New faces abound in influential Washington postions, promising revised priorities and new pet interests. And as the guard changes, there is con siderable questioning whether antitrust enforcement has accomplished anything.

The three-judge panel appointed to examine charges that the New Rochelle Police Department had failed to investigate a 1975 murder threat by the sniper, a Nazi sympathizer, who fatally shot five persons there last February has threatened to resign because of alleged political interference with its work.

PROSPECT, CONN., July 27 A young mother and her seven children, victims of murder and arson in this suburb of Waterbury early last Friday, were buried side by side in a single grave here today following a restrained funeral service that drew nearly a thousand mourners to the St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church.

DETROIT, July 27 The General Motors Corporation, the nation's biggest automobile maker, today reported a profit of $1.1 billion for the second quarter ended June 30 an increase of 20.6 percent. Until now, only the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had earned more than $1 billion in a quarter.

OTTAWA, July 27 The Anglican Synod of Canada has been asked to consider endorsing the termination of life at birth for severely retarded infants, as well as the withdrawal of life support for the terminally ill.

Scientology, the religion at the center of the conroversy over raids by Federal agents, is an amalgam of elements from Hinduism, Buddhism, Hellenism, Taoism and Christianity, selected, assembled and imaginatively modified by the man whose title is founder and whose works are subject to official veneration.
JOHNNY MERCER was such a versatile and productive songwriter that any evening spent dipping into his song bag is, inevitably, both rewarding and disappointing.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) William T. Bagley, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, recommended that the sale of commodity options be banned in the United States.

HOLLYWOOD "SCARLETT O'HARA'S Younger Sister" is a strange sort of autobiography for a prim Southern girl to have written a sexual odyssey up and down the decades, in which Evelyn Keyes pauses only occasionally to mention a movie she has just started or just finished.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) A bill to authorize $2.96 billion for small-business programs in the two years beginning Oct. 1 was sent to President Carter today.
A Brooklyn grocer whose wife was shot to death by robbers Monday night was arrested on a murder charge yesterday afternoon, accused of having killed one of his wife's assailants.
ELY, Minn. With a small grunt of disgust, Dan Engstrom bent to pick up the Coca-Cola can lying in the mossy bog and placed it carefully in the center of the trail.

System controllers of the Consolidated Edison Company made an abortive attempt about an hour after the start of the blackout of July 13 to restore widespread service, according to a detailed timetable released this week by Con Edison.
JERUSALEM, July 27 Prime Minister Menahem Begin today rejected the Amercian contention that Israeli settlement in occupied Arab areas violated international law.

THE FIRST of Harry Chapin's two performances at the Dr. Pepper Festival in Central Park was rained out on Monday, but on Tuesday at 5 P.M. the show began under faultless blue skies, opening with the Jazz Tree led by Mr. Chapin's father, Jim.

Bill Robinson hit his 12th home run of the season in the ninth inning and tied the game, then scored the winning run in the 11th on a single by Rennie Stennett as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros, 3-2, at Three Rivers Stadium last night. The victory was Pittsburgh's seventh straight.

NEW HAVEN, July 27 A document made public tonight by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that the agency had rented an apartment for the New Haven Police Department to do legal police work in. The bureau was unaware, according to records, that the apartment was being used for an alleged illegal wiretap operation by the local police.

An application by Prince Saud al-Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, to buy an 18-room apartment at 640 Park Avenue has been rejected by the building's residents, real-estate informants reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The House of Representatives voted today to eliminate from the $5.6-billion-a-year food stamp program the requirement that recipients pay for a portion of their coupons.

KENNY'S CASTAWAYS, at 157 Bleecker Street, has an appealing if not entirely satisfying triple bill through Sunday. Actually, two-and-a-half bill is more like it. First there's Bridget St. John, a veteran British folkie now based here. Miss St. John is accompanied on guitar and vocals by Jesse Walden, who then does three songs (15 minutes) on his own. The headliners are the Lunsfords, a family country-folk group from Tennessee.

WEST CREEK, N.J., July 27 Governor Byrne and 1,000 firemen from around New Jersey and neighboring states visited this small, sleepy coastal hamlet today to pay homage to four volunteer firemen who were killed last Friday in a forest fire near Bass River State Forest.

ALBANY, July 27 (AP) The Consolidated Edison Company should be allowed to raise its rates for its 1.1 million gas customers an average 8.5 percent, a hearing officer for the Public Service Commission recommended today.

The National Football League has ordered George Atkinson to leave the Oakland Raiders' training camp until he pays $2,000 in fines, Atkinson, the defensive back who just lost a $2 million slander suit against the Pittsburgh Steelers, was fined $1,500 for alleged dirty play last year when he sidelined Lynn Swann with a concussion and another, $500 for another incident against the New England Patriots in the playoffs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, July 27 Eight of 10 New Jerseyans believe they pay too much in state and local taxes for the services they receive, and a majority think government pays too little attention to them when making decisions, according to the latest poll on "New Jersey Images," released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 27 (Reuters) Gun and knife battles flared between rival groups in the Catholic slums of western Belfast tonight and the toll rose to four dead and 40 wounded.

LEE, MASS. THE LATE Ted Shawn, performer, choreographer, cultural zealot and general father figure of modern dance, refused to turn his back on any form of dance. The Jacob's Pillow Festival, which remains as testimony to his all-inclusive embrace, still features those programs of ballet, modern and ethnic presentations that were so dear to his heart.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Senate Banking Committee voted 12 to 3 today in favor of confirming Robert H. McKinney as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which oversees the nation's savings and loan associations.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, said today at the close of his organizations convention that he was leaving town as he had arrived, "dissatisfied and discontented" with the Administraion's progress on social issues.

WHAT better way to dispel the moisture of the mind brought on by the clinging heat and humidity than to think dry or dried. To be more specific, consider drying flowers now from summer's bountiful stand of color to cheer the fall and winter days ahead.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 27 A field of eight will start tomorrow night at the Meadowlands in the final of the $186,000 Governor Alfred E. Driscoll pacing series. Rambling Willie, the top money-winner in the first three legs, has drawn post No. 2 and been named the 5-2 morning-line favorite.

"IF YOU'RE going to give me an expensive gift," said Leonard Pollikof, the Los Angeles interior designer, "give me a painting." He prefers a Johns or a Rauschenberg. It was his interest in contemporary art that led to the creation of "Dropcloth," his first line of handpainted fabrics. It is being sold to the trade locally through Groundworks, Pat Ross's wallpaper and fabric showroom at 231 East 58th Street.

THE FOUR families on the second floor of our medium-sized, unpretentious West Side building redecorated their hall. One day it was the same muddy pink and green as the rest of the building's public spaces; the next day a lovely black and white scenic paper appeared opposite the elevator, and tasteful gold letters and numbers identified the apartments. The doors had been painted black and the rest of the walls were a beautiful shining white.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy today ended an official visit to Washington marked by extreme caution on the part of President Carter and Administration leaders on the problem posed by Italy's powerful Communist Party.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Carter Administration, in another major policy decision on supplying military equipment to African nations, said today that it had informed the Sudan that the United States was prepared to contribute to its "legitimate defense needs."

The first of this summer's free park concerts by the New York Philharmonic will be given next Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. Andre Kostelanetz will conduct Tchaikovsky's "Coronation March" and Symphony No. 6, Ravels Daphnis and Chloe Suite No. 2 and Offenbach's "Gaite Parisienne." As is customary, fireworks will accompany the final measures of the concert.

Cocoa futures prices closed down the daily limit of 6 cents a pound yesterday, with the spot September contract finishing at $2.02 . Aside from some technical factors, the drop in cocoa reflected two statements by the Hershey Foods Corporation.

The United States is closer than it has been in a decade to successful completion of negotiations for a new treaty on the Panama Canal, a principal American negotiator, Sol M. Linowitz, said yesterday.
Mayor Beame announced the hiring of 600 new firemen yesterday, but his Fire Commissioner said the new men would have "no impact" on his department's response time.

In giving official sanction to three previously unauthorized settlements on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, Prime Minister Begin's new Israeli Government has surely complicated the search for a Middle East peace settlement. By making the move only hours after his return from a generally amicable meeting with President Carter, Mr. Begin has also complicated further his relations with the United States.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 27 A Federal judge in Palo Alto has thrown out 18 of the 24 counts of a tax fraud indictment against Harry Margolis, a Bay Area lawyer. The ruling came as a blow to Government prosecutors, who had called the case "perhaps the biggest breakthrough we've ever had in the whole area of fraud and the widspread use of offshore tax havens."

BERKELEY, Calif., July 27 Nuclear chemists at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory today released evidence that a brass plate thought to have been left by Sir Francis Drake when he landed on the northern California coast in 1579 is not authentic.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 27 Madalyn Murray O'Hair, who in 1963 successfully argued before the Supreme Court against prayer in public school, now is preparing an assault on United States currency and the Pledge of Allegiance.

WITH ROONE ARLEDGE, ABC's chief of sports programming, now taking over the news department as well, tinkering has finally started on the format of the network's evening news. And, quite understandably, nervousness reigns.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The House of Representatives voted today to eliminate from the $5.6-billion-a-year food stamp program the requirement that recipients pay for a portion of their coupons.

The Tappan Zee Playhouse in Tappan, N.Y., closed for the last two years after a fire that partly destroyed its backstage, will reopen next Tuesday for a five-week summer season with the premiere of "Columbus Circle," a musical with book and lyrics by Isaiah Sheffer and music by Bobby Paul.

Despite disappointing earnings reports from such leading companies as Exxon, United States Steel and Bethlehem Steel, second-quarter corporate profits appeared to be registering moderate to relatively strong gains.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 27 (AP) Henry Bunis of Cincinnati, who played for Columbia University, stunned ninth-seeded John Alexander of Australia, 6-4, 6-2, today in the first round of the $125,000 Louisville international tennis tournament.

A selling wave that engulfed the stock market pushed the Dow Jones industrial two years. The blue-chip barometer, declining from the opening bell, closed a 888.43, its lowest reading since January 1976.

JON GIBSON, who plays reed instruments and flutes with the Philip Glass ensemble and other SoHo-based groups, is presenting solo recitals of his own music this week at the Franklin Street Art Center, 112 Franklin Street. The final performance is tonight at 8. Interestingly enough, the new works Mr. Gibson is performing are not in the hypnotic, steady-state vein he has often favored.

KIDDERMINSTER, England, July 27 (Reuters) The rock group Led Zeppelin today abandoned an American tour after the death of lead singer Robert Plant's 5-year-old son Karac from a mysterious infection. Mr. Plant rushed home to be with his wife, Maureen, after he had learned of their son's illness.
Inside the yellow-painted storefront on Olmstead Avenue in the East Bronx the old people were talking with the young people.
Dr. Morris Gleich, a retired pediatrician, died yesterday at his San Diego, Calif., home. He was 88 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Senate voted today against using tax funds to help to pay for the primary campaigns of candidates for the Senate.

A selling wave engulfed the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 19.75 points in its biggest one-day drop in more than two years. Only 262 issued showed a gain, while 1,327 stocks declined.

ALBANY, July 27 The State Education Department intends to increase substantially its spending for school desegregation and for private education of the blind and handicapped, according to a preliminary budget request for 1978-79 released today.
CERTAIN BOOKS are so wonderful that I can't bring myself to finish them, They "stimulate me" as James Thurber once commented about a brilliant friend "to a point beyond which I think I cannot go."

IT'S NOT OFTEN that the composer takes a bow after the performance of a piece by someone born 221 years ago. But that's what happened at Tuesday's Mostly Mozart Concert in Avery Fisher Hall (the concert was repeated there last night).

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 27 Jack Saunders, a modestly prosperous farmer who came to Rhodesia from Britain in 1906, has voted in the last four elections for Prime Minister Ian D. Smith. But next month, his vote will go to the newly formed Rhodesian Action Party, which has repudiated Mr. Smith's tentative commitment to majority rule.
Prices moved lower in the Government bond market yesterday as participants sensed a possible upward adjustment in rates by the Federal Reserve.

FREMONT, Mich., July 27 An exchange between the chairman of the Gerber Products Company, John C. Suerth, and a Wall Street stockbroker who challenged the company's opposition to a proposed takeover enlivened Gerber's annual shareholder meeting today.

WEST CREEK, July 27 Governor Byrne and 1,000 firemen from around New Jersey and neighboring states visited this small, sleepy coastal hamlet today to pay homage to four volunteer firemen who were killed last Friday in a forest fire near Bass River State Forest.

TRENTON, July 27 Dr. Joanne E. Finley, State Commissioner of Health, and Dr. Martin Goldfield whom she demoted from assistant commissioner to director of research earlier this year, were embroiled in another dispute today.

Imports of crude oil for the week ending July 22 were down sharply to 6.4 million barrels a day from 7.1 million barrels in the previous week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute. An industry spokesman attributed the decline to irregularities in arrivals of ships.

NIAGARA ON THE LAKE, Ontario IT CAN BE hard work and on stage it can be the hardest work of all. The Shaw Festival's version of "Man and Superman," which not only is uncut but includes the entire "Don Juan in Hell" sequence of Act III as well, is often memorable and ultimately exhausting.
District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday the arrest of 79 government employees on charges of defrauding the New York City Department of Social Services of nearly $500,000.

MOSCOW, July 27 The Soviet Union's sensitivity about its trade deficit with the West was underscored today as the press rebutted suggestions that Moscow might have overextended itself in seeking Western credits.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y. Jo (Vollers) Tolhurst traveled the farthest, from Kailua, Hawaii. Janet (Shearon) Armstrong brought the most famous husband: the first man to walk on the moon. He didn't say much. George ("Duke") Hust, a Minneapolis broker, had aged less visibly than any man present except maybe Billy Jenks (we who knew him in the sixth grade never think of him as Bill), a marketing manager in Toledo.

PARIS, July 27 Yves Saint Laurent startled the fashion world a year ago with a collection that was single-minded and direct. Incredibly luxurious and lavish, it launched the haute peasant look that is still being recreated in couture salons and ready-to-wear workrooms around the world.

The Yankees paused in their daily soap operatics last night to play an old-fashioned baseball game (one played with actions, not words), but by the time it had ended, they were reminded of another controversy out of their past.

THE FIRST WE SEE of Evel Knievel he is visiting an orphanage, handing out toys to children and fudge to the nuns. Then he stops by a stadium to sign some autographs and chat with his fans. Later, he returns to the stadium to make a little speech about why America's youth shouldn't get mixed up with drugs and, almost incidentally, to jump his motorcycle over a cage full of lions and tigers.

ANTHONY SAMPSON continues to bring us the bad news. The author of the exemplary "Anatomy of Britain" has in recent years addressed himself to huggermugger among the multinational corporations, such as International Telephone Telegraph in "The Sovereign State: The Secret History of ITT" and the oil cartel in "The Seven Sisters."

LONDON, July 27 In a move to minimize danger to Britain from the skidding dollar, the Government today abandoned a months-long policy of holding the pound at about $1.72 and let it rise nearly 1 cents to the highest level since last September.

WHEN WE MOVED into our house on Long Island, one of the first things we did was to remove all the cornices from the living room ahd library windows. Heavy draperies are old-fashioned and definitely not our style, we said, so we dressed our windows in living curtains of plants, with a few shutters and blinds where necessary for privacy.
WHEN it comes to home improvements, the usual combinations of carpenters, plumbers and painters click automatically into our minds. But consider some of the more unusual alternatives.

STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 27 (AP) Britain headed the medal list with 14 golds today, one ahead of the United States, on the fourth day of the Olympic competition for physically handicapped persons. In third place was West Germany with eight golds.

Mayor Beame announced yesterday that his administration was rejecting an application by real-estate interests to remove from rent control all controlled apartments in New York City renting for $300 a month or more.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday cut its quarterly dividend in half, to 25 cents a share, and announced that its second-quarter earnings fell by 36 percent almost an identical decline to that reported on Tuesday by the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 27 A House committee will begin an investigation tomorrow into possible legal violations by the Customs Service, which since 197l has opened international mail that it believed might contain contraband.
Irmgard von Cube, a motion-picture script writer, died Monday at her Hollywood, Calif., home. She was 77 years old.

THE WAY IT IS Details of book production, book trends and other aspects of the publishing world will be discussed today at 12:30 P.M. in the regular, admission-free Hour With the Author session at the Mercantile Library Association. The guest speaker, Carol Houck Smith, a trade editor of W.W. Norton Publishers, will also examine the relationship between editors and writers.

Jacob Marschak, an important developer of economics information theory and a contributor to the early study of econometrics at the University of Chicago, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

Perelman say that, after Arabic, Yiddish is the world's richest language for cursing and that one of the strongest epithets during his boyhood was: "May a trolley car grow in your stomach." Even in English this sounds painful, and the only consolation is that it sounds unlikely.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Federal Trade Commission made public today a revised and more complicated set of proposed regulations concerning the application of 1976 antitrust legislation requiring advance notice to the Government of some corporate merger, acquisition and takeover plans.
